I Tore You Apart In My Head

by Anonymous

Summary

Rules have never been a difficult concept for Rio Vidal. Following them hasn't either, although she has never been beyond the human experience of making mistakes.

After years kept within the steel walls of the Cook County Coroner's Office, very little has come to challenge her anymore. That is, until a series of deceased men come across her table, all seemingly fine and yet, all in possession of a severed spinal cord.

By the fifth body, Rio is beginning to saw her nose off to spite her face; not knowing how such a thing keeps happening, even if it is at the hands of another human being, starts to tilt her focus and skew her moral compass.

How far will she go to get answers?

Rio isn't even sure she knows.

And We All Have a Hell

"Hey, what's a ten letter word for 'a typical instance or case?'"

The plastic end of a BIC pen muffled such a question as Cook County Coroner Rio Vidal's dark gaze lifted from the wrinkled newspaper in front of her, the day's crossword puzzle only halfway complete. Her feet were propped on the corner of her desk, white coat dangling loosely at her sides in her relaxed state. A crew neck sweater clung to her chest with a depiction of the moon, but comprised of floral print. She greeted her compatriot with elation and warmth, though a simple 'good morning!' could never have been quite enough.

"Good to see you too, Rio," came the grumbled response of the mortuary attendant, Alice Gulliver, as she backed her way through the doorway that would allow her to deposit the delivery she'd arrived with. Every day, a new silver cart. Every day, someone knew to wash and clean and dissect to search for answers. It was usually multiple carts a day, but for it being the first of that day in particular, Alice seemed in good spirits. That was always a plus.

When Rio had graduated from Rutgers with a masters in Forensic Sciences, she had possessed dreams of approaching crime scenes with vigor and curiosity, seeing things from all angles. She had wanted field work for herself, to be in the throes of assistance when it came to determining the true cause of the world's worst crimes.

Yet somehow, she had landed herself in the Cook County Morgue, ten years later.

Even though it had not been anywhere near the aspirations Rio had maintained for herself in her younger years, she had found a home in those steel walls and linoleum floors. She found peace in the silence, and a beautiful understanding of true mortality in the countless causes for death she had come across.

Normally, in the day-to-day, no two cases were usually the same.

Lately, that had started to change and as such, a concern was beginning to grow within the brass that passed in and out of her doors.

Rio liked to keep to herself in that cold, soulless basement, but she got visitors frequently. It was usually the police or the forensic investigators, but it was often a gentle reminder that while she spent the majority of her day with the dead, the living still needed things, too.

Some of them were more friendly than others and some simply wanted the answers to their questions so they could scramble out as quick as they had happened in, escaping the eerie and heavy air that seemed to hang stagnant within those walls.

Not Alice, though.

Alice was the closest thing Rio had to a teammate while venturing down such a macabre career path. They had met on Alice's first day, having transferred in from Will County, and had formed a fast friendship. Rio was drawn to her, to the small hand tattoos and the several piercings that lined her ears. She fit into that darker vibe, but was able to mask it pretty well in the same manner Rio did.

They had both built a mutual understanding that in the hours of the day, they dealt with heaviness and loss of human life. In the hours of the night, they had come to lean on one another to find ways to compartmentalize and separate work from personal, searching life for what was worth living versus living to know death for a paycheck.

"What about... 'ILLUSTRATION?'" Alice called from the autopsy room. Rio was already on her feet, pushing her way through the door to assist her.

"I think that might work, actually," Rio concurred, tucking the chewed up pen behind her ear. She approached the foot end of the steel table so that she could fist two corners of the body bag and help Alice in the relocation of her latest find to a less mobile resting place for the time being. "What have we got this morning?"

As Rio's eyes landed on the woman opposite her, looking only a little winded, there was a faint darkness that lapped at Alice's brown irises. It was an indication that Rio was either going to love her answer or find the same disappointment everyone else had.

"Another seemingly explanation-less death. Which means that when I come back in several hours, you're probably going to inform me, for the fifth time in the last four weeks, that the spinal cord was severed between the C3 and C4." Alice had folded her arms over her chest, as if she were defying the clear indication here: The boys down the road had a serial killer on their hands and they had absolutely no idea where to even start looking.

"Still no bruising or incisions?" Rio questioned with a curiosity-laden tone; she knew that she would find her answers once she got to work, but it was easier to just ask ahead of time.

"None. They just turn up at the foot of random graves throughout the city, looking otherwise fine." Alice lifted the clipboard at the end of her cart, jotting something on it before she held it out in request for Rio's signature.

Locked in a trance as her mind began to turn and roll toward knowing what she would find and still having no answers, Rio only snapped out of it when Alice waved the clipboard in her eye-line.

"I've got another pick-up in Bucktown so I can't hang out, but I can bring lunch later?" she offered as Rio finally took the clipboard from her.

With a quick flourish of the pen she plucked from behind her ear, Rio quickly scribbled her signature across the form to signify her acceptance and forked it back over to a smiling Alice who took it with a quick 'thanks.'

"I've really been craving some spicy pimento cheese," she announced decisively as she followed Alice out of autopsy, those misaligned wheels making a little too much noise for Rio's liking now that they weren't under the pressure of dead weight. It only desisted when Alice stopped by the main doors, not immediately pressing the button to open them.

"Do you want the kind from the chicken salad place or The Smoke Daddy?"

Rio's eyes lit up at the suggestion, a warm smile filling her face. "If you love me enough, you'll get it from Smoke Daddy and bring me an order of their buffalo cauliflower, too."

"You're so needy," Alice huffed back through a light laugh as she smacked at the button on the wall to open the doors. "But yes, I will bring you pimento cheese and buffalo cauliflower for lunch. I'll text you when I'm headed back."

"You're the best!" Rio called after her just as the doors sealed shut once more.

It was time to get to work.

Rio had developed a method to her madness, a way to move and operate that was both easier on herself and still maintained a healthy sense of respect for the husk of a human life that had ended up in her morgue, on her table. If it was only nine in the morning and Alice was already headed back out, it was a heavy indicator of a busy day ahead. That meant Rio needed to be quick, efficient, and she needed to keep to her precise guidelines that helped her procure the most accurate results.

There were few people that Rio came into contact with that had ever considered her to be normal, especially in a work environment. Wasn't it almost a job requirement to exist a little outside of the box? Wasn't it a good thing to have enough emotional maturity that she could deposit parts of her humanity into a box so that she was able to complete her job thoroughly and without too much emotion?

Rio had always been deemed weird, even as a child. Instead of trying to run from it or act as though it was something she had a distaste for, she chose to embrace it instead.

When six-foot-tall suits bustled through those doors, they did not often expect to see all five-feet-six-inches of Rio Vidal awaiting them, hair usually knotted in a bun that revealed the intricate orchid tattoo on the back of her neck that dropped below the collar of her shirt in geometrically pointed shapes that angled toward her spine. The linework was prominent with minimal shading, but it was the one tattoo that showed the most in terms of her existence in a professional setting.

Her arms remained covered at work, hiding the full sleeve of ink on her left one. It was an artful dedication to the many, many survivor stories Rio had heard over the years of those who had fought for the right to keep living their lives.

In the ink, there were nods to true warriors like Jennifer Morey -- a pair of legs bent and stoppered between a door and a bathtub for panicked security -- and Mary Vincent -- crossed prosthetic arms holding lilies -- and Scott Johnston and Sean Farmer -- an abstract visual of a finger inside of a bullet hole at the base of a skull -- that she carried with her every single day to remind her that the human condition could survive absolutely anything if given the right amount of determination.

Despite dealing in sources of death for a living, Rio believed in the tenacity of the human spirit. She believed that fighting was always an option, and she wore it on her skin to keep it fresh in her mind at all times.

Life could be worth fighting for, if it meant enough to the person living it.

And then, Rio realized after she suited up in her gown and unzipped the bag on her table, there were some people who never had a chance.

The man before her was one of them.

Per his ID card, his name was Tristan Ambruster. He was six feet and two inches tall with a weight of two hundred and thirty eight pounds. His dark hair was short and matched the color of the stubble that lined his jaw. He looked peaceful, as most did before Rio began to scour them in search of an ability to tell the proper end to their tales.

Tending to the dead with care was a faculty that had to be curated and perfected through experience, something Rio had invested far too many hours in. Even though she knew nothing of the man before her, she was still gentle as she cut his clothing and peeled it from his cold and stiffening frame. Her gloved hands were tender as they removed his shoes and shucked him of his socks.

There, naked on that chillingly cold steel table, his life was no more, and it was Rio's duty to discern why.

Through hours of incisions and diagnoses, Rio had reached the conclusion that Alice had known she would, even before she sent the toxicology specimens in for testing.

Tristan's spinal cord had been severed.

Rio was more certain than ever that this, as well as the four bodies that had faced an identical fate, could only be the work of one person, or a team at most. These men were large, they were fit and built. For the fifth time now, someone had managed to fell a beast in the exact same way and it was beginning to eat away at Rio's cognitive understanding of the world.

There were no suspects. There wasn't even an idea of how this was happening. It seemed to be such a violent crime, one that should have required force and yet, all Rio found in terms of visual proof of such an idea were the pinprick bruises in the same odd shape across the chests of each and every man that had met their fate in nearly identical conditions.

The first time she had caught them, it had been on the second victim. They had not quite formed on the first by the time he had come into her morgue, but when she went back for an additional review, they'd been there in that same strange arrangement.

By the third victim, Rio realized that they were points, ones that belonged to an invisible pentagram that had not been drawn. Nothing else about it felt occult and so, even having made such an observation to herself, she'd kept it quiet. There was no real reason to include anything other than the presence of the bruising; all it would do was induce a sense of panic that might end up being unnecessary.

In the process of sewing Tristan back together, another thought struck Rio.

If this was the same person that had been responsible for the last four bodies, the tox screen was going to come back with a flag for Rohypnol. That, in and of itself, was curious and had led Rio to draw her own conclusions.

The idle chatter she'd caught in passing had been that if the police were looking for anyone, it had to be a man. It had to be a large man, a man who could subdue these victims without a visual representation of force left behind.

Rio thought they were idiots.

If this truly was the same perpetrator, Rio was of the opinion at the end of examining her fifth victim that this could not have been a man in any way, shape, or form.

A man wouldn't have been so meticulous about not leaving unintentional marks. A man wouldn't have been invested in leaving the bodies as neatly and deliberately at specific graves in different cemeteries throughout the city. A man wouldn't have resorted to drugging another man for the sole purpose of killing him.

Whoever this was, she was good. She was smart, calculated. She knew what the fuck she was doing and quite frankly, it was really starting to piss Rio off.

How was she doing it?

Clearly, the drugging was helping her relocate from whatever hunting grounds she was choosing, but the spinal cord... How on earth was she severing it without doing any exterior damage?

It was bothering Rio. In fact, it was bothering Rio so much that she could think of little else, even as she moved through two other bodies before lunch. She hadn't gotten a text from Alice and had considered starting another case, but a soft ding at her computer indicated that she'd received an email -- likely the results of the tox screen from her first case of the day.

She had been right, on both accounts.

1) It was the results.
2) In them, Rio found what she knew she would. There was a high concentration of
Rohypnol in his system.

One arm was extended, palm hovering over her mouse as the other swiftly plucked the pen from behind her ear and deposited the end between her teeth, gnawing on it as her eyes scanned over the report again and again.

If she turned this over as it was, it was possible that someone else was going to start thinking the way she was thinking. They were going to shift their profile, and they were going to start looking for a woman.

The stupidest thought struck her:

Rio didn't want them to find her.

Not yet.

She felt even more insane because she had absolutely no proof that this was a woman. Rio was a master at developing inferences and more often than not, she was right, but there was something about this that had really gotten under her skin. It had been easy enough to put to bed when it was two men, then three. Had it still been annoying? Of course, but with Rio having picked apart and reassembled five now-empty vessels and still not having determined what had actually happened to them, she was getting angry.

Rio needed to know.

The process of getting there was murky at best, but as she leaned forward in her office chair and began to click and type, she knew she was making the wrong choice. She fully understood that by changing the toxicology results to indicate opioid usage as opposed to the Rohypnol, she was actually committing a fucking crime that could not only get her fired, but could place her behind bars as well.

Maybe this had been a long time coming; Rio had maintained a thin veil of sanity when it came to how she presented herself to the public, but the madness that could sometimes fester within her felt a little dangerous, if only to herself.

Rio couldn't hurt a fly and yet, she was driven to understand those who could. More than that, the psychopathy behind violent acts was something that had always drawn her in, something that she had spent countless hours investing her time in. It hadn't just been for college, but had since grown into something akin to a hobby even in the years since graduation.

It was why she loved her job; she got to pick apart and dissect and study and search. Rio got the chance to be hands-on in her quest for knowledge, into determining the absurd and pinpointing what others had let slip by.

She had never been the type to break rules, much less laws, but something about this had been turning circles in her mind since that very first body, even if she had professionally staved off forming an opinion. It wasn't her job to guess what was happening, it was her job to find it, identify it, and present the facts.

Right now, the facts were that someone out there was murdering men in an incredibly heinous manner and if they kept it up, they were going to get caught. If Rio was putting the pieces together, it was likely that someone else would be right behind her, no matter what terrible choices she was making in the meantime to try and prolong it.

As she submitted the "official" report with the tap of the 'enter' key, the doors to the morgue swung open and Alice came through with a bag in each hand and a grin on her face.

"All that work made you hungry, I bet," Alice teased in her approach as she forked over Rio's lunch. Little more than a delighted laugh met her as Rio reached for her meal, a soft 'thank you' passing through her lips.

She pulled out the contents of the bag and set out her meal, watching as Alice pulled a chair over to sit opposite her, the desk between them. "Always does," she returned with a grin of her own.

"So, big boy from this morning? Was it what we suspected?" Alice questioned, tilting her head as she tossed a tater tot effortlessly into her mouth. That look on her face as she chewed was almost scrutinizing, Rio thought, but she dismissed it and prepared herself to do something she never did, especially not to Alice.

Rio lied.

"The injury was the same, but..." she paused, taking a bite of cauliflower for the sole purpose of taking her time in deciding the best lie to proceed with. "The tox screen was wrong. Opioids. The four others were Rohypnol. It doesn't make any sense."

Rio was not an actress by any means, but the faux sense of irritation she was brandishing seemed to be working. Alice looked just as perplexed, if not a little off-put by the idea that they had been wrong. It was close enough that she could have called Rio out on it, could have suggested that she re-run the test, but she seemed to leave it at that, picking at her tots for a moment longer before her next question came.

"Anything else that might make you think it's the same person?"

"Look," Rio sighed, placing the half-empty container of cauliflower on her desk as she leaned forward, simply assessing Alice's expression for the briefest moment before she continued. "They aren't classifying this as a serial offender yet. And maybe... I don't know, maybe it isn't? What if it's multiple people, or a team? Who knows, it could even be some stupid internet dare that people are willing to risk prison time for. So until then... I just do my job and be angry about the fact that I cannot for the life of me figure out how the fuck it's happening."

Alice had been attentive, listening, watching Rio as she tried to sort through her thoughts, but Rio felt like she was seeing right through such a massive serving of absolute bullshit.

Rio could not very well look her friend in the eye and admit to falsifying records and expect her to still think she was sane. Rio could not, within reason, justify the choice she had made that afternoon and so, she would lie her ass off to save face with the only other person she actually respected.

"Suppose you won't, at least not until next time," Alice offered, though she still had not torn her attention from Rio.

Something in Rio's middle began to twist uncomfortably; what was she doing? What was she actually doing?

Rio was buying herself time.

She needed to figure it out, to figure this person out, at least before the police took that ability away.

"Who knows, maybe they'll skip town and wreak havoc on some other County Coroner's office instead of souring my mood almost twice a week," Rio returned, her tone admonishing in spite of her internal admiration.

She was the first to break, her eyes dropping to the container of cheese spread and the crackers that were piled next to it. She had thought that busying herself and diverting her focus might chase off that wily twisting in her middle, but the reality of the decision she had already made was still there, feasting on her morality.

"You okay?" came Alice's gentle inquiry, though there was an undeniable edge to that curiosity.

"Yeah," Rio dismissed with ease. "Just annoyed." To staunch any further elaboration, she shoved a cracker into her mouth and looked to the screen of her computer. In an attempt to change the subject, she pulled up the site-wide email she'd received that morning.

"You see the email this morning?" Rio asked, gaze flickering to Alice and back before she began to read without having received an answer. "'Please be attentive toward designated parking spots. Any threats or acts of physical violence in relation to parking disputes may be met with automatic termination.' Who the fuck is scrapping it out in the garage? Are we all not at LEAST in our mid-thirties?"

As Alice laughed, Rio's panicky inner monologue seemed to die down, or at least find reason for pause. She had no reason to believe that Alice would suspect anything, but the paranoia was still trying to rear its ugly head.

Rio did the right thing, almost always. She was human and had made mistakes before, but when the time came for a choice to be made, she tried her hardest to make the right one.

Not this time, though. This time, it hadn't even been a battle. She'd done the wrong thing because it felt right in her own quest for understanding. The only way she was going to find it was to do her own work, her own research. She needed to delve deeper without anyone else looking over her shoulder.

"Oh, yeah. That dude in accounting went insane. He ended up damaging his own car," Alice offered back, taking the last bite of her sandwich.

"Sometimes I worry for this world," Rio mused sadly, and while it was a dark sentiment, she also knew it was one she was powerless to change.

"You and me both," Alice replied, wadding up the wrapper from her sandwich. Rio's attention fell on her as she pushed to her feet and discarded her trash in the bin, that warm smile finding her face as she looked back down at Rio. "Well, I've got a few more runs this afternoon, but if you're not busy after work, we should get a beer or food or both."

Rio appeared to consider the offer, but she'd long since made up her mind on what she was doing with her evening, even before Alice had put the idea of food and drinks on the table.

She was going to dig. She was going to go home, order a pizza, crack open a beer, and she was going to spend the entire night somehow finding a way to figure this out. She had her vast array of knowledge and that should have been suitable, but the anomalies and complexities of these five deaths were never going to leave her alone until she understood them.

"Maybe not tonight," Rio returned, though her voice was soft and sweet. "Just kind of want to go home and curl up on the couch with Phineas while we continue through our eighth rewatch of Nightwatch."

"You and that cat," Alice chuckled with a roll of her eyes.

"He's a sweet boy, even if he weighs twenty-two pounds. He can't help his breed."

Phineas was her three-year-old charcoal grey Maine Coon and he was the king of Rio's jungle. Her apartment, no matter how spacious, was his territory and anyone who dared approach only succeeded with his approval. Thankfully, he had taken to Alice quite easily. It made the nights when they stumbled in at 2am, harebrained drunk, a little easier to navigate when his hackles weren't raised.

Cat or not, Phineas was protective over his human and Rio loved him even more for it.

"Well, if you change your mind," Alice suggested, glancing over her shoulder with a curl of her lips as she slapped the button on the wall, "you know how to reach me."

Rio's head tipped back, the truly tickled laughter spilling from her as she formed her retort.

"You got it, Kim Possible! Have a good rest of your shift!"

Just before the doors automatically swung shut, Rio could see as Alice's left arm shot up and she flashed a very loud middle finger, pulling even more joyous noise from deep within Rio's lungs.

For as vexing and sometimes downright depressing as her job could sometimes be, Rio could still find those flickers of light, the ones that kept indicating to her what it meant to move forward.

Now, she was trying to remind herself -- as she sat alone in the office again -- that this one time, it was okay to be curious, and to be willing to do what was necessary to satiate that curiosity.

The only person that Rio needed to convince was herself, and by the end of her shift as she hung up her white coat and headed out for the day, she was pretty certain she had managed to do just that.

After picking up a couple of Modelos at the gas station, she'd returned home to order her dinner and tuck in for a quick shower. Of course, she had not been able to accomplish such a mission without greeting the distinguished gentleman of the house first.

Phineas had slinked off the couch, languid as he stretched out to reinvigorate himself from the nap Rio had apparently disturbed him from.

"Well, hello handsome," she cooed, squatting down to scratch the top of his head. The way his eyes closed and his ears pinned back pulled the quietest chuckle from her every single time, her entire demeanor softening from whatever in her day that plagued her. It was a distraction, and a welcome one, but it could only last for so long.

Rio had not even finished her shower by the time she was looping back around to fixate on Tristan. On work. On this serial k -- No. She couldn't use those words yes, not officially.

She had been trying to distract herself, and it had been going... alright, but the moment the quiet found her, the volume in her head only seemed to increase. No abrasions. No incisions. No fucking sign that anything had happened to these men and somehow, each and every one of them had died because of a severed spinal cord.

It felt repetitive, to keep getting hung up on the same facts but at this point, it was all Rio had. All she could work with was all she had worked with, and that was giving her nothing.

Minutes after she had dressed and returned to the living room to crack open one of the cans of beer, there was a light knock on the door that signified the arrival of her dinner. After signing for the charge and thanking the driver with an extra five dollar bill, she kicked the door shut and fastened the deadbolt so she could comfortably set about the rest of her evening.

It hadn't taken her long to settle in and devour a couple of slices of pizza, but almost as soon as she was done, her MacBook was open in her lap and the hunt was officially on. Obviously, there was a certain line of caution that needed its due attention, but Rio was an intelligent human being and if there was anyone who was going to sort this, it was going to be her. That was one thing she was bound and determined to prove.

The cursor blinked in a taunt, over and over and over, begging for her to just type something.

All she had to do was pose an inquiry.

The best place to start would likely be the freshest prey.

In went her query; Tristan Ambruster.

The first few results that populated were coverage of his murder the night before and that morning. She skimmed through them and found nothing useful; it was still too soon for people to have found much in any excavation attempt on his life.

As it turned out, the short summaries of his expiration weren't due to a lack of content.

In fact, the eight results below it were about the plethora of run-ins he'd had with police; several were domestic violence charges that got overturned and a couple more detailed sexual assault allegations that never went anywhere.

Something tugged at Rio's focus, causing her to press on such a sore spot. She pushed a little harder, searched a little more thoroughly.

One of the women that had been publicly outspoken about Tristan's violent demeanor had ended up dead six months later -- official cause of death was ruled as a suicide. Whether or not that was true did not seem to matter. When Rio saw the woman's name, she realized that it was not the first time she had read that name in the last thirty minutes.

Scrolling back up, she started scouring again, though it did not take her long.

In a photo of the crime scene from earlier in the day on a local news site, the headstone above where Tristan's body had been found was visible, as was the name that was etched so plainly into it.

It was the same name in relation to the suicide.

Wanda Maximoff.

Whoever had killed Tristan had specifically laid him at the foot of Wanda Maximoff's grave. That wasn't random. That wasn't a haphazard decision. No, that was most certainly a very, very intentional choice.

Whoever this killer, this woman -- as Rio was now more certain of than ever -- was, she had sent a message. Rio got it loud and clear.

The only thing left to do in her mind?

Dig deeper and discover if she had missed those first four messages on her initial pass, too.

Two hours later, Rio saw it all, like a road map before her.

Every corpse had been left at a grave of someone they had wronged but suffered no consequence for. This was a calling card, as well as a victimology; these men had public appearances even without lengthy criminal records, and someone knew how to use Google.

The last remaining item left on Rio's list?

Find her.

Shame, Shame on Me

There was a fine line between curiosity and fixation.

Three days after making Tristan's acquaintance just before finding herself elbow deep in his chest cavity, Rio's toes were threateningly close to crossing that very line.

She stuck to her routine, showed up to work and performed every duty she had to perfection, committing to every responsibility she was tasked with. It fell back into a pattern of the times, nothing amiss and nothing that frayed Rio's nerves to a point of no return.

It was only a matter of time, Rio knew.

On that third day, something in the deep crevices of her mind just knew that if there was ever going to be a night that she might find answers, it was going to be that one.

Alice had asked -- at least once if not twice a day -- if Rio wanted to go out, or if she wanted to come over. Each invitation was met with a deferral, though Rio was trying her hardest to be cordial without revealing what it was she would rather spend her time doing. She had hated lying to Alice the first time, about the tox screen, so she tried to keep her excuses as close to the truth as she could manage.

"Just haven't been feeling very social," Rio had offered once.

"Crowds just aren't it for me right now," she'd given another time.

That morning, Alice hadn't even tried.

"If you feel up to it, I'm going to Roscoe's tonight. If not, no worries, but... You should consider it." She had sounded resigned, like she already knew that for the third night in a row, Rio was going to choose to tuck up in her apartment and keep to herself.

Rio could see the concern. She could see that Alice was watching her pull away and she was growing worried. She would play it off as just needing to recharge, to isolate from the world for a bit to just be content in her choice for complacency. Rio didn't want Alice to worry, but there were certain things she just couldn't talk about.

If she told Alice that she had slept maybe seven hours the last two nights, and why she had been losing sleep, Alice was going to make a prompt phone call to the nearest psych ward and pack Rio's bags for a vacation that included frequently wearing a pair of socks with rubber grips on the bottom.

Instead, Rio offered a soft acknowledgement that she would consider it and wished Alice a good day. Their conversation and chatter had been almost nil as she came and went throughout the day and while Rio had thought more than once that she should say something to break the tension, she was never able to find the right thing. So they moved bodies in quiet, they murmured soft goodbyes and by the end of the day, Alice had tossed a reminder over her shoulders.

"If you change your mind, Roscoe's. Shoot me a text."

"I will. Have fun, Alice," Rio called after her as the doors swung shut on their own accord and she was left to tend to her own evening.

Rio was going home, yes, but only to change.

Then, she was going to make a decision between Best Intentions or The Heavy Feather. They were both bars in Logan Square and, per her research over the two days prior, that was the neighborhood that four of the five victims had resided in. With the fith one -- the very first victim -- having been from Wicker Park, it made sense that She had migrated.

That was all Rio could think to label her as. Anything else felt like a cheesy tag-line, something that was too beneath the complexity of what this woman was achieving.

Between the four victims that had lived in Logan Square, Rio had located all of their social medias. In their photos, three of the four had been to Best Intentions. The fourth -- Tristan -- had been to both Best Intentions and The Heavy Feeather. It left Rio with a decision: Did she look at this as a very clear sign that Best Intentions was a hunting grounds, or did she follow the thread that the killer could have migrated to somewhere new when selecting her prey?

She felt positively out of her mind, chasing leads that she knew she could do nothing with. What was the play here, even if Rio got what it was she was looking for? Did she just outright ask to know? Did she ask to be told, or to be shown?

Wait -- What the fuck?

Why had that thought even crossed her mind?

To be shown?

To be shown what exactly?

How countless men were being murdered?

No, that was fucking absurd. Rio might have headed toward the deep end on this one, but the idea that she could bear to witness a life be taken? Didn't that seem a little extreme even in her quest for knowledge? It did, right?

Right?

Right?

None of it even mattered at that point, she supposed. She was no closer to knowing the truth than she had been the very second that first mystery had been dropped onto her table.

There was no denying that She was clever. Even those days later, and perhaps with Rio's helpful diversion, the police were still popping by to ask questions, though she gave the same answers every single time. It was the same injury in all five but different illicits in the last. Pinprick bruises on the chest. Nothing more, nothing less.

But She still had to hunt.

She still had to follow whatever compass was guiding Her and if she shortening of her cooling off period was any indication, Rio had a feeling that tonight would be the night. Between her two options, she still felt as though she was going to wind up with a body on her table in the morning. Even if Rio chose wrong, She wasn't going to stop this spree. If anything, She was just finding her groove.

With a click of the switches, the lights cut to the morgue and Rio was headed home to shower and change, still waffling over what option she needed to select in regards to the bar she was going to occupy for the evening. By the time she pulled on a red satin slip midi dress and fastened a matching pair of heels around her ankles, Rio had made a decision.

She decided to go with her gut.

Something felt all too fitting about Best Intentions, and the fact that four of the five men had been there, that wasn't coincidence and no one in the world could ever convince Rio that it was.

With a once over that led to her fussing with her hair a moment longer, Rio was satisfied with her appearance; the dress hung well on her frame and the way she had tied her hair into a neat bun at the back of her head while leaving several strands to frame her face showcased her natural, soft beauty. The thin straps that held the dress up covered nothing else, leaving her full sleeve of ink bare and beautiful. As a bonus, with the way the dress was cut, the very tip of her sternum tattoo -- a geometric wolf with bared teeth and raised hackles -- was visible, but no other part.

With the full understanding that she did not intend on finishing even a full beer, Rio had been confident that she could drive herself. If it turned out that she was wrong and she had spent an entire evening in a bar corner, she could at least lay claim to getting in a couple hours of people watching.

So, she had climbed into her dark green Tiburon and took off toward Logan Square, a woman on a mission.

Did it matter that it was an insane mission that had no good outcome?

It should have, probably, but Rio no longer was of sound enough mind to actually care.

After arriving, she'd ordered one Modelo in a glass, thanked the bartender, and floated her way over toward a booth in the far corner of the bar to sit, to wait, to watch.

Idly, Rio took the smallest sips of her beer, those dark and curious eyes scanning and assessing. Time began to wear on and while most of the crowd within the bar walls were being rather tame, there was one man in particular who seemed to be a little... excessive in his flirting with the bartender. She was being professional with him, but it was clear that the vibes he was exuding were not ones she was a fast fan of.

Occasionally the bartender would glance over her shoulder to make sure he didn't think she was ignoring him, but overall it appeared as though she just wanted to be left alone. It might have been annoying, but it seemed harmless.

With her beer a quarter of the way gone, Rio's gaze landed on the corner opposite the one she was in to find a couple indulging in a drunken and overt display of public affection and while it was rather gross, it wasn't the worst thing they could have been doing.

There were a couple of men playing pool in the corner, occasionally getting a bit rowdy though it seemed as though the majority of the banter happening between them was friendly and in jest. They were just a couple of friends engaging in healthy competition. While they were amusing, even for a few minutes, Rio's interest in them inevitably waned, too.

Even the man yelling at whatever hockey game was on the television was a minimal distraction, lasting only a moment or two before Rio's attention was diverted and scouring the bar again for anything that might have seemed even minutely out of place.

No matter how much she began to hate it, it had stayed relatively quiet, in those first forty-five minutes. It was rather calm was after them, too, but at that forty-six minute mark, something happened that immediately grabbed at Rio's attention for reasons unintelligible to Rio herself.

A woman -- roughly five and a half feet tall -- came striding through the front entrance of the bar, her head held high as her wild and thick sandy brown hair cascaded down her back, untamed and haphazard in an elegant way that made little sense. She was clad in a deep violet ruffled chiffon dress that had a very dangerous slit up the thigh and while she was in heels, Rio noted that they were rather short given the formality of the dress itself.

Rio had only caught a brief glimpse of her profile upon entry, losing it the moment the woman seemed to glide right over to the bar, her hand landing flat on the back of the man who had previously been annoying the ever-loving fuck out of the bartender. She leaned in over his shoulder, spoke to him and he seemed to straighten on his stool. After she took a step back, he got to his feet and offered her a quick, if not slightly awkward, hug.

From her vantage point, Rio thought she had never seen a more mismatched pair in her entire life. The woman had an air of eleagance to her, even though Rio hadn't even gotten a good look at her face. She was poised, well-dressed, and the way she began to flirt with the man seemed so well-practiced.

He, on the other hand, looked like he had been plucked straight from a cornfield that could be found outside of the city and planted in the middle of a borough sidewalk.

When the woman touched his arm, Rio felt something flare in her middle.

She wanted to be that man. She wanted that woman to touch her arm like that and she didn't even know what the fuck she looked like. It was the air around her, the way she tossed her head when she laughed -- a laugh that was bright and electric -- and the way she bobbed her foot, circling it around absent-mindedly as she held conversation with her date.

Someone stumbled into the corner of Rio's table and immediately, her attention was jostled away from the confident woman in the purple dress that was clearly on a date with a man, snapping up to find the culprit already heading toward the door.

Fuck. She wasn't meant to be fixated on some random person. She was meant to be paying attention, to be looking for...

What the hell was she even looking for?

In reality, Rio knew very little about Her. All she knew was that She had a process for selecting Her victims and while Rio had considered Best Intentions to be her best bet, she was starting to feel like she had made a mistake. She had pushed too hard only to lose a mental coin toss. She should have gone to The Heavy Feather. In fact, She was probably already there, already schmoozing up some poor schmuck who had no idea that he was going to be found with a cleanly severed spinal cord in the middle of a random cemetery in a different part of the city.

The decision had been made and so, Rio supposed, all that was left to do was wait it out. She could have relocated, but what would have been the point? It was probable that she had already missed her window of opportunity and so she was instead going to have to turn up at work tomorrow to perform an autopsy that would ring true to five others she had done in the last month.

She just wanted to know how.

It was all she wanted.

Knowing that she wouldn't even get a buzz off of it, Rio downed a considerable amount of the beer that remained in her glass. She wasn't ready to leave, but she needed something that might help her temper the bubbling annoyance that had formed in her chest.

She had been so convinced that she was right. She had been so fucking sure that if this woman was going to turn up anywhere, it was going to be that bar. The fact that all Rio had found inside was typical partons, horny drunks, and this haphazard ass Tinder match of a couple, it left her feeling more than just irritated.

Rio was pissed.

She had made a bad call and now, she could choose to keep watching the most interesting thing in the bar, which was that spectacularly painful date, or she could just choose to go home. While she made her decision, Rio decided to watch the show.

And it was a damn good thing she did.

Just as she had been teetering over the edge of deciding to get in her car and go home, she saw something. The man excused himself and got to his feet, meandering his way toward the  bathrooms down the back hall. The woman was still situated with her back to Rio, but she was not as sly as she had thought she had been, not when she reached over the man's beer for a napkin but hesitated long enough to dump something into it first.

No way.

No fucking way.

Suddenly, Rio's heart was hammering in her chest, thundering in her ears. She had seen it, she had watched this woman drop some kind of substance into the man she had met's beer and was acting completely cool about it. The truth was, that woman could disappear into thin air and Rio never would have been able to identify her. That alone was another annoyance that Rio found herself adding to her growing list.

Minutes later, the man returned and, as predicted, resumed the task of consuming his beer.

Rio had hardly torn her eyes away from that back of chiffon and skin and tangled hair, aching for the woman to just turn around so that she might have even a glimpse of what she looked like. Rio had never actually anticipated getting this far and as such, she was scrambling to put together a plan.

The woman was still flirty, still touchy, but the effects of the drug started to become apparent in the man's form and how it had started to slacken. It was clear that the window for this woman to make her move was closing; she didn't want him to be so fucked up that she couldn't get him out of the bar. Rio simply watched, waiting for it to happen.

And then, it did.

The woman leaned across the bar and paid the bartender, slipping her an additional tip before she grabbed the man's hand and stood from her stool.

At long last, she turned around.

The dress was even more stunning from a frontal view, but the true heart stopper was just how fucking beautiful the woman was. That hair framed her face so well, soft against the sharp angles of her jaw, her cheekbones, her nose. She was frighteningly stunning and, if Rio was right, she was undeniably deadly.

Although they did not lock with Rio's own, it was also very clear that the woman had the most breathtakingly blue eyes, even in the rather dim light of the bar.

The woman was a sight, and it was no wonder these men were beguiled enough to succumb to her prowess and charm. She still radiated nothing but confidence, even as the man threw and arm around her shoulder and let her escort him out of the bar.

It was a fight, but Rio diverted her eyes, pretending to scroll at something on her phone as it laid atop the table in front of her. She didn't want the woman to catch her staring, though as She passed by, Rio could swear she felt the heat of Her stare. And then? Then She was gone and Rio was sat in that booth realizing that she suddenly had another decision that needed to be made.

The opportunity was right there in front of her and all she had to do was take it and not be completely obvious about it. Or, she could just sit there like an idiot and give up the entire night's mission because she was what? Afraid? Nervous?

Fuck that. Rio had come this far. To let Her get away was stupid.

There was a little less than a quarter of her beer left as she abandoned it on the table, grabbing her phone and keys as she calmly made her exit and ventured toward her car. On her journey, those dark and excited eyes scanned over the parking lot, finally spotting what she had been hoping to: after the sound of a car door slamming, the woman came around the back end of a Lexus SUV and hurried into the driver's side.

Stalled and deathly still, Rio waited for the SUV to start before she scrambled the rest of the way to her car and climbed in, waiting only a moment as the woman pulled out of the parking lot behind the bar and onto the street to the right. She could use a little bit of a head start as to not make Rio's attempt at following Her completely obvious.

By the time Rio pulled out onto the street, the tail lights of the Lexus were still visible and she could see the body of the car as it passed beneath the occasional street lamp. She was vigilant, paying close attention when the woman would make a turn or stall a little too long at a stop sign. She kept that distance, now having become the one stalking her prey.

Rio did not wish to devour this woman, did not wish to flay her alive. No, Rio just needed the insatiable pit of curiosity within herself to be filled with the knowledge that had been so fucking elusive to her up to that point. She just wanted an answer, an explanation for something that seemed to have none. She wanted to know how it was that this woman was killing these men with nothing short of magic, and she was willing to do anything to get results.

Being confined to the city streets kept their speeds low, but Rio hadn't lost sight of the woman's vehicle longer than it took to catch up to a corner and take the turn. She recognized that they were heading west, progressing at a snail's pace toward the edge of the city. Rio knew that she could not lose Her before She left the municipality and hit country roads or else she would wind up bountiless and disappointed.

The overhead lamps started to grow sparse, illuminating less and less of the road they were traversing, even if Rio was maintaining a healthy gap between them. The neighborhoods began to dwindle and the space between homes started to grow. And then, the vast emptiness of farmland opened up ahead of the SUV in front of her, if only by a hundred yards or so.

Rio watched as the Lexus picked up speed and she did as well, not wanting to squander what was right in front of her. She had somehow gotten this far and the last thing she wanted to do was see it speed off into the night.

The little car rocketed forward, keeping an even pace with the SUV as they wound out into the country, leaving bound and determined to not let Her get away.

They drove, and they drove.

They drove even longer, to a point where they had been out of the city for twenty-five minutes and had taken minimal turns. With their location, Rio had eased up on her tailing, leaving a quantifiable amount of distance between them.

Another five minutes passed and something unexpected happened.

The woman's brake lights came on. She slowed rather quickly, and then pulled off to the side of the road, her hazard lights beginning to flash in the darkness of the night.

Shit.

Rio had no other choice than to keep driving. She couldn't stop; that would be obvious. She couldn't turn around; that would be even more obvious and would take about a ninety-six point turn that could not be pulled off without an embarrassing and awkward display.

All she could do was keep going forward and that fact alone pissed her off beyond measure. All she had wanted was a fucking answer and now, she was going to have to drive right by the possibility of getting one. Perhaps she should wave at it in longing as she passed.

Her speed decreased only slightly, but Rio had maintained every intention of continuing forth only to wind her way back toward the city and back to her empty apartment and awaiting cat who was surely annoyed that she had not been home at the proper time to give him his wet food. He'd get over it, but it angered Rio even more because it had been for absolutely nothing.

If she had at least returned home having succeeded in her mission, that would be one thing. At least then, his suffering would have come only at the cost of her accomplishment. Now, there was nothing to show for her effort and it was discouraging. Rio pressed on, ready to turn it in for the night, but as she got a good fifty feet away, the door to the SUV flew open and the woman was climbing out.

In a reaction that caused Rio's body to lurch forward as a result of the force, she stomped on the brake and threw her car into park. Her eyes were wild as she tried to understand what was happening, watching as the woman marched out into the street, hair more like a lion's mane and less like a halo, even though it was catching the headlights just right.

The most noticeable thing about her presence in those moments was not her hair, or her dress, or that positively and ferally insane look in her eyes.

No, the most noticeable thing about the woman standing in the middle of a country road in the middle of the night, staring dead ahead, was the fact that she was holding a pistol. Not only was she holding a pistol, but she was pointing it directly at Rio, who had both of her hands up in an instant in surrender.  Truth be told, Rio was not even certain the woman could see her with the way the headlights were shining in her eyes.

This was what she had asked for, wasn't it? Rio had wanted an answer.

She had one, now.

It was very apparent, very loud:

FUCK OFF.

Swallow People Whole

"Out!"

It was demanding, it was forceful. It was a command that Rio wanted to obey, but she felt like she had been chilled to the bone, frozen in place.

The beautiful, stunning, authoritative, cold, calculating killer was standing several yards away, pointing a gun directly at her. She had offered her command and it did not seem as though it was negotiable in any way. She wanted Rio out of the car and Rio knew she needed to comply, but there was no possible way this ended well for her.

"I said OUT!" she woman shouted again, but this time it came with advancement as she paced forward, flicking the gun to the side in indication. She seemed to believe that her previous two requests had not been enough to signify what it was she was looking for. "Get out of the fucking car!"

Like being hit with lightning, life surged back into Rio's form and the thoughts began to barrel forward, tangling and knotting in an incoherent mess. Sucking in a sharp breath, her right hand began to move, contorting so that she could point downward to indicate her seatbelt. Apparently the woman had gotten close enough to make her out and gave a curt nod of approval. Slowly, Rio reached down, still leaving her left hand up, so that she could unbuckle her seatbelt and slide it over her left side.

With an overabundance of caution, Rio reached for the handle and popped the door open, using her foot to shove it open so that her hands could remain visible as she climbed out of the car. She could already feel the beads of sweat that were rolling down the back of her neck and was almost certain she could actually taste her heart as she chewed on it in those moments.

Hands still raised, she kicked the door shut, seemingly not concerned with the fact that the car was still running.

"You a cop?" the woman called, voice razor sharp on the other side of that gun.

Rio's chest was heaving, her mind was racing. She knew that the best option here was to be honest, to just tell the truth, but was that even believable? That she was a morgue attendant who had become unnecessarily fixated on finding out how, exactly, she was killing men that were nearly twice her size?

Her head shook, but it wasn't enough of an answer for the other woman.

"I said are you a fucking cop?!" she asked again, voice slicing cleanly through Rio's chest, stilling her heart for the length of several beats before it jumped back into rhythm again.

"N-No! N-Not a cop!" Rio croaked, thoroughly startled by how fucking weak her voice sounded.

The woman was immobile, lit up by the light pouring out from the front of the car, her anger and alarm so plainly broadcasted on her expression. She looked devastatingly furious in a way Rio had never witnessed before in another human being.

"I don't kill women," she shouted informatively, the edge in her words not nearly as lethal. "But I'll make a goddamn exception if you're lying to me!" There it was, right back as if it had never left, though this time that edge was coated in venom.

"I'm not a fucking cop!" Rio spat back, garnering a little more strength than she'd been able to muster previously.

"Then why are you stalking me?!" the woman barked, though her voice distanced the slightest bit as she looked over her shoulder at her own vehicle for the quickest moment. There were the slightest traces of alarm as they twisted and pinched at the muscles in her features.

"I -- I'm not!" Rio yelled back, hands still up in her surrender. This woman could just fucking shoot her, get back in her car, and take off. It was that easy. It would be that simple and Rio would simply bleed out in the middle of some back-ass road where she likely wouldn't even be found until morning.

This had been stupid.

This woman had gotten away with five impossibly complex murders in just under a month and was well on her way to completing number six, but Rio had thrown a wrench in such a plan, if only for the time being. She could just as easily make Rio number seven and toss the pistol in a nearby river, never thinking twice about it.

What had ever made Rio think she could follow her without being clocked? What had she been thinking, acting like this was a sane or rational thing to do?

The woman looked over her shoulder again and then back to Rio, inching forward half a step. "I saw you at the bar! You've been following me the entire time! If you're not a cop, why the fuck are you following me?"

Her volume was raising again and the tone she was choosing was bordering on threatening. It was clear that Rio had spooked her and as a result, she was baring her teeth. She was showing her power as an intimidation tactic and Rio would have been lying if she tried to say it wasn't working. The truth was, she was amazed that she hadn't pissed herself yet.

Never before had Rio been face to face with the fuck-around end of a gun and she had quickly realized that it was not somewhere she liked being. All this woman had to do was apply the right amount of pressure and it was over for her.

She needed to say something. This dangerous woman was demanding an answer to a very forceful question and yet, Rio wasn't sure what the right one here was. If she told her the truth, it wasn't going to earn her a one-woman show. If she lied, it was very possible that whoever this woman was, she could simply choose to squeeze the trigger and put an end to the life of County Coroner Rio Vidal.

Just like that.

And then who would feed Phineas?

"WELL?!" came the woman's pressured prompting, soles of her heels scuffing the asphalt as she edged forward again, her arm tightening as she shoved the pistol forward. "Why are you following me?!"

The last word had barely left her lips by the time Rio was shouting her answer back.

"I know why you do it!" she managed, though it was far louder than the squeak she had thought it would end up being. "I know why you kill them!"

Rio couldn't see her face clearly because of the way she was holding the gun, but the woman's expression was just visible enough that Rio could see the shock as it began to seep into her form, the weight of understanding pulling her down. She drew in a sharp breath, taking two full steps this time, leaving the muzzle of the gun only a couple of feet from Rio's face.

"That's not an answer," she sneered, causing a painful chill to fire straight up Rio's spine.

Honesty hour it was, then.

"I... I --" she stammered, trying to swallow down the mouthful of sand that had developed the moment she braved to stare down the barrel of the pistol. "I just --"

"I swear to fucking God," the woman threatened, arm straightening again.

"I just want to know how!" Rio screamed back, her breath jamming in her throat in a manner that made her cough and sputter. It had scared the fuck out of her to be so forthright, but it seemed to win her some favor. The woman shuffled back a few inches, but she did not lower the weapon.

"What do you mean you want to know how? " she clipped venomously, posture stiffening at such an idea.

Rio blinked; this woman didn't seem dense and yet, she seemed completely confounded by Rio's request. It was simple enough, wasn't it? She just needed the knowledge. All she had to do was just tell Rio and Rio would happily get in her car and drive home. She would pretend like this had never happened, like she had never seen that woman before a day in her life.

Even more, she would go into work and by noon, Alice would roll in with a man on a cart that had a severed spinal cord and no other indication as to why he was dead. When that time came, Rio would act like she was still angry and indignant over the fact that she still 'could not figure it out.' She just needed to be told, first.

"I mean I... I just... need to know how you do it... How you can sever the entire spinal cord and just... not leave a single mark. And the pinprick bruising on the chest... What's the point? Is it a red herring? To make it seem occult? Or do you prop them on a stand that's shaped like a pentagram? And Rohypnol? How do you move that much dead weight once you get out of town? I --"

"Jesus fucking Christ, Miss Marple," the woman snapped, silencing Rio in the middle of her ramblings. "I didn't ask twenty questions for you to give twenty fucking answers." Again, her head snapped over her shoulder and the alarm was a little more prevalent when she turned back around.

She seemed to consider the situation for a moment. Rio could see them, the thoughts as they rolled through her head and wrote themselves for Rio to bear witness to on her face. She was clearly warring with herself and judging by the way she kept looking over her shoulder, she realized that the time she had to get where she was going had started to dwindle as a direct result of this interaction.

"I could tell you," she offered, but Rio could tell she wasn't going to. What Rio did not see coming was the next offer that followed up the first. "But I could also show you."

NO! Say no! What the fuck, Rio?! She can show you how she's fucking killing men?! What the fuck?!?!?! SAY NO!

Her internal monologue was practically screeching at her, shouting and screaming and wailing and bellowing. It didn't matter, it was never going to be louder than the sirens that were blaring, telling her she had what she wanted right there, right in front of her, and all she had to do was agree.

She had to say yes. It wasn't even an option at that point.

"Sh-show me?" Rio stammered, seeking clarification. She needed to know that this was not a stunt, that it was not some way for this woman to isolate her further just to kill her off.

That would have stupid. She could have killed her already and been on her way. If she had, she'd likely have been a lot less pissy because there would have been minimal risk of her guest coming-to in the car.

"Yes, I'll show you. But we have to go."

Okay.

Okay, so... this was happening. She was being serious. She wanted Rio to follow her. It had suddenly become the most insurmountable task just to breathe, but Rio sure as fuck was trying with all of her might.

In and out. In and out. In and out.

Breathe, idiot. Breathe and answer her .

"Okay."

"Follow me."

Finally, the gun lowered and Rio could see her fully, clearly. She still looked wildly irate and irritated beyond measure, but she seemed serious in her offer. "It's not far from here. Stay close."

With that, the woman climbed back into her vehicle and slammed the door shut with a thunderous force that left Rio feeling two inches tall. As she started to pull back on the road, Rio found a sudden urgency to get her ass back into her car and do as she had been instructed. She was quick in getting situated, throwing the car into drive as she pressed the gas in an attempt to catch up.

The woman had been right. They'd only driven for a few more minutes before she turned off to the left. Rio was not at all surprised when they hit a dirt road that was entirely riddled with potholes and divots that Rio's tiny car was most certainly not built to handle. After another minute, the Lexus veered off to the right and stopped, but it did not shut off.

Rio watched, leaning over her steering wheel for a better view, as the woman marched up to the doors of the barn to unlock and open them. Before she ventured back toward her car, she waved a hand in Rio's direction, a call for her attention. Rio rolled down the window, tilting her head so that she could hear any direction offered a little better.

"Park around back," the woman demanded and Rio nodded, following the command to a t. Once she had pulled around and shut the car off, she was not surprised to find the woman waiting at the mouth of the barn for her arrival.

As Rio started to walk inside, she was stopped by the woman's firm palm on her chest. It was the lightest contact, not forceful by any means and yet, Rio could feel the raw strength in the touch. Her suddenly wide gaze snapped toward the brunette as she drew in a sharp breath. Not only was this woman touching her, but this woman was touching her, directly in the center of her sternum in that fucking dress.

Those blue eyes damn near sparkled in the moonlight, shimmering with a staunch sense of righteousness and determination. Her voice was chilled and hollow when She spoke, offering Rio a piece of advice before she made a choice that would likely change her life forever.

"Once you step inside, there's no going back. And if I go down, you go down with me. Am I understood?"

It was ominous and it felt akin to a threat, but Rio simply nodded her understanding. She didn't feel the need to point out that this woman did not know who she was or anything about her other than the fact that she was stupid enough to agree to this just to finally obtain an understanding of something that had skated around the edges of her comprehension for far too long.

"I understand," Rio forced out, trying to deliver an assured nod in assistance, but it was barely a bob of her head.

"Don't make me regret this. I don't like killing women, so don't make me start now," that smooth but low voice warned, those dangerous blue eyes boring straight into Rio's as she listened.

That time, she did not offer a verbal agreement, but the reservation of energy allowed her to give a more assertive nod of her head. She swallowed down the fear and the nerves that had bunched up somewhere in the center of her throat and drew in a deep breath. This was it. She was making this choice and once both of her feet passed over that threshold, there was no turning back.

This was a commitment to something Rio knew was wrong.

She should have called the police. She should have walked away. She should have gotten in her car and driven away. All of the things she should have done and yet, she chose to do the one thing she should not have done.

Rio stepped inside.

It took mere seconds for the woman to begin blowing around, not faltering in the slightest over the uneven ground in those heels as she pulled the doors shut and locked them with a large wooden plank that settled into hooked metal arms; no one was getting inside unless She decided they would.

"Stay out of the way," She ordered, waving a hand that said she wanted Rio to move. Immediately, she volunteered compliance and removed herself entirely, giving Her the space she needed to tend to the purpose for their occupancy in the run-down and bordering on dilapidated barn. Rio watched in interest as the woman collected a dolly and wheeled it over toward the passenger's side of the car.

The view had been obscured by the body of the vehicle; that wasn't good enough, so Rio shuffled to the side. It wasn't painfully obvious that she was fixated, but she peeked around to watch as the woman lifted the man out of the car and propped him on the dolly. It was clearly modified to suit this need for her, but it was... interesting.

Had she crafted it herself? Did she know someone who had helped her build such equipment? If so, how had she explained that away?

There were already a plethora of questions beginning to brew in Rio's mind, but she stayed silent in her observance of the woman's work. She tipped the dolly back and began moving, wheeling the man to a large steel table, one that had leather straps worked into the steel, sticking up and unfastened.

She was not close enough to see, but there was something different about the table. It didn't make sense, but something about it felt different. It was a little lower than the tables she had in the morgue, but there appeared to be small divots toward the top, though she couldn't quite make them out. It was perplexing, to say the least, and Rio could already feel herself growing antsy at the idea of having to endure the process in order to discover the functionality.

She didn't want to endure the process. All Rio wanted was the end result.

What she was not stopping to consider was that the end result here included a dead man.

The woman lined up the dolly perfectly with the end of the table and tipped it forward, causing the man's dead weight to slump forward, slamming face-first onto the steel tabletop. It was almost comical, but Rio was far too enraptured by what was unfolding right before her to give it much of a chuckle.

His feet hung over the edge of the table -- one of his shoes had fallen off at some point -- and every single inch of the front of his body was forcefully flush with the surface beneath him.

As the woman finished fastening the last strap around his ankle, the man's head began to rock slightly. A deep groan rumbled low in his lungs, but it was silenced as the woman jerked his sock off and marched up, forcefully cramming it into his mouth.

She had some righteous public-serving agenda here, clearly, and Rio knew that if she tried to intervene it would not end well, but the full gravity had yet to really pull her in.

Where she was, in those moments, was a suspended state of fascination. She needed to just get it. Maybe then she might find peace. Maybe then she might be able to shake the thoughts that had been knotting her up for weeks over this woman and her brazenly successful attempts to eradicate souls that radiated nothing more than malice and cruelty.

There was something so fluid and... well, so beautiful about the way this woman before her was moving like a well-oiled machine. She had this down to a science, knew exactly what she was doing. She was unable and unwilling to blink more than necessary out of fear that she might miss something vital or crucial to truly having a comprehensive analysis of what had been plaguing her mind for weeks.
