Immediately, she reached inside and grabbed hold of something, though Rio could not quite make it out from where she was. Cautiously, she took a step forward.

The woman's head whipped up, her eyes filled with a primal crackling of light at the sound of Rio's shoes scuffing over the dirt. To show she had no ill intentions, Rio's hands were back up in a gesture reminiscent of when she had gotten out of the car, a clear showing that she was not there to cause any issue, but simply to observe.

Her dark gaze dropped to the woman's hand and what she was clutching within it.

"Is that... Is that it? What... What you use?" Rio managed, though her voice cracked and broke as she tried to force the question out.

The woman did not voice a response. She simply nodded.

She did not offer it for inspection but instead plucked it into a pinched grip in her other hand. By doing so, Rio could see it better.

It was a cuff, a collar of sorts. It was open, but only because the pronged ends slid into the table the man was strapped to. It clearly went around his neck, but... There were still unanswered questions in regards to the mechanics. Before Rio could ask, the woman found her words first.

"There's a blunt edged rib of metal inside here," She explained, holding the collar up so that Rio was able to see it better. In the dim lights of the barn, she could see the tiniest glint of the interior piece of metal.

It made so much sense.

Instead of announcing that she suddenly understood, Rio tipped her head in silent acknowledgement. The woman took it for what it was and set to her work, sliding the collar over the mans neck, pressing until it clicked into place in the table. At the same time, she had grabbed a hand full of his hair so that she could rearrange his head to rest with his face smashed against the cold steel below him.

The only thing Rio had not caught sight of were the five small prongs of metal that had been welded to the table, elevating the man's torso the tiniest amount.

The brunette shifted, planting herself toward the head of the table. She surveyed her prize, looking him over from heel to head before her hand found his hair, gripping it tightly.

Rio didn't know why, but the way the woman's attention snapped up and that weapon of a gaze found her felt like a bolt had been shot through her chest. It felt harder to breathe, like it took more conscious thought to replicate what should have been a mindless action. She managed it, though she was immediately holding her breath when the woman started to talk.

"I don't know what it is you're expecting out of this --" She gave a rough pull on the man's head, but because of the way the collar had been snugly fixed around his neck, there had been no movement. The lack of space had ensured that the only thing that happened there was that the metal rib dipped into his physicality and did exactly as it was designed to do: it severed his spinal cord and his entire body went limp as his head lulled just slightly to the side. " -- but that's all there is to it."

Her tone was so calm, so cool, and so completely empty of any emotion. It was as though her words had been filtered through steel and were stripped of any and all emotion that could have found them.

Rio was numb, from head to toe.

Just like that, the man was dead, and there the woman stood not having even broken into a sweat.

It was mechanical, it was a process, it was so... devoid of humanity.

In a way, Rio felt as though in a matter of seconds, she had just broken. She wanted to say something, wanted to move, but too many things were happening at once. She was blinking, processing, making sense of the fact that she had literally just witnessed the most efficient and clean murder she had ever fathomed.

The effortlessness that the woman before her was exuding was verging on absolute psychopathy... But...

It was also creating a familiar but unwelcome sensation low in the pits of Rio's middle, inching downward in a dangerous fashion.

"Th-That's... You... I --"

"You asked for it. There it was. The rib does all the work. No mark, no magic. Just physics."

Just physics.

Just physics?!

Who the fuck applied physics to a restraining collar that was capable of severing the spinal cord with a light jerk? It made no fucking sense. Even the explanation of fucking physics didn't quite strike Rio as enough, but she didn't know what other questions to ask. She was spinning on a loop, running on a wheel like the inch tall rodent she felt herself to be.

Rio had been so convinced that if she knew, it would make things better. If she knew, she could stop wrestling with the frustration of feeling so inadequate that she could not figure it out. She had been so fucking committed to the idea that knowing would solve all of her problems.

She had been wrong.

Now, she had even more questions and with the way the woman had started moving, Rio realized that she was not going to be getting those answers any time soon.

Still methodical and measured, the woman moved with grace as she unbuckled the straps and removed the collar. Before she started to move the body, though, Rio inched forward.

"Can... May I?" she question, her voice mousy and tight. Her gaze flickered to the man's neck and the woman on the other side of the table dipped her head in agreement. Rio shuffled forward but kept her distance. Not a trace of her -- skin, hair, anything -- could be found on this man or her life would be over as she knew it.

As her assessment began, she could see the faintest red line, but it appeared to be fading right before her eyes.

"How --" she started, but the woman launched a hand up to silence her.

"Nope. Not the deal. You're not interrogating me. This might have been idiotic on my part, but I'm not stupid enough to explain every detail. You wanted to know? Now you know." Despite the fact that she had started to move the body, no trace of her effort touched her voice. It was almost freakish in nature how she was able to handle this.

That man was at least two hundred pounds of literal dead weight and while her form was strained, the woman looked like she was capable of doing this in her sleep. She slid him down the table and back into the dolly, having placed stoppers behind the wheels to keep it from moving too much.

She had really thought of everything.

She was literally a killing machine. This was just an operation to her, a duty.

Rio was positively stunned by what had unfolded in the last five minutes and she had no blueprint for where the fuck she was supposed to go from there. Instead, she just watched in abject fascination as the woman loaded the man into the back of the SUV and shut the hatch, as if she were loading up the week's trash to be disposed of.

Even as the woman removed the brace from the door and pulled it open so she could leave, Rio had not moved an inch.

"Alright, well... Have a good night," the woman offered, lifting two fingers to tap her forehead before offering a salute of farewell. She angled to the right and started to head toward the car, but in a move of pure possession, Rio reached out for her arm.

She could feel the muscles beneath her fingertips as the woman tightened and spun on her, that very terrifying look filling her eyes. They dropped to Rio's hand and lifted again in silent demand that she explain herself.

"I... That's it? I'm just supposed to leave?" Rio asked, her brow pinching tightly.

"Yes," the woman responded flatly, blinking at Rio like there would have ever been any other answer.

She was right. Rio knew she was right. She hadn't owed her a thing, but she had given Rio the answer to a question she had been asking for weeks, and no one could ever know that she knew.

"Now let go of me."

Rio looked down at the contact, but she did not release it, not even as she looked back into the woman's white-hot gaze.

"Tell me your name," Rio requested, her voice soft but a little louder than a whisper.

All the woman did was laugh, right before she yanked her arm out of Rio's hold. "Oh, pretty girl," she chastised, elegantly striding toward the helm of the car, "this decision could absolutely be a false flag of my ignorance, but do not mistake me for a fool."

She stopped, just outside the door, her hand hovering over the handle. With what appeared to be a second thought, she turned on her heel and strode back over toward where Rio was planted. The closer she got, Rio had thought there would come a point when she stopped. Instead, Rio was almost convinced that they were going to collide.

With an inch between them, the woman stopped moving everywhere except her head which bobbed forward, chin tucking over Rio's shoulder. Her lips were so very close to Rio's ear. So close , in fact, that Rio instantly felt her breath as it licked and lapped at every divot and crease there.

Trying to will away the immediate throbbing between her legs that had no rational explanation, her eyes slid shut and head head tipped back. Her lips parted, but no sound emerged, even if an uneven breath shook its way out.

"Maybe if you tell me yours, I'll find you first."

Everything that was happening inside of Rio's body and mind wanted her to simply combust. This should not have been effecting her the way it was, should have had such a vice grip on her. It was an instance that assaulted all senses, that made her feel overloaded. She could smell the woman's perfume as it mixed with her shampoo, could hear the slight hitch in Her breath. She could see the thinnest sheen of sweat as it had coated Her skin.

Rio should have kept her mouth shut. She should have placed more distance between them and walked out of that barn. Again, there were a list of things that she should have done and instead, she made another choice to do something she should not have done.

"It's Rio. Rio Vidal."

The sinister hum of satisfaction that left the woman caused Rio's skin to prick with goosebumps, her heart freezing over in her chest.

"Well then, Rio Vidal," came a sultry purr that did unimaginable things to Rio's brain, "I suppose I'll be seeing you."

She did not speak another word, just turned her head so that her lips just barely skimmed Rio's ear before she turned on her heel and made her way to her car. The engine started and she began to back out, her gaze pinning Rio in silent instruction to move as she passed by. In accordance, Rio shuffled out of the barn and simply watched the woman seal it up before climbing back into her car.

Before it started moving again, the woman's curious gaze found her one last time, and then she backed her way down the drive and found the dirt road just to disappear into the night. There, resolute in her confusion, Rio stood just staring off into the darkness, the pitch black of the Illinois countryside.

All she could think in that moment was one solitary thing:

What the fuck did I just do?

The Craving it Grows, Fiercer it Grows

It had taken Rio close to twenty minutes to start up that tiny Tiburon. It had taken her an additional five to find the ability to shift gears into drive and pull out from behind the ramshackle barn to find her way back to the city. Back to her apartment. Back to her cat who was surely losing his mind over the fact that she was not home for him to crawl into bed with.

Back to her life where she was not supposed to have the knowledge she now had.

Back to her job where she would have to feign anger in front of Alice, as if she had not borne witness to the exact cause of these deaths, and the person responsible for them.

The woman responsible, as she had known all along. Everyone else had their assumptions, but Rio's gut had not led her astray anywhere throughout her search.

The beautiful woman responsible.

The genius beautiful woman responsible.

Fuck.

As Rio pulled into the parking garage attached to her apartment, all she felt capable of doing was cursing herself. She had fucked up. She hadn't just fucked up as in 'oopsie.' She had fucked up in the sense that if this ever hit the light of day, she was done for. Not only would she be unemployed, but she would be sitting in a prison cell for the rest of her life.

Rio was too pretty for prison.

She was also too soft for it, as well.

With those facts taken into consideration, Rio knew she had no other choice than to act right and not let even the slightest flicker of that night find its way to the surface. This was something she had to bury, much in the same way she had to bury her humanity when she was dissecting and examining human bodies for a living.

This could never see the light of day or her life was over, and Rio wasn't ready for that to happen.

As she had guessed, Phineas was poised only a foot away from the front door as she slinked through it, her mind still a complete tangle of thoughts and emotions and images that she could not seem to sort out. She could see the woman as she moved about like it was child's play to kill a man. She could hear the woman's chilling but stern voice as if she were whispering in Rio's ear again. She swore she could even still smell her perfume.

After tending to Phineas by means of food and fresh water, Rio sulked off to strip down and shower, somehow of the mind that maybe it might rinse off the shame she was feeling at how... unbothered she was by all of it. Yes, it was startling. But it had also been so easy and that fact alone was just as jarring in its own right.

There was no emotion there, no suffering or cries or pleading for her to spare his life.

That man had sipped at that beer, none-the-wiser that it would be his last, and that it would be the reason he would simply cease to exist.

It should have revolted Rio, should have made her sick. It should have been repulsive that someone could claim a life with such finesse and little remorse. Yet, Rio stood in the shower, washing herself clean and fixating on every single detail she could remember, both about the woman and about what she had witnessed.

It had started with the method of it all, the way that woman had planned out every single aspect. She held the meeting, was casual while dosing the man, helped him out innocently to an awaiting car and drove. She drove and drove until no one would notice her anymore. Once stashed away from the world, her transport had been crafted to minimize effort. The trip might have been short, car to table, but it lessened the physical force she had to exert.

Even after those brilliant measures came the table. Rio wanted to know how she'd gotten both the table as well as the collar crafted without question or suspicion. It was something new that she absolutely needed to know. How did this remarkably poised and insanely beautiful woman pull in all of these parts and pieces to be nothing more than a black widow in the night, her venom soaking the blunt rib inside of that collar?

Clearly, her appearance was lending to the fact that she kept getting away with it. It left Rio wondering who this woman was, what it was she did for a living that allowed her to own secluded property and wear expensive dresses and smell as though she'd spritzed thousands of dollars onto her skin.

How could she drive a nice car and consistently meet men in bars and flag absolutely no attention? Rio's inference had been right in that this woman was hunting in that bar in particular and yet, no one seemed to notice a thing, not as it was happening and definitely not the next day.

Rio's mind continued to wander, to play through the footage of how practiced and methodical She had been as she had secured the man to the table. She had brandished that collar like it was a source of pride for her, a devious and devilish glare to the snarling grin she'd worn as she had shown it off.

Fuck she was so beautiful in the most goddamn dangerous way.

The thought happened at the same time something else did: Rio's hand had apparently started sliding down her stomach, her fingers finding sensitive and slick flesh as those flashes of the woman flickered in and out of focus.

FUCK! NO!

Rio whipped her hand back and grunted in frustration. What the fuck was she actually doing?! This was nothing but sheer madness mixed with a healthy dose of sheer stupidity and she was slowly losing her grip on all that was sane and made sense.

Because honestly?

None of this made any fucking sense.

What the fuck did it mean that she had been so willing to watch the most damning crime? What the fuck did it mean that as Rio had watched the woman glide about, doing what she set out to do, Rio had been turned on?! And now, it was happening AGAIN?!

It was idiotic. It was irrational.

It was fucking dangerous.

With a flick of the shower knob, the stream shut off and Rio stood there, staring at the low level of water as it began to swirl and disappear down the drain, taking the last remnants of her sanity with it.

She had to distract herself. There was still a tall boy in the fridge and even though it was nearing 1 in the morning, she still had to be up and getting ready for work in just over five hours. She could drink the beer, climb into bed and hopefully find a way to stop thinking about the way her night had unfolded.

If only.

The beer had been consumed in its entirety and yet, even buzzed, Rio couldn't stop dwelling. She was ruminating and living in the memory of that dank and dusty barn, the smell of mildew and musk burning her nose. It didn't matter that she hadn't been there in hours because in her mind, it was as if she had never left at all.

Phineas had followed her down the hall and into the bedroom, easily hopping up into his place at the foot of the bed, tucked in his little corner. It took him little time to curl up into a large ball, snug and tight.

Snug and tight, Rio thought, just like that collar.

How had she made it? What had given her the idea? How had she known it would work?

Even as Rio laid down and turned off the bedside lamp, closing her eyes did not help in getting the memories to desist. If anything, they became a more vivid display in front of the darkness of sealed vision.

The woman's pale skin had looked almost opaque in the moonlight outside of the barn and the way her eyes had absolute sparkled in their evil? It had been mystifying, captivating. It had been like falling into a trance, one Rio had not known how to break herself out of until the woman was urging her off the property.

Having been completely fixated on watching her as she had moved about her domain in preparation for her kill, Rio had noticed a few things:

1) The woman had two scars on her left arm, up toward the shoulder.
2) The woman had very nice hands. Her fingers were long and nimble, precise.
3) The woman was fucking strong. Even with the assistance of the dolly, the way she had moved that man around had made him seem no heavier than a sack of potatoes.

Subconsciously, Rio rolled to her back, feeling more than restless. Why wouldn't the images stop? Why couldn't she find it in her to just fucking rest when she had to wake up in four hours? It was becoming a nuisance, but those visuals kept looping. The only thing different she focused on was varying parts of the woman's body.

Her neck, and how long it looked with the way her hair had framed it.

Her hands. Those damn gorgeous fucking hands.

Her eyes, so hungry and angry and full of manufactured justice.

Her chest, exposed so blatantly by the neckline of her dress and the way it dipped so low.

It wasn't the only thing dipping low; Rio's hand hand started to wander, surfing over the soft cotton of her shirt where it covered her toned abdomen. It continued, fingertips pressing firmly into skin so that they could creep below the elastic that encircled her waist, keeping her shorts snug around her hips.

Neck. Flexing and bulging muscles.

Hands. Careful and intentional.

Eyes. Studious and sharp.

Chest. Full and supple breasts barely hidden.

Rio's fingertips skated through the hair between her legs before sinking into desperate and dripping heat. Her knees bent slightly and she wiggled into a more comfortable position, head nestling deeper into the pillow below it. Her eyes remained closed, but her lips parted at the minor relief that came with feeling out her own body and the incriminating slick that had formed as a result of her evening's festivities.

Oh what she would do to that neck. The marks she would leave.

Rio's fingers were almost mindless in their movements, up and down, up and down, just dancing their way through her desire, that product of aching that she did not consciously dare admit to having.

Oh those hands and how they would have felt, strongly gripping at her body.

Slowly, Rio's touch raised and began to trace the lightest circles around her clit, causing her hips to shift in automatic reaction. Those parted lips allowed for the gentlest and weakest moan to leave her, so quiet that it hardly reached the wall above her head.

Oh what it would have been like to stare into those eyes while being at Her mercy.

The pressure increased as she found a rhythm, whisps of pleasure beginning to swirl in her stomach. The moment she drifted to the next thought, to the contrive image she managed to build herself, Rio's fingers slipped down and inward, pressing into herself with a much louder moan than the one she had tried to form earlier.

Oh what her skin would have tasted like, dewy with the sweat of her effort, as Rio kissed and sucked and licked at those luscious breasts.

The more she fantasized, the more her body chose to act on its own accord, hips shifting and jilting to accommodate more of her own touch.

A new train of thought jumped onto the tracks as Rio's fingers pumped in and out of her soaking core:

Oh what it would have felt like if they were Her fingers instead, filling her, bending her will by means of pleasure.

It was impossible not to feel the way her muscles tightened around her own fingers, those whisps becoming waves in the matter of a few seconds. They were getting closer to shore, closer to crashing right into her.

Those teeth, so polished and sharp as they were displayed in the most wicked sneers.

Oh what those teeth could do to Rio. To her neck, her chest, her breasts, her stomach, her thighs.

And oh what that tongue might be able to --

"Ohhh, fuck!" Rio cried, her hips bucking up into her own palm. It was as if she were physically granting the permission to feel as much of herself as she could as she came to the thoughts of the most intriguing person Rio was certain she had ever come across, even if she was a murderer.

Despite the fact that the images had still not stopped and she wanted to keep going, as the spasms began to lessen, Rio withdrew her fingers, allowing them to rest in their own mess atop the patch of hair at the apex of her lips. Her chest was heaving and a couple of beads of sweat had started to form near her temple.

For the first time since she had laid down, Rio's eyes opened in the darkness, leaving her staring at the ceiling ten feet above her face.

The pleasure began to ebb, her breathing slowing to a more reasonable pace as rationale and common sense began to fill her form again.

Oh God.

Oh God.

What the fuck?!

What in the actual fuck?!

The hand she had not just used to pleasure herself raised, palm smacking to her forehead in a mildly painful display of just how fucking stupid she felt herself to be. No fucking way had she just fantasized about a literal fucking serial killer while she fucked herself to orgasm. Was she okay? There was no way she was actually okay.

Panic.

Self-doubt.

Questioning.

Rio's head was spinning and after only a couple more minutes of getting lost in the severe moral breach that had occurred within her, she'd worked herself up enough that she launched herself out of bed and bolted to the bathroom. She fell to her knees before the toilet and immediately began to wretch inside, the beer foaming in a way that caused her to heave harder.

What the fuck had she been thinking? Why on earth had she ever agreed to something she knew was wrong?

Because Rio's quest for knowledge apparently held more weight within her than her normally coveted moral compass. And, really, when it came to the morality of it all, didn't it fall into a grey area more than all else?

Morally , what the woman was doing was... not exactly wrong. Yes, it was absolutely wrong to take a human life, but if that human life was a detriment to other human life... Was it really the worst thing?

It was four-thirty in the fucking morning and there Rio lay, having an internal debate on whether or not murder was wrong if it happened in the right context. It was not a dilemma that she would have ever considered before, but as she tossed and turned, she kept thinking about that small little pull, the tiniest jerk that had just... snuffed out a life.

It wasn't even an effort for Her. Hell, the woman had put more effort into getting the man on the table and strapping him down than she did the actual act of killing him. That alone was something that perplexed Rio; the build-up was all work and for that kind of payoff? It might have made more sense if the kill was exhilarating, if it was violent and raw and full of emotion. But for it to be the slightest jerking of a head and that just be all there was to it?

The climax felt anti-climactic.

Rio knew now and yet, much to her own chagrin, she still didn't understand. The pieces made sense on their own; it was vigilantism in its most pure form. That alone was dangerous, but when welded to this woman's sheer brilliance and determination? Whoever She was, She was a human weapon.

Just before exhaustion won out and allowed Rio to slip off into sleep, she had a thought.

At the end of it all, she was damn lucky to be alive. What she had done was stupid, it was careless, and she needed to remind herself consistently that she could have wound up cold and riddled with bullet holes if the woman had been anyone else. For whatever reason, she'd decided to succumb to Rio's need to understanding and while it had panned out well enough, it had still been a very, very large risk.

If nothing else, at least she lived to see another day.

_________________

When Rio's alarm went off sixty-eight minutes later, it took every single ounce of will in her body to not launch her phone across the room.

She did not want to get out of bed. She did not want to wash her face and brush her teeth. She did not want to get dressed and drive to work. She did not want to see Alice.

She was going to see Alice, there was no question about that.

There was also no question about the fact that when she did inevitably see Alice, she was going to be wheeling in a cart that carried the man from the night before, the one from the bar. She was going to bring him in and jabber at Rio about how for the sixth time in a month, another man was dead because his spinal cord was severed.

She was going to look Rio in the eye as they transferred the body bag and Rio was going to have to put on the best fucking show of her life. She was going to have to act, and acting was not a profession Rio had ever once considered. She wasn't the best liar, she got clammy under pressure and when things got to be a little too uncomfortable, she just laughed until she could make a quick exit to stave off any embarrassment.

So how the fuck was she going to look her friend in the eye and act like she was angry that she still had no clue this was happening? Lying about the tox screen had been one thing, but this was another level entirely. It wasn't something she was proud of, but Rio knew it was a necessity.

If Rio chose to tell Alice the truth, there was no telling what Alice would do. On one hand, she would lose her fucking mind and call the cops right then and there until they beat Rio into submission and convinced her to give the woman up. That would never happen -- Rio didn't even know her name and she realized as she walked through the front doors of the municipal building how that specific choice had been by design for that very reason.

Maybe the woman knew what she did for a living, maybe she didn't.

If she hadn't before, all it was going to take was a quick Google search of the name she had provided the night before and the woman would know who she was, what she did for work, where she went to college. Hell, she'd probably find several photos posted to Roscoe's Facebook page of her and Alice grinning like idiots while drunk off their asses.

That was an entirely separate crisis to consider; she had just handed over the keys to her life when she had told the woman her name and now, she was realizing that she had placed herself right beneath Her thumb.

She had every ability to make good on Her word and find Rio first. That both thrilled and horrified Rio for almost the exact same reasons.

Once she had slid on her crisp white coat and went through her morning checklist, Rio had placed herself behind her desk and sipped at the coffee she had grabbed from the break room while looking over that morning's crossword puzzle. She always stole them out of the paper in the break room, no matter how many people it annoyed.

It had not taken long for Alice to arrive with her first pick up. Instead of watching her sail in like she usually did, Rio was up and on her feet, curiosity winning out in spite of the fact that she was meant to be playing it cool and collected.

"Good morning!" she greeted brightly -- oh, this was going so poorly. Rio was being far more of a morning person than she usually was an Alice picked up on it immediately, though the way she chose to call it out was surprisingly gentle for her.

"No crossword clue to bark at me today?" Alice question and Rio took the other end of the cart, though she didn't need to push much with the way Alice was already pulling the entirety of the weight.

"Nope, hadn't really started on it today," Rio answered with a shrug as they lined up the steel tops so that they could shift the body to stability. "What do we have first thing this morning?"

White male, early thirties, dead but no visible cause. Likely a severed spinal cord.

"Forty eight year old woman. Picked her up near Wicker Park in an abandoned house. If I had to call it, I'd say an overdose," Alice plied informatively as she released her hold on the bag and grabbed for the clipboard, as was routine.

For just a moment, Rio had been listening to the Alice that had been speaking in her head that she had not understood what the real Alice had actually said. Rio blinked at her, the last word looping over and over again until she spoke it aloud in hopes that Alice might repeat herself.

"An overdose?" Rio asked, brow knitting to show that she didn't quite understand.

"Yeah, she has some track marks between her fingers," Alice answered easily, not realizing that Rio had not been having the same conversation she was.

Track marks. She.

It wasn't the man from the bar.

Something in Rio sank, but she fought to keep her expression neutral. She couldn't show that she was disappointed that she would not get a closer look at the man from the night before. At least, not right then. The day was still young, sure, and there was plenty of time left for Alice to show up with him, but Rio had been hoping it would be first thing.

That was... fucked, wasn't it? Something had to be wrong with her that she was fucking disappointed that the first victim on her table was not the man she had watched die the night before.

Alice didn't catch it, though. As Rio scribbled her signature on the paper and forked the clipboard back over, Alice was already tending to the pager that had sounded on her hip.

"Fuck. Looks like it's going to be a busy one today," she grumbled, tucking the clipboard back into its holder on the outside of the cart. "I've got two, so I'll probably just grab both at once and then head back here. I'll text you if I wind up at a cemetery."

Alice was being funny. She was making a joke. It was something that was meant to make Rio laugh.

Rio just realized it after two seconds too long, long enough to make it weird when she started laughing, completely delayed in the reaction.

"Maybe while I'm gone, you'll get through at least one cup of coffee and stop being weird."

Oh, whoops. Maybe Alice was a little more perceptive than Rio was giving her credit for.

"I will try. I slept like shit, so no promises," Rio returned, following Alice out into the office area so that she could depart.

"Phineas taking up the whole bed again?" came Alice's teasing in return.

"Doesn't he always?" Rio mused, removing her pen from behind her ear as she flipped it along her fingers.

"Have a good day, Rio," she offered as she slapped the button on the wall and the doors swung open to enable her departure.

"You too, Alice. See you soon."

With that, Rio set to work. It had taken her only a few minutes to determine that Alice had been correct and the woman had died as the result of an opioid overdose. It was an open and shut case, but she did her due diligence to make sure that everything else could be excluded. Once satisfied, Rio sewed the woman back up and tended to cleaning and storing her just in time for Alice to make her return.

"This one can just go straight into cold storage," she offered, no greeting or quip beforehand.

"Yeah? You good?" Rio questioned, glancing down at the bag on the cart. It did not look like a fully grown adult. Her stomach sank, but Alice realized very quickly she needed to clarify.

"It's not a kid," she stated bluntly, though the expression she was wearing told Rio it was meant to soothe her. "It's just not all there. A lot of it was eaten by wildlife."

Rio's lips turned down at the corners in a way that could have been a showing of her disappointment that her work was entirely unnecessary in that case. What it really symbolized was the fact that she thought it was Bar Man from the night before.

"If you can grab it, I can go get the man of the hour."

Rio knew immediately what, exactly, Alice meant by that. She had recovered another man's body from another cemetery and it would inevitably be another case of a severed spinal cord with no other indication that the man should be dead.

"Another one?" Rio asked, her eyes widening slightly.

"Six in less than five weeks," Alice agreed with a nod.

"And they're still reluctant to call this what it is?" Rio posed, her right brow arching sharply in a slightly over-exaggerated manner. "Let me guess, they're still convinced this is a man, too."

Alice snorted, giving a shrug of her shoulders as Rio lifted the remains off of the cart and walked them over to the cold wall, pulling one of the drawers open with the toe of her shoe. Once she had tugged it far enough, she laid the bodybag gently inside and pressed it shut.

"Be right back!" Alice shouted from the other side of the wall as she disappeared through the doors to retrieve her other delivery.

This time, Rio knew what she was going to find when she opened that body bad. She knew that it would be the same motions that she'd been replicating for the last month, that she would find the same things she'd found every other time.

The decision to be made was whether or not she was going to keep manufacturing the tox results to make it look like a shift in MO or if she would let it pass as it came through with the Rohypnol results.

There was only one problem with that.

Letting it through as normal would most certainly draw attention to the fact that while the actual kill had been the same, the previous tox report had been submitted bearing an anomaly. That could fall back on her and if it did? That meant a whole world of hurt and headache that she did not want to face.

She never should have changed it in the first place. In doing so, she had created a snare and as it stood, her foot was right in the middle of it. One wrong move and she was going to hang herself out to dry.

When Alice returned, Rio had somehow found a way to center herself, a way to tame the way her heart had started to sprint in her chest, running suicides back and forth. Once they had made the transfer and Alice had move the cart toward the entryway, Rio had not been expecting her to come back. A shout of farewell usually did the trick, but Alice stepped right up to the table as Rio unzipped the body bag.

The one thing Rio could not give Alice right then was eye contact. If she looked Alice in the face after seeing the man that had spent almost an hour annoying the fuck out of the bartender at the bar that Rio had been staked out in the night before, she was going to crumble and her will to stay stoic would break in an instant.

She unzipped the bag and began to work, shimmying him out of it before she folded it and handed it over to Alice who took it but did not retreat to place it on her cart. She was still watching, though shew as doing it quietly.

"We're never going to figure it out," Rio finally announced, forcing a well of defeat to tug at the bottom of the statement. She needed it to sound like a fact, like it was something that Alice would believe without protest.

"I wouldn't say never," Alice countered, trying to sound hopeful despite the circumstances. "It just might take us another twelve bodies."

Rio scoffed at the idea, and while it was a natural reaction, she was thankful for it. It had happened without thought and that was good; it was an indication that lying might prove to be a little easier than Rio had first considered.

"You think whoever's doing this will keep going for that long?" Rio asked, finally braving a glance at her friend. Thankfully, Alice seemed focused on the man on the table, so grey he was almost green.

"Whoever it is, they don't seem to be slowing down. It's pretty much every three days at this point, right?" she posed, finally looking up to make eye contact with Rio. Surprisingly, Rio remained steely and firm in her facade to keep Alice from peering inside of her head.

"Three days," Rio repeated, her gaze dropping to a familiar face, one she had to look at like a stranger. "Every three days."

Alice started speaking, but whatever she wanted to say died on her tongue as her pager went off again and she heaved an annoyed sigh. "Break's over, I guess," she grumbled, fidgeting with the empty body bag in her hands. "See you in a bit, Rio. I heard Gina's ordering pizza for everyone today. Catch you in the break room for lunch?"

"Of course. I never turned down a five cheese," came Rio's light teasing. "Have fun, be safe, typical mom shpiel."

"Bye!"

With that, the cart squeaked, the button clanged as Alice slapped at it, and she was off to make her next pickup.

It had been three days.

What if it was less?

What if the woman's mission was to have a turnaround of one body a day? What would Alice have to say every single day when it was more and more of the same?

The entire time she spent dissecting and cleaning the man before her, all she could think about was what he had looked like when he was alive. He had been cocky and arrogant, pissing off anyone close enough to hear him talk. He had thought that he was some kind of gift to the world and even if she had not been there to drug and kill him, the woman could have done ten times better than him.

Rio could have been better than him.

Oh fuck, not again.

She had to stop thinking like that, had to stop fantasizing that the woman would ever actually make good on her word and come find her. It had been a tactic, nothing more, to just get Rio out of her way so she could move freely about the world again.

Then, a thought struck her.

Maybe she didn't want to wait for the woman to find her.

What if she'd make her presence known even sooner?

And so, that was what Rio decided to do.

She went home, showered, spent half an hour with Phineas and made sure he was well fed before she grabbed her keys and blew out of her apartment. She was dressed in joggers and a form-fitting t-shirt that hugged her curves in all the right places, and while something in her wanted to drop the other woman's jaw, something in Rio had told her that her plan that night was not likely to work.

She had been right; she'd waited at the barn for three hours. The woman had never turned up.

It was disappointing, but Rio was not deterred.

If anything, she had two more nights. It was a fifty-fifty shot. If she repeated the process the next night and She was a no-show?

Well, third time would be a charm, wouldn't it?

A Spark I Saw As a Bomb

Night two.

It was the second night in a row that Rio sat reclined in the driver's seat of her car, careful gaze sharp and observant for any sign of headlights.

There was nothing.

Just darkness.

Upon checking the time, Rio heaved a sigh of resignation; it was after midnight. If She was going to show up, She would have done so already. Rio had known better; it would have broken the pattern and yet, she couldn't help herself.

It was quite a feat that she remained the least bit useful at work, as she could hardly stop visualizing and deconstructing what her life had looked like that night, the night she had gone to that bar.

The night she had gotten in her car and followed someone she had suspected of murder. The night that she had been caught red-handed in her pursuit. The night that startlingly beautiful woman had so simply offered her a ticket to the show. The night that Rio's perception of morality and the finality of death began to crack and crumble.

There had not been a slumber since that night that did not begin with a hand between her legs as those bountiful and vivid images rolled through her mind like the most delicious soft core porn. It made it a little easier to ignore the fact that it was actually a snuff film, one only Rio would ever have to play through over and over again. Only Rio got that privilege, that pleasure.

And then, the orgasm would wash over her, she would recover enough to realize that she might actually be losing her grip on sanity, and she would roll over and fall asleep ten minutes later.

The previous night had gifted her more than an hour of sleep, though she was nearing the precipice of not getting quite enough to remain cognizant and aware. Rio was fighting her way through it, continuing to press on.

Work had been rather uneventful, though Alice had been in an uncharacteristically good mood, something Rio quickly realized was because she had gotten laid the night before. Of course, that opened the door to a day full of Rio relentlessly making playful quips and jabs to finally celebrate Alice's liberation from celibacy.

They backfired every time when Alice would retort that the last two times Rio had a woman between her legs was only because she was at the gynecologist.

As much as Rio wanted to be bitter about it, Alice wasn't exact wrong. It was just that Rio didn't want to make time to date. She wanted to spend time with her friends and with her cat. She wanted to read, to research, to learn.

Now, she apparently wanted to stalk a serial killer that she could not stop thinking about to save her own life.

She should have just left. It was 12:08am and she had to be up at 6am for work. She needed to just drive home, check on Phineas and climb into bed and fall asleep after an orgasm she would feel guilty about for a few minutes.

Yet, Rio sat there for another twenty-two minutes. Y'know... Just in case.

At 12:30am, she knew it was useless. The woman was likely keeping to her timeline, taking precautions to ensure that no one else caught onto what it was she was doing. It had taken Rio a little more effort than anyone else would have likely put into it, but Rio's insatiable thirst for knowledge had led her to push harder than the average person might have.

She was home and in bed, asleep by 2am.

Day three.

Work was about the same, though Alice had disclosed upon her first drop off that she had been ghosted by the woman she'd slept with two nights prior.

"Oof, sorry about that," Rio offered in consolation as they moved the first subject of the day onto the altar of all there was to know at the end of the line.

"I mean, it's alright. I didn't want to date her, she was just really good in bed," Alice returned with a shrug, an air of nonchalance falling snugly over her.

That might have been true, but Rio had her own opinions about communication. "A 'Hey, we're just not compatible' text sure does go a long way."

"Ah," Alice replied, clucking her tongue. "My dearest Rio, have you not realized that such a level of emotional maturity is capable only by those in possession of more than one braincell? And... that's not a common occurrence these days."

Sometimes, Alice said things that, while true, were phrased in the most insane ways. Each time, Rio was never able to combat the laughter that sounded as a direct result.

"The fact isn't funny," Rio tried to recover, her hand finding her stomach as if it would assist in calming the amusement. "But the way you stated it had that Wu-Gulliver flair without question."

Alice shrugged and forked over the clipboard, thanking Rio when she handed it back.

"Another day another dollar. I think we should do falafel for lunch. Text me what you want," Alice rattled off as she grabbed hold of the cart and made her way out of the autopsy room.

For them, it was like clockwork, like a machine that dictated their routines in and out of that morgue. It was no wonder they had become such good friends; through all of the death and disease, the one constant they had was each other. People came and went, always needing something or another from Rio, but not Alice.

All Alice wanted was someone to talk to, someone who had similar thoughts. What Alice had wanted was a camarade and that was exactly what Rio had been able to be for her. She showed up, she cared, she poked fun when she could. She did all the things a good friend should, and in return, Alice provided the same in kind.

"Have a good day, Alice!"

"Make sure they're all dead first, Rio!"

The grin Rio wore as the doors swung shut behind her best friend was vibrant and tickled, amusing enough that she was focused on the interaction for almost ten whole minutes before she found her mind looping back into that place she kept trying to restrain it from.

It stayed there through five bodies, lunch with Alice, and the normal evening she tried to have. Cooking herself a meal and spending twenty minutes playing with the laser pointer as Phineas chased it around the living room had not been enough to shift her focus elsewhere. Even when she was actively doing something, her mind was still dancing away and winding up in that old barn.

The black Lexus. The purple dress. The silver table. The orange lighting.

Night three.

This one, Rio had been convinced. She had been so certain when she placed a kiss atop Phineas' head and strode out of her apartment, that this would be the night she would finally be able to see Her again. She'd been trying both nights since they had last seen one another and Rio would have absolutely been lying right through the small gap in her teeth if she tried to lay claim to not being frustrated that she'd wasted almost seven hours waiting for someone who was never going to show.

It was down to her own stupidity, really. Part of her absolutely knew that the woman was not going to break her routine, her schedule, just because Rio wanted to see her again. Hell, she probably had no fucking clue that Rio had even shown up the past couple of nights.

And so, for the third night in a row, Rio sat behind that barn until almost one in the morning, pissed off beyond measure by the time she pulled onto the street and headed home.

It was the third night after the last kill. She should have been there. If She was keeping pace, there was no reason She had to not show up.

So where the fuck was she?

More than that, why the fuck was Rio so bent out of shape about it?

It was a question she had not been able to answer, even as she spent twenty minutes trying to masturbate that night only to find herself too annoyed to come. That only pissed her off even more. In fact, it compelled her to take a hefty swig of ZzzQuil so that she could fall asleep a little easier. She had clearly misjudged the dosage, so much so that when she woke up the next morning, it was to realize that she had slept through both of her alarms, two calls from work and three texts from Alice.

She was already almost an hour and a half late.

Fuck.

After making a quick call to let her superior know that she had overslept, Rio had scrambled to get ready. She made her way straight in, only partway amused when she walked into the office area of the morgue to find Alice in her chair, boots propped on Rio's desk.

"Well, good morning, sleepyhead," Alice greeted, wearing a grin that felt too smart-allecky for the fact that Rio had been awake just over thirty minutes.

"Yeah, yeah, I fucked up," Rio conceded as she hung her bag on one of the hooks fastened to the wall. "I took some ZzzQuil to try and get some decent sleep and it obviously backfired." As she paced toward the desk, her eyes cast toward the autopsy room, a little shocked to only see one bag given the fact that she was just over two hours late.

"Slow morning?" she questioned, gaze dropping to Alice. She still looked way too relaxed and comfortable in Rio's spot.

"Actually yeah. Several remains pick-ups from yesterday that just got stored and I was able to grab them all at once."

One body.

What if it was a product of Her work?

What if she had decided that Rio had completely compromised her operation and had just packed everything up and changed venue? What if the body in that bag was lying there with a severed spinal cord and Rio would have to face the fact that the woman wanted nothing more to do with her?

She hadn't followed through, hadn't found Rio in those three days. She hadn't reached out, not at all. Even when Rio had tried to beat her to the punch, there had been nothing to show for it. Instead, Rio was standing at that desk fighting herself on asking too eagerly to know what she would be dealing with that morning.

"And that one?" she decided on. It was casual, lacked too much interest.

"Eighteen year old woman. Rough accident, but first responders think that she was gone before the crash and lost control. But, that's what you're here for!" she tacked on, obviously feeling a little more playful that morning in particular. Maybe it was Rio's tardiness or maybe it was the fact that they had reached the end of the work week. Whatever it was, it was a little unnerving.

"Gotta earn a paycheck somehow, right?" Rio mused, glancing toward the autopsy room once more before finding Alice again.

"Wanna help me real quick before I'm sure you'll be summoned?" Rio posed, somehow finding it in her to be sweet in her request.

Truthfully, Rio was annoyed. She was mad. She was tired. All she wanted was to go back home, curl up in bed with Phineas and somehow find a way to get over this... fixation? Obsession? Whatever it was, Rio wanted to let it go, to find a way to eradicate those thoughts from her mind. She wanted to stop thinking about the woman, about how beautiful she was and how good she smelled. She wanted to stop thinking about those fucking hands.

All Rio wanted was to go back to what her life had been like before that first man had thumped onto her table with his seemingly undamaged physical form, save for the severed spinal cord.

Alice swung her heels off of the desk and stood, following Rio to tend to her work day. The move was quiet until Alice's pager inevitably sounded and she heaved a sigh that told Rio she did not want to leave.

"Be back soon," she offered, slinking off toward the exit.

"Have a good day, Alice," Rio called after her, indignation filling her as she looked down at the unopened body bag on her steel table.

It wasn't a man in his thirties. It wasn't a body that held Her trademark. It wasn't another piece of a puzzle Rio wasn't even sure she wanted to put together.

It was a tragedy, and as Rio determined, the aneurysm the young woman had just before the collision had been the true cause of her death. It was an anomaly, especially in someone that young, but it hadn't been impossible. While unfortunate, it was another very clear indication that life happened as it wanted and no one really had much of a say.

Not unless they were Her.

Then, they got to call the shots, got to choose who lived and who died.

She had all the power in a world that was so quick to make its inhabitants feel so powerless.

Another three bodies filled her shift and the disappointment and irritation that found Rio each and every time it was not what she had been hoping for had become paramount by the end of the day. It had gotten bad enough that when Alice had tried to convince her to come out drinking with her that night, the way Rio chose to decline had not been the most polite choice.

"I don't want to, Alice," she'd tried, but Alice kept going.

"Oh, come on, Rio. You've been shafting me for the last two weeks. We can just go out, get a few beers and --"

"Fuck, Alice! I said I don't want to go!"

Alice's mouth snapped closed and her eyes went wide, not having seen such a side to Rio in quite some time.

Rio was not an abraisive person, did not usually snap or yell or come across as aggressive. She was soft-hearted and so well put together on a day-to-day basis, but the irritation of what had been happening on the outside of those walls was clearly getting to her. She was being reduced to nothing but frustration and longing, a desire to know more, to have more, to see more.

"Alright, I'm sorry," Alice offered, holding both palms up in surrender. She turned to leave, not wanting to elongate any kind of confrontation, but it was clear she had something else to say. "Rio?"

Rio's head lifted, eyes tearing from the desk to land on her friend.

"You're... You're okay, right? Like... Should I be worried?"

Alice's inquiry was so soft, so gentle, so... concerned. She knew Rio, perhaps better than anyone, and such a mildly volatile display from her was abnormal and cause for reassessment. The way she had asked it, it melted that angry front Rio had been maintaining over the last two minutes.

"I'm okay, Alice," Rio responded quietly. She chewed on the inside of her lip for a moment in thought before she continued. "I just really need to take the weekend and just... sleep in. I think it might fix me." The small curve of her lips she wore was accompanied by a light laugh that, while forced, showed she held no hard feelings toward her friend.

Alice was just trying to care.

Rio was making it really fucking hard.

"No beer, no caffeine. Just sleep and junk food and Phineas snuggles. Scouts honor."

Alice's gaze was pointed, studious as it searched Rio's expression for any give, any tell that she might have been trying to cover. When she found nothing, she offered Rio a kind smile and a nod of understanding.

Rio realized in that moment a very sad, very dangerous fact: she was getting better at lying.

"Have a good weekend. If you wanna come out for drinks or brunch this weekend, just text, yeah?" she offered. It was an open invitation and it was one of the reasons Rio adored Alice so much. Alice was letting Rio make the choice and making sure Rio understood that it could be made at any time, whenever she was ready.

"Have fun this weekend, Alice. Be safe."

Alice had departed first, but Rio had been right behind her, thankful to walk away from those steel walls for a couple of days. What she had not taken into account was the fact that she didn't really have much else to spend her time on in those two days.

What she could do, to start the weekend off, was try one last time -- on night four -- to wait it out at the barn in hopes that the woman would return. If she did not, Rio would have had enough reason to believe that She had left town and Rio would simply never see Her again. It was a very viable reality and yet, Rio didn't want it to be her reality.

She had spent the time it took her to cook dinner trying to convince herself that she was better off just staying at home. She could find a movie to stream or watch and pour herself a glass of scotch to simply spend her night on the couch under the weight of her emotional support idiot.

However, by the time she had finished eating and rinsed off her plate, Rio was already headed to shower and change so that she could drive out of the city and sit in her car behind a piece of shit barn that no one would otherwise pay any attention to. It took her little time and within a half an hour, her wet hair hung over her shoulders and she was dressed in a baseball t and jeans that were maybe a little tighter than they needed to be. With the pair of Doc Martens she pulled on, she didn't look like a complete bum and felt suitable enough to be seen by the woman.

Per her ritual, Rio placed a kiss directly centered between Phineas' ears and made her exit, finding herself cutting her headlights as she pulled behind that now-too-familiar barn about thirty-five minutes later.

She knew it was pointless. Something had changed; the woman's pattern was faltering, regressing. It should have been progressing, shorter cooling off periods the longer it went on, yet She had just... stalled. Or stopped. Or left. All three options left Rio feeling perturbed in the worst way.

Ten minutes passed, then an additional twenty. With thirty more, Rio had accepted defeat and come to understand her own stupidity. Whatever that tiny wave of heat had been between them that night, especially when the woman had whispered in Rio's ear that way, it had meant nothing and Rio's obsession with trying to find it again had done absolutely nothing for her. All she found in it was disappointment.

She sighed, lips twisting as she chewed on the insides of them. It was time to pack it in, time to give up. If the woman wanted to be found, she would find Rio first, as she had stated she would. Coming here night after night was a stupid choice on Rio's part and the idea that it ever would have brought anything positive to her life was an absolute farce.

Lifting a hand, Rio had been ready to call it quits by starting her car.

And then she watched to the left as headlights faintly appeared and got brighter before making a left turn, getting even brighter.

Holy shit.

Holy shit. It had fucking worked .

Without a second for thought, Rio was ripping out of the car to take off toward the barn as the woman bumped down the drive. With her urgency, Rio had appeared into view of the headlights at the same time the woman rolled to a stop.

Proud of herself, Rio was wearing an ear-to-ear grin, even as the door to the SUV swung open and the woman clamored out.

Rio couldn't see her face at first, or the color of the dress she was wearing. She couldn't see how nice her hair looked in the fishtail braid she had woven it into, or how soft her makeup was. Rio couldn't see anything other than the way the woman stalked forward, sharp and quick as she barreled right toward -- and then right into -- Rio, a hand snapping up to lock around her throat.

The woman kept going, forcing Rio to take the couple of steps back needed until her spine was pressed to the barn door, those headlights lighting up the confrontation as if it were a primetime showdown.

"What the FUCK are you doing here?!" the woman growled fiercely. Even in the dark, she was too close now for Rio not to see the burning rage in her eyes.

Rio had been wondering since that night she'd followed the woman just how strong she actually was. She was afraid she had her answer in the way the woman's hand was gripping tightly at her throat. She wasn't deliberately crushing Rio's windpipe, but the hold she had was forceful and firm. In fact, Rio was almost certain that if She tried to raise her arm, Rio's feet would come cleanly off the ground.

One of Rio's hand had somehow managed to land on the woman's wrist, gripping and pulling to no avail. She wanted to answer, but speaking was a little difficult with how they were arranged.

She tried. What produced from her lips was merely a croak, a grinding of vocal chords that creaked and groaned in the effort. When she made the sound again, the woman realized that Rio was trying to answer her. Her grip loosened, but only enough that it was easier for Rio to speak.

"I found you first," Rio managed, though it was still a little difficult to push words out around the still-present pressure around her neck. There were traces of arrogance in what tone she could manage, but it was covering up the fact that she felt like she could have combusted with what it felt like to be at the woman's mercy.

There was a sense of certainty within Rio that if this woman really wanted to, all she had to do was squeeze and lift and she could literally choke the life out of Rio with one hand, using the barn door to support her weight.

"You're a fucking idiot," the woman spat at her, eyes flashing in warning. The way the moonlight rippled through them in her anger made the hair on the back of Rio's neck stand on end. "I've seen you on the fucking cameras. You realize that showing up here every fucking night is only increasing the risk that you might go to prison, right?"

Squirming slightly against the woman's hold, Rio couldn't fight off the smirk that curled her lips, devious in nature. "You think you'd get caught?"

At this, the woman scoffed, seemingly insulted by the mere suggestion.

"Of course not."

Rio's smirk only grew. "Well, you were a lot closer than you might have thought. I've changed the last two tox screens to throw them. Also edited each report to reflect physical altercations to explain away the chest bruising. If they'd started to think they were looking for a woman, they quickly changed their tunes."

The woman just blinked at her, a stupefied expression broadcasting clearly as those blue eyes filled with incredulity.

"You broke the law to cover for me?" She asked. At the same time, her grip around Rio's neck slackened slightly, the heels of Rio's feet settling in the dirt again, grounding her.

Rio simply nodded, swallowing despite the awkward feeling it gave her with the woman's hand still stationed on her throat. She realized, taking total physical account of her own automatic responses, that the throbbing between her legs that had started beyond her comprehension only worsened.

Jesus Christ, Rio was in far too deep for this to ever end well, and she knew it.

"I... Don't ask me why, because I do not fucking know," she admitted, eyes dropping to where her hand was still wrapped around the woman's wrist.

Finally, the woman relented and let go of Rio's throat, stepping back with a look of contempt so loud on her face. In the exact same moment, that thunderous pulsing between Rio's legs waned and lessened, losing its intensity. Her arms folded across her middle and she shifted her weight to her left side, taking the time to size Rio up. She was also apparently taking the time to figure out what the fuck She was supposed to do with an unexpected audience for the second time that week.

"What do you want?" She finally asked, though it was more of a bark of demand.

"I... I just want to observe. To assess and understand," Rio answered honestly, though she sounded like a high school science geek looking for extra credit as it came out.

"This isn't some fucking Broadway show that you get encores of," the woman snapped, her brow pinched tight.

"I know that," Rio shot back sharply. "But I..."

She what? Hadn't been able to stop fantasizing about the woman before her and every fluid and choreographed move? Had fucked herself nightly to the thought of Her? Had lost sleep turning over this string of murders? Now even more because this dangerously hot woman was behind them?

"You what? " the woman bit back, taking a step forward again.

Maybe if I piss her off, she'll choke me like that again.

Oh, what the FUCK.

"I... I..." Rio stammered, clearly succumbing to the nerves that were flustering her. "It doesn't make any sense, okay?! I just keep thinking about you, about this, about how fucking easy it all it, and how it shouldn't be. I... I just want to learn."

"Learn? Learn? Like you're some fucking protege?"

"No! I just... I don't care about killing shit bag men. All I want is to just..." Rio's lips twisted, debating the next words she was going to choose. "Get you."

That confident and resolute silhouette stiffened in the headlights, but Rio still couldn't make out much of her face. Maybe it had been a poor word choice and maybe the woman was about to choke the life out of her for it, but at least it had been honest. At least this time, Rio wasn't even trying to lie.

"Get the fuck out of the way," she grumbled, having lost her volume.

In a far-too-snappy manner, Rio shuffled to the side, watching as the woman unfastened the locks and shoved the barn doors open. That made sense; a duller edge might not have enough force but too sharp and it would slice through skin. It was fascinating, really, how the woman had managed to perfect such a lethal weapon.

"I said no questions," she reminded Rio, but there was an undeniable venom coating her words.

"But a yes or no answer isn't going to send you straight to prison," Rio tried to reason. "I'm not saying anything to anyone. If I do, I'm either being submitted to the psych ward, or I'm going straight to jail without passing go. Either way, I'm not telling a fucking soul about this."

The woman shifted her weight as she stood by the driver's door, assessing whether or not Rio was being honest. She must have decided she was, because She spoke again.

"I did. It took me about three months to get right. The first six tries, it never severed and only paralyzed them. Left too big of a mess and I took off."

Well, She definitely knew who Rio was. Whether that was bad or awful was still to be determined, but at least She knew who Rio was.

It was a pathetic question, one that Rio knew she never should have asked. It stung even more when the woman climbed into her car and shut the door. Before she backed out, though, she rolled the window down, a devious grin on her face.

With that, the window rolled up again and the woman put the car in reverse, disappearing once more on her trek to whatever cemetary she was going to dump this body at.

Ten seconds. Fifteen.
