Rio was but a rodent in the wildlands, scampering and scurrying as this lioness of a woman was hot on her tail, quite literally. She could have tried to keep running, tried to find somewhere to hide, but they were long past that, weren't they? Rio had given this woman the biggest piece of her identity by giving Her a name, and now, there was no going back.

Now, it seemed, this woman was going to turn the tables and let Rio know what it was like to be stalked and followed. Fair, but it had still scared the absolute shit out of her. That was the unfair part; the woman hadn't been scared that Rio had been following her, simply for the fact that she could have just shot Rio directly in the face and walked away.

Somehow, none of this had been enough of a deterrent. She was standing there, fingers wrapped snugly around the handle as she gave it a pull and the door swung open. When Rio's gaze found her, illuminated by one of the overhead lights, she was so fucking gorgeous that it actually hurt somewhere in the middle of Rio's body. It wasn't even being turned on, it was simply seeing this woman for her true beauty and also knowing just how deadly she could be.

It was a dangerous dichotomy, a lethal one, but Rio still slid her ass right onto the seat and shut the door. Suddenly, the idea of looking over at the woman made her stomach twist with uncertainty; they were close again, much closer than they had been throughout the majority of the time when they occupied the same space. There was less distance, more perfume. Less focus, more opportunity.

"And what might you be up to tonight that brings you all the way out here?" the woman posed, having removed her seatbelt so She could turn ninety degrees in her seat. It afforded her a full-on look at Rio, something She was clearly thrilled about.

Rio wasn't looking at Her. Rio could not tear her eyes from her hands in her lap long enough to look at Her. While she picked at her cuticles and debated on an answer, all she could think about was yet again, for the umpteenth time in two weeks, that she had made a decision that lacked any true thought at all. She'd gotten into that car like this woman could not just speed off and dump her body in a nearby creek.

No, that would be too sloppy for Her. She had more finesse than that. Plus, she'd been quite insistent that she did not kill women and she did not want to start with Rio.

Despite the fact that Rio was like a thorn in her side, hopefully that had not changed.

"I was going home," Rio informed her, finally making the decision to lift her head to peer over at the other woman. "But then someone started following me and I got spooked. So... You. You brought me all the way out here."

The accusation was not harsh, but was merely an indication of the facts. Rio had been more than happy to go home, drink enough beer to get tired and then try to fucking sleep. That was now completely out the window. Now, she sat next to the beacon of her fixation and every nerve in her body felt like it was buzzing with anticipation.

A snide chuckle fell from the woman's lips, an almost sinister sound that did an absolute number on Rio's stomach and heart at the exact same time. Her heart skipped and her stomach knotted, nearly punching the breath right out of her lungs.

"You don't strike me as the type to run from danger," the woman observed, her tone so chilled and measured that it sent Rio's heart skipping and squeezing all over again in her chest. "In fact, my inference had been that you chase it. Crave it, maybe."

Rio's jaw swelled with the way she clenched her teeth, though she had not looked away. She was trying to focus on those cold blue eyes but her attention kept wandering, as did her gaze. It would trace over a cheekbone, down that gorgeous nose, over Her top lip and back across the bottom one. And then those lips would twitch and move revealing those threateningly pristine teeth.

Her dark gaze snapped back up and the amusement the woman was wearing was clearly mixed with something else, something carnivorous. She looked like she could absolutely devour Rio without a second thought and be content to move on about her life.

"Do you always talk like some kind of DC comic book villain?" Rio questioned before she could stop it from falling out. The moment she heard herself, though, her eyes widened and her jaw hinged just slightly.

Are you trying to get yourself killed, you fucking idiot?!

This time, when the woman laughed, it wasn't just a fucked up sense of delight that had soaked into the sound. The woman actually sounded like she thought Rio's question was truly funny .

In their previous encounters, there had been little room for humor. In fact, Rio had been terrified both times, but only in the way that she knew what the woman could do, and not in the way that she thought She would do it to her. Still, their dialogue had been minimal and Rio was quite certain that She preferred it that way.

Hearing her laugh like that, though, it was inducing an entirely new and perplexing feeling that Rio was not quite ready to embrace. She was also doing her best to ignore how fucking sexy that laugh was.

"No, not usually," the woman finally responded. Her chest had stopped shaking with the giggles, though they were still just audible enough that Rio could tell by the sounds alone that she had clearly touched a funny bone. More than that, Rio was focusing most of her energy on ignoring how captivating the woman was when her lips spread so wide that several wrinkled appeared at the corners of her eyes.

"But I was attempting to be mysterious. First time I've had to work at it, though," She informed Rio, quirking a brow. "Didn't work, I take it?"

Rio shook her head, but her words almost contradicted her answer. " That didn't do you any favors, though I wouldn't say you're failing at being mysterious." The astute observation landed in a way that left it displaced as it ran through the other woman's mind, her eyes darting around as she tried to figure it out. Sensing that She was not going to quite get there, Rio offered an addendum. "I still don't know your name."

The woman's expression relaxed and that arrogance crept back into her form, her shoulders shimmying as she corrected her posture. It was meant to assert dominance in the enclosed space, but she didn't need to do it. Rio was already afraid. Kind of. Maybe halfway. The other half was a mixture of turned-on and undeniable guilt.

"And you don't need to," the woman returned. "This is not a longstanding arrangement."

Rio's brow furrowed in her disdain to hear such words, despite the fact that it was something she already knew.

"Then why did you follow me tonight? You could have just... I don't know, fucked off and skipped town and... You know... Not followed me. But... here we are."

WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU DOING? ALOOF IS NOT THE WAY TO GO!

There was the angriest, smallest voice absolutely bellowing near the back of her mind. It was her own voice, but it was wanting and demanding that she not fucking blow this. But why? Why should she keep this up? It was literally driving her to the brink of insanity and realistically, it was providing nothing fortuitous to her life.

All she had done since the presence of this woman in her city became prevalent in her life was spiral further and further into a put of obsession and desperation. The people around her were beginning to notice. Hell, even her cat had started to notice. Phineas had been entirely up her ass for the last few days and while it was sweet, she was also beginning to get annoyed with him, too.

It, of course, only was happening because she was annoyed with herself most of all.

"Because I saw your car. Very noticeable, by the way. Consider investing in something a little more inconspicuous." The levels of patronization there were off the fucking charts, but Rio did not let it show. Instead, she focused on that razor sharp gaze, those pursed and twisting lips, those pink cheeks in the dim light.

"That isn't an answer," Rio finally returned, brow pinching in her hesitance. That critical gaze was searching for the truth, trying to pry it out of the absolute steel trap this woman was. It was not getting her anywhere.

"I noticed you by accident when you passed me at 58th. And I... I know it's been quiet on my end... So I just wanted to tell you that I'm not going to be around for a little while longer," the woman explained, though her gaze tore from Rio's and dropped to the empty cup holders between them. "I just... Didn't want you to think that I got caught, or that something happened to me."

Rio was torn; she wanted to blink away her incredulity at what the woman was saying, what little olive branch she was offering and at the same time, she was terrified if she did it too many times, she would snap-to in her car, driving through city streets to take her home after running errands.

This woman who owed her nothing was giving her some sliver of an explanation, some inkling as to what was going on with her, though she offered zero elaboration. They were simple facts. For Her, simple facts were safe. For Her, they could be used as currency, an exchange that might keep Rio at bay and buy Her some time.

"You... You think I care about what happens to you?" Rio asked softly, not actually thinking through the words she had chosen.

In automatic response, the woman recoiled just barely, a stern look crossing her features. Right then, Rio realized she had fucked up.

"No! Wait, I... I didn't mean it like that ," she tried to salvage, feeling like she was choking on her own words. "I... I just meant... Why do you think that?"

The woman's head tipped to the side in a silent nudge, as if to imply that Rio could not actually be serious.

"I mean... You found me. Followed me. Drove at least thirty minutes out of your way four nights in a row to see me. And you blindly and willingly got out of your car to come sit right here, so... More inferences were made, I suppose," the woman detailed, her criticizing gaze hot and pointed as it searched Rio for any give, for any sign that she was going to try to combat such allegations.

She didn't even try. The woman wasn't wrong.

Rio chose another route instead.

"You're not on anyone's radar," Rio informed her, but something deep within her bones felt like the woman was already aware of that. That suspicion was confirmed by the skeptical expression that found its way onto Her features.

"I know that. It's not why I'll be gone," She returned. Something about that answer and the way she said it made Rio curious.

"Then why?"

The woman chose not to answer right away. All she did in response was spread those lips wide and Cheshire-like, the cruel delight sparkling in those icy blue depths.

"You do care," She pointed out.

Again, Rio's stomach was sinking, sliding right through her form and transferring via osmosis right into the leather seat beneath her. Sure, it might have been painfully obvious, but having the woman point it out and wave it right in front of Rio's face was making her squirm, as she was certain it was meant to.

Rio's lips twisted and pressed in her indecision; she should have gotten out of the car, gotten into her own and just gone home. Then again, a lot of Rio's life since this woman had turned up had been filled with quite a bit of 'should haves' and not enough 'she dids.'

What Rio was doing was playing with fire and having little regard for the imminent injury she was bound to incur.

"Does it really matter?" Rio shot back, trying to garner a little sense of rigidity that might make her seem more confident than she was currently feeling.

"I suppose not..." the woman mused, her head turning so that she could look out the windshield.

Oh no. No no no. Rio's aloofness was turning her off. She was trying to seem as cool as the woman liked to tout herself to be, but it was backfiring exponentially. She had to find a way to salvage it, to set things back to how they were when the woman had simply been chasing her for the thrill of it on a Friday evening.

"Do you want me to be honest?" Rio asked her softly. She, too, turned to tuck her left leg under her so that she could properly face the woman head on. Her question had very obviously pulled at the woman's attention, her head righting as it sat atop her shoulders. Those shocking blue irises locked into Rio's in the dim light of the overhead and she simply nodded her head.

"I haven't had an intellectually stimulating kill since Tuesday. And... It's pissed me off. Because I miss it... I miss..." Rio's focus dropped instantly, watching as she picked at her cuticles to the point of causing them to bleed. "I don't know, I guess I missed you. The way you challenge me, the way I would still have no fucking clue what was happening if I hadn't witnessed it with my own eyes."

By the time Rio felt brave enough to lift her gaze, the sight she was met with made her stomach sink even farther, seeping into the ground below them.

The woman looked impossibly fickle in how fucking giddy she was at what Rio had said. That grin was downright diabolical and she looked like she was staring at a feast for the ages, but she was just staring at Rio.

Setting her jaw, Rio pulled out of her slouch, a new found curiosity burning within her. Yes, the reaction made Rio feel about an inch tall, but there was more to it. It made the woman happy to hear Rio admit something like that. It wasn't that she felt praised or coveted, but Rio had admitted to missing her, to missing her mind. Rio had let her know a little too loudly that her presence was what was missed.

In return, she'd unknowingly sacrificed a bit of information about herself; it was in that look in her eyes, the one that lasted all of a few seconds before it disappeared.

She cared about Rio, too.

No one else had ever had the gall or the brains to figure Her out, let alone catch Her in the act. Even more was the fact that Rio had pushed, had wanted more and more and the woman had been unwillingly serving it up, little by little. Rio had clearly piqued her curiosity, too, and as a result, there were engaging in this strange battle of wills where neither of them wanted to admit to how far they might go to understand it.

"So then I suppose it was a good thing I caught you," the woman said, her devious amusement seeming to subside.

"I suppose it was," Rio agreed. She was maintaining a level tone, not getting too tangled up in the idea that this had been a courtesy. Sure, maybe the woman found her interesting and gave a shit that Rio seemed to give a shit, but Rio had little reason to believe it to be any more than that.

"But you still never answered my question," she added, giving her best attempt at boring a hole through the woman with her gaze. "Why are you leaving?"

This time, the woman did not ponder her answer. When she offered it, it was not a jab or a slice. It was simply fact.

"I have things to tend to. Things that require my full attention, so --"

"Like what?" Rio pressed again, eyes narrowing in her scrutiny.

"Just because I let you in my car does not mean you get my full itenerary. And the more questions you ask, the less I find it cute and the more I find it annoying." The woman's head turned to the right, glancing out the back windshield before she turned back to Rio.

"But... I will be back. And... Maybe I hope to see you around." The woman's voice had dropped, smooth like velvet as she made her delivery.

Rio could have said anything and yet, what came out of her mouth was probably the one thing she should not have said.

"You said you'd find me. A lucky pass-by in town doesn't count. Figured you'd be a bit more creative." It was a challenge, a very intentional one that caused Rio's lips to twitch into a smirk.

"Hmph," the woman huffed, turning to right herself in her seat. "Don't know if that makes me want to try harder or if it makes me want to just... forget you exist."

The moment those last three words left Her lips, Rio's stomach was right back into her body and it felt like someone had dumped a hefty pour of battery acid right into it. She began to scramble, to find a way to recover, but as her panicked gaze landed on the woman's profile, she was grinning. She was joking.

And She had nearly given Rio a coronary in the process.

"Go home, Rio," the woman offered gently just before she started her car again. "You will be the first to know when I return."

Rio hadn't moved. She was still situated sideways in that leather seat, just staring at the woman, silently willing Her to just look at her. Somehow, someway, She must have heard Rio's call, because She turned her head, granting Rio one last full view of Her beauty.

"I still don't know your name," Rio reiterated, though there was a touch too much longing in her tone than she felt comfortable with. The shame did not touch her expression and she held eye contact with the other woman.

"I know," the woman returned. After a moment of thought, she leaned a little closer in a way that left her half-way over the center console. She raised a finger, beckoning Rio closer.

Holy shit. Had that worked? Had that actually worked?

Eagerly, Rio's torso tilted forward and her head shifted just enough so that the woman could deliver the holy grail of all Rio had been dying to know straight into her ear.

"We'll get there soon enough. Be a good girl until then, won't you?"

Several physiological reactions happened within Rio's brain and body:

- The most intense drop of pressure occurred between her legs before it morphed into a full-blown hammering.
- Every inch of her skin sheeted in goosebumps.
- At least five beads of sweat appeared simultaneously on the back of her neck.
- She choked on the breath she had been drawing in.
- Her own fingernails dug roughly into the skin of her shin in a subconscious reaction.

In all actuality, Rio was almost certain she had just experienced Living Death.

The woman pulled back, but she did not go far. Instead, the way they were both tipped left their faces only a breath apart as they hung directly over the center console.

All Rio had to do was move an inch. All she had to do was lean a little further and their lips would touch and she would know what it was like to kiss the lips of vengeance herself.

Just as she drew in a lungful of courage, the woman pulled away and turned herself toward the wheel again.

NO! No, turn back! Almost! It was almost magic! It was almost a definitive answer!

"Have a good night, County Coroner," the woman offered, glancing only briefly toward Rio as she reached to click the lock, although the door had already been unlocked.

Rio blinked no less than twelve times at her before suddenly her faculties came rushing back and she knew her only option was to remove herself from the space. As she complied and planted her feet in the dirt, the woman had something to say before she shut the door. She didn't look over, but she spoke loud enough that Rio heard her clearly.

"Try not to miss me too much," she teased, a smirk visible on the right side of her mouth as Rio simply rolled her eyes and shut the door. Before she even made it back to her own car, the woman was off and Rio realized that at least some of her groceries were going to be ruined if she didn't make it home quickly enough.

With a slight toe over the speed limit, she had made it home in time, but the feeling that had developed low in her stomach felt like it was going to push her to a mental break.

She was trying to run through it, to think about the entire conversation that had unfolded in the front of that car and how she still had few answers to the consistent questions that were plaguing her relentelessly. All she knew now was that for some undetermined amount of time, her work days were going to be a little less exciting and her nights would be empty of any hope that She might actually do as she had said.

She was not going to turn up at Rio's door.

In fact, if She ever did decide to track Rio down, Rio had the theory that she would be audacious enough to simply show up while Rio was at work and strut around that morgue like she wasn't the most prolific serial killer that side of Chicago had seen in some time.

The woman was most certainly brave enough, and Rio would not have put it past Her, but for the sake of her own sanity, she was hoping that She had a little more decorum than that.

After putting things away, Rio had slumped into the couch to try and watch something with Phineas laying on her chest. It worked for all of twenty minutes before she was gingerly laying Phineas on the couch and hurrying back to her room. When the door slammed behind her, she had been startled by her own strength. It was a distraction only for a moment before she was tearing into the closet to find something to ease the ache that had been rumbling in her core since the moment her ass touched that leather seat.

By some miracle, she'd been able to sleep that night. It hadn't taken her long to drift off and she had somehow managed to sleep until her alarm went off the next morning.

The weekend hadn't been awful, but with the understanding that she didn't need to be vigilant and on the look-out for Her, Rio decided to let herself relax a bit. She'd called Alice and they had spent the majority of the weekend together, bouncing around from bar to bar and ordering baked potatoes from a food cart at two in the morning. They'd gotten brunch and day drank until actualizing their limits and still being of the understanding that they both had to work the next day.

Somehow, the time out had served as a rather decent distraction. When Rio returned to work on Monday, the disappointment had resurfaced.

By Wednesday night, Rio was driving herself insane again, at least to the point that she had to know more. She had been trying to show some form of self-control, but the only person she'd been lying to in that respect was herself. Not searching had been some kind of moral high ground she had taken, but it was pointless anymore.

Fuck morals.

It took several long moments of staring at the search bar for Rio to think her way to a starting point. She tried to dig through the few conversations they'd had, anything that might have been some kind of end to a thread that she could pull on to unravel who this woman was.

And then, she found it.

The second night in the barn. Rio had asked her about the collar and she had answered honestly. Maybe too honestly.

In went the search:

'six men found paralyzed'

Out came the results:

'IMPERIAL PA - SIXTH MAN FOUND PARALYZED IN THREE WEEKS'
'THE IMPERIAL STAR - SEVERE SPINAL CORD INJURIES TO SIX MEN DRAWS FEDERAL ATTENTION'
'IMPERIAL NEWS - FIRST PARALYZED VICTIM DIES OF HIS INJURIES'

So she had started in Pennsylvania, all the way back in 2010. Then, there was something else.

'IMPERIAL POLICE LOOKING FOR SUSPECT IN SPINAL CORD CASES (SEE PHOTO)'

Rio clicked it without a second's hesitation. Inside, she found a photo of an old Toyota with a very clear showing of the Iowa license plate. The county name had been scratched away, but after Rio loaded the photo into Photoshop and spent twenty minutes messing with the settings, she could see the imprint of the pressed metal.

Humboldt County.

She was typing again, searching, digging, unearthing anything and everything she could about Humboldt County, Iowa. Going back five more years, she found exactly what she had been hoping for.

There, buried pages deep in a Google search was a link to the Humboldt County High School Science Club.

There were twelve teenagers in the photo, each nerdier than the one next to them. And then, there was a girl on the end with her arms folded and a scowl on her face that was practically shouting that she did not want to be in the photo.

That nose, those eyes, that scowl.

It was Her. As a child. A teenager , at the very least.

Rio's attention shifted to the text below the photo. She skimmed through it, reading over the names despite the fact that she could have just skipped to the end to find what she was looking for.

And there it was.

'Agatha Harkness (far right).'

Agatha Harkness.

Agatha Harkness.

Rio had been fucking herself for weeks without question to Agatha Harkness.

And now, she knew her name.

With that knowledge and in spite of Agatha's absence, Rio had found herself to be in quite the agreeable mood on Thursday, so much so that Alice asked a couple of times if she had gotten laid. She had laughed it off and dismissed Alice each time with a wave of her hand. No, Agatha had not fucked her. Yet. But at least now Rio could put a name to all of the ferally filthy thoughts she persistently had about her.

Rio had assumed that the following day would be much of the same, leading right into a weekend where she was sure she would wind up at Alice's side, pounding beers and shoving down pancakes at brunch.

Instead, when Alice had practically sprinted the cart into the morgue that morning, Rio had truly been stunned when she was informed by her friend that their mysterious serial killer had made a triumphant return. She had been right, as Rio had realized two hours later when she finished to autopsy.

Rio was mad.

She was more than mad.

She felt shafted, slighted, like she hadn't been good enough for Agatha to reach out to upon her return.

It had taken every bit of energy she'd had to get through the rest of the day without alerting Alice to the fact that something had changed and Rio's frustration had mounted. It had been a task, and it felt like being put through the ringer, but she had managed it all the same.

When Alice had asked if they were going to hang out that weekend, Rio had manufactured some lie about needing to take Phineas hiking for some fresh air, but added that she would reach out if she had the time.

Truthfully, all Rio wanted to do was sulk.

Her feelings had been hurt; she was so confused about whatever dynamic had formed between herself and Agatha , and now it felt like she had been just shoved to the back of the other woman's mind, forgotten as if she had never meant much in the first place.

She'd microwaved a serving of pasta and broccoli with cheese sauce and ate it straight out of the bag as she sat, legs crossed, pouting on the couch. Well, she had tried to eat it, at least. She got about three bites in and decidedly no longer wanted anything to do with it. To supplement for the loss of her meal, Rio retrieved a beer from the refrigerator and took her post back up on the couch, this time with Phineas laying his chin on her thigh, asking that she pay attention to him.

A soft and defeated sigh passed through her lips, her hand raising to smooth over the fur between his ears. She'd kept up the motion as she drank a good portion of her beer, only stopping when he snapped his head up and looked toward the door, as if he had heard something.

Reaching for the remote, Rio muted the television, listening hard for what it was that might have alarmed him. She didn't hear voices, or any other sounds from the hallway and she was listening hard.

She was listening so hard that when a very loud and very strong knock sounded on her door, she nearly jumped right over the back of the couch. With all the grace of a newborn fawn, Rio rocketed to her feet and stumbled over to the front door, peering through it to find nothing but blackness.

Someone was covering the peephole.

Fuck.

"Can I help you?" Rio called through the door.

Instead of an answer, there was another powerful knock.

Well, shit. There was only one thing to do that didn't involve calling the cops.

She had to open the door.

Okay, she didn't have to and she probably should have called Alice at the very least to see if it was her, but she did anyway.

And when she did, she didn't regret it.

There, in a deep scarlet evening dress that almost looked like it was made of leather and with her long and wild hair tamed into loose curls, stood the woman.

There stood Agatha, at Rio's front door.

Holy fucking shit.

A Portrait Bruised Just Like You

Rio blinked.

And then she blinked again and again. Ten more times.

"Well are you gonna leave a girl out in the cold?" Agatha questioned, cocking an arrogant brow, a cunning smirk playing across her lips with sickening ease.

There Rio stood in her tank top and shorts with her hair pulled up in the most shoddy bun; she hadn't even really tried. A night in with Phineas had been the only thing on the agenda and so she had felt no need to look any other way than relaxed and comfortable. The last thing she had been expecting after a frustrating day was for Agatha of all people to show up at door.

For one moment -- all that was needed, apparently -- Rio felt the insult flame up in her belly. Her brow pinched and she wedged herself between the door and the frame, denying Agatha even a peek into her life.

"You told me I would be the first to know when you got back," Rio pointed out sharply. Okay, so maybe that hadn't been the exact promise, but it was close enough.

The expression that filled Agatha almost looked wounded as a hand raised to brush fingertips over her exposed chest.

"Did you not get the body I left you?" she questioned, the gears beginning to turn behind those wicked blue irises. It was as if she were trying to calculate where else it could have gone.

"Yes, I got the body," Rio answered flatly. Her expression had not lifted or wavered from how stoic she was trying to keep it, and she had not budged from the doorway. "You came back yesterday?"

"I did," Agatha answered with a curt nod, her gaze wandering to the sliver of space between Rio's head and the doorframe. "You should go get ready." By the time she delivered the instruction, they were locked in a stare again and Rio wasn't sure if she wanted to slam the door in Agatha's face to catch a breath or make the decision to actually let her in.

She had little time to make it, or else Agatha was going to decide this was a waste of time and take off. Important information needed to be acquired first, thought.

"Get ready for what?" Rio asked; she was genuinely surprised at the strength she was managing in her voice. The fact that it hadn't started to quake once during the interaction to that point was impressive in itself.

"Dinner," Agatha answered simply, flipping her hair over her shoulder. The confidence that was oozing out of her was delicious but Rio also knew that it could be filled with nothing but poison if she was not careful.

"Dinner?" Rio returned, clearly confused. And then her eyes began to wander. The way the dress was cut was drool-worthy in its own right, but the way it bunched in certain spots -- like her hips -- and tilted slightly at the hem line, it made Agatha damn near irresistible. Her eyes snapped back up and Agatha was smirking again.

"Yes. Dinner. You. Me. Oriole. Made the reservation the night after our little countryside chat." The cadence that Agatha was choosing in those moments was doing something to Rio, something she didn't want it to do: It was melting away the heat of her anger, the anger she had been carrying with her since that morning when that body had come across her table.

Then Rio actually heard what she had said.

"You made the reservation a week ago?" The skepticism was thick and tight, but Rio had yet to move. She was still torn between pouting and engaging.

Oh. That was new.

Rio had been so willing to chase and chase and chase, but now that she was the one being chased, she was developing a whole new anxiety. It was a new brand that came with the realization that while she had wanted Agatha to come and find her, the fact that she actually had was mildly startling.

It had been this idea in Rio's head, especially since her shift that day, that Agatha had moved on. She was tired of Rio and her little games and as such, she had packed up and relocated, even if she had given warning that she was going to disappear for a short while.

For her to be standing there in that insane dress looking like absolute royalty, it felt like Rio was experiencing some kind of fever dream. Had someone spiked her beer? That was stupid; she lived alone and Phineas did not possess opposable thumbs.

"I did. I told you I would be back. And you behaved yourself, it seems. So, I'm here to make good on your reward."

My reward would be better if we forget about dinner.

Thankfully, that thought didn't leave the house.

They had not even kissed; Agatha was not going to march right in there and throw Rio around her apartment like a ragdoll -- though Rio had zero doubts that she was entirely capable of it -- and make every stupid and wild fantasy she'd had over the last few weeks come true. It hadn't even been a month and yet, Agatha was all Rio could think about. Now that she was there, in the flesh, Rio had to wonder if it was simply too good to be true.

"You really made reservations at Oriole?" Rio asked back finally, just seeking confirmation before she decided to allow a serial killer into her home.

"I did. And if you take any longer to get ready, we're not going to make them," Agatha informed her, gaze flickering over Rio's shoulder again.

Crunch time.

Rio had to make a decision.

She was running out of time.

Agatha was going to leave.

Agatha couldn't leave.

This was Rio's opportunity, the one she had been practically chomping at the bit for: Agatha was going to give her just a little more. The boundaries of which were surely to be determined, but this was a chance for Rio to know a little more, to get a little closer. She'd been thinking about this woman, about her big and beautiful and twisted brain, for weeks on end and now, she was about to squander the potential to know more.

Rio could not fucking do that.

The moment she passed Rio, that dark and suddenly hungry gaze dropped down the exposed section of Agatha's back that was covered by her hair, down that plush material to where it hugged every perfect curve of her ass.

God, she was so fucking sexy.

"His name is Phineas. He's two."

What was then not surprising was how Phineas lifted his head and sniffed at Agatha's hand. It took him about three seconds before his ears pinned back and a low growl began to vibrate out of him.

"Oh, not friendly! Noted!" she declared, righting herself as her focus shifted to assessing the space around her.

Hell, she'd even brought women home when she'd once given a shit about social dynamics enough to sleep around. Right then, having Agatha in her inner sanctum, Rio felt squirmy and uneasy.

Who the hell did this woman think she was to march into Rio's apartment and start ordering her around? Who was she to think that she was the one who could call the shots within those walls? What made her the authority on what Rio chose to do with her time?

Despite her desire to be affronted, it was fucking pointless.

Of course she was going to scour her closet for the most fucking diabolical thing she could find that would drive Agatha up a wall. Good. She deserved it for doing it to Rio first by showing up the way she had.

"Science."

It didn't matter. Rio felt the breeze as Agatha blew by her and stalked her way out of the restaurant.

Rio didn't know what it was like to be electrocuted.

She didn't know how it felt to be hit by a car.

She had never experienced a heart attack.

But right then as she took in a breath to steady her wildly beating heart and was only met with a nose full of Agatha's woodsy perfume, Rio was certain that all three things were happening to her at once, even if there was no actual proof for such a deduction.

All she cared about was getting the fuck out of there and retreating to her apartment to wallow in her own misery.

She'd fucked up.

The worst part about it was knowing she would never see Agatha again.

And Agatha still thought Rio didn't care enough to know who she actually was.

Dressed You Up In Different Names

Rio had known, but by the time she made it out to the front walk of the restaurant, Agatha was long gone.

Shit. Fuck. Goddamnit. Motherfucker.

Sure, she had leaned against them and applied the slightest pressure, but Rio did not ask her name, did not ask for names of any important milestones, and did not ask any publicly inappropriate questions.

Rio had lost focus, though, and had indulged her own need to see Agatha squirm, effectively flipping the table that was supporting whatever game it was they were trying to play.

It was over, now, and as Rio watched the city pass by the Uber window on her way home, she felt like a fucking idiot.

Being stupid about things like following a suspected serial killer and continuing to engage with her was a familiar brand of idiocy. This form of being an absolute moron was something different, something a little more gut-wrenching.

Rio had not meant to anger her, even if she had meant to toe the line of mystery between them.

She had, though, and she was alone.

Well, not entirely.

"Did you behave while I was gone? Because I did not and one of us needs to have a little decorum," came her soft murmurs.

Brrp brrp.

Those tiny little chirps seemed to hone directly in to the path it took to reach her auditory cortex and nestled there like a warm hug. She'd been kicking herself since she'd watched as Agatha disappeared, but seeing that there was still a little soul out there who needed her around was grounding.

Part of Rio felt like Agatha probably did in those moments. She just wanted to run. She wanted to disappear and forget that any of this had ever happened to her. Rio couldn't do that, though; she had a job where people knew who she was, a job where she frequently rubbed elbows with law enforcement.

Rio couldn't vanish because someone would come looking for her. If no one else, Alice would never rest until she saw Rio with her own two eyes again.

Agatha could because she never let anyone in so that they could care enough to go looking when she left.

There was a sense of care there, for Rio, but she also knew that if she went looking for Agatha, it was going to end nowhere good. Stop that! she internally scolded, though her body's reaction was to simply intensify the feeling.
