"I take it you're not a cuddler," Rio surmised through a yawn. One hand raised and tucked behind her head; the other lifted enough that she could drag her fingers up and down the length of Agatha's shin.

"Mmmm," Agatha returned, but she did speak to qualify it. "I knew you were a smart girl."

Rio, on the other hand, was a cuddler. She liked physical closeness, liked feeling someone else's skin against her own. She liked being able to hear the heartbeat of the person she'd been with, just to remind her that the experience was real.

But for Agatha, Rio could get over that.

What it all came down to was that there was no actual name for whatever the fuck this was. Rio had admittedly stalked her -- twice -- and then Agatha had returned the favor -- also twice. They had tried going on a date (as if they could have ever been normal people) and that had bombed spectacularly. Then... Well, Rio was going to be feeling what had happened after for the next several days, she was positive.

They weren't dating, this wasn't a relationship.

But still, Rio didn't want this to just be... it.

She wanted to talk to Agatha about it, wanted to have some kind of conversation where she could request more of Agatha's time and not seem desperate about it, but she was quickly fading. Impressively, she had managed to keep cognition throughout pleasuring Agatha, but the heavy weight of exhaustion was beginning to anchor her consciousness, pulling it down.

Her lips parted, as if to ask for Agatha to stay a little longer, or perhaps to request that she lock the door on her way out, but before she could muster even a sound, Rio had fallen asleep.

It had been an impossibly long time since Rio had slept more than five or six hours in a night. It was something she had accepted as commonplace, something she knew she likely could not change.

So when she woke the next day, she had expected it to be no later than eight or nine in the morning. When her eyes opened, Rio was not surprised in the least to see no one on the other side of the bed.

Of course Agatha had left. Rio hadn't actually thought she would stay, even if some stupid part of her hoped she might. When she rolled to her side, there were about four very vivid reminders of her inside Rio's body, though, and what they had done the night before.

Her gaze landed on the empty pillow in front of her and what she saw there did surprise her.

There was a phone laying on the pillow.

As she picked it up, Rio realized it was not her phone. It was a generic smart phone, one that had an awaiting message and no pass code. Rio swiped up, opening a message from the only contact: 'A.'

There were three messages.

The first one read: 'Text me when you wake up.'

The second?

It was a picture. It was a picture Agatha had apparently taken before she'd left the night before.

Her shoes had been discarded by the dining chair she had first placed herself in, but in the photo, they were barely visible. That was because Phineas had curled up on them and was fast asleep.

The third was technically part of the second, but it made Rio smile.

'I will win him over yet.
Ps. Don't forget to text.'

Agatha had encouraged her twice to reach out, which was enough to say that what had happened the night before was not a complete one-off, but that wasn't what Rio was focusing on.

Rio was just reading that second message again and again, but only the first sentence.

Agatha wanted Phin's approval, and she was making a statement that she was going to garner it. That meant more time, that meant more of getting to be in Agatha's presence. She was surely a busy woman, had a job and a deadly hobby that occupied great portions of her time, but in those six words, she said so much more.

The grin that found her as she began to type her response was giddy, growing when she sent the message.

"Good morning, you psycho. Who the fuck leaves a burner phone as a morning-after gift?"

Agatha's response had her in giggles, only moments into consciousness.

"Oh, so I should cancel the breakfast order I just placed to be delivered? Or... Brunch, rather. It IS almost 1pm."

Despite the panic at the hour, Rio's grin grew wider still.

For any and every doubt that Rio had toward the idea of this thing between them somehow finding a way to go on, as she read over the text again where Agatha admitted to buying her food, they seemed to just... disappear.

In that moment, Rio knew one thing for certain:

She had not been able to get her fill of Agatha before the evening they had spent together.

Now?

Now, Rio was in big fucking trouble with how badly she wanted more.

Bad Apple, Why Do I Want More?

Chapter Notes

*taps tags*
Morality is a weird soup here.

The last time that Rio had sunk further into bed after sleeping in far too late while holding a phone close and grinning at almost every response that came through had been when she was still a teenager, and she felt like an entire dumbass for it.

Rio was thirty-six years old. She had a career that she had invested herself into, had a life that she had built for herself, things she could be proud of. She should not have been proud of the fact that she was reduced to a pathetic school girl, pink-cheeked and delighted by having a conversation with a pretty woman.

Okay, no. Calling Agatha pretty should have been a crime for how much of an understatement it was. Agatha was much, much more than that.

Agatha was captivating. She was remarkable in every way imaginable. Her beauty was stunning in ways that Rio could hardly make sense of. Agatha was like knowing darkness for so, so long before finally seeing the light.

So to call Agatha pretty , Rio almost had half a mind to instill some form of punishment on herself in reprimand. Maybe a thought for another time. Right then, she needed to respond to Agatha's text about the breakfast that was apparently on the way to her home.

She should have said 'thank you,' or at the very least told her it was kind of her. Rio's still partially-asleep brain fired back a response before actually thinking it through.

"...Did you poison it so no one will ever know?"

She grinned as it sent, the little zzzp sounding in confirmation. She watched the screen, her eyes flickering to that contact name, just the lone 'A,' before a small bubble appeared to indicate that Agatha was typing.

The first thing that sent was a lone emoji with two puffs of air leaving its nose, brow pinched tight in frustration. Her actual response came right after.

"That's not a very nice thing to say to someone who fucked you into a coma and is having breakfast brought to your front door."

Well... Agatha wasn't wrong. At the same time, could she really blame Rio for being skeptical? This dance they had been doing, it was dangerous for both of them for vastly different reasons that had the same end consequences: prison or death.

It made sense to Rio that Agatha could see her as a loose end. She could show up one night and simply decide that the risk of keeping Rio around wasn't worth the reward of whatever the fuck the night before had been and then some. Rio was realizing very quickly how that was not a decision she would have any say in; Agatha was very capable of making very consequential choices and staking around the repercussions. Tying up that loose end might have been worth the moral anguish of breaking her own code.

Ha. Agatha having a moral dilemma. It seemed so unlikely and yet, Rio had seen it. She had spotted those brief flashes in Agatha's eyes that made her seem as though all was not as composed as she tried to make it seem. Agatha was not infallible, but Rio had yet to pinpoint a single weak spot, other than her inability to turn down a good fuck.

Well, until that text message.

Perhaps Agatha had done an impeccable job of maintaining her armor of indifference, but here she was, texting Rio on a burner phone she'd left instead of just giving Rio her fucking number. Why did she have to be so extra? More than that was the gesture of breakfast, even if Rio's suspicion had not been entirely snuffed out.

"Can you blame me? It WAS only our first date. And... We didn't even finish dinner."

She had expected push-back on that one, for Agatha to offer some cutting quip that would hurt in the best way. Rio was very quickly learning that she liked pushing Agatha's buttons because Agatha tended to respond with force and whether it was physical or verbal, it caressed all of the right spots in Rio's brain.

Rio had not thought Agatha would admit to being a snoop.

"Yeah, well... I looked in your fridge. Spicy V8 and Modelo do not a breakfast make. Are you actually okay?"

The quick whip of indignance that flared somewhere in Rio's middle was quickly gone as she rolled her eyes in response. Before she offered back a response, she flopped to her back, squealing in her shock when she realized for the first time that Phin was behind her. He let out a low meow of disapproval, but did not move and forced Rio to scoot forward to achieve the ability to lie flat on her back.

"And when did you come in to say good morning?" she asked him softly. The phone dropped to her stomach for a moment so that she could turn her full attention to the way she ran her fingers through her fur, eliciting the quietest purring of contentment.

"Thanks for being a good sport about last night. And the shoes? Nice move. But still growl again next time, yeah?" she murmured at him, the softest huff of a chuckle puffing through her nose.

A little too long into paying him attention, she realized that she had not actually responded to Agatha's previous message. She pulled the phone back up and formed a response that was short and sweet.

"I don't eat breakfast."

Rio knew it was bad for her, knew that per her physiology, a healthy meal in the morning would be best for her, but there was no interest in there when she could chug three cups of coffee to power through her days and fuel her quippy and fun sarcastic demeanor. Who needed a banana and oatmeal when Death Wish Coffee existed?

This time, Rio found herself staring at the bottom corner of the conversation, waiting for the bubble to appear that would signify Agatha had something to say, but it took... too long. Rio had been ready to lock the phone and get her day going, but just as she pulled it away, she caught sight of those three little ellipses as Agatha composed her response.

"And you don't get fucked like that every day either. Look at you, trying new things!"

Rio's laugh was loud and instant, so bright that Phineas startled and shot to his feet, though he realized quickly that Rio was just being ridiculous -- and annoying. With a disgruntled chirp, he paced in a small circle before tucking himself back into a ball once more, clearly not done with his rest.

In the strangest aligning of events, two things happened at exactly the same time: there was a sharp rapping on the front door of the apartment and Rio's phone started ringing somewhere from the direction of the living room.

Fuck.

Quickly, thumbs were moving to at least offer a half-assed response as to why she might not respond otherwise.

"Food's here. Thank you... A. (;"

Rio tossed the burner to the mattress and scrambled out of bed, nearly dropping to her knees the moment she let her weight sink down onto her feet. Immediately, she was hit with the full gravity of what the night before had done to her body. It wasn't painful , but hurt in the most delicious way.

Annoyingly, she could feel her core clench at the mere thought.

Somehow, without tripping over her own legs, Rio made it to her closet and yanked down an oversized hoodie, one that would cover enough bits and pieces to allow her to answer the door without taking the extra time to put on more clothes. She had shaken it down enough by the time she reached the door, pulling it open with an exaggerated grin to greet the delivery man.

In his arms was a box from Gotham Bagel Company with a bag that surely had a couple of different schmears inside. Rio simply rolled her eyes, though her gine didn't really go anywhere as she thanked him and took the food. Finally, her phone had stopped ringing from behind her.

"Did you get tipped? I think I have a five in here?" Rio asked him, glancing over her shoulder to try and locate her wallet, finding no lucky.

"On top of the thirty?" he asked back and Rio wanted to simply cackle at the absurdity of it, though for his sake, she managed to stuff it down. "I'm okay, thank you. Have a good day, though."

"You too!" Rio called as he turned to head off down the hall. She kicked the door shut and turned to see Phin sulking toward the kitchen, heading right for his empty food bowl.

"Alright, alright. We eat together," Rio mused softly. She paced into the kitchen and set down her morning's feast so that she could fill his bowl, but in the process of doing so, her phone started ringing again. Taking the time she needed to get the cat kibble in his bowl, she was quick as she rushed to the living room and scoured it for her phone, finally finding it shoved into the cushions of the couch.

The moment Rio could see the screen, she was not surprised to see it was Alice. As fast as she could, she answered, throwing the phone up to her ear.

"Hey! Shit, sorry, was that you that just called a minute ago? I was at the door grabbing breakfast. Got Gotham because why not?" Rio was trying to sound casual, trying to act like she wasn't so fucking sore that it was making moving around the house feel like an entire task.

"Good, you're alive!" Alice chirped over the line, though it was almost a little too hard to hear her over the noise in the background.

"Uh, yeah? Why wouldn't I be?" Rio questioned, the nerves suddenly tangling around her wildly beating heart.

"Maybe because I've been texting you since nine and you never answered? I'm at Ipsento, do you want some coffee? I can grab it and bring it to you," she offered. It was a sweet gesture, but at the same time Rio was absorbing it, she was walking by that armchair. Indubitably, her gaze dropped and her stomach followed suit.

There was absolutely no missing the two stains on the arm of the chair; not only was there the larger one that Agatha had left behind, but there was also a smaller one where Rio's own excitement had reached a little further than it had in her previous self-satisfaction sessions.

"Uh --" she choked back, trying to think of a reasonable excuse as to why Alice could not come into that apartment. Rio was certain that if she took a step out into the hallway and took in several breaths, the moment she retreated inside of the apartment, her olfactory senses would be assaulted with nothing more than the sheer stench of sex.

It would likely stay that way until she found a way to saw up and burn that chair into fucking dust.

It was the only possible solution as how she could continue to keep living in that apartment. That was a tricky line of thought; she was obviously not going to do away with the dresser, but it probably did need a thorough wipe down.

Fuck, Agatha was going to have to stop coming over or they were going to end up desecrating every flat surface in Rio's apartment and probably end up traumatizing Phin in the process.

"Do you think maybe we can hang out at yours today? You have the balcony and it's supposed to be beautiful out. We can grab some Zing Zang and vodka and day drink?" she supplied, working her hobbling out into something that could be considered more of a gait or stride as she trekked back to the kitchen.

"Yeah, that's fine," Alice answered, but suddenly the sounds of the cafe were replaced with the sounds of the city streets. "I can be there in ten. Will you be ready?"

Ten minutes was not a long time, and most likely not long enough for Rio to shower, at least towel off her hair, and change, but she could try to make it work.

"I might not be right at ten minutes, but if you'll wait the extra few, I'll be out?"

Alice chuckled and Rio could practically hear over the line as she rolled her eyes.

"Oh, gotta kick out last night's conquest and scrub the evidence?" Alice jabbed.

While every last bit of Rio knew that she was just joking as she always did, that arrangement of words hit a chillingly cold nerve in Rio's middle. Thankful Alice could not see her expression, she used that to her advantage and offered a laugh that she hoped sounded genuine.

"Of course. Now let me go shower!"

"Alright alright! I'll be waiting in the visitor's spot. See you soon, Rio."

"See you soon, Alice."

With that, Rio disconnected the call and tossed her phone to the one undefiled piece of furniture -- the couch -- and booked it for the bathroom, though her pace was hindered a bit by the current state of her physicality.

As she climbed into the shower, Rio found herself thinking those familiar thoughts from the night before and earlier when she had woken up: How had those parts of her body never been touched like that before? How had she slept with enough women that she'd lost count and still had never been so thoroughly fucked into place like that in her life?

Agatha was... She was something fucking else, that was one thing Rio knew with a painful and absolute certainty. The authority she carried with her at every second was bewitching and the fact that she knew how to back up every bit of that talk she so casually fired off?

Rio had been trying to focus on the non-sexual things about Agatha that were so damn appealing to her, but when a little voice in the back of her head piped up -- and sounded a lot like Agatha's -- as if ripped right out of the night before, Rio wanted to completely forget that Alice was coming to pick her up and just try for one more orgasm within a twelve hour window.

No!

Be a responsible adult!

More importantly, don't be a shitty fucking friend.

Rio finished washing up and dried off with as much haste as she could manage, her hair still measurably damp by the time she had pulled on a pair of leggings and t-shirt. Not wanting her shirt to get too wet, she decided to throw her hair into a clip and set about locating her necessities. Once she had her phone, her keys, and her wallet, she collected the box of bagels, as well as the schmear, and called to a Phineas she could not see.

"Behave, Phin! I'll bring back some fabric refresher... Or a steam cleaner! Don't open the fridge again!" With that, Rio let herself out and locked the door behind her. When she made it out into the parking garage, Alice was waiting as Rio knew she would be. Thankfully, she was looking at something onf her phone to it gave Rio those couple extra moments to sort herself out. When she slid in with her bounty, Alice's expression lit up.

"You brought them with you!?"she asked excitedly, as if the answer were not already in front of her face.

"I cannot eat them all and I don't know how good they'd be if I waited to bring them in on Monday, so we can day drink and eat bagels I guess," Rio suggested, her lips tugging up at the corners in an endearingly sweet smile.

"You're the best. Why did you even buy a dozen?" came Alice's inquiry as she started the car and back out to drive them to her place.

"I didn --" Rio abruptly cut herself off, pressing her lips together as she redirected and steered in a different direction. "I didn't mean to. I thought I was only getting six. So, hope your funny neighbor guy likes poppyseed bagels."

They both fell to a soft chuckling that then turned into casual back and forth about the happenings of the weekend and any recent drama either of them had heard about -- which was nothing that week. It had been enough to fill the time it took to stop at the liquor store and then make it to Alice's.

Calmly, Rio lifted herself from the car and walked ahead up the front path to Alice's house, bagels secured snugly in her arms. She was not sure what in the world she would have needed to have done to prevent Alice's next statement, but she would have done anything in the world to have seen to it that the words never left her lips.

"Oh my God, Rio!" she exclaimed her voice jumping at least one octive at her humor. Alice surged up to Rio's side, turning her head to gawk. "You really needed the extra time to kick someone out?!"

Ugh. Alice. Fucking perceptive Alice. God damnit.

"No," Rio answered truthfully. She hadn't needed the time to kick Agatha out, she'd needed the time to wash the absolute filth of the night before off of her skin and out of her hair. She needed to remove any trace of Agatha that might have been visible to anyone else, especially Alice.

"You're lying. You got laid." It was an astute and pointed observation, but it was one that made Rio's jaw clench. She was trying not to grind her teeth to prove Alice write, but she was suddenly watching as the circus of her life began to devolve into obvious madness.

"Can you maybe... I don't know? Unlock the door and let me in so I can set this stuff down?" Rio huffed, her annoyance sharp and bitter on her tongue.

"Jeez," Alice grumbled, shuffling forward to unlock the door. "I thought you laid would make you less grouchy."

"If you stay still too long," Rio clipped back, nodding her head toward the inside of the home for Alice to continue, "I'm going to kick you on my way in."

Maybe it wasn't exactly common for them to pass up on an opportunity to gossip about their sex lives, but it had been no secret that Rio's had been rather lacklustre as of late and Alice never missed the opportunity to poke fun of her for it. Meanwhile, Alice's latest conquest was a woman that worked in the County Title Office. She'd been rather tight lipped about it, so Rio felt as though she could take up the same stance here, keeping this one a little closer to the vest.

As if Alice was ever going to let that happen.

She did give in to Rio's direction, tucking inside as Rio followed, but she was quick to relieve Rio of the box. They both wound their way to the kitchen, Rio's eyes wandering over the interior of the home. It was comical, really, the way it was never the same each time Rio came over. It wasn't always a massive change, but Alice was the restless type, never able to stay in a pattern or pocket for too long comfortably.

She took to rifling through the bagels and picked out two everything for them and set about the work of slicing and toasting them. Half-way through, she glanced over her shoulder at Rio who stood staring into the fridge.

"You have nothing to put in a bloody," Rio pouted, kicking her foot in a feigned tantrum.

"So who is she?" Alice asked, hoping to be so curt and sudden that it threw Rio off.

It didn't work.

"Do you have any of those bleu cheese stuffed olives left?" Rio questioned, surveying the various jars in the shelves of the door. She was finding nothing suitable, but she was still trying to pretend like she was looking really hard for something that might improve the quality of their drinks.

"Where did you meet her?" At this point, Alice was an absolute mockery of herself, bent at the waist with her elbow on the counter and her head propped on her fist, staring up at Rio with a playfully inquisitive gaze.

"Do you not even have any celery? Anything?!" Rio was ignoring her. On purpose. Because she hadn't concocted quite the right lie to spin here and lying to Alice was hard enough as it was. She didn't need the pressure of a deadline creating unnecessary nerves.

"Rio, come on," Alice pleaded, wanting the tiniest crumb. She just wanted to be let in on a secret that Rio was clearly very terrible at keeping.

Heaving a sigh, Rio leaned forward, as if inspecting more of the contents in a way that might show her something she had not noticed before. She even bent a bit, sticking her head inside as if it might offer her an out in relation to the conversation Alice wanted so desperately to have.

"Was she at least good in bed?" Alice attempted, hoping Rio might bite.

Rio was an asshole. Of course she would bite, very facetiously.

"Oh yes, absolute killer."

Rio had expected a laugh, a snort, for Alice to throw something at her. When Alice fired a retort back that pierced through Rio's entire body, her reaction was instant.

"What, you fucked the serial killed?" Alice shot back.

Rio tried to stand up, completely forgetting that she was hunched over with her head stuck in that refrigerator. The moment she did, the back of her head slammed into the bottom of the freezer door and she yowled in pain. Her hand flew up to cradle the back of her scalp, stumbling back enough that her back hit the opposing counter.

"Motherf --!"

"Rio!"

By the time Rio stopped seeing stars long enough to realize where she sound of Alice's voice was coming from, she had no time at all to formulate any plans of attack on how to field what was bound to come her way.

"No fucking way, Rio," Alice pressed, stepping forward to shut the door before she turned on her friend. "Please tell me there is a perfectly logical explanation as to why you reacted that way when I suggested you are fucking the serial killer we have suspected to be a woman without telling me that you are fucking the serial killer we have suspected is a woman."

Rio was still rubbing at the back of her head, trying to soothe the miserably sharp pain that had happened as a direct result of the contact. She had suspected she might have split skin, but the lack of anything warm and sticky negated the possibility.

"Can I... Just tell you that there is just not a perfectly logical explanation and we just leave it at that and eat our bagels and drink our shit-ass excuses for bloody Marys?" She was grumbling now, wanting to find a way through this conversation that did not involve her revealing anything crucial.

Rio might have been an idiot, but she was not a nark. She was not going to rat Agatha out, not even to her best friend.

"Stop it right fucking now," Alice admonished, stepping closer to pick apart Rio's expression with her pointed and hot gaze. "You really found her?"

"Can you like... Go back to what you were doing before this turned into the Spanish Inquisition? My soul is far from saving, Alice."

Rio was trying to prompt her to let it go, but she had already known it was never going to work. She had given too much away, just enough for Alice to surmise that she wasn't lying and was instead trying to hide her impeccably poor decisions beneath a stony blanket of poorly compiled humor.

"Rio..." Alice tried again, but this time the look she was wearing was much softer. "If you're being serious... You can tell me. I'm not going to fuck off and run to the cops."

Rio was still rigid and unnerved, her back awkward in its positioning against the counter, but she did not slacken or back down. Her dark gaze swept over Alice's features, trying to find even a twitch that might tell Rio she was being dishonest.

Rio knew Alice better than that, though, and she always had.

What had started as a working relationship had formed into something stronger, something that was perhaps even a little too well-seeded to be called just a typical friendship. The platonic love they had formed for one another was a true showing of a different kind of devotion, one that was about to prove itself then and there.

"And no calls to county for a psych admittance?" Rio pressed, both trying to see how far Alice might be willing to compromise and also to gauge where her true loyalties were going to lie.

"Rio... Am I going to think you're insane and making terrible choices if you're being honest? Of course, but that's because I'm your best friend and I'm allowed to tell you when you're being insane. But... I'm not going to turn you over to care of the city." Alice paused, considering for a moment as she chewed on the inside of her lip. She wanted to say the right thing, but she also wanted to make sure that Rio understood that their friendship truly was a safe place for her to fall.

Rio's lips worried and twisted in her indecision, her stomach churning like it were being torqued with a cement mixer. How did she tell Alice the truth? More than that, how much of that truth did Rio tell her?

She had known all along that this was stupid, but she had been hoping that her acting abilities had gotten better since she was a child. As it turned out, that was not the case. Instead, Alice had pinned her pretty quickly and there was little salvaging what had remained of her ruse.

"Yes."

It was all Rio said, and it wasn't a direct answer to any questions Alice had asked, but it said all she needed it to say.

The shock filled Alice in the blink of an eye, her own going wide as it registered that Rio was being honest, that she was choosing to tell Alice a very big and very dangerous secret. That startled gaze was daring everywhere on Rio's expression, trying to locate a jumping-off point, somewhere that she could propel this conversation from, but she was coming up empty.

Instead, Alice chose to state the obvious.

"Okay, first off, you're a fucking dumbass. Second... What's her name? Is she hot? Can she fuck?"

Alice had pressed forward, picking both of Rio's hands in her own as she fired question after question, not actually giving Rio any time to answer them before she was offering the next.

"Alice, Alice," Rio tried to calm, her fingers fastening firmly around Alice's. "Listen, I am more than willing to answer most of the questions you probably have, but I'm going to need to down at least one full glass containing liquor before I do. Can that be arranged?"

She knew what kind of choice she was making, and she knew that she was going to have to be very, very careful about what she revealed. She could offer a made up name, one even different from the one Agatha had used at the restaurant the night before, and she could fudge a job title. That one wouldn't be as hard; she didn't actually know what Agatha did for a living anyway.

The difficult one was going to be knowing how to field the true reason for her search; the knowledge. Rio had sought this woman out because she'd possessed questions that she had needed answers to. By standard reasoning, admitting to the fact that they had fucked implied that she had at least bare minimum knowledge about the mass murders that had been going on.

It wasn't quite so simple, though.

The thing that made it so complex was that Rio had agreed to be a witness.

Not once.

But twice.

That bit of information perhaps needed to stay under a little more lock and key than some of the more vague pieces she might have been able to offer.

Alice had agreed to alcohol with ease; they prepared their drinks and headed to the balcony where they spent the majority of the afternoon and early evening discussing the basics. There had been only once or twice where Alice had pushed for a little more information that Rio had been willing to give, but when Rio made the line known, she backed off.

It seemed, more than anything, that Alice was just fascinated. In the way that Rio had been driven by her need for answers, Alice was driven by her need to observe and assess the complex dynamic that had been built between Rio and this woman who was literally picking men off like they were cherries on a tree and she had the world's largest step ladder.

She found the fascination in it that Rio had known she would, the one that Rio herself had that had started this entire thing to begin with.

By the time Rio realized she should be getting home to feed and check on Phin, she had divulged as much to Alice as she could without crossing any hard set boundaries. She did not divulge information about the phone, or that she had any way at all to contact Agatha -- who she had taken to calling Amelia, after all -- and that Rio was sure she would reach out when she was ready.

When Rio's Uber messaged that he was approaching, the two shared in an embrace by the front door and Rio bid her goodbyes to head home.

The car ride home had been painstakingly long, most likely because of the state she found herself in where she was sort-of drunk but not-quite-actually drunk. It was annoying more than anything else, but she did her best to set it to the back of her mind and wait for her body to tip one way or the other.

She had let herself into her apartment, stopping the moment the door shut behind her, stunned by how right she'd been with her earlier thought. She had been a little too buzzed to remember to grab the fabric spray and as a result, the first thing she smelled as soon as she was inside was a very stark and heady reminder of all that she had been up to the night before.

Phineas was perched, front paws tucked together, at the threshold from the living room into the dining area, his eyes pinched in a squint of scrutiny. Or, maybe he'd just woken up. Either way, Rio was painfully aware of something.

Even if she could find a way to eradicate the smell, there were still very vivid and present reminders of Agatha in quite a few spots located throughout that apartment.

Coming home had been enough on its own to kickstart that irrational lust in her brain and she knew that it was not going to go away if she chose to stay.

Heaving a sigh, Rio dug her phone out and dialed Alice's number, putting her on speaker.

"Hey, Rio! You alright?" came her brightly tipsy greeting, though she did sound genuinely concerned.

Rio cleared her throat and matched Phin's stare as he watched her expectantly, silently demanding a break from whatever the fuck it was she had done to that apartment.

"Yeah, no, I'm fine. But... Phin and I are going to come stay for a couple of days, if that's okay?" she half informed, half asked. Before she even finished the full question, Alice was laughing, clearly amused by the fact that Rio couldn't seem to stand the idea of keeping residence in her apartment after the tour of the spiritual plane she'd taken the night before.

"Pack a bag, get him on a lead, and get on over here. If you have any Spicy V8 left bring that, too. I'm out."

Rio's grin on her side of the line was bright, so vibrant that she knew it had to carry over the line.

"Thank you, Alice. You truly are the best friend a girl could ask for."

"Remember that the next time you're able to get your transport license. I need someone to cover my shifts every now and again."

Again, Rio was laughing, tickled by the bartering system Alice was choosing to use in that instant, one that never would have worked out even it if had made sense.

"Anything for you, Alice."

The thing of it was, Rio meant it. How many women could say with total honesty that they told their best friend they were fucking a serial killer and jail or loony bin were not immediate options?

Rio could, and that meant everything to her.

Keeping Up With Double Standards

There was a perk to choosing to stay at Alice's place: Rio didn't have to drive herself to work. She'd offered on a couple of instances, but the deeply paranoid part of Alice hadn't been willing to give up such control. She was probably the most defensive driver Rio had ever met in her life and more often than not, it came in handy.

Rio would let her have it and enjoy the ride each morning.

She would also fight every burning desire to rip that burner phone out of her messenger bag and check to see if Agatha had texted her. She'd been rather quiet since the weekend, but Rio found herself staring at the last message she had sent, just reading it over and over again until she had read it at least a thousand times. She did it in private, but the image had been burned into her mind's eyes for easy recall whenever she wanted, like on those car rides to work at 7am.

"Don't make plans this weekend. You're mine for 48 hours."

Those words brought with them a flaring of intense heat, one that came from a pained yearning deep within, right between Rio's legs.

Now that she had put forth the effort of committing it to memory? She had really fucked herself over. She could access it easier, sure, but she had also opened the door to the possibility that it was going to appear unsolicited times as well. One of those times had been the day when Rio had been at her desk -- presumably alone -- and had been signing off on a couple of release forms when she thought about it.

She thought about the phone in her desk and how she had turned up the volume just enough that she would hear if Agatha finally decided to message her. Thinking about the phone led to thinking about the message again, a dangerous and slippery slope. It had only been a couple of days and already, she... missed Agatha?

Or was it her hands Rio missed? Those collarbones? Those sharp and beautifully harmful teeth? Those soft and driven lips?

The softest worked-up sigh passed through her lips as her thighs squeezed together and shifted slightly.

"You okay?" Alice asked, causing Rio to plummet into a reality where she had not known Alice was even in the room.

"Christ! Yes! When did you get here?!" Rio snapped, though the blush on her cheeks was a true showing that she was embarrassed more than anything else.

It also caused Alice to smirk.

"You know how I always say I would have loved to have been friends with ferally horny teenager Rio?" she asked, though that smirk amplified into a bright and annoying grin that almost started to grate on Rio's nerves, but only because she knew what was coming. "I think I'm friends with her now and I gotta say, I love it."

Rio's lips dropped at the corners and her brow furrowed at such an accusation.

"I've been laid before, Alice," Rio returned bitterly as she sent in the last form. She leaned back in her chair, looking up at her friend with a disgruntled sense of being misperceived.

"You wouldn't know it with the way you've been acting the last few days," Alice teased back; Rio still wanted to guard against her, but what was the point? She'd already given away far too much in regards to whatever the fuck it was she was doing with Agatha, even if it wasn't much at all. The sex was the most prominent headline there and it had sort-of dominated the conversation. Rio wanted to keep it that way.

The less Alice knew about Agatha, the better.

It didn't feel all too difficult to maintain that air of mystery, but things had definitely taken a hard right turn that afternoon.

The two of them had eaten lunch in Rio's office; bread bowls with broccoli cheddar soup just before Alice departed for her first afternoon run. When she had come back, it was with a twenty-three year old male who it taken a tumble -- to put it gently -- off of a forty foot bridge and had met his untimely demise at the end.

Rio had set to work immediately, but Alice's lack of another run left her with little else to do that sit at Rio's desk, calling out crossword clues for Rio to guess at while she worked.

She had been nearing the end of the autopsy when the sound of a phone notification dinged from Rio's office. It hit her ears and as such, she assumed it was her actual phone and did not hesitate to make her request.

"Can you check that for me? Passcode's still the same!" she called over her shoulder.

There was a brief moment of silence, but then the sound of Alice's feet scuffing over the tile hit her ears. "Uh, there's nothing here?" Alice spoke, holding the phone up for Rio to see for herself, as if she might have thought Alice was lying.

Seeing it triggered a slightly panicked thought: the burner phone. It was also a thought that made her want to bite her lip and giggle like a kid with a crush. She was in the process of figuring out something to say when another notification sounded, causing her skin to blanch.

"You have another phone!?" Alice all but squealed as she rushed back into the office, leaving Rio's hands inside this dead man's chest while she wanted to plead and scream that Alice needed to just leave this alone. It was too late, though, Rio could already hear the scratching metal of the desk drawer being opened.

There was silence and then --

"Oh, what the FUCK!? Rio! Who the fuck is A and what the fuckkkk?!"

It wasn't the easiest feat in the world to embarrass Rio Vidal, because she had very low levels of shame, but right then Rio wanted to do nothing more than crawl into some hole and forget that this had ever happened to her. She didn't even know what the fuck Agatha could be sending her that could have Alice reacting in such a manner, but Rio needed to find out.

She was hasty as she finished stitching up the man on her table and tucked him away into storage so that she could rush back into the office. She was so quick as she blew into that office that Alice had never had a hope of seeing her coming.

"Give me that!" Rio cried as she snatched the phone right out of her grasp, not slowing in the least as she kept barreling around where Alice sat in the office chair. She didn't know what was on that phone, but she knew she wanted to be alone when she found out.

"Are you not gonna explain why you have two phones?!" Alice called after her, leaning far enough to watch Rio disappear out the doors toward the lobby bathroom that she almost fell out of the chair. Thankfully, she was smart enough to catch herself on the edge of the desk for.

Rio felt red and hot at such a a question; she wasn't ready to answer that and Alice had also just shouted it. No one would actually give a fuck, but Rio felt like she'd been put on the spot and she needed a moment to regain a modicum of composure. She needed to re-center, to remember that while Agatha was implementing the schedule and rules here, Rio still had some control over her own  life.

She made it to the bathroom and tucked herself in the farthest stall from the door, not actually having to use the restroom but needing the privacy regardless. She laid down three of the seat covers and sat, pants still all the way up. It would take away any temptation to be an irrationally irresponsible idiot at work.

When she opened the messages, she was so thankful to thirty-seconds ago Rio for being the executor of that decision.

The very bottom image -- the last one Agatha had sent -- was clearly her thighs, cutting off at the top just before reaching whatever panties she might have been wearing... or not wearing.

Rio scrolled up.

Above it, there was another photo. This one was very clearly of the upper part of Agatha's body. Her shoulders were visible enough that Rio could tell she wasn't wearing a shirt. She didn't need to see nipple to know that much. That wasn't the most riveting thing about that photo, however.

No, the part of the photo that made Rio wish her pants were around her ankles was Agatha's gorgeous, pale, bony, veiny, ring-adorned hand was secured around her throat. Her head was also tipped back and her chin was just out of frame by less than an inch. Rio could already picture it in her mind, the way Agatha's hair was flowing so freely down her back, the way it was likely tangled as a result of her day's effort.

Rio could untangle it for her.

Rio could untangle Agatha in her entirety, if Agatha would let her.

Okay, so maybe those were thoughts best saved for anywhere other than work. Alice's wasn't going to be a much better place to be having them, but at least she had a hand with her and could be quiet if she needed to be.

Rio kept scrolling upward, finding the very first photo Agatha had sent. Agatha had clearly laid the phone on a flat surface and set the timer so that she could take it; both of her hands were clearly in view, a display of her most powerful weapons.

Oh, did Rio know how powerful those weapons could be.

In reverse order, the photos had been hot , but understanding them in context had been even hotter. It was only fucking Wedsday and she still had two more days until Agatha might decide to make an appearance. Sure, she'd talked her shit and spit her game, but Rio was a firm believer in the follow-through. She thought that unless you truly meant something, you simply shouldn't say it.

So until Agatha showed up, Rio would tell herself she wouldn't get her hopes up. In reality, she was calculating the hours until Friday night each and every time she glanced at the clock.

Thursday morning, when Alice had rolled in per routine on her second delivery, there had been a strange look on her face. She was smiling , but there was a dangerous flickering of knowing in her eyes as she strode in, pushing the cart with a bounce in her step.

"Your girlfriend's in town, then?" Alice mused, glancing down to the body bag before her as she let herself into the autopsy room.

From her place at her desk, Rio's booted feet dropped from the corner and she was on them in an instant, a scowl finding her with ease. "She's not my girlfriend," Rio reminded her sharply. She knew Alice thought she was being funny, but Rio was strict about boundaries, and she and Agatha were absolutely not dating.

What Rio suddenly realized was that Alice was asking was because her second pick-up had been very indicative of Agatha's handiwork. This caused an entirely different form of umbrage to form in Rio: Agatha had sent her those fucking photos with a 'To get you through til the weekend xx' and then she'd just... gone out and killed someone without saying anything?

"And also, I'm not her babysitter. I don't get to tell her what to do, or when to do it. Nor does she run any schedule by me." The way Rio was stating each fact, she was doing it more to remind herself than she was to remind Alice, but Alice was taking it a little personally, judging by the look on her face as Rio moved to the foot of the cart and looked up at her.

For a moment, Rio needed to find herself and recognize who exactly she was.

She was a county employee. One who had developed a very strong obsession with a lethal and deadly woman. They had spent one insane night together, one that Rio could still physically feel the reminders of, even if they were beginning to ease.

She was also Alice's friend and this entire charade of being selective with information was new for her and it was putting a weight on the tie between them.

Rio was being a bad friend, full stop. She was letting this woman play games with her head and as a result, she was become a little snappier, a little more quick-tempered. Alice didn't deserve that out of her.

"Sorry, yeesh," Alice murmured as they moved the body to the table.

Drawing in a breath, Rio's hardened expression dissipated into something that conveyed a little more guilt.

"No, I'm sorry. I don't mean to be an asshole." Rio sighed softly and took the clipboard Alice had held out, looking at her expectantly. "I didn't know about this... I haven't talked to her since the messages yesterday. But, neither here nor there as I won't see her at least until tomorrow night, if not Saturday."

Alice didn't deserve any ire in this situation, as she was not a responsible party. If anything, she was the only outlet Rio had in regards to any of it, and even then, she had to be very, very careful about what she revealed. Rio wasn't a complete idiot; she knew she needed to find a way to break it to Agatha that Alice was at least aware of her presence in Rio's life, but she had no idea how Agatha would take to such news.

It was like she would be angry and as such, Rio had a rather good feeling that Agatha would end up splitting and leaving her high and dry, blaming herself for every inability she had to keep an entire secret. Lying had never really been her forte and it was so obvious why in the simple fact that Alice knew as much as she did, not matter how little it truly was.

"Well, it looks like she had her hands full last night. This one actually had five little tears in his shirt where the bruising usually is. Not sure what's up with that," Aliced informed her before she backed the cart out and moved it toward the entry way by the door.

"Do you have another run?" Rio called as she set to the work of removing the man from the bag and getting his clothing cut off of his body.

"I don't! Not yet! So I'm gonna eat this apple and pester you!" she called back from the office with a laugh. Rio lifted her head to see Alice through the blinds, assuming the position of boots on the desk corner that Rio had been keeping previously. She pulled the paper off the desk and began to read, giving Rio the permission to begin her work.

She was about halfway through the autopsy, the man -- Jed O'Leary, by name -- was cut open and half empty with Rio's scrubs were dirty with the result of her efforts. With her hands in his chest cavity, she heard something from the next room over.

It was Alice, she was asking Rio a question.

"Shit! You ordered lunch from Lou Mitchell's? What did I do to be so lucky?!"

This struck Rio as odd for one primary reason: She had not ordered them lunch from Lou Mitchell's. In fact, she had not even thought about what she was going to be doing for lunch that day. Before she could process and offer some kind of response, she heard Alice again.

"Hey, you can't-- !" she tried, but whatever was happening that she was trying to stop happened anyway. Rio lifted her head from her work to source where the sense of distress was coming from, but what greeted her caused her stomach to pit out and drop into her toes.

Agatha was standing in the doorway to her autopsy room, a bag from Lou Mitchell dangling from her fingertips. That wasn't what was most noticeable, though. The most painfully noticeable thing about Agatha right then wasn't her form fitting business attire, or the way her hair was artfully braided again. No, it was that vicious and impossibly smug grin that filled her face. It was predatory in a new fashion, one that said she was quite enjoying flexing this little... whatever it was between them.

Rio would be the first to admit that Agatha was displaying intense amount of moxie in those moments, but there was little Rio could do right then -- elbow deep in Agatha's latest victim -- to try and communicate all the things she needed to communicate to both of them. She needed Agatha to not say something stupid and she needed Alice to act like she had no idea who this woman was the moment she realized who this woman was.

The first qualification?

Out the fucking window in a heartbeat.

"I'm quite certain he looked better last night," Agatha mused right as Alice appeared in the wide doorway at her side.

Jesus fucking Christ. The following ten minutes were going to be the most painful and awkward of Rio's life and she had never wanted so badly for Alice's pager to sound as she did in those minutes.

"Hello," Rio returned, completely ignoring Agatha's comment to seem as nonplussed and collected as she could possibly manage. "It's very kind of you to stop by..." Rio's gaze dropped to the bag and swept back up. "With lunch. Were you planning on joining me?"

Both Agatha and Rio were very obviously ignoring the fact that Alice had completely morphed into a golden retriever at Agatha's side, looking between them like she could see the sparks flying back and forth. If Rio didn't know any better, she was certain she could hear Alice's tail as it thumped at the ground in excitement.

"I was, but if you have company..." Agatha returned, giving the most bodacious but critical side-eye to the woman next to her. "I would be happy to leave this for the two of you."

Immediately, Rio began to panic. She didn't want Agatha to leave. She wanted her to stay, to enjoy the forty-five minutes of lunch she might get with her before she had to wait at least another day until she could see her again. She was trying to be patient, trying to tame her desperation, but it wasn't proving to work out thus far.

Instead, Rio was standing there with her hands in a dead guy while having an inner war of wills for the ages.

Agatha was fucking bold. She had some serious brass tacks to be showing up in that building at all, much less to bring Rio lunch. Those walls were crawling with law enforcement and it seemed as though Agatha had not a care in the world for that very fact. She was a brave and gutsy woman, Rio would give her that much.

She was also at work. And having Agatha there would only serve as a distraction, but it was not one she wanted to sacrifice, especially not at the risk of Alice staying.

Thus, the battle.

She didn't want to give Alice the boot, but she wanted Agatha to stay.

By the grace of any and all Gods to ever exist, Alice seemed to pick up on the slight tension and vocalized a third option.

"When you're finished, I'll run and grab myself lunch so you guys can eat together," she offered brightly.

Inwardly Rio was fighting to keep Agatha's gaze locked with her own. She did not want Agatha to look to her side and see the absolutely devious and disastrous shit-eating grin that was canvassing Alice's entire face. She knew who she was standing next to, but Rio couldn't risk breaking her grip on Agatha's attention to deliver Alice a silent warning to keep her mouth shut without Agatha picking up on it.

"Well, with that settled," Rio voiced decisively, standing stalk still until she could resume her work, "I would like it if you stayed. I should be done within about ten or fifteen minutes."

Agatha's grin dimmed but her lips remained pulled tight in a vicious smile. She recognized easily that she had caught Rio in her snare, that she had gotten under her skin and she was eating it up. What Agatha likely did not realize was why.

Rio had said too much. Rio always said too much, and now she was going to have to put on the show of her life until she could shoo Alice out the door. Surely, a new conversation was going to be needed, but Rio was almost confident that over the course of the following ten minutes, nothing was going to happen that would make her regret not having it sooner.

She was also an entire fucking dumbass who should have known better,

The drawer clicked shut to the cooler and Rio began to strip out of her protective wear, shedding her face shield and gown to pace back into her office. The moment her foot crossed the threshold, she announced a fact that both women in that room would have known for different reasons.

"Same COD. Severed spinal cord. Another to add to the list, I suppose," Rio voiced, trying to be casual, trying to make it seem as though she were having the conversation explicitly with Alice.

And then Alice had to go and speak.

Her eyes swept from Rio to the other woman and her mouth was moving far faster than Rio ever could have to shut her the fuck up.

"So how do you do it?"

Oh God. OH GOD.

OHGODOHGODOHGOD.

NONONONONONONONONOOOO!!!!!!!!

Rio was practically screaming herself hoarse in her own head, wanting nothing more than to leap over the desk and tackle Alice to the ground. From there, Rio could have just smothered her and everything would have been fine.

While it seemed like a viable and reasonable option, Rio's attention snapped to the chair on the far wall that Agatha was perched in. Rio watched in real time as Agatha's skin darkened and then reddened, deeper and deeper until the paleness was nothing but angry crimson.

There was a total of maybe five seconds that Rio had to figure out what the fuck she was going to do. That was not enough time.

They passed in the blink of an eye and Agatha shot up to her feet, eyes white hot and angry as she snapped her head to look across the space between them at Rio, irate and downright pissed.

"Wait! Just give me a second -- !" Rio tried, but Agatha was lightning quick as she grabbed up the handles of the bag and whipped it forward, slinging it across the room until it hit the desk and dropped to the ground. The likely outcome there was that everything inside was ruined, just like everything inside Rio's body as Agatha snapped to the other direction and stalked toward the doors.

Rio started to follow, but she heard Agatha's angry question first.

"How the fuck do I get out of here?!" she shouted, but Rio did nothing to answer aside from pressing the button to open the doors. Agatha shot out of them like a pent up racehorse, but Rio was quick on her heels. She did not want to have this conversation within those walls, but she was also a little weary about following Agatha outside.

Outside, there would likely be no filter and Rio was not thrilled with the idea that Agatha might feel she had free reign to pick Rio apart, even if she deserved it.

The hit the afternoon air to an empty parking lot and Rio was still close, but not within arm's reach.

"Hey, can you just --" Rio tried, but Agatha cut her off.

"No! I'm not doing a god damn thing for you! Are you fucking kidding me? Have you ever kept a fucking secret in your life?!" Agatha shrieked, making a charge for her Lexus as it sat parked at the far end of the lot.

"I haven't told her anything more than she hasn't figured out herself! She knew, okay?" Rio attempted again, but Agatha simply waved her off. It was just a dismissal from the conversation they were having, but something deep in Rio's bones felt like it was more than that. She felt like this could very well be the reason Agatha might have been looking to run away. That was not something she had wanted out of this.

"Look -- Can we just... talk please?" Rio asked as she swung around the end of the car to see Agatha reaching for the handle.

"About what?!" Agatha bellowed back, spinning on Rio to stalk toward her until they were chest-to-chest. "About what a fucking idiot I am?! About how I thought for two stupid seconds that I might have found someone I could trust? And you're just walking around like a fucking talking head with all in the world to say?"

"No!" Rio argued back, but it felt pointless. Agatha was never actually going to hear her. "She knows the fake name, but nothing else. But... Fuck, it's not like I expected you to show up at my fucking job! "

"I was trying to be nice!" Agatha snapped back, her gaze so wickedly angry, burning so very hot with the rage she was obviously feeling. More than that, Rio saw something else: Agatha was panicking. She didn't realize that she was safe with the two of them, with Rio and Alice. "But clearly, not a great idea. Won't happen again."

"Oh, come on. Wait a minute!" Rio pressed as Agatha stepped away to let herself into the car. "Please don't go. Or... If you do... Come over tonight? So we can talk properly?" She was scrambling, trying to prevent Agatha from leaving. She was afraid. She was afraid that if she let Agatha drive out of that parking lot, she was never going to see her again.

"Toss the burner," Agatha clipped at her, jerking the door open.

She said it, and maybe she thought she meant it, but Rio saw something on her face that told her it was a demand made out of fear and fury. She was angry with a choice that Rio had made, one that effected them both and not just herself. She was angry that Rio didn't seem to be willing to apologize for that choice.

Rio wouldn't, either, at least not until Agatha was willing to listen to her reasoning.

When she slammed the car door and turned the car on, Rio realized that she might never get to have such a conversation.

The way Agatha peeled out of the parking, leaving a frustrated and pissed off Rio alone in her wake, Rio felt like it was probable that she was never going to see Agatha again.

She hadn't meant to fuck this all up; telling Alice had been rather innocent in regards to intentions and yet, Agatha was all the way pissed off. She probably felt panicked, felt like she had been outed and was at risk of being caught out. Rio wasn't going to let that happen; telling Alice had been a calculated decision, one that she'd found an ability to justify after the fact.

It was all she wanted, to just tell Agatha that much, to tell her that her secret was safe with them and even respected by them, but the parking lot of a County building was not the place to be having that conversation.

No, the only place to have such a conversation would have been behind closed doors.

Right then, Rio realized that Agatha was not going to grant her such a privilege. If anything, Agatha was making it apparent that Rio should just do her best to forget her existence altogether.

Maybe she was serious, maybe she was just angry. Whatever the case was, as Rio trudged back inside, the ominous feeling that had taken up residence within here was unlikely to vacate any time soon.

And she hated it.

I'm Only Alive When I Need to Be

Rio wasn't mad at Alice.

She knew even before Alice rushed to explain that it had been nothing more than a foot-in-mouth moment, a brief skip and time where Alice's curiosity had escaped her before she had a chance to cage it in. Rio had been guilty of the same, hadn't she? Didn't that explain how she had even crossed paths with Agatha in the first place?

Alice just wanted to know, the same way Rio had, only Rio wasn't going to tell her and had made that painfully clear that afternoon on the balcony. It wasn't Rio's place and she owed Agatha that respect.

At the same time that Rio wasn't made at Alice, she wasn't really mad at Agatha, either.

How could she be? Agatha had felt trapped and cornered, like she was a step closer to losing her hold on all that she held dear. Even though she had never said it in so many words, Rio knew that this process for Agatha, this ability to enact justice beyond the walls of the law, was Agatha's holy grail. It was something that made her feel like she was doing the world a favor, a power that she got to wield and use to cull the world of all she deemed unnecessary.

There was only one person to be mad at in all of this, really.

Rio was angry with herself.

Did she still think it was rather innocuous that Alice knew what little bit she did? Of course. Alice wasn't going to sell Agatha out the first chance she got. She wouldn't do that because she knew in some way, it would sell Rio out too, even if she did not know to what extent. Despite her poor choices and mindless light stalking, Alice knew who Rio was as a person; she was a good person, and if she saw something in this woman? It had to be for a reason.

That evening, Rio had clocked out from work and rode quietly back to Alice's in the passenger's seat. They had already said most of what there was to say back in the morgue office and as such, Rio was taking the quiet time to decide what it was she was going to do.

By the time they'd pulled into Alice's driveway, she'd made her decision.

"I'm gonna pack up and grab Phin and go home," Rio stated, but she realized that there needed to be an explanation. She turned to Alice quickly who was well on her way to apologizing again. "It's not that I'm upset or angry with you. I just... think it would be better if I got out of your hair for a little bit."

"Rio..." Alice attempted, but just looking at her, Rio could tell that Alice knew she was right.

"Plus, if she's put a tracker on me at all, would be safer if I was alone," Rio attempted to joke, but it fell flat between them.

"You don't have to go," Alice tried to reason. She probably thought it was pulling away, that their friendship was going to be under some strain, but that wasn't the case at all.

"I know. But I want you to have your space back. I promise, we're fine. But... I need to clean my apartment and can't keep putting it off." Now that much was absolutely true. That apartment was undoubtedly rank as fuck and it needed tending to. The longer she put it off, the worse it was going to get.

Alice heaved a light sigh, glancing out the windshield for a moment before she turned back to Rio. "Okay but... Please remember that my door is always open to you."

Rio knew she meant it. Rio knew that deep down, Alice cared about her and wanted to see her happy. She had never meant to cause any kind of issue or give Rio any unneeded grief, but it had happened anyway.

"I know. And I thank you for that. So how about before I go, I'll buy us dinner?" she posed, as if it were some sort of consolation for her deciding to abruptly pack up and essentially run away with her tail tucked between her legs.

"Alright deal," Alice conceded, a gentle smile filling her face. It almost touched her eyes, but Rio could tell she still gelt guilty.

Rio spent the following hour doing all she could to make Alice understand that everything was fine, that Rio was not really upset with her, and that they would resume their typical shenanigans over the weekend now that her days had opened up exponentially. It wasn't a fact she was all too thrilled about, but Rio had a feeling that if she tried to text Agatha from the burner, it wouldn't lead her anywhere good.

Agatha had been very clear about what Rio should do with that phone and each time Rio dared listen to her tone in her head during the replay, it made her stomach knot worse than the time before it.

So they'd eaten their sushi and Rio had collected her things, including Phin, and headed home. She made a stop on the way at the local Home Depot; something akin to industrial strength cleaner was going to be her only hope for cleaning the stains in her life --not just her furniture -- Agatha had left. It wasn't even about the chair anymore, it was trying to find a way to remove any trace of her if Rio hoped to keep living there.

It was stupid; she shouldn't have cared. She should have simply stated that her life would be better off without the presence of a serial killer in it.

That was a fucking lie and she knew it.

Agatha provided her a challenge, something to actually pick apart and understand. Agatha showed Rio what it was like to think so critically and still not be able to find the right answers. It was the most beautiful form of frustration, mostly because the answers were there, but it required a keenly sharp mind to even start to understand what they could possibly be.

Agatha was different. There had never been any question about that, but it was why Rio felt so drawn to her. Not only was she deadly, but it was only in the most intelligent fashion. She had committed herself to the idea of this crusade, taken the time to mentally develop a device that had kept Rio perplexed for weeks, and moved around like a ghost in the night.

Her beauty offered a helping hand, but it was her charm that truly did the trick.

Even as Rio sprayed and scrubbed and sprayed and scrubbed, she was only removing the physical traces that Agatha had left behind, not the images embedded in her brain. She could still picture, with crystal clarity, as Agatha had said poised in that damn dining chair in the middle of her living room, hand moving easily around her mouth and chin in her observation.

She had obviously been beholding something she quite liked. That had been a good feeling, to be looked at, appraised, watched by Agatha like that.

An angry grunt passed through Rio's lips as she scrubbed hard at the arm of the chair; it wasn't getting moved by only her any time soon and she wasn't ready to ask Alice for that kind of help. The only option was to try with all her might to baptize it with as much Kaboom! as she could possibly manage.

Twenty minutes into her effort, Rio had thrown the bottle of cleaner across the room and slumped against the couch to pull out her phone and place an Amazon order for a chair cover. It was fabric, of course, as she wasn't ninety and didn't wish to have her furniture covered in plastic.

But then again...

No! That chair was not getting defiled ever again. She would get rid of it when the opportunity presented itself, but for now, it had to stay.

And it would forever be a memory of the time Rio rode that stupid fucking strap while Agatha rutted herself to climax right in front of her.

Agatha might have made the choice to walk away, to leave, but the truth for Rio was that the idea of her was not going anywhere any time soon. There was no way to get her out.

Stupidly, Rio had hoped she might.

She knew it was a long shot, and she knew even more that she didn't really deserve it. Rio had just been hoping that she could have been the one to tell Agatha, that she could have been the one to explain the situation.

Alice wasn't an idiot and Rio let out just the tiniest sliver of too much information. Those two things together had been an unfortunate combination, but even worse when applied in the wrong setting.

Rio tapped her pen to her lips, visualizing the letters in the little blocks they should belong to. "You know what? I think you're right!"

Rio's weekend was... fun?

That wasn't really the word for it. She had a good time; she and Alice had more or less agreed on a bar crawl on Saturday, starting and noon and only ending when Alice was doubled over behind Roscoe's at 11pm heaving her guts out.

By the grace of some God, Rio had managed to load her into the back of a cab that took them to Rio's apartment which, with the windows having been open most of the day, actually smelled like the strawberry and jasmine wax burner she'd turned on and forgot about before they'd set out on their adventure.

Sunday had been a day filled with nothing but recovery from the day before.  They'd laid around on the couch and ate burgers they had delivered to the apartment. They drank the remaining beers that had been in Rio's fridge for a kick of hair of the dog and it had seemed to level them out a little more. After a handful of ibuprofen each, they'd both been right as rain.

It didn't encourage them to do anything other than lay around watching television while they scrolled through their phones, showing each other stupid memes and videos when they would come across them.

Maybe they were in their thirties and should have shown a little more maturity, but sometimes life just called for a wild weekend.

It had helped quite a bit that they hadn't talked about Agatha once.

It didn't stop Rio from thinking about her entirely, but it was more of a fleeting thought every now and again than it was something that consumed her every waking moment. Even having Alice at the apartment made it a little easier to stay distracted over fixated.

She had been laying on the couch, Phineas and all twenty-two pounds of his thickness were pooled on her stomach and chest, his happy purrs getting louder and louder the longer she scratched at his ears. He looked so happy and content there that it had been easy enough to pay attention to, but the moment his head dropped and he fell asleep, Rio found her gaze wandering.

By Monday morning, that was out the window.

Rio had laid on her side for several long moments after her alarm had gone off, just staring at the nightstand. She shouldn't open the drawer. She shouldn't pull out the phone. Most importantly, she should not check the text messages.

She did all three of those things in rapid succession and was thoroughly disappointed when she found what she knew had been awaiting her: nothing.

How was that supposed to work? How was Rio supposed to just navigate away from the most fascinating human being she had ever crossed paths with? How the fuck was she supposed to forget about the woman who was not only beautiful and cunning, but could fuck like that?

Rio was quite certain that she'd never had such an experience with another woman and it was almost impossible to scrub from her memory.

Did they make a pill that could be Kaboom for her damn brain?

They did, it was called cyanide.

It just so happened that an unfortunate side effect was death.

Rio would simply live with the memories long enough until they finally faded away. She wasn't sure how long it would take, but time eventually grabbed at all things and buried them deep enough that they might only be found with intentional and purposeful thought.

Work had been... work. There had been nothing exciting, nothing challenging. Two OD's, one suicide by firearm, an elderly man who had suffered a heart attack, and a teenager that had quickly faced the repercussions of distracted driving.

Not one of them had a severed spinal cord but looked the picture of living health.

None of them had been taken from the world by a swift and clean jerk of their head.

No one had faced Agatha's wrath the night before.

All she wanted was the chance to explain, for Agatha to just take the time to hear her out. Agatha wasn't the type. Agatha hadn't wanted it. She hadn't wanted to hear why Rio had put her at risk. She didn't want her hear Rio make excuses and not take accountability.

But, if Rio was good at anything, it was accepting responsibility when she fucked up, intentional or not.

She had made a mistake. If there was anything in the world to be done to amend for that, she would have done it. She would have taken any chance thrust at her feet, even if it meant bending the knee to Agatha and whatever it was she wanted.

She needed to get used to the idea that there was never going to be an incoming message. Nothing felt challenging or perplexing. Nothing made her feel excited about the fact that she was at work. But it was when Agatha was in the picture.

Agatha had left. Packed up. Vacated. Disappeared.

She was likely onto the next highly populated city that she could disappear within to skulk around and claim an entirely new subset of victims.

It meant that Chicago was no longer her home. All because Rio had opened her big mouth.

While she put everything away, she turned on her speaker and threw on some random mix of songs that had no true theme or purpose, simply a compilation that Spotify thought she would enjoy.

Three songs in, it wasn't wrong.

She was enjoying herself as she shimmied around her kitchen, stowing things and then preparing to start her dinner for the evening of tostadas with black beans, corn, avocado and her own specially crafted and blended salsa.

The music filled her ears, every beat reinvigorating her more than the one before it. Because it was all that filled her ears, she could hear little else.

Like the perpetual ringing of inbound calls and incessant dings of incoming messages to the burner phone that was shoved in the back of her nightstand drawer.

Rio was content for what felt like the first time a week. It was also the first time in a week that she had been able to stop thinking about Agatha long enough to accomplish something with purpose. It felt good. Her life was slowly getting back to normal, one boring day at a time.

One of the EMTs, Holly, was dealing with a man who was heavily intoxicated. In speaking with him, he tells her that he's chosen to drink so much because it was the anniversary of his daughter's death.

Holly's dialogue over it had always intrigued her; it was a lengthy monologue about human connection, about the desire to just be seen. It was an echoing of things that had passed through Rio's mind a time or two in her life, more frequently since she had met Agatha.

At home, surprisingly, it was easier. It wasn't going to happen. That was the reality now. There was no more pining, no more hoping, no more wishing. Agatha existing in Rio's world as any more than a figment of her imagination was an impossibility.

Agatha was gone, period.

Gross.

Rio couldn't miss Agatha. Agatha wasn't hers to miss. Never had been, never would be.

But Rio couldn't help but wish she would just... show up.

Phineas leapt off of her stomach, nearly ripping up the carpet in an attempt to take off toward her bedroom and his massive cat cave that was tucked inside the closet. Whatever the intrusion on their night was -- at nearly eleven -- he wanted absolutely nothing to do with it.

No, they weren't just knocking. They were fucking pounding.

Whoever it was, they were not trying to make themselves known in any way and for that very reason, Rio considered the possibility that she needed to call the police. Whoever it was, they could be angry. They could try to hurt her.

And then, the pounding stopped.

A voice came through the door.

"Rio, open the fucking door. Please!"

Holy shit.

HOLY SHIT.

That sounded almost exactly like Agatha.

"Or at least answer the fucking burner! I know you didn't throw it away!"

There, looking pristine, if not a little drunk, stood Agatha, clad in an impossibly beautiful silver evening gown with a portion of her hair pinned back while the rest of it flowed down her back and over her shoulders, passing the top hem of the dress.

"Oh! Rio!" she chirped, snapping into a completely horizontal position, though it was only a couple of inches off from where she had been.

"Hi, Agatha... I just --"

She just what? Woke up? Wanted to say she was sorry? Wanted to grovel for the mistakes she had made? Wanted to drag Agatha in and peel her out of that dress?
