Agatha had been on the prowl the night before, apparently as she had been texting Rio at ten the night before. Had she been sitting next to this stupid man who thought he could actually gain the interest of someone like Agatha? Had she already slipped the Rohypnol in his beer and taken a moment to shoot a message over to Rio that they had weekend plans? Maybe she had been sitting in the front seat of her car, this idiot slumped and passed out in the passenger's seat, thinking about how now that her hunger was satiated in that regard, it was her turn to get her fill of Rio.

Rio didn't know if any of it was reality, nor did she care. All she cared about was finishing the rest of her shift and getting home to set about her weekend.

She'd managed to get through three additional autopsies that afternoon, still buzzing from the one fresh off of lunch. Agatha had killed again. She was staying. For now. For the weekend. The weekend she wanted to spend with Rio.

Rio didn't know where they were going or what it was that Agatha had planned, but she didn't care. The most pertinent thing about the invitation was solely that Agatha wanted to spend time with her, wanted to be around her. Rio didn't care where they went, so long as she got more insane sex and pillow talk about weird shit like taxidermy.

Being with Agatha in that capacity, laying next to her and talking about the dark shit no one really liked to have conversations about, it was a weirdly liberating feeling in that Rio had never felt more like herself before in the presence of someone else.

Was she going to go out and start her own murderous crusade? Of course not.

Would she defend Agatha's right to keep to her own? Absolutely.

It had taken Rio little time to get home, an eager Phineas greeting her when she strode in and shut the door behind her. Squatting down, the gave him the rougher pets he often liked and grinned as he purred in response.  Her head tilted as she kept at it, his large head forcefully rubbing against her palm in the places he wanted her to pay attention to.

"I know you're not fond of travelling, but we're going on a little trip for the weekend. So... just prepar yourself," she murmured at him, giving him one last scratch between the ears before she stood and set to packing things for the weekend.

After grabbing clothes (including Agatha's dress that had been left behind), toiletries, cat food, cat treats, and Phin's travel water and food bowls, she was certain there was nothing left behind. When the burner sounded from where she had stowed it in her back pocket, she knew that Agatha had likely arrived. The text confirmed as much.

"In the parking garage. Take your time."

Rio grinned and shot back a quick response.

"Getting Phin dressed now. Be out in a minute."

It took her a little longer than a minute, but after getting Phineas suited up in his harness, she let him walk her out of the apartment and to the elevator, her overstuffed backpack secure on her back. When they reached the doors that opened into the garage, she leaned down to scoop him up, gathering him in her arms so she could venture outside.

To the right, there was a black Escalade with tinted windows sitting, waiting with the tail lights on in the dark garage. Rio's gaze swept the rest of the garage, looking for any sign of Agatha, but found none.

She had been in the process of pulling out the burner so that she could ask Agatha where she was when she heard a window on the Escalade roll down.

From inside, a voice called out.

"Ride's over here, princess. You just gonna stand there and look pretty?"

That was Agatha's voice. And the back passenger's side window was rolled down.

With uncertainty steeling over her nerves for some reason she did not understand, Rio made her way to the open window, peering inside to see Agatha, a bright and delightedly wicked grin on her face. Rio's gaze flickered to the driver's seat as it was occupied by a large, burly man with a head of thick dark hair that was tied in a neat bun near the back of his head.

"Oh, that's Francisco. He's my driver," Agatha told her, waving a hand toward him in introduction. He lifted a hand off the wheel without turning around, offering a light greeting.

"Evening, miss."

Rio's attention snapped back to Agatha, confused. "You have a driver?"

"Doubles as personal security, too, but yes."

At this, Rio's eyes narrowed, shooting a threatening glance through the window. Agatha did not need personal security. In no reality did Agatha need anyone to protect her.

"So, are you going to stand out there and interrogate me on my method of transportation or are you going to get in so that we can set about our weekend?"

Phineas was starting to squirm in her hold, wanting to be put down, so Rio simply gave a nod that encouraged Agatha to lean over and open the door. Once everything was tucked inside, Rio slid in as well and shut the door behind her, settling into the seat as Phineas took up the space between them.

"So... Where are we going?" Agatha asked her as Francisco began to drive.

Agatha was looking out the window when Rio asked the question, but her head turned just enough that she was still not looking directly at Rio, but could still see her when she delivered her answer. It was an answer Rio didn't understand, one that she wanted to request elaboration on, but the way Agatha said it felt so... sure, that she just let it be, if only for a few minutes.

"Home."

Instead of Chasing Doves, We Could Fake Some Love

Home?

Like... Chicago home... Or... Iowa home where surely too many answers were buried and hidden?

She had a driver.

He was not about to drive them to fucking Iowa.

"Home, huh?" Rio asked quietly. She knew there were other ears listening, that she had to be coded and soft-spoken. It was a dangerous question to be asking, but she was framing it as innocuous, innocent, just a way to understand the circumstances she had found herself in. The circumstances where this woman she had been convinced was so solitary and withdrawn was being chauffeured around the city with personal security.

Agatha was a fucking serial killer. What kind of life was she living that this was a daily appearance for her? What did she do outside of the only way Rio had come to know her? She was obviously important and obviously... rich.

That was something Rio had gleaned already, but right then as Agatha sat next to her in that dashing heather grey suit, Rio found her mind running away from her.

She had so many new questions, so many things that she had never dared to consider before. Agatha had been reluctant to give up pieces of herself and now Rio understood a little better why that was. It was because whatever side of herself she presented to the public, it was someone who had some accredited authority to her name.

Her fake name.

Her fake name that she had made up to hide who she truly was.

But Rio knew.

Rio knew who Agatha truly was, and she was beginning to understand that she might have been the only person in the world who did.

She might have been the one person on the face of the earth that had uncovered the truth and lived to tell the tale. But how? How did Agatha move about the world wearing such a well-crafted disguise when murder was her hobby? How was she so composed, so put together that not a single person in the world would have had any inkling that she was deadly?

Rio had thought Agatha to be interesting enough as it was before, even if it was in a morbidly obsessive way. Right then, Rio's interest was at an all time high. She had thought that she'd been putting the pieces in the right places, and that she had assembled enough to see a true picture of Agatha, but that wasn't the case.

Maybe it was. Maybe Rio could see the picture of Agatha.

It was the picture of Amelia that was tripping her up and causing her to stumble.

Agatha was a complex human being, that much Rio already knew. But these different facets to her were bringing Rio right to the understanding that there was still so much more of her to comprehend.

She had started to spin and weave those thoughts, but Agatha answered her question.

"Yes. Home," Agatha confirmed with a nod of her head, though she still was not looking at Rio.

"And where might 'home' be?" Rio pushed again, her volume still dropped and a tender care to her tone, a showing that she was not trying to press for the sake of pressing, she was simply curious.

"Water Tower Place," Agatha answered easily, as if that wouldn't have had any impact.

Rio choked. On her own spit, no less.

"You're full of shit," she accused, her head jerking to the left to look over at Agatha, who had taken to petting gently between Phin's ears, even if she wasn't looking at him.

"Okay, fine," Agatha returned, shrugging her shoulders. "Don't believe me. Maybe you'll get there on the elevator ride. It's seventy two floors, so should give you enough time for it to sink in."

It almost sounded like a joke, like a taunt that Agatha was throwing her way that they could laugh about when they showed up to some tiny brownstone tucked away in some corner of the city. However, there was something about the half of an expression that Rio could see in the dim passing streetlights that told her Agatha was actually being truthful.

Water Tower Place was... Well, it was something . But it also fell in line with the fact that they were sitting in the middle row of seats in a 2025 Cadillac Escalade while being driven around by a man that likely weighed twice as much as Rio did.

What the fuck did Agatha do for work that she could afford a condo in Water Tower Place? That was where the greats had lived, where celebrities and other people of elevated reputations who resided and worked in Chicago took up residence. Rio wasn't sure that she actually bought it, but Agatha was wearing her conviction like a suit of armor, honesty nearly bleeding from her despite being so impossibly stoic.

Rio realized what was happening.

They had company. They were in the presence of someone who could hear the discussion being had, and as such, Rio needed to cater to the intrusion. She needed to remind herself that the Agatha that Rio knew? No one knew that Agatha aside from herself. No one knew who she really was.

This Agatha -- or, rather, this Amelia -- was someone worthy of respect, someone important. So how did Rio not know about her? How had she never heard a thing about this wealthy and pragmatic woman who rode around Chicago in her man-bun drawn carriage? She wasn't in showbusiness, didn't hold galas in her own name. She didn't front charities or run organizations.

So who the fuck was she?

Who the fuck was Agatha, in all of her iterations?

Maybe Rio would never know. Maybe she would never be given that kind of access, because for all she knew? For all Rio knew, there were tens of them, if not more. Agatha had been moving in the beginning, so how had she wound up in Chicago? How had she established this kind of reputation for herself?

Rio's list of questions seemed to be perpetually growing, getting longer and longer the more time she spent with Agatha.

"Is..." Rio started, but Agatha's gaze remained cast out the window. "Is that the only plan for weekend?"

It was one question, but there were two in there if Agatha was listening hard enough.

a) Are we actually doing something together?
and
b) Is your plan to lock us up in your ivory tower and use me like some kind of sex slave?

Any answer to either question would have suited Rio just fine, but her curiosity was evident; Agatha had clearly formed some sort of a plan, but Rio wanted to know to what extent. What even could this be called, really?

They were not dating. Period. End of sentence.

It wasn't because Rio didn't want to, but rather because she knew that Agatha was not the kind of woman who dated or did relationships. If Rio's inclination was right, Agatha had never even really spent honest time with someone she actually found herself interested in. Maybe it was because she had never been interested in someone enough to want to commit that amount of time to...

Ah, Rio realized, that was what this was.

Agatha was interested, and she was making time for them to spend together. But in what capacity? The majority of the time they had spent together up to that point, Agatha had been either angry or horny. She'd either been yelling and irate about Rio's overstepping or fucking her brains out (and choking her when she felt like it, which was always a plus) and so, the only true moments of connection between them had been Agatha's gift of the burner, Rio's apology, and the very strange -- and probably unsettling to anyone else -- and rather deep pillow talk they had shared Wednesday night.

That had been enough?

Agatha had told her she'd been heard, but to that extent?

"You're in the car now, so I suppose you will just have to commit to waiting so that you can find out," Agatha answered. It was smooth, it was rich, and there was just enough inflection there that it answered for her since she would not choose words to do it for her.

Whatever it was, whatever they did, it was calculated, it was considered.

And that made Rio feel... Things? Special? Appreciated? Like she was going to inevitably read into it too much?

It was clear to her, with that answer from Agatha that they were not going to speak about anything of note in that car and while it was fine, Rio couldn't help but feel rather detached from the woman across the bench seat. So she did the only thing she could: she reached between them and began to pet Phin as well, her fingers just barely brushing against Agatha's as a reminder that she was right there, no matter the space between them.

Only a few minutes later, the Escalade was rolling to a stop... Right in front of the residential entrance to Water Tower Place.

Agatha had been telling the truth. She really did live in a seventy-eight floor condo-filled high rise in the heart of Chicago. And if she'd also been telling the truth about the elevator ride, her own home was over seventy floors up.

Rio reached down for her bag and the other supplies she had brought along, but when she grabbed for the lead, it moved too quickly. It took only a moment to register, but Rio suddenly understood what had happened even before she lifted her gaze to see Agatha coaxing Phineas to hop down out of the car so they could stroll lazily into the building together.

Feeling like the third wheel, Rio threw her sack over her shoulder and bustled around the back of the car to try and catch up to the two of them. How the fuck had Agatha just... shown up and commandeered Rio's entire existence in mere minutes? She had Phineas following her like she was waving a giant fish in front of his face, bewitched by her.

And there was Rio, right behind them both, doing the exact same thing.

She was quiet, observant, just pinning every point worthy of remembering that she could think of, trying to lock everything away from the over-the-top and too-large lobby to just how stupidly fucking nice the elevators were. In that building, the wealth accumulated there had to total into the billions and it showed through the interior alone.

Phineas was losing his entire mind. He was pacing the elevator as they rode up, yowling so loud that trying to converse over him felt rather pointless. Rio had attempted it once, but Agatha had just tapped her ear, making a face with raised brows that stated she could not understand. The moment the door opened, Phin might as well have been a dog with the way he bolted forward, wanting out of the new and unfriendly enclosed space.

He had no clue where he was going, but he didn't care. When Rio followed, she realized that it wasn't just an elevator that took them to the floor Agatha lived on. It took them directly to her apartment, which Rio should have guessed by the keycard she had swiped when they had entered.

The immediate area outside of the doors was a foyer in ways, but was open and expansive. Directly across from her was a wall filled with nothing but windows that stretched from the floor all the way up to the ceiling. The furniture was of a luxury quality and there was far too much of it for just one person, but Rio already knew that Agatha had to live alone.

"Jesus fucking Christ, Agatha," Rio breathed, still clutching at the strap of her backpack as she knelt down to unlace her boots so she could take them off. Once righted, Rio's eyes scanned the available area again, still filled with absolute wonder that this was... it. This was Agatha's dwelling, the place she could fully be herself with no judgement.

It was massive and Rio was certain that she had only seen a fraction of it.

"Did you buy this from Bill Gates?" Rio cracked, watching the way Agatha was just... following Phin around with the lead dangling from her fingers as he sniffed around and gauged the new space.

"Oprah, actually," Agatha called back over her shoulder. The answer immediately caused Rio to laugh. It was loud, a full-bellied laugh that showed just how funny she thought the joke to be. But Agatha did not look back and she did not laugh.

"Shut up," Rio shot back, disbelieving as she made her approach to land at Agatha's side, watching Phin the longer he inspected anything he came into contact with. "You did not."

"Oh, but I did," Agatha responded coolly, tone steady. "Two million over asking, actually. But only because it was the cost of her leaving it fully furnished."  Agatha finally knelt down, gingerly pulling Phineas to her so that she could remove his harness. He didn't fight her, mostly because he knew it meant freedom. From her knees, Agatha's head tipped and she donned a bright but cunning grin. "Joke's on her, though. I sold everything for eight million and bought my own. Turns out, people are really willing to pay up when they see 'As Used By Oprah!' in the item description."

"You're being serious," Rio deduced, though the look on her face as she stared down at the beaming Agatha was certainly still filled with traces of incredulity.

"Of course I am. Why would I lie?" she asked, standing again. She glanced over her shoulder for just a second before meeting Rio's inquisitively dark stare. "Would you like a tour?"

Rio wanted to ask her if it was the entire floor, even if that was a stupid question. Then again, how stupid of a question was it when the elevator was her front fucking door? Instead, she decided she could probably get such an answer by telling Agatha yes.

So she nodded. "That would be nice."

Agatha held out a hand, but it was one that offered direction, one that indicated that Rio should follow her, and so she did. "This is the living area, obviously, " Agatha informed her, waving toward the large sectional, the actual couch, and the two large armchairs. There were two coffee tables as well as several end tables. Even a faux stone fireplace was fitted into the wall, even if it was only for show. It added to the elegance of the space, elevated it just that much more.

"Dining room," she voiced as they walked over to the open space that was occupied by a table that sat ten, made out of what looked to be some kind of dark wood... Rosewood maybe? It was massive .

"Your table's a lot bigger than mine," Rio mused with a soft chuckle. She was a step behind Agatha and could not see her face, but she knew she rolled her eyes. Rio gave a light swat to the small of her back. "Oh, come on. You can't tell me you don't have your own fantasies."

At this, Agatha halted in place so suddenly that Rio accidentally bumped into her. She recoiled instantly, stepping back with an apology on her face as Agatha turned to face her. Rio hadn't meant to offend her, but when the look Agatha was wearing finally registered, Rio realized that wasn't what was happening.

Agatha was wearing a familiar rapacious expression that made her look so threateningly beautiful and the gleam in her eyes was nothing short of vulturine.

"Oh, Rio," she admonished, pausing only to lick her lips. "I have my fantasies. And none of them are as boring as a dining room table."

Before giving Agatha's words a proper run-through, Rio caught the tail end only and pouted, her lip folding outward. She was trying to be offended, trying to act like Agatha had scorned her by calling her apartment boring in a roundabout way, but with that downright shit-stirring sparkle in her crystal blue eyes, how could she?

And then she played through the entire sentence again in her mind.

Like a lightbulb had gone off of her head, sparked only by the electric jolt she got per understanding, Rio brightened up, a deep grin of her own forming. "Share with the class?" she prodded, but Agatha didn't bite.

"Kitchen is over here. Anything not already out is likely stowed under in cabinets, such as toaster, kettle, blender."

Agatha was rattling these things off like it would be helpful to Rio, like she might need any of those appliances in her two day stay there.

"Groceries were delivered this afternoon, so help yourself." Agatha was being informative, but she was also still moving and expecting Rio to follow her. She was like a cloud, rolling over the gorgeous hardwood floors, clearly the most comfortable Rio had ever seen her within the walls of her own sanctuary.

Rio was trying to take it all in at once, trying to absorb it all, but she already knew it was going to take some time. That thought only solidified itself when Agatha opened the first door on the right that was on the far side of the dining area. When she flipped the light on, Rio was not sure what she had been expecting, but it was not what she saw.

In the windowless room was a good handful of old paintings stacked against a wall, all dingy and a bit dark from what Rio could see of them. There were a couple of high wooden tables that were covered in different metal cylinders with different warning labels on them, as well as empty containers that were likely used to mix product.

In the middle of the room was a stool that was placed before an easel. On it, there was a landscape of a painting, one that was about sixty percent old and forty percent... rejuvenated.

"Is that a Niemann? The Wight of Edmund?" Rio asked curiously before Agatha could explain the purpose of the room that was already apparent.

"You know art?" Agatha asked, sounding surprised.

"Not much," Rio answered with a shrug. "But enough about English art from a college friend to know what that is. And what you're doing with it." She stopped for a moment, surveying the room before she looked back to Agatha. She could have tried to hide her perplexed amusement, but she didn't. "You're full of surprises. Next thing I know, you're going to tell me it's your personal mission to put a man on the moon."

When Agatha snorted, Rio hadn't been expecting it and cut back to her suddenly to verify that she was okay and was not choking. She was grinning again.

"You good?" Rio offered, but Agatha simply dismissed her with ease.

"Anyway," she segued back to their purpose for being there, "if you cannot find me, I will like be here. It's a way to keep my skills sharp and usually can make a pretty penny off of some finds."

"You afford this place on turned around art?" Rio asked her, disbelieving.

"I didn't say that was my only way to make money," Agatha corrected her, striding back toward the doorway as she flipped the light back off. "Just one of them."

Rio backed out into the hallway so that Agatha could shut the door, turning to her right to venture further down the hall. She opened the next door, revealing a spare bedroom but did not turn on the light. "There's an ensuite, but it's more just inclusive of the tour than anything you should need. But here..." She shut the door again and crossed the hall to the door on the left; Rio had noted that there were not other doors on the left, but she thought nothing of it. "Here's the true beauty."

Rio had been expecting her bedroom.

What Rio had not been expecting was a wide and spacious room that held minimal furniture -- a couple of lounge chairs and an oversized ottoman that could likely fit three people comfortably -- and had a fucking pool in it. It wasn't large, but it was of a decent enough size to be startling.

"This cannot be fucking real," Rio muttered, shaking her head. "What the fuck do you mean you have a pool in your condo?!"

"In my defense," Agatha voiced, flipping on the majority of the lighting, "it came with the condo. This was not my doing. Oprah, remember?"

Okay, so she had a fair point, but still. Who the fuck had a condo with a damn pool in it?! Agatha Harkness -- shit, Amelia Cohen -- did. Rio was almost compelled to ask her again what she did for work, but it felt useless at that point. Agatha would tell her when she was ready.

"I still think I'm going to wake up and realize this was a fucking fever dream," Rio offered in response, and she meant it. There was no way that she had been spending the last months thinking that Agatha went home to some tiny little townhome or brownstone that blended in and made her look like everyone else.

Rio did not expect her to be high up in her castle with her massive condo that had its small pool and room full of ancient and pricey art.

Agatha had floored Rio, truly.

None of it had come close to any theories that she had spent months forming and it was more than a little jarring.

Agatha was more than Rio had been giving her credit for, and there was a lot of it being given there. She had just been applying it to the wrong charges.

Agatha did not hide. She did not sulk in the shadows and try to disguise this cover identity. No, she had very clearly gained status and notoriety for choices she had made in her life. She had become someone to the world, Rio just had yet to figure out how. By day, Agatha had carefully crafted this persona, one that suited her needs.

And then, at night, she went out to bars in fancy dresses, drugged men, and then broke their necks in a barn forty minutes outside of the city.

Right, Rio remembered, she was still a murderer.

A murderer with a cushy condo and more money than she clearly knew what to do with.

"The bed's kinda high so make sure you don't roll out," Agatha teased back, leading Rio out of the pool room to shut the door. "Please, by the way," Agatha added, indicating the door with two fingers, "use at your leisure."

"But I didn't --" Rio started before she caught herself, even before Agatha grinned at her again. "No one's going to see me naked if I skinny dip, huh?"

"Well, I wouldn't say no one ," Agatha informed her, those little embers beginning to burn in her gaze.

"Noted," Rio fired back quickly with a lively grin, one that Agatha almost missed because she was moving on to continue the tour. Once more, Rio was hot on her heels, interested to see what other surprises were held within that condo.

They passed through the main area of the dwelling again to the other side, one with a much shorter hallway. There was a bathroom, a linen closet, and at the end of the hallway was one large and rather ornate door.

Ah, the true holy grail.

Agatha pressed on and pushed the door open, striding right through it into her bedroom. When Rio entered behind her, she found herself... puzzled. That was the right word, wasn't it?

Rio had clearly been building her own preconceived notions about what Agatha's life would look like beyond the scope of their interactions and yet, she was surprised with each and every single door Agatha opened. The bedroom was fucking huge , as most was in the condo, but it was also wildly impressive. There was a grand armoire against the wall, set next to a matching dresser. A chaise had been placed in the corner close to the windows, likely a good reading spot.

Several pieces of framed art hung on the walls, midieval pieces, ones that offered a new darkness that could not be found in the rest of the house. They were morose in fashion, think pieces, but also ones that had connotations of pain and suffering. That was more the Agatha that Rio had come to learn about and attempt to understand. It made perfect sense, really, that her bedroom was where she kept the visuals of those feelings.

Against the wall to the left of the doorway was the largest bed that Rio was sure she had ever seen. That was not a California King, like the one Alice had at her house.

"What the fuck is that?" Rio questioned. Agatha spun to see what it was she was pointing at, following to the bed. Her brow knit before she looked back to Rio, clearly confused.

"A bed?" she answered in a question, not seeing what was hanging Rio up.

"For like forty people? Is that like a Russia King or something?"

Agatha laughed, and while it probably shouldn't have, it made Rio feel like a total fucking idiot.

"That's not a real thing," Agatha dismissed, finally pacing over to Rio to relieve her of her bag. Rio handed it over, eyes still wild over the sight of the bed. "It's an Alaska King. Hundred and eight inches by a hundred and eight inches."

"Agatha, what the fuck do you need a bed this big for? Do you throw orgies here every other weekend?" Rio's line of questioning felt legitimate in her mind, but it was clear that Agatha was finding nothing in this but unadulterated humor.

"Why? Wanna be invited?" Agatha returned over her shoulder as she moved over to the side of the bed that would clearly be Rio's for the weekend, setting her bag down by the nightstand. When she turned back, she looked pleased with herself, like she'd gotten in a dig that wouldn't hurt but might entice Rio to say something daring.

It was Rio's turn to not bite.

"You don't have any televisions?" Rio asked pointlessly, not actually caring, but she hadn't caught sight of one to that point. "You have a pool, but don't like to watch Netflix?"

Agatha clucked her tongue as she began to float around the border of the bed to her side. Scooping up a small remote with ease, she turned and pressed a button, one that dropped a rolled screen from the ceiling, right in front of the window.

"You're so fucking extra. What do you need half of this shit for?!" Rio asked her, doing what she could to not fall into an endless pit of hysterical laughter.

"I don't need it," Agatha told her, pointed stare finding Rio across the bed. "I want it. And what I want, I take."

Rio had been kidding, mostly. She didn't care, exactly, that Agatha had acquired so much pointless and excessive shit, but it was more than a little mind-boggling. But Agatha's response?

Agatha's response as enough to make Rio want to vault across that gigantic bed and lift her up onto it and spend the next twelve hours bending the knew to whatever it was Agatha wanted. She did it, too.

Shoeless and clad only in her jeans from her work day and her half-buttoned blouse, Rio took off, clamoring up on the bed and then across it, depositing herself on her feet directly in front of Agatha, eager and willing. Before she dove straight in, she had something to say first.

"Is that why you brought me here?" Rio asked her, stepping closer so that their faces were so close she could feel Agatha's warm breath as it rolled over her lips, her chin, her cheeks. "To take me away?"

Her voice had dropped low and the entire atmosphere in the room had shifted with that single statement from Agatha and the look she had been wearing to drive the point home.

Agatha wasn't intimidated by the show Rio was putting on, but she did seem to find it appealing. She licked at her lips, eyes dropping from Rio's gaze to her lips and back up again. Agatha stepped forward with nowhere to go, forcing Rio to take a step back at the same time she raised her hands to grasp at the open collar of Rio's blouse. It was a way to keep her close, to make sure she didn't try to get away.

Rio wasn't going anywhere.

"Well?" Rio challenged, an obvious enticement to get Agatha to answer.

"I brought you here," Agatha told her, voice low and gravelly, "because I think you needed a little more freedom than you'd ever find in your routine."

It sounded like a threat, but it was an exciting one.

"And what am I supposed to do with that freedom?" Rio questioned back, voice only slightly louder than a whisper. Her head had moved forward slightly, just enough that she could feel Agatha's lips so very close to her own.

"Whatever you want," Agatha whispered back, but she didn't let Rio offer a quip in return before she bit down on her lower lip, pulling on it in a taunt that made Rio's stomach bubble with lava.

The move in and of itself felt crippling to Rio's thought process, as if her brain had been tossed into a blender that was whirring at full speed. It was why what came out of her mouth severely lacked finesse and any trace of tact.

"All I want to do is you," she managed, sounding nearly choked by how suddenly turned on she felt with their proximity.

Agatha didn't quite laugh, but a breath of one left her in some state of amused horniness, but the second it was over, it was on.

Jerking on Rio's collar, Agatha's grip of both hands tightened as their lips collided in a messy and chaotic kiss, one that did not stay solely lip-on-lip. Rio stared. And then she blinked. Again and again, she simply blinked at Agatha, as if waiting for her to crack.

She did not.

Not dating. Once more, period. No elaboration necessary.

But she didn't need to, not with Rio and most certainly not in her own home.

Rio had followed, like a curious puppy, and watched as Agatha set about preparing them a salad of spinach, mozzarella balls, tomatoes, and balsamic glaze from her place at the island.

Phineas had come to say hello and Agatha had forgotten he was there.

And it felt good.

It was.

"I can, and I do frequently. Kind of like the restoration, I like to dabble in things like molecular gastronomy. It's fun to play around with and requires a lot of process and attention to detail, something I know all too well." There were little notes of that familiar arrogance clutching her words, a boasting to remind Rio who she was.

Rio knew. And she didn't care. She was never going to care.

"There's chicken marinating in the refrigerator which I planned to pair with a mushroom risotto, barring that you have any allergies," Agatha responded, moving to grab for a few shallow bowls to hold their lunch.

Maybe, Rio considered, it made Agatha happy when Rio dropped new bits and pieces about herself, her likes, the things that made her happy. The obvious answer was that it meant being a little more sentimental.

The other obvious answer was that she enjoyed making Rio squirm.

And I like that you seem to be enjoying it too."

When Agatha lightly kicked her beneath the table, Rio's smirk grew into a truly amused grin, eyes flickering from the bowl before her to the woman beside her, a strange tide of delight washing over her.  It rolled in again even stronger when Agatha didn't move her foot and instead ran it tauntingly along the side of Rio's calf.

Rio knew exactly where she was going.

Yet, she still took a moment to stare after the traces of her left behind, stuck in a state of wonder.

Agatha Harkness was something else.

"My, my," Agatha crooned, lifting herself to her feet. "Someone's an eager beaver."

Agatha only shrugged, lifting her palms out of the water to do so, trying to seem so nonplussed, but it wasn't working. "You seem like the semi-meticulous type that might have 'hope-to's' and 'want-to's' and 'have-to's' scribbled on sheets of crumpled paper somewhere."

This made Rio laugh. It was full and it was loud, but it was more amused than it was to mock. "I write nothing down, actually. It is... a fatal flaw. And why my refrigerator is empty ninety percent of the time. Never met a shopping list that liked me."

And so went their afternoon, light conversation where Agatha learned a few more things about Rio -- like how she adopted Phineas on her birthday as a gift to herself, that she was incredibly skilled at the game Go, and that she used to collect glass eyes when she was a teenager (which Agatha had called her a freak for, ironically) -- and in the in-between, Rio learned a few new things about Agatha.

Rio learned that Agatha knew a lot of things there were to know about the world, and a lot of it came from her countless hours as a child with her nose buried in encyclopedias, dictionaries, textbooks, and biographies. There had been little context clues in that conversation that had probably given away more than Agatha meant to; Rio was almost positive that whatever home life Agatha had been given, it had been a curse for her and knowledge was how she had made it out.

When Rio asked her about where she went to college for her degree, her answer actually left Rio speechless and stunned. She stilled in place as she tried to tread water despite not really needing to.

"I didn't."

Rio's brow pinched harshly, confusion scribbled over every inch of her face.

"You didn't go to college... But you're an aerospace engineer? How the fuck does that work?" she'd asked, watching as Agatha pulled herself from the pool, a shit-eating grin plastered to her face.

She paced to a small hutch and pulled out a towel to remove some of the water dripping down her fit and toned form before she perched herself on the front end of a lounger, bemused gaze finding Rio again.

"You make friends with shady people who are incredibly talented. If you get just the right group, you've got the world at your fingertips." Agatha leaned forward over her knees, the look on her face all but screaming that she knew she was brilliant. "I snuck into lectures at the local university and used a tape recorder so that I could go back and re-listen to anything I missed in my live notations. It took me longer than it would have if I would have just went but... We will just say Amelia has been with me a very long time, and it's her name on that fake as shit degree that has fooled anyone who has looked at it, as well as the paper trail to back it up."

Agatha was leaving out details, ones like which college she snuck into and where her degree actually claimed she went to school, but Rio had already gathered the bits and pieces Agatha wasn't ready to share. Thus, Rio did not shove them in her face with the full understanding that it was simply... unnecessary.

She did not talk about Imperial, or Iowa, even if the thought had tripped her up in the car. She did not ask why Agatha had chosen that name, or how many places she had lived in her life. Having that conversation, and all of the things Rio knew Agatha was choosing not to say, it introduced yet another layer to this perplexing woman, a layer of additional questions and a desperate need to know more.

Still, it was clear that Agatha was proud of herself for having conned her way to the top, and Rio couldn't say she blamed her.

Agatha had the life , as it appeared from the outside. She had a cushy job that allowed her to utilize the incredible intelligence she had been blessed with, had more money than it seemed she had feelings, and lived at the very top of the city, so high up above anyone and everyone she considered to be beneath her.

But not Rio.

Rio was right there, on the same level, occupying the same space.

Agatha saw something in Rio and while Rio felt it a little more after those conversations, she still didn't know what to call it, so she chose to leave it alone.

They spent hours like that, in and out of the pool, chattering back and forth about too many things. Rio wasn't sure how much time had passed, but when they both wound up back in the water again, she had grown a little restless with the lack of true contact between them.

Agatha had brushed over her skin a couple of times, but had not dared to hold her or get any closer than playing with her fingertips as they floated on top of the water.

So, as Agatha splashed her as a result of a bickering competition they were having over reality television -- in which Rio found true delight, learning that Agatha watched Big Brother in the summers when she could,  and had given her hell for it -- Rio was tired of the distance.

She was tired of being so worried about crossing a line that she was making the choice to hold back, and maybe giving Agatha the wrong impression at the same time.

Still grinning from her aquatic assault, Agatha had not seen it coming; Rio was quick as a missile as she launched toward Agatha, using just enough force to push her back to the bench seat that was about two and a half feet below the water. It was comical, the way it happened so fast and left Agatha actually shouting in surprise. Rio landed in her lap with Agatha's hips locked between her knees, only flecks of her amusement still dancing in her eyes.

"Well, hello there," Agatha murmured at her, tilting her head up so that she could pin Rio's gaze with her own. "It's been a while."

They were closer right then, closer than they had been all day. It wasn't that it had been weird or awkward, but Rio was trying to gauge the boundaries of what was okay and what might be too much. She didn't want to attach herself to Agatha's hip, and holding hands was very clearly off limits, but Rio wanted to be closer.

If throwing herself at Agatha in the pool was how she got there, then that was perfectly fine with it.

"I figured it best to try and not climb you like a tree for at least the first four hours of consciousness," Rio joked, but it was only half of one. What she wasn't saying was that she was not sure yet what was welcome and so, she was trying to show restraint.

Was it mainly sexual? Yes, of course. Rio was physically attracted to Agatha, every single inch of her, but in this new territory they were exploring, it left Rio wondering what else might be entering the realm of possibility. Agatha wasn't going to hold her hand every five minutes, not like she had when she had pulled Rio into the closet, but could it be okay for Rio to put hers over Agatha's when they were next to each other?

Was it okay to rub her thigh when she didn't want to immediately initiate sex? Would Agatha hate it if all Rio wanted to do was touch her, and just run her fingers over the skin of her arm when they were sandwiched together on the couch? Would it be alright if she absentmindedly played with Agatha's hair, as had crossed her mind a time or two?

She knew she should have just asked, but she wasn't ready to just yet, and part of Rio knew that maybe Agatha wasn't ready for her to ask those questions, either.

"So you bully me onto the pool bench instead?" Agatha posed, craning her neck just enough that she could swipe her lips softly against Rio's in a move that could not have even been called an actual kiss.

"Yes," Rio responded plainly before reinstating the contact with a fuller, more intentional kiss. It wasn't immediately heavy or desperate, but it was an honest showing that she had rather missed the physical closeness between them. That, coupled with the way her hands had come to rest on Agatha's shoulders, had to indicate as much, if Agatha was paying close enough attention.

They would figure it out, the boundaries of their entanglement, but getting to kiss Agatha like that without feeling like Rio was overstepping felt nice. It felt even better as Agatha's hands found her hips beneath the water, holding them gently in place as she reciprocated the same energy Rio was giving her through that kiss.

It was merely lips and sighs and the gentlest little giggles when Agatha would nip at her the flesh she was meant to be kissing.

In many ways, Rio felt like a teenager quite often in Agatha's presence. She was drunk on physical affection in the late afternoon while naked in a swimming pool that was housed inside one of the tallest buildings in chicago. Even Teenage Rio might not have been so rash to make such choices, but the longer they sat in the water making out, Adult Rio had no regrets.

It was definitely sexy by any and all measure, but it was not fueled by the primal desire to fuck or be fucked. No, it was just... blissful to sit in Agatha's lap and kiss her like time itself had stopped for them.

It was a soft scraping, a scratching almost.

And then, the most forlorn meow that Rio was sure she had ever heard.

Phineas was hungry.

They had spent hours in that room, and at least half of that time in the water. While the reserves that had been like a wall between them had started to melt away, so, apparently, had the time.

"Must be dinnertime," Agatha mused.

As Rio's eyes finally fluttered open -- not having been as interested in the sound -- Agatha was staring up at her with a smile that felt too sweet for her and a pink to her cheeks that actually made her appear rather disarming in the late afternoon light.

She could tell as much by the way Agatha's hands started to travel to her ass. As a preventative measure to keep from disrupting their night, Rio broke the kiss off.

"Tonight."

With that, Rio braved to press a quick kiss to the side of Agatha's head before she pushed off so that she could climb out of the pool to dry herself off. To prevent any conflicting feelings, she did not dare glance at Agatha's expression as she did so. She wasn't sure how such a move might land and if it was negative, she didn't want to be privy to the immediate after effects.

"Of course it is. I'll put dinner on and shower when we're done eating. We should be able to make it to the pier by sunset."

Rio didn't know why it mattered to Agatha that they made it before sunset, at least not at first. And then, as she finished drying off, she realized it was because it was simply an experience that Agatha wanted to share with her, one that was renowned for being so beautiful and breathtaking.

Rio offered a nod and started to depart, but her feet cemented to the ground the moment she felt Agatha's hand wrap around her bicep, holding her in place. Alarmed, her dark and concerned gaze snapped to Agatha in question, but Agatha offered no verbal answer.

Instead, she did the unthinkable. The unthinkable in the best way.

Open-eyed and a little stupefied, Rio's mind was hurtling at warp speed, trying to understand how Agatha had just made the choice to kiss her outside of a present and immediate physical closeness. It took a couple of seconds, but Rio's lids finally slid shut and her full attention was on that kiss, on what Agatha was actually saying to her.

The collar was high and slightly ruffled and the sleeves were long, covering her arms but not disguising them.

Agatha hadn't been kidding.

She did know how to cook, if only judging by the aromas wafting throughout the home.

That was confirmed when they sat down to eat and Rio put that very first bite in her mouth.

It was heaven .

It had been difficult to not rave throughout the meal each time she took another bite, but she found it in her to refrain somehow, instead indulging Agatha with answers to questions that tickled her mind.

"What's your worst injury?"

That answer was easy: dislocated shoulder.

"What was the worst you've ever hurt another person?"

That one was a little trickier, but she'd been honest: she'd broken a girl's nose at a concert when she was seventeen by punching her in the face.

The last one, Rio chose to answer as they finished their meal. It was also the one that had required the most thought to respond in the fullest scope possible.

"Do you ever think, given the right set of circumstances -- anger, despair, vengeance, whatever it is -- that you could take a life?"

It wasn't exactly dinner conversation, but they were still within the walls of that steel fortress of Agatha's home and she knew that she was free to ask such things without scrutiny from anyone who did not understand them, or understand her.

Rio had taken her time, taking a pull of her beer before she leaned back in her chair and glanced to Agatha, the consideration still heavy in her dark eyes.

"I don't want to say I never could, because never is an impossibly finite word, but I think I can say that I never want to, and I hope I never have to. But if the day should come where I do, I..." Rio pressed her lips together, huffing a soft sigh. "I think it would take a lot to get over, for me. But... here's to hoping that we always leave that to you," she quipped playfully, tipping her beer in Agatha's direction before polishing it off.

She suddenly snapped back into focus, as if she had just remembered they still had plans and got to her feet, taking to cleaning up the table as she had earlier in the day.

"What? My outfit?" she questioned, leaning forward onto her elbows as she watched Agatha's back for a few seconds, eagerly awaiting her response.

"Yes, your outfit. It's far bolder than I ever thought you capable of being in public," she answered truthfully, shrugging her shoulders.

"Good to know that you're not the only one full of surprises here, then," Rio shot back, tone light and teasing.

Shutting off the water, Agatha turned to face her as she dried her hands, though it was rather pointless when she announced her next destination. "I'm going to shower and we can head to the pier. It's about a twenty minute walk from here, if you don't mind, or I can call Francisco. Give it some thought and we'll head out when I'm finished."

She turned to weave the towel through the oven handle and surely was intent on doing as she said, but in a brash move of boldness that Rio had in no way telegraphed, she reached up and found light purchase on Agatha's bicep, much the same way Agatha had done to her earlier.

Agatha's head whipped to take her in, clearly startled by the sudden move, but she did not stiffen or try to pull away. In fact, when their eyes met, realization washed into her features, and then that deep blue gaze.

Rio didn't move an inch.

She didn't have to.

Agatha's lips twitched upward the tiniest amount, but if they pulled any further, Rio didn't see it. Her eyes fluttered shut as Agatha minimized the space between them, closing it off with a firm but somewhat reserved kiss. It was Agatha giving Rio what she was wanting, but at the same time, it was also her giving back the courtesy Rio had provided to her earlier in the afternoon.

Even though they were baby steps, it was still forward progress.

In the same vein as Agatha's earlier act of pleasurably painful physical force -- and to prevent either of them from attaching too much thought to the moment -- Rio gave a light swat to Agatha's ass.

"Go get ready! It'll be dark by the time your hair's dry if you don't!"

It felt liberating to Rio to laugh the way she did as Agatha sauntered off down the hallway to shower and ready herself for their night out.

Their first night out.

Their first night out together .

In the time it took Agatha to shower and do her make-up and hair, Rio had found herself on the couch with Phineas who had curled up at her side, fat and happy after the dinner he'd gotten, too. The silence had started to get to her five minutes in, so by the time Agatha emerged, the television was on some news program that was droning on quietly in the background.

Rio's gaze tore from Phin when she noticed Agatha stride into the room, hair down and blowing wildly behind her.

She looked stunning.

The jeans she was wearing were lighter than Rio's, but not by much and had a very large, very excessive gold belt buckle -- Gucci, Rio thought by the design -- that held them up. She had on a black camisole and over it was a smart black blazer, one that had several white buttons for show.

"Holy shit," Rio managed, doing her best to prevent the gawking that was trying to win out.

"Oh, this old thing?" Agatha mused, plucking at the lapels of the blazer in show. "Got it years ago. Almost forgot I had it."

Rio was on her feet, moving with fervor to minimize the distance between them. She knew, even as she approached, that she should have kept her hands to herself, but it didn't stop her. No, she marched right up to Agatha and slid her hands beneath the blazer and over her waist, beaming at her with a truly delighted grin on her lips.

"You're full of shit, but it's hot as fuck, so I'll let it pass this one time," Rio informed her.

This time, when she leaned in to place an assertive kiss to Agatha's lips, she didn't hesitate. Agatha seemed to like that, given the way she gripped at Rio's hips and pulled her just a little closer, not wanting her to get away quite so soon.

It was another small victory, another inch forward, one that was leading them to figure out what they might be able to become when they stopped standing in their own ways.

Maybe it would still take time, but they were getting closer, little by little.

"Are you ready to go?" Agatha murmured against Rio's lips, breath warm and still smelling of mint from where she had brushed her teeth. It steadied the thumping in her chest as her heart had started to get away from her.

Keep it in check, idiot.

With an affirming nod, the two of them set out into the evening, sensible footwear carrying them to their intended destination while they kept idle chatter. It was the lightest back and forth mostly revolving around the characters that littered the streets as the night started to unfold.

There had been a serene air around them as they walked side-by-side, occasionally lightly bumping into one another as the littlest reminders of presence and accountability. About halfway there, Agatha decided to switch that up. She did not reach for Rio's hand, but instead held her arm out and tipped her head silently in suggestion when Rio went to question what she was doing.

With an instant understanding, Rio threaded her arm through Agatha's, trying not to let a lip curling that was too tickled touch her features. No one died. Nothing exploded. There were no gunshots. It was just a peaceful transition from distance to less of it, and Rio found herself with that smile because of it.

Rio had been to Navy Pier before. She quite enjoyed spending time there, and herself and Alice had gotten far too drunk on too many occasions at the Beer Garden to keep honest tally of. It was always a good time, but it was always within the comforts of being allowed to be wild per their friendship.

This, with Agatha, was new.

It was unchartered land that Rio was still trying to feel her way through. Yes, they strolled down that pier arm-in-arm like they had done it a million times before, but what did that actually mean?

Right then, the only meaning Rio could assign to it was that Agatha wanted her close and honestly? She was more than okay with that.

As they began to walk the length of the pier, something caught Rio's attention.

The Centennial Wheel.

She'd had the opportunity to ride it only once before, but it had been midday and way before the drinking had started. There was a different context here, one that she couldn't help but ponder.

Rio could just ask , but she felt like it might have been toeing the line of what was acceptable between them. It was already ambiguous enough that they were walking arm in arm through a popular city attraction near sunset; she didn't want to tread much further and push Agatha into any kind of fight-or-flight reaction while they were in the public eye.

Apparently, Rio had been staring at the wheel for just long enough that it had drawn Agatha's attention. She gave the slightest squeeze of Rio's arm, offering an answer to an unasked question.

"No."

Rio turned to look at her, curiosity pulling at her features. She hadn't even asked, and Agatha had shut her down, clearly already having an idea of what was going on within her head. Although Rio could have assumed that it was for the very reasons she had chosen not to ask, something about the way Agatha's jaw tensed told her that there was more there.

"Can I ask why?" Rio inquired as they continued walking. It wasn't an interrogation or a demand that Agatha tell her, but just another instance of Rio realizing that there was more to a situation than met the eye. She could have just asked 'why' straight up, but Rio was of the complete understanding that there was a need for her to be delicate, and so she posed the question within another.

Agatha did not look at her, instead choosing to lift her chin a little as they walked, but she did provide an answer.

"I don't like heights," she offered, but Rio thought it was a lie.

"Oh, come on. You live seventy stories above the city," Rio goaded, slinging a little of her weight into Agatha's side, although their arms stayed linked. "There has to be more to it than that."

Rio watched Agatha's profile, studying it carefully until she realized something. Whatever it was that was keeping Agatha from getting into one of those little glass boxes to view the city as the sun began to sink, Agatha saw it as a weakness. It showed in how her lips were pursed, how there were lines in her forehead as a result of her frown.

"I don't like the combination of heights and enclosed spaces," she revealed, tone emotionless as she made the admission.

There it was: having any kind of fear was absolutely viewed as weakness to Agatha and that was clear with such a response. It wasn't something Rio had meant to dig into, knowing their surroundings, and she hadn't even actually been the one to do it, but her obvious wants had been a catalyst anyway.

"Okay," Rio stated simply. Facing forward again, she decided to switch gears; while she still felt a little tipsy from her beers at dinner, she was suddenly of the mind that a little more alcohol might be a considerable amount of a help rather than a hinderance. "Why don't we grab something to drink?"

They had done just that, garnering their wristbands and respective alcohols -- more beer for Rio and a plastic cup filled with wine for Agatha -- and set off again to scale the pier. They would stop and look into shops or ruminate in the smells outside of one of the restaurants, but every so often, Rio found herself glancing toward that stupid Ferris wheel.

Every single time, Agatha clocked it but never said a word.

The sun was creeping lower, the oranges and pinks filling the sky over the vast expanse of the lake in the most breathtaking ways. Even more breathtaking was the way the light shined on Agatha's face, creating the most stark contrast of hues and shadows, one that made her seem just that much more attractive.

Agatha was sexy beyond words, but in that sunset, Rio saw what only Rio was capable of seeing.

They were in front of so many people who would only see Amelia when they looked at her, but right then? Rio just saw Agatha as she basked in the end of another day, a day she was choosing to end by holding Rio's arm in her own as they enjoyed everything the pier had to offer them.

On another pass, Rio's eyes wandered once more to the highest gondola on the wheel, just watching as it swung easily in the breeze while the lower one emptied and refilled. This time, when Agatha noticed it, what she had to say was vastly opposite of how they had begun their evening.

"Fine," she murmured lowly, lightly pressing into Rio's side so that they steered more toward the Ferris wheel.

"Agatha, you don't --" she had started, but Agatha was quick to cut her off as she shoved her empty wine cup into a trash can as she passed by.

"Do not do that because I will absolutely change my mind."

Rio realized what was happening.

She had been giving Agatha everything she asked for and then some without ever protesting in a way that was not meant to entice or rile her up. As such, Agatha was trying her hardest to find small areas where she could offer a little more give, and show Rio that she was capable of making concessions, too.

They purchased their tickets and waited in line, though Rio could feel Agatha's anxiety growing as they stood arm-in-arm, the minutes dragging on. She would lift her chin, looking up at the highest gondola, and Rio could feel as every muscle in her arm would tense, followed by a forceful sigh that told Rio she was the only reason Agatha had not bolted in the opposite direction.

Rio wanted to say something.

She wanted to look Agatha in the eye and tell her it was okay, that they didn't have to do it, but Rio could almost predict what her reaction might be.

Agatha would want to do it just because she had the idea in her head that Rio thought she couldn't.

So Rio just squeezed her arm a little tighter each time they shuffled forward in line. Agatha wasn't shaking, but Rio could feel her nerves as they jettisoned throughout her body, up and down, back and forth.

A few more shuffles landed them at the front of the line, stepping forward so that the attendant could scan their tickets.

That gondola was only ten steps away, but as Rio turned to Agatha to ask if she was sure, Agatha pressed forward, pulling Rio right along with her. She didn't want to hear Rio offer her an out because, as she had stated earlier, she would take it. However, Agatha could see that this meant something to Rio and that obviously was making it mean something to her, too.

Once seated inside, Rio's gaze turned Agatha, but Agatha was already looking out the glass, probably willing the ride to be over already.

"Agatha..." Rio voiced softly, glancing at Agatha's hand as it rested on her lap.

"I'm fine, R--" Agatha started to insist, but as the mechanics kicked on and the gondola began to move, her hand snapped out and wrapped tightly around Rio's, squeezing her fingers firmly out of nothing more than fear.

It happened so quick, but time seemed to stop for Rio as the gravity of it all settled around them.

Agatha was uncomfortable. Her anxiety was palpable, but she was willing herself to do something because she wanted to do it for Rio. In the process, she had been jarred enough to seek out comfort, a comfort that was easily accessible and right there for her to take. The fact that she found that comfort in a physical hold on Rio's fingers? That was fucking important.

Casually and without saying a word, Rio flipped her hand within Agatha's grasp and threaded their fingers together as they began to move higher and higher. At the same time Agatha's breathing was growing more and more shallow as they seemed to ascend further up.

"Wouldn't it be funny if there were dolphins in the lake?" Rio mused aloud, eyes cast out on the water, though she was still gripping Agatha's hand with ferocity over her own thigh.

Agatha breathed a soft snort, but Rio could tell immediately that she recognized the comment as an attempt at distracting her. Even if it wasn't working, it had seemed to pick at her attention for a few seconds, at the very least, enough to get her to breathe a little slower. The longer they sat there, though, the closer Agatha got to actually panting, unable to catch her breath.

They went around a couple of times and Rio kept muttering quiet musings in an attempt to get Agatha through those few minutes, but when they stalled at the top of the wheel so that the people below them could get off, Agatha had finally had enough.

"I need out," she stated suddenly, cheeks the deepest red they had been since they'd climbed into the car.

"Agatha, hey," Rio tried, but Agatha was starting to panic.

"We have to get out, Rio!"

Rio knew that was not an option. Rio also knew that Agatha was fully aware that it was not an option and yet, it didn't matter. Whatever it was about enclosed spaces coupled with heights, it was worse than Rio had expected when Agatha had offered her explanation.

When Agatha tried to pull her hand away, Rio grappled at it and sandwiched between both of her own, keeping it in her hold.

"Agatha, please look at me," Rio requested, once again utilizing the name only she knew to try and reach the part of Agatha that truly needed to hear her.

It didn't matter, Agatha couldn't actually hear what Rio was saying, not over the alarms and bells going off in her head.

Rio wanted to keep her tight hold on Agatha's hand, but she needed one of her own for something else. Slowly, as to not startle Agatha, Rio lifted one of them to reach across, fingertips gracing Agatha's far cheek in a request for her attention.

" Please look at me, Agatha, " Rio attempted again, applying a light pressure to convince her to comply.

Finally, Agatha's head turned and those terrified blue eyes found Rio in their frenzy.

" You're okay. We're okay. I promise, " Rio tried to convince, though she wasn't certain it was working with the way Agatha still looked so fucking frightened.

"I just want out," Agatha managed back weakly, looking every bit the poster child for a panic attack.

Rio couldn't get her out, but maybe she could take her away from it all, instead.

Still maintaining that light touch on Agatha's cheek, Rio closed the space between them with a kiss that was most assuredly far too fucking soft for who they were, but she didn't care.

She had needed to do something that was going to pull Agatha's anxiety-addled brain from its fugue state, and she had needed to do it fast. Even though the decision came with a certain level of risk, Rio didn't give a shit. All she cared about in that moment was getting Agatha calmed down.

And it worked.

Agatha stopped trying to get away, instead melting into the contact of their lips brushing tenderly. Rio's fingertips lightly caressed her cheek as she deepened the kiss, warming it enough to keep Agatha's focus on her over the fact that they had started to move again.

It continued to work!

Agatha suddenly seemed oblivious to their surroundings, only interested in the fact that Rio was kissing her, that she was squeezing her hand and paying every last bit of attention to her. Rio could feel it, the way the fear was slowly seeping out of her, leaving her form a few seconds at a time. So Rio just kept kissing her, almost as if both of their lives were utterly dependent on it.

It wasn't anywhere near was heated as the make-out session they'd had in the pool, but it had been effective all the same.

She didn't want to fuck Agatha, though, not after that.

What Rio truly wanted was to pull Agatha into her arms and apologize for making her feel as though she had to do something she knew would upset her. What she really wanted to do was kiss away every bit of the foreign emotion she realized she did not like seeing on Agatha's face and in her eyes. All she wanted was to make it go away and atone for the indiscretion of forcing Agatha's hand.

Her lips worked tirelessly, just kissing the panic straight out of the startled woman before her and swallowing it whole. When Rio felt the gondola loosely swing to a stop, she pulled away, much to Agatha's chagrin. Her eyes flew open in worried question, one that fell from her immediately.

"Why did you stop?"

Rio leaned back, indicating the door as the attendant pulled it open.

"We're back on solid ground. How about we get out of here and get another drink?"

Agatha didn't say it, but Rio could see that she was thankful, not for the reprieve of the ride being over, but because Rio had managed to make what could have been a nightmare into something more akin to a lucid dream.

Rio scooted out, fighting herself the entire time to not reach behind her to offer her hand for Agatha to take. She didn't, despite how badly she wanted to, and instead waited for Agatha to slide out as well. Turning to begin their mini hike to the nearest beer cart, Rio found herself confounded by a catch on her pinky finger.

It was Agatha.

Of course it was Agatha.

She wasn't holding Rio's hand, not again, but she was assured in the way her pinky was locked tightly around Rio's, gripping firmly in her gratitude.

Rio let it happen, squeezing right back as they ventured toward the nearest beer cart.

"Maybe you should get two wines for yourself," Rio teased softly, trying to ease any remaining nerves Agatha might still be having over her perceived moment of vulnerability.

Rio knew it was hard for her because she could see it written over every inch of Agatha's body and face. She was tense, she was uneasy, and she likely wanted to forget that it had even happened, but it wasn't something Rio could let go of so easily.

"I think I'm going to," Agatha murmured back. They stopped near a few high top tables and Agatha turned to face her, though she didn't drop the hold she had on Rio's finger.

"I'm gonna go grab the drinks and we can head back home, but I'm gonna go alone. Just... for a minute, hm?" she told Rio, even if she tried to pose it as a question. Hidden in there was an unvoiced request for space and a second to catch her breath. Agatha was being too hard on herself, upset with the way she had buckled so easily, both to Rio's request and then to her own fears, but she wasn't understanding that it simply wasn't necessary.

There wasn't any reality where Rio would ever judge her.

Rio nodded her understanding, even if she felt a ball of hot lead sink in her stomach when Agatha walked far enough away that the contact between them ceased. That unbearable heat might have gone even further if not for the way Agatha looked back over her shoulder, relieved blue pools landing on Rio for just a moment before a tiny smile caused her lips to twitch.

As Rio leaned against one of the tables, propped on her elbow, she knew she had a lot to consider. She wanted to watch Agatha as she stood in line, but she didn't want to provide any unnecessary level of perception that might cause her to draw inward just as Rio was getting her to open up, even the most minute amount.

Rio knew that she had not been meant to see that. She knew that if Agatha could reach inside of her head and pluck that memory right out, she would never hesitate to do so. To Agatha, it was a moment of weakness. It was breaking down and showing that something could effect her in the future if Rio chose to hurt her with it. Now, she had given Rio this piece of her that she probably felt paramount to all else.

But Rio wasn't going to turn it into a weapon.

No, those several minutes in that glass gondola had reminded Rio of one very important thing that she seemed to find herself forgetting with frequency: Agatha was still human.

She might have been a stone cold serial killer, but she was still very much a person and one that had reasonable and logical emotions, no matter how good she had gotten at masking over them.

And that humanity, Rio guessed, seldom made an appearance in front of another human being. Agatha's shame didn't need to consume her; Rio didn't care. All Rio cared about was making Agatha feel better, making her understand that if she had legitimate and valid reasons for saying no to something, Rio would never knowingly push. She needed to understand that Rio actually cared about how she felt in any given situation.
