Rio had always been of the opinion that most white men looked like Machine Gun Kelly, and this guy looked to be no different. His hair was longer, but he had a hideous pencil thin mustache and the most mud-colored brown eyes Rio was sure he had ever seen. He had various tattoos and while Rio tried not to judge, the ones on his neck were so awful she couldn't even tell what they were meant to be.

He'd seen her, alone, covered in tattoos, dressed the way she was, and assumed she might like a conversation.

It was the last fucking thing in the world she wanted.

"Heyy," he greeted, rubbing his palms together in front of him. Rio had watched too many TikTok videos of women mocking the behavior relentlessly, but she had never witnessed it in real time before and she saw the cause for disgust. That alone told her he was but a boy trying to step into a man's shoes.

A man that never would have had a shot with Rio anyway.

Even if her serial killer not-girlfriend was not standing thirty feet away, paying for wine and beer so that they could be moderately buzzed on their walk home.

"Not interested," Rio informed him immediately, tone flat and expression deadpan.

"But you're here all by yourself? Don't you want to have a little fun for the night?" he asked, reaching up to smooth back his untidily long hair.

"Not with you I don't," Rio assured him. "I have a girlfriend."

She was so fixed on him, waiting for the next stupid thing to spill out of his mouth that she had lost sight of the background and lost sight of how Agatha was returning, all three cups pinched in the fingers of her left hand.

Rio delivered another warning, still oblivious to Agatha's beeline straight for them.

"So please, fuck off."

In fact, as he started to spew some comment where Rio was sure he was going to ask if he could watch, Rio jumped back, startled as he was jostled forward by Agatha who had deliberately bumped into him from behind.

Rio almost missed it, the way Agatha's empty hand slid into the pocket of her blazer, stowing something away, but she caught it at the last second. Even so, it didn't quite register and she was instead focused again on the man who had been bothering her as Agatha came around and he snapped to her in order to voice his dissatisfaction at the physical contact.

"What the f--" he started to bellow, but Agatha's free hand snapped up in front of his face, one finger held up to silence him.

"I believe I heard the lady tell you to fuck off," she stated plainly.

The man blinked, but was quickly fumbling over his words in response. "I was just..."

Agatha's fury was visible even from Rio's view as she stood behind her; she couldn't even begin to imagine what the look in Agatha's eyes was conveying to this asshole.

"Y-y-y-you were just what?!" Agatha mocked, holding the cups out to her side as she took a step toward him, giving no shits that she was about two inches shorter than he was. "You were just annoying the fuck out of her is what you were doing. Now do as she said and fuck. Off. Or I promise you I will make you fuck off and no one you love will ever hear from you again."

It was a good thing he looked as scared as she did because just behind Agatha, Rio knew she meant every single word she was saying to him. She also seemed to be situationally blind for just a moment because she did not lower her voice or make it a quiet threat. Agatha wasn't shouting, but anyone who was trying to listen certainly would have heard her.

The man didn't move. He just stared down at Agatha, as if she were going to tell him it was all a joke.

When she flinched at him menacingly instead, he stumbled backward and took off, briskly heading toward the end of the pier. She watched after him until he disappeared into the throngs of people that were only illuminated by the lamps posted on the railings, hanging overhead.

Slowly, when she turned around, Rio saw something else new on her face.

Worry.

"Are you alright?" she asked as she paced the few feet between them, not shifting any of the cups to her right hand so that she could place it against Rio's side, looking her over.

"I'm fine Ag--" Rio immediately bit her tongue, stopping herself from saying something she had no business saying given where they were. "I'm okay," she corrected softly, gaze dropping to the half-empty cups in Agatha's hand, having lost some of their contents in her collision with the nuisance of a man that had tried to ruin Rio's night.

Taking the beer, she tossed back the few swallows left and crumpled up the cup before she found herself brave enough to look at Agatha again. "Can we go back to the condo?" Rio asked, her voice suddenly small and uncertain.

"I think we should," Agatha agreed.

This time, when they departed, it was Rio's entire hand Agatha picked up after she threw away her own refuse so they could begin the journey back.

Though it had startled Rio those first two times, when Agatha clutched at her fingers through their trip back to the mouth of the pier, and then the lively city streets, Rio wasn't as shocked. In fact, she was more shocked at realizing how much she liked it, and how she never wanted Agatha to let go, no matter how unrealistic that was.

Only a few blocks from the tower, Agatha slowed her pace at the sight of a small ice cream stand to the left on the sidewalk.

"Do you want some ice cream?" Agatha asked her softly, though it gave Rio pause.

"You don't strike me as the type to eat street food," she returned, glancing to Agatha with a wrinkled nose that displayed her confusion.

"That's why I asked if you wanted some," Agatha answered, finally meeting her gaze with a playful curl of her lips.

Rio considered for just a moment; she didn't actually want it, but something in her felt as though Agatha was probably asking for a reason, and so after another second's thought, Rio gave a gentle nod.

When she ordered a single scoop of brown butter almond brittle, Agatha had informed her she was paying. What she had not included was how she was paying.

Smoothly and with an air of absolute arrogance, Agatha reached into the blazer pocket and produced a wallet. It was a wallet Rio had never seen before. It was... a man's wallet. Agatha coolly slid a $20 out and forked it over to the man who had served Rio her ice cream, a sweet smile on her lips.

"Keep the change," she assured him, snapping the wallet shut once more before she tucked it back safely in her pocket.

As the two of them began to walk again, Rio immediately pinned her with a narrowed gaze.

"Agatha?" she cooed accusatorily, feeling safe to do so with no one close enough to hear.

"Yes, princess?" Agatha shot back, not daring to meet Rio eye-to-eye.

"Did you steal that man's wallet when you bumped into him?"

Agatha was grinning, ear to ear, as she chose her answer.

"I refuse to answer that on the grounds that I believe you should get to maintain plausible deniability."

Rio laughed, lowering her ice cream.

"You fucking criminal."

That time, they both laughed.

I'm Spellbound, I Forget to Breathe

By the time Rio and Agatha made it back to the tower, Rio had happily finished her ice cream and even as they entered the elevator, Agatha was still holding her hand.

It was the most immature sense of joy that had filled her, one that made Rio feel as though she were a teenager all over again with a crush that finally started paying her attention. Agatha was not a crush, though, not by any measure. Agatha was this perplexing and stupefying human being that had managed to wrap Rio around her finger with little effort and was holding her there with no reserves.

On a deeper level than that, whatever was beginning to brew between them was more than just some physical dalliance that they would both move on from after a couple more rounds. It was stronger than the parameters of a fling, and for as much as pointing that out might flag Agatha's fight or flight response, it had weight to it.

It was something that Rio found herself spinning on when they'd made it back up to the condo and she had departed for another shower with the explanation that she just wanted to wash off quickly. Agatha hadn't let her leave without something to say first.

"Take your time," she assured, leaning in for a kiss that filled Rio's stomach with a too-tender heat that she tried to ignore.

"And if I don't want to?" she asked back coyly, their lips only an inch apart.

"I will always be a champion of you doing whatever you want," Agatha returned, the slyest smile finding her.

"You say that because you have enough awareness of the fact that the thing I want to do most as of late is you." The smirk that found her was close to Agatha's, but she hid it by taking a kiss of her own.

"Can't fault me for being practical," Agatha offered with a shrug. Her arm raised, and while Rio was almost certain Agatha was about to commit to the cupping of her cheek, she was not disappointed when Agatha held her neck instead, thumb working immediately to caress her jaw.

"You are a realist, I'll give you that." A braver but quicker peck left Rio with a smile as she pulled away. "I'll be right back. Don't have too much fun without me."

While she had no intentions of taking longer than necessary, she knew that having some time to think wasn't going to be the worst thing in the world.

So, washing her body, Rio simply thought.

She thought about where she was, in that condo, and how she had come to be there. She thought about how Agatha hadn't asked, had just told her to be ready for a weekend away and then once she was too far in to turn around, Agatha had told her the truth. She thought about how Phineas was there, too, because of a calculated decision on Agatha's part, one that more than took Rio's feelings into consideration.

Rio thought about how Agatha had asked her to stay in the first place because the true intention had been to offer her somewhere to go if she wanted out of her day-to-day for a couple of weeks. It had been a generous offer, but Rio didn't buy her whole 'you can if you want but a house sitter might be nice' act, not for a second. Agatha wanted it to have a surface level cover and she had aptly found one to provide, even if Rio saw through it.

Then, she thought about the pier. Agatha asking her to go in the first place had been huge, but the several steps she had taken in their time out? It had been an arm hold at first, but the ride on the Centennial Wheel had changed all of that.

When Rio found herself thinking about that gondola ride, something in her chest squeezed. Agatha had been so insistent when they arrived about not doing it, but something had changed her mind. Rio knew it was likely her own wandering gaze and how it kept appraising the wheel and the sights she knew it offered, but Agatha hadn't needed to make such a concession.

Had Rio known that the outcome would be, she wouldn't have let her do it.

Therein lay the beauty of it all; Rio hadn't known, but Agatha had, and she still made that choice. When Rio asked herself why, she wanted to find every insignificant reason that would not add to the fixation she already had with all that Agatha was. Maybe 'fixation' wasn't the right word, but Rio was in no way ready to admit that she might be feeling a little more than she should when it came to their dynamic.

She wasn't allowed to have feelings here, she knew that much. Whatever Agatha was, she was never going to be a romantic partner, or a 'girlfriend' as Rio had floated to try and get that man to leave her alone.

The man.

"Come here," Agatha requested softly. She wiggled a bit under the covers and raised her arm to tuck her hand behind her head, exposing the right side of her body for Rio to curl up against.

Rio wanted to ask if she was sure, if it was what she really wanted, but she didn't want to risk it. More than that, Agatha seemed to not like it very much when she challenged her seemingly out-of-character decisions. For anyone else, hand holding and cuddles were almost obligatory after a third fuck and first date, but not for Agatha.

For Agatha, making sacrifices where she could was how she said the things to Rio she couldn't say in words.

As Rio snuggled into her side and let the tiredness weigh heavy on her form, she found a request that she couldn't let get away.

Tracing the lightest shapes over the center of Agatha's chest, Rio whispered hushedly into the night, not really expecting an answer.

"Do you think I might be able to get to know more about you tomorrow?"

It was quiet, but it was an obvious plea.

Agatha's muscles did not tense, but she did stop breathing. It was at the peak of an inhale, one that she kept in and did not exhale. Rio kept waiting, anticipating that release of breath, but the seconds ticked on as Agatha seemed to think and think. And then, she seemed to think more.

By the time Rio was going to lift her head to gauge if Agatha had actually passed out as a result of the question, the softest sigh fell from Agatha's lips, her chest sinking beneath Rio's head. She kept tracing those shapes, not having stopped throughout Agatha's stillness.

She didn't answer, still, and Rio considered pressing, but something else happened first: Agatha dropped her arm, her hand landing on Rio's hip.

"If you ask something I don't want to answer, a 'no' is good enough. It's my only rule."

Agatha's voice was akin to a whisper, but lacked even the volume to qualify as such, but Rio could tell that she meant it. Once more, Agatha was making a choice to try to give Rio what it was she wanted. She did not have to do these things, but the fact that she kept choosing to spoke to her true intent.

"I can abide by that," Rio murmured back, eyes falling shut as her fingertips slowed in their light caress, but did not stop.

At least, they did not stop until she finally dozed off to the feeling of Agatha's thumb brushing back and forth over her hip.

The next morning, Rio did not wake when Agatha did, nor did she wake when Agatha slid out from under her to make her way to the washroom to undergo her morning skincare routine. She did not even rouse as Agatha dressed herself and made her way to the elevator, descending to greet the city streets on a not-so-typical Sunday morning.

In fact, even as Agatha returned an hour later with coffee and bagels, Rio was still fast asleep. The only difference was that she had wound up face down, the bare cheeks of her little ass uncovered despite the blanket covering most of her back. Well, not the only difference, as Phineas had taken up residence against her elbow in the spot Agatha had been occupying before her departure.

It was in those quiet, sleep-filled moments that she missed something.

She missed the way Agatha had watched them, watched her, as she contemplated how she had been living her life for nearly forty years. She missed the way Agatha traced her form with that chilling blue gaze, but in those moments when no one else -- not even Rio -- could see, that gaze was much softer.

Rio even slept through the ten minutes it took Agatha to set up the small spread for breakfast and make her way back to the bedroom, back to finally stir Rio from her slumber. She kneeled on the bed enough to reach Rio's form, giving her a light shake by way of the hip she could reach.

"M'up, m'up," Rio grumbled, heavily wiping at her own face as an irrational first act of consciousness. It had no logic to it, but perhaps she could brush away some of the exhaustion in the process.

"There's bagels and coffee in the kitchen," Agatha informed her, but instead of removing the hold on Rio's hip, her palm flattened and smoothed over Rio's asscheek. It wasn't suggestive or inappropriate, just a light caress that might get her synapses firing a little faster.

It did.

With that little nudge, Rio's form wound to life, pulling herself up enough to scoot toward the edge of the bed. Before she could get there, Agatha had already departed toward the door and was passing right through it.

It was silly, but Rio wished she would have stayed, if only for a moment. She would have liked to sit at the edge of the bed and start her day with a kiss, starting the day bare and on full display in front of a woman who's attention felt awfully fucking nice. It would have been nice to just feel normal for once, but she had to be real with herself.

Nothing about her dalliance with Agatha was ever going to be normal.

She dressed herself, that morning in leggings and a sports bra, not bothering with an actual shirt. There was really no point; they weren't immediately headed out and it was clear Agatha had brought breakfast to them. Rio wondered if that had been by design; just before she had fallen asleep, Agatha had agreed to be a little more forthcoming. Surely, she did not want to do so in any kind of public setting.

"A lazy Sunday in for us then?" Rio crooned as she paced into the kitchen, surveying the spread of thirteen bagels and three tubs of schmear.

"I thought it could serve us well after our little adventure yesterday," Agatha returned calmly, as if those words didn't say several other things at the same time.

Agatha had dared to breach her bubble of comfort and it had taken its toll on her.

If someone would have told Rio three months ago that serial killers could have emotional hangovers, she would have laughed. Even more, she would have undeniably cackled , but she could clearly see that despite all of her ego and arrogance and steely demeanor when it came to executing the unworthy, Agatha was still capable of feeling something.

Rio couldn't guess what that something might be, or if there was even actually a word for it, but she was quite certain that whatever it was, it had a firm hold on Agatha whenever they shared space.

That was even more obvious as they ate breakfast and sipped at their coffees at the dining room table, Phineas chirping softly from his spot at the window. When Rio lifted her head to peer over at him, a grin found her at the smears of sweat visible on the glass.

"I can clean that later," she mused with a light giggle, dark but amused gaze sweeping over to Agatha as her grin only seemed to grow.

"You don't have to," Agatha dismissed, "the maid will be here tomorrow while you're at work. I'll be here, but I don't mind looking her in the eye." The smirk that tugged on Agatha's lips was most certainly daring, but there was a light of humor that sparkled in her eyes.

This raised a flag of abnormality at the forefront of Rio's mind, causing her to perk up slightly. "You don't have to go in tomorrow?" she asked, trying not to look too eager, or like it was giving her the idea of calling in sick to work.

"I don't, but because my flight leaves tomorrow evening at nine. So, I will be here if you want to take the time after work to go back to your place and get more of your things," she explained, as if it were still so fucking casual that Rio was going to be staying in that multi-million dollar condo for the next week and a half to two weeks.

"Or..." Rio offered, popping a piece of bagel into her mouth as she chewed in thought, watching Agatha carefully. "I could just call in and we could spend one more day together before you have to go."

The moment she said it, Rio regretted it. She wished she would have found another way to word it, like maybe 'I can call off tomorrow so we can spend all day fucking like wild beasts,' or maybe 'I can pretend to be sick so that we can go for a daytime round against the window.' She wished that she would have said anything other than what she said, because what she said caused Agatha's face to shift just enough to be noticeable.

It was a big enough shift that it made Rio wonder why she had to get so fucking far ahead of herself, seemingly forgetting the reality in which she consistently existed.

"You know that thing you said about not breaking code?" Agatha posed back, lifting her coffee to take a long sip as she eyed Rio over the rim.

Of course Rio knew, she was the one who said it. But that meant she also understood what it was Agatha was trying to say.

"Me calling out of work pales in comparison to --"

"Situationally, yes, but in terms of moral culpability, not really," Agatha retorted, setting her coffee cup down with a raised brow as she stared Rio down, daring her to raise protest.

"Would you care to elaborate on such an interesting theory?" Rio asked back, tilting her head slightly.

"Your work means quite a bit to you," Agatha explained with a shrug, reaching down to thumb at the paper that had been laying untouched on the table in front of her. "Deciding to call out for no other reason than to spend more time with me is a misuse of a sick day that you might actually need. Plus, you don't actually want to miss work. I know you better than that."

She was right. She did know Rio better than that.

Rio wasn't sure if that should excite her or put her on the edge of not knowing what it was they were actually doing.

For the time being, she chose complacency and did nothing but shrug her shoulders.

"It's just work, but I understand the point you're trying to make, even if I believe them to be vastly incomparable situations." It was a white flag, an offer that the conversation had run its course and she understood that Agatha did not want her to make that choice.

Maybe she just needed a little time to herself.

That was something Rio could understand, something she could even relate to at certain times, but it wasn't something she'd ever really felt when it came to Agatha. Actually, every time that Agatha had left her alone in her apartment, she'd wanted nothing more than for her to come back, to staunch the loneliness that she felt so deeply.

Rio hadn't much felt the need to say it so plainly, but she knew what it felt like to fuck but not love, to be physical but not actually feel. She knew what it was like to seek out comfort in a sexual connection and find little relief.

So maybe that was what this was. Maybe it was relief, a relief that neither of them had really known.

It was empty of love, but not connection. That connection had bloomed out of the physical, but something else was branching off, growing slowly but strongly. Rio didn't know how to identify it, how to put some kind of brand or label on it, but she was watching as it seemed to progress hour by hour.

"Then you'll go to work like a good girl and I will have dinner for us when you make it back. I can't stand the thought of plane food, first class or not," Agatha detailed, making a face that showed her disgust at the idea of a tray meal that might be dropped in front of her.

"You can't just pepper in a 'good girl' when you're trying to convince me to do something I don't want to do and think it'll work every time," Rio told her, picking up her coffee to take a long sip, eyes dark and challenging as she watched the woman beside her, not oblivious to the way Agatha's foot had begun to caress her calf again.

"But it'll work this time," Agatha offered back, her grin bright but glinting in the morning light like a freshly polished blade.

"We'll see," Rio pushed back, but for no other reason than to appear as though she were putting up a fight.

They both knew she would listen, even if it meant less time spent together.

"We shall."

That seemed to end the conversation only moments before the finished their meal and decided on a plan for the day.

Movies and snacks (grapes, pineapple, and strawberries, though only later) while propped in bed.

Between the blackout curtains and the massive projector screen, they might as well have been in a theater. When they had initially settled in, Rio was... unsure. What was too much? What was not enough? So, instead of over thinking it, she placed herself directly next to Agatha, their hips barely touching.

Agatha was the one to scoot over, the one to close off any amount of space that might have existed between them. She was the one to make sure they were pressed together as they scrolled through an endless list of films.

The one they settled on?

Ironically, it was Agatha's choice.

The Accountant.

Rio laughed. "Is there a kinship there or something?" she teased, leaning into Agatha in a humorous show of heckling.

"No," Agatha responded. "It's just a good movie."

Rio let her put it on, let her sink back into the pillows and did the same, finding herself comfortably leaned against Agatha in a way that did not seem to draw any kind of protest. It felt nice to simply relax and watch a movie she had already seen next to someone whose company she was finding she quite liked to keep.

However, that did not mean that Rio was clueless to Agatha's motivations.

She was clearly stalling.

Rio let her, if only a little while longer. By the time The Accountant was over and Agatha was turning on a Halle Berry horror film from the early 00's, Rio had fetched a bowl of fruit for them to share and they settled in once more.

But Rio was never going to let the chance to know more get away from her, even if Agatha was clearly trying to stave it off and avoid it for a little while longer.

In front of them, almost in front of the very point where their knees met, the remote was laying on the bed. Without picking it up, Rio pressed three times on the little negative symbol, the one that lowered the volume around them -- still slightly annoyed that there was fucking surround sound in the goddamn bedroom, too -- and sat back as if she had done nothing at all.

Slowly, Agatha's head turned; Rio could see it in her periphery but she did not meet it. Instead, she popped a grape into her mouth and waited for Agatha to speak.

When she did, her voice was low and tried to be sharp, but did not quite make it there.

"Yes?" she questioned, clearly sensing that Rio had lowered the volume for a reason.

"So I've been wondering," Rio began, stealing one more grape to chomp on before she continued, "if heights and enclosed spaces are a big 'no,' how are you able to fly? Or ride the elevator up here?"

Finally, Rio turned her head so that she could find those curious blue eyes, though as the question settled in her mind, the softened the tiniest bit.

She was quiet for a moment, considering the best way to answer such a query. Rio sensed that there was likely an obvious answer, but she wanted to hear it off of Agatha's lips.

"When I can't see what's around me, I'm okay," Agatha answered lowly, reaching over to pluck a strawberry from the bowl before taking a bite to stall the continuation of her explanation. Her eyes had wandered, no longer finding comfort in Rio's dark gaze; she was taking a painfully long time to finish, but Rio knew why. To Agatha, she was admitting flaws, weaknesses, and it was making her uncomfortable. "It's irrational. Truly. And I think that's why I hate it so much. But if this fucker only had a glass elevator? I'd find somewhere else to live."

She finished her answer by also finishing off her strawberry, but she did not otherwise move. It was a fair enough answer, but Rio felt like there was more to it.

"But," Agatha decided to amend, "planes are... mostly doable with a bar of Xanax. It's not often I like to be robbed entirely of my wherewithal, but if I can sleep for eight to twelve hours as a result, I'm alright with it."

Ah, so Agatha's anxiety was a little deeper than she'd dared to let on before. Rio had an inkling, but she hadn't wanted to spook Agatha by pointing it out.

Alright. One question down.

"So... Does that mean if you travel a lot for work that you have a Xanax addiction?" Rio teased, looking back over at the woman beside her despite the fact that Agatha's gaze was fixed on the screen across the room.

Agatha parted her lips to form a retort, but before she could, a flash of grey appeared over the edge of the bed as Phineas made the leap, clearly upset by the fact that no one had paid him attention in a few hours. He padded his way over to Rio, begging for love that she met with several rough strokes along his spine. The pressure mixed with the relief caused him to lower to the bed, laying contentedly in front of Rio's crossed legs.

"No, it's the only time I use them. I don't really like being too out of touch with my faculties and awareness. It's why I don't drink enough to get drunk, or use illicit substances," Agatha informed her, picking up a piece of pineapple to munch on. It was a fair enough answer, one that Rio felt aligned perfectly with who Agatha presented herself to be.

Cooking up her next question, Rio couldn't help but lean into Agatha a little more, letting her head drop to rest on her shoulder in a daring show of boldness. It was likely Agatha would scoot over, try to separate them again.

But she didn't.

She didn't lay her head on Rio's, but she let her stay there, even as she posed her next inquiry.

"What was your longest relationship?" she asked, though this question sounded at a much lower volume and with less of an interrogatory tone.

Agatha was quiet for a moment before she gave her answer, one Rio really hadn't been expecting.

"No."

Rio did not lift her head, did not swing an accusatory gaze and tell Agatha she wasn't being fair. All Rio did was provide a response of her own.

"Okay, hm," she murmured, her lips twisting as she considered the next query to pose. "What about the last time you were happy? Like... truly happy. Where you might have found yourself sitting in it to bask in what it felt like."

Rio could already tell Agatha wanted to offer that one word again by the way her body tensed ever-so-slightly, but it relaxed again at the same time she heard a soft sigh pass through Agatha's lips.

"Maybe a year ago," Agatha finally supplied, though she picked up another piece of fruit. It was quickly becoming an obvious stalling tactic, but Rio wasn't going to call it out. There was really no point; Agatha was still being cooperative, even if she was taking her time to do so. "It was a work thing, so kind of pathetic. But there had been a cooling issue on the ISS that --" she paused, sensing that her lingo might need slight elaboration, "International Space Station -- we only had two weeks to fix. I spent about eight of those days in an office with six white boards and another woman and two men."

Agatha paused, offering a chuckle that almost sounded snide. "I drank at least five gallons of coffee in that time, but before the two weeks was up, I had mostly figured out what it was that we needed to build to send up so that they could repair it on board. With some help from Gina -- the other woman -- we had it manufactured and a mission slated to have it brought to them. By the end of that two weeks, it was rectified and I celebrated with the most expensive Filet Mignon I could find in the city."

Listening to Agatha, as her tone and her inflection matched with the content of what she was actually saying, Rio could tell she meant it. She was proud of what she had accomplished in those two weeks, rightfully so.

Agatha was still a mystery, but she was a mystery with reasons and motivations for the things she did. She was still an individual that sought fulfillment in life, just one that found it in unlikely and depraved places that others would never dare to look. For Agatha, she found it in a career she had conned her way into because she could not find it in connections with other people. She found it in her moral crusade that she took on under the cover of night.

Now, it seemed as though she was seeking it in the form of company.

Not just any company, but Rio's company.

Instead of pressing on that thought, Rio switched things up. "Have you ever had a pet? You seem to really like cats..." Rio trailed, her eyes casting down to the sleeping feline beneath the gentle strokes of her fingertips.

"I haven't had one myself, but my roommate when I was nineteen did," Agatha answered honestly, reaching out on her own accord to join Rio in her light petting of Phineas. He did not stir or mew or chirp. He simply enjoyed it in his slumber. "Her name was Tofu and she was a calico. Absolute little shit."

At that, Rio could not contain the light giggle that left her. "I take it she was a vegetarian?"

Agatha's head shook. "No. There was no reason for it. She brought it home, looked it in the eye and said 'Your name is Tofu.' No elaboration, no explanation. So... she was just Tofu."

They were both laughing by the time Agatha finished speaking and in a moment where Rio's inhibitions slipped, she scooted a little closer -- or, at least tried to -- and snuggled in just that much more.

As Agatha's hand rested on her knee, Rio considered just... picking it up. Just holding it in her lap as a show of a little more. It could have been reassurance, could have been comfort, wouldn't have really mattered. Rio simply wanted to be closer to her. But she didn't. She kept her hands to herself and pondered what it was she wanted to ask next.

The one she found felt... a little dangerous and yet, the impulse of asking won out.

"When was the first time you saw a dead body?"

Agatha surprisingly did not stiffen at such a question, although Rio wasn't sure why she thought she might. She was even more surprised when Agatha's return came calmly and was almost metallic in tone.

"I was eight." It was a fact. It was a statement of a fact, one that had likely changed Agatha forever. "It was a kid down the street."

Holy shit. No way had Agatha started that young. Even if it was an accident, Rio couldn't imagine a world where Agatha had taken a life before she reached double digits.

Not wanting to come off like an insensitive asshole, Rio chose to remain quiet. She didn't know the proper arrangement of words to use that might coax Agatha into giving her more. Thankfully, her silence did it all the same.

"It was a little boy named Caleb. We liked to climb the tree in the back yard and see who could run from fence to fence the fastest." Agatha was revealing more than she probably ever had before and yet, the way she was telling it was as if she were reciting Pi to its infinite decimal points. "My mother never let him inside. And the first day she did was his last day alive. I don't really know what happened other than I went upstairs for a toy shovel, and when I came back, she told me he was 'taking a nap.'"

Rio wanted to lift her head so fucking badly that it nearly caused a crick in her neck. She wanted to look at Agatha as she was saying such weighted things, but Rio also realized very quickly that doing so might put unnecessary pressure on her.

Agatha was telling her these huge facts because she did not have to look her in the eye as she did so.

"She sent me to my room for the rest of the night, but I watched from the window as she carried a lump of sheets out the back gate and down to the creek that ran behind our house. She was gone for a while, but she came back with nothing. The next day, it took me five minutes to find where she buried him like a fucking idiot."

Agatha hesitated, drawing in a slow breath that quaked the smallest bit near the tail end. "So... I went every day when I knew she wouldn't notice. I checked on him, watched every day when I swept away the dirt as more and more of him just... disappeared. Sometimes it was from wildlife, but a lot of it I now know was nothing more than natural decay."

It probably should have been alarming the way Rio felt so calm as she sat and listened to Agatha recount a very awful core memory from her past, but she was only being so calm because Agatha was being so calm.

This was Agatha's life, near its beginning, and it had a very heavy impact on who she had grown into as a person.

Rio had half been expecting her to continue and half expecting her to get up and walk away. It wasn't that she seemed upset, but Rio could tell that she was unearthing more than Agatha had probably thought she might.

But, Rio reminded herself, it was within Agatha's control to decline to answer any question she asked. It was a rule that Agatha had instilled herself, likely telegraphing the nature of this conversation before it had started. So, it stood to reason that she was answering most of Rio's questions because she wanted to.

While still not brave enough to initiate a hold, Rio's right arm crossed over her body so that her fingers could brush gingerly along the length of Agatha's forearm in search of the next question she wanted to pose.

"Can I..." Rio cut herself off, tucking her bottom lip between her teeth in a harsh bite.

"Go on," Agatha urged her quietly, not moving away from Rio's touch, or her instinct to ask questions that Agatha had never thought she would have to answer in her life.

"Why did you start?"

That question dropped in Agatha's lap like a ten ton anvil, heavy and demanding of her attention.

Rio could feel, that time, as her muscles tightened and her breath hitched somewhere low in her chest. She did not jerk away, but she was suddenly tense and Rio could tell that Agatha hadn't been anticipating on her being so forward about it all.

Hadn't she learned anything? If Rio wanted to know something, she found a way to know it.

Agatha was quiet for long enough that it left Rio wondering why she just didn't say no and move it along. Why was she choosing to let the conversation between them just die instead of letting Rio redirect?

When Agatha drew in an impossibly slow breath through her nose, Rio realized it was because she had been searching for the right answer.

"Tofu's human was named Amanda. Amanda and I, despite being roommates, were pretty good friends. She was... a lot like you, actually. Not a mean bone in her body, but a morbid curiosity that she could never seem to satisfy," Agatha began to explain, though she was staring down at the space in front of her, a space that was filled a moment later as Phin slinked over, stretching out before their knees as they remained pressed together.

"Her boyfriend was... a real fucking piece of work. The first time she came home with a black eye, I told her I'd kill him for it. She always talked me down, said it would be fine. She was wrong. It was never fine because he killed her when I was supposed to be at work. I came home early that night because I got into it with a coworker." Agatha cleared her throat, but her voice stayed steely and did not waver.

"When I unlocked the door, he was choking her to death on the couch. Well, he had choked her to death on the couch. And I made good on my word. I went right up behind her just as he was letting her go and used every last muscle I had in my body to snap his neck. And then... I grabbed my shit, headed back to the house I said I'd never return to, and I... I..."

Agatha was fumbling, but Rio could immediately identify that she was not upset. No, Agatha was second guessing sharing more because it might cross a line that Rio could not be okay with. At least, that was most likely what Agatha thought. The truth of it was, Agatha could have told her anything and Rio was pretty sure it wouldn't have mattered.

"I had money and valuables stashed there. And when I showed up for them, my mother was less than thrilled that I decided to show my face. So, when she tried to physically stop me, I... Well, I suppose I dispatched her, too."

Finally, the pieces were presenting themselves and quickly, Rio was finding the ways they fit together.

Agatha had started running when she was barely 20 because of an impulsive series of decisions that had given her a thirst for justice. She'd gotten that vengeance, on both fronts, and so she sought to ensure that as few women as possible had to suffer at the hands of men like the one who took away her friend when she was younger.

So, as it turned out, Agatha could relate to Alice a little more than Rio had initially guessed. Perhaps that was why Rio's apology had been heard, as Agatha had promised her it had.

"You weren't wrong for the things you did," Rio voiced softly, though she was being genuine. "In the legal system, maybe, but... You removed two threats that had already dealt irreparable damage. I don't think you a bad person for that."

Agatha released a soft sound, one that could have been a chuckle, but wasn't quite a hum. Her gaze cast to the spot on her arm that Rio was still touching, grazing lightly.

It was clear that this conversation had reached its peak and they could slide safely down on the other side, but there was still one more thing Rio wanted to know.

"Agatha?" she breathed, fingers tracing further toward Agatha's wrist than they had before.

"Hm?" Agatha returned, lifting her head to peer over at Rio, those blue eyes looking a clearer window to Agatha's inner monologue than they ever had been before.

"What do you want? Out of life? Out of... this? Us?"

Agatha's jaw tensed and bulged on both sides, her lips pressing into a tight and flat line. It seemed as though she had known it was coming and yet, Rio actually asking her while looking directly at her had still caused her to snap shut like an agitated clam.

Instead of answering, Agatha turned it around on her.

"What is it that you want, Rio?" she asked, those eyes not daring to break the stare they were locked into.

That was easy.

"What I want is for you to know that you can trust me to take care of you," Rio returned easily, her expression soft as she delivered such a blatant truth for her.

"Whatever you will let that mean, one day I want you to believe that I can and will always handle you with care. It could be bringing you soup when you're sick, being close by when you're nervous about something. Or maybe someday, even as far as letting me be the one to strap you down," she added, and while she offered a disarming chuckle, she wasn't actually kidding.

Agatha was still silent, just listening to what it was Rio was saying. Slowly, her arm turned and her palm faced upward in the quietest give of permission. Recognizing it for what it was, Rio's touch continued on past Agatha's wrist, pressing their palms together before her fingers filled the spaces between Agatha's.

"What about today?" Agatha asked back, though she had diverted her attention to their hands together and began to chew on her lip the moment the question left her.

"You mean...?" Rio asked back, brow pinching in her confusion.

"Not right now... Because I do want to keep watching the movie... But maybe tonight?" Agatha's voice was so soft, almost like it was filled with shame, but there was no need for it.

She was growing. She was making choices because she knew that by doing so, Rio's image of her was not going to chance.

Rio leaned her weight against Agatha's side again, letting her head drop to rest on her shoulder as it had done earlier in the afternoon.

"Maybe tonight," Rio concurred, giving Agatha's hand the lightest squeeze.

There was another wordless moment between them before Agatha spoke again, clearly having redirected her attention back to the screen across the room.

"You know what my favorite thing about this movie is?" Agatha asked her.

Without lifting her head, Rio provided her answer.

"Tell me."

Agatha hummed a light laugh, reaching for a grape. "The ghost girl still finds a way to kill the bastard man that took her life."

Of course that was Agatha's favorite thing about it.

Of course it was.

I Don't Look At You, I Look Into You

What a lazy Sunday, indeed.

After their second film selection, Rio had suggested something she wasn't actually interested in. It was something to simply have on in the background as she took the ninety minutes it offered to curl into Agatha's side as much as she was allowed to take a light nap.

Agatha let her have it, even to the point of still being there when Rio stirred to the feeling of Phineas licking her finger to garner her attention. It seemed like a dick move as Agatha was petting him where he sat on the top of her thigh.

When she came more to her senses, Rio realized that how they were positioned, Agatha's hand had landed on her side. More than that, Rio was suddenly aware of the light brushing that her thumb was doing, a gentle back and forth as a little whisper that their conversation before Rio's nap had actually happened.

Her eyes flickered to the screen, the credits rolling from the film she had selected earlier.

Lifting her head, there was a grin sprouting on Rio's lips before she even asked her question. "Did you sit here and watch that whole movie?"

Agatha's gaze dropped to her and a sly smile gave her away prior to the little shrug she offered. "I had never watched it before. I like that it was very Bond style spy meets slapstick comedy. To maintain her sanity, Rio had to convince herself that Agatha could never love her back.

Wait.

Back?

What the fuck kind of thought was --

"It's okay," Rio dismissed half-heartedly, not really meaning it. "I can just skip a shower. I mean, its not like dead people have an acute sense of smell and Alice has a deviated septum. I should be fine."

"Rio," she murmured back admonishingly, "go shower. Work your nine to five, go grab your things and come back to see me off proper." Something like that.

Something like that.

More specifically, what feelings Agatha was capable of.

"Rio?"

"Yeah?" she returned, glancing over her shoulder to see Agatha pointing at something.

"You forgot your breakfast."

Work was... work.

That day was the first in Rio's career where she simply did not want to be there. Alice had brightened her morning of course, but even her chipper demeanor had not been enough to ease the yearning of being back in the condo, curled up in bed and spending her day lazing around with Agatha and Phineas.

After lunch, though, Alice definitely called her out. She'd been leaning over to gather a box of personal items and because she was not wearing her coat, the shirt she had put on that morning rode up just high enough to sell her out.

"Rio! Oh my GOD!" she squealed, shoving her last French fry into her mouth as she leapt to her feet and surged forward. "Did you have a dream about a really scarred guy with insane claws?! Because fuck!"

"Phin got me," she attempted, but by her tone of voice alone, Alice knew she was lying.

"You saw her again?!" she pressed, her eyes as bright and wide as her smile as Rio turned around.

Admittedly, Rio was also grinning.

"Yeah, I did," she conceded with a shrug, her lips not dropping from their brandishing of teeth.

"And she did that? Are you actually okay? First the hickeys and now that?"

Rio knew what Alice was asking, but it was not a conversation that she was ready to have yet. Whoever Agatha was, she had completely disrupted Rio's sense of self in the most insane way possible and yet, Rio wasn't bothered. Not in the slightest.

"Oh. Right. Sorry," Alice murmured in return, reaching up to rub the back of her neck which was likely just as pink as her cheeks.

Immediately, he snapped forward to turn it down, seemingly embarrassed.

"I'm sorry, ma'am," he offered with a brief glance over his shoulder.

"Don't be, turn it back up."

He didn't turn around to acknowledge her, but she could see his cheeks shift with his smile before he leaned to do just that.

"Goodnight, Francisco. Thank you for the lift."

"And to you as well, Ms. Vidal. Take care," he offered. It was a professional courtesy, but it was warm considering that he was a stranger and it was only the third time they had shared in the space of the car.

She knew that smell.

"Somehow, I knew you'd be thrilled," Agatha offered back with a haughty show of teeth.

She needed to find a way to push the night before out of her mind.

Placing herself on a endless running wheel of those thoughts would lend nothing useful to her work day and would instead only dig the hole deeper, the one she was trying to stay out of where she admitted that she missed Agatha.

Rio had told Agatha that she would miss her before she left, yes. While she had not been lying when she delivered the sentiment, Rio instead came to question if she had ever truly known what it was like to miss someone.

Every person on the planet could do it, could be something different in both the best and worst ways.

It was a choice.

Agatha always made choices, much in the way she gave Rio the availability to do so, as well.

She had been too willing to dismiss the idea that Agatha could ever want... more.

But as she knew, Agatha took what she wanted, and right then, she was making it clear that she wanted Rio.

Maybe there would never be a day when Agatha would admit to being capable of those deep, rich feelings like romance or true emotional connection, but for now, Agatha was copping to far more than Rio ever truly thought she'd have. That was something she could find peace in, and it was also something that offered her the sliver of comfort she needed to make it through the next week or so.

"Me too," Rio responded softly. It took a beat, but she felt the need for recovery; they had softened enough that she was certain Agatha might begin to ruminate if Rio did not provide her mind another avenue to travel down. "So maybe you'll have to show me when you get back just what that means."

That time, there was a thickness in the sound of her voice, an intentional layer of lust that coated every word.

"Don't think for a second I won't. And that is both a threat and a promise."

"Oooh, you've got me shaking in my skivvies," Rio teased back, gaze finally lifting to the camera as a pompous smirk curled her lips.

"More like pounding in your pussy," Agatha snorted in return before falling prey to a bout of laughter she could clearly not control.

"Yes, well," Rio offered with a light giggle of her own, "Imagine if I tried keep from orgasming until you got back."

"First off, don't put Alice through that misery. Second, if you tried to do that, you'd cum the moment we lock eyes from across the room. While it would be a massive ego boost, I want to at least touch you before that happens."

While it wasn't the most alluring conversation, Agatha was still finding a way to tie Rio into knots over the fact that she would have sold her soul just to feel Agatha's hand on her body right then. But, she had to be patient.

She had to be, as Agatha liked to call her, a good girl.

"Don't need to be even easier, do I?"

Their laughter together felt like the sweetest song, the most delightful melody that Rio had never wanted to let herself like as much as she did right then.

She could have tried to stop it, could have tried to rein in her feelings, but for the time being it seemed as though they were alright to wander around the pen, still contained but with a little more freedom.

They talked for another thirty minutes about the weather, about some of the cases Rio had seen that day. They talked about the culture where Agatha was and what she was doing to fill her down time. Finally, though, the time had come for Agatha to set about preparing for her day.

"You just want to go shower so you can fuck yourself," Rio jeered playfully, her smile growing despite not looking at the camera.

"It's not a crime," Agatha retorted, drawing yet another full laugh from Rio.

"Go, shower. Have a good day, Agatha. I'll talk to you tomorrow."

"Goodnight, Rio. Talk tomorrow."

When Rio hung up the phone, she was still grinning and fully aware that Agatha could see it. She didn't care. She was happy, and it was a direct result of Agatha's choices, the decisions she was willingly making.

She didn't need to get up and relocate to the bedroom, but as she did so with Phin at her heels, it was for only one reason.

The moment Rio reached the edge of the bed, she flung herself onto it and immediately buried her face into the pillow. Using it to muffle a sound she was sure no one else would have heard anyway, she squealed as long as she could and then rolled to her back, that same grin still stuck to her face as if it had no intention of leaving.

How could it? She was happy.

She was Agatha's and she was happy.

Tomorrow Always Happens Yesterday

By the time Rio woke up Saturday morning, the weight of her aloneness had finally settled heavy in her bones. She had talked to Agatha the night before until she fell asleep, letting her ramble on about work things until she simply hadn't be able to listen anymore.

It had been a little embarrassing, but Rio had asked her outright.

"I'm going to lay down, but... since it's Saturday and you're not leaving any time soon... Do you think we could just stay on the phone? If you're not busy I mean."

The moment it left her, Rio felt like an idiot. She felt like a needy teenager whose crush was finally paying attention to them for the first time. But that wasn't the case, was it?

Agatha had always been paying attention.

Even before they ever actually had a legitimate conversation, Agatha had taken to watching Rio the way Rio had been eyeing her the entire time. It had been a pre-game before they actually started the mental chess match they'd been playing, a way to read the opposition and attempt to deduce which way they might move.

Now, they had reached an understanding that instead of attempting to outmaneuver one another, they could move together and dominate the entire board.

It was still tricky to navigate, but Rio was loosening her hold on the idea that Agatha might bolt, given the right reason.

"I'll throw my AirPod in, as long as you don't mind listening to me bitch about work."

Agatha called it 'bitching,' but Rio quite liked the little tangents she went on when trying to work her way out of an unexpected hole. She used words Rio knew but did not understand, and her irritation waxed and waned only a couple of times before Rio finally dozed off.

That morning, she awoke to a text.

"I've gone to dinner with some colleagues, but I should be up a bit later tonight if you would prefer company for a little while."

But then, there was another below it.

"Did you know you talk in your sleep?"

That one made Rio pale about six shades.

Oh god . She did!?

She wanted to ask, to just type a message back of 'what the fuck did I say?!' but instead, Rio just rolled to her back, arm flopping out onto the bed with the phone still clutched in her hand. The very tips of her knuckles graced soft fur and an irritated rumbling sounded from Phineas.

In his new spot.

On Agatha's side of the bed.

"Phin, dude, what the fuck did I say last night?"

The only answer Phineas provided was a relocation from where he had been to curl against Rio's side with the quietest little chirp.

Well, if he wasn't going to tell her, she supposed if she really wanted to know, she had to ask the only other witness.

The message she typed went through about six variations before she finally settled on one, pressing send before she could overthink it again.

"What did I say?"

Awaiting a response, Rio busied herself with stroking Phin's fur and scrolling through Reddit for anything interesting. Before she found anything, Agatha texted back.

"You said 'but I like the green marbles,' and 'I think the cat ate all of the cheese.'"

The moment Rio read it, she burst into laughter. There she was, worried that she had professed her undying love to Agatha and really, she was talking about green marbles and missing cheese. As weird as it was, she wasn't all that upset. In fact, it was pretty fucking funny.

Still smiling to herself, Rio typed back a reply.

"Well, at least I didn't give up my SSN or bank PIN."

Agatha was fucking quick with her return.

"You mean ending in 9866? Who keeps their social security card in their wallet? And not even in the pocket where it won't fall out and land on someone's bathroom floor?"

Well, shit. Agatha was feeling feisty as fuck on that fine Saturday, wasn't she?

"My,  my. Someone's feeling... sassy? Oh! Wait! Are you drinking right now?! Are you still at dinner?!"

Rio's smile had amplified into a grin, knowing she had hit the nail directly on the head. Confirmation -- and inflation of her own ego for being able to clock it -- came only a moment later when Agatha sent another message.

"Dinner ended 40 minutes ago. I'm on the patio sharing a bottle of Kaoliang with Gina while we spend half the time on our phones. But the weather isn't miserable?"

Admittedly, Rio had no fucking clue what Kaoliang was. So, she threw it in to trusty Google search bar and had her answer within seconds. Taiwanese Liquor. Well, shit. Agatha was having one hell of a Saturday night.

Good for her.

"It's what? 8pm there?"

It was more of a request for clarification; Rio was honestly still half-asleep, but she had not been able to procrastinate when it came to responding to Agatha.

"Almost 8:30, but yes. So... Why are you awake at 7am on a Saturday morning?"

That was a fair question; Rio usually slept in to a normal hour of 9 or 10 on the weekends, but truthfully, her sleep had been off a bit the last week or so. It wasn't anyone's fault, but she woke up and while she knew she'd slept, it still felt as though she'd run a marathon through the night.

"I don't know, actually. But it's okay. I'm sure I'll find something to do. Haven't utilized the pool yet, so might put that on the agenda. But you, go! Enjoy your night with your wild liquor and the company of a like mind. I will talk to you in your morning."

When Agatha had one last message to offer, there was something deep within Rio's chest -- a part of her long since frozen over -- that warmed even the tiniest bit.

"Not the likeness I'd prefer, but I suppose I'm in no position to refute what little I have available."

Oh, so when Agatha was actually drunk drunk, she started waxing philosophical? Both adorable and good to know. Before Rio could get a dig in about it, another message rolled in.

"Do something fun today. If you don't want to drive, you can text Francisco and he will happily take you wherever you'd like. His number is 312-798-1180. Seriously, go get shitfaced with Alice or something. You've got a DD now. I'll check in when I wake up tomorrow."

It was sweet, too fucking sweet. Not only was it encouraging, but Rio could feel the emotion behind the text. Clearly she had been resigning herself to taking up space in the condo, but they both knew that it wasn't because she was taking her house sitting duties too seriously. It was because she just... needed the time to herself.

And then there was Alice.

She wasn't ready to spill every single bean to Alice, which was probably why she was going to her go through her weekend thinking that Rio was hours away visiting family. Because Rio had lied. To her friend. It had been a harmless lie, one that had no real consequence, but dishonesty wasn't a common currency Rio liked to use.

Yet, Rio still knew it was the right thing to do. She just needed the open air of not being perceived or judged for the decisions she was making, including practically living at Agatha's very expensive condo above the city for two weeks. She had thought she was finding it by secluding herself, but something else was happening, especially since Thursday night.

Rio had started to actually let herself miss Agatha. She had told Agatha it would happen, and it had been to prepare them both, but Rio had realized that there was no amount of preparation she could have done that would have made it any easier to digest.

So, Rio fired off one last text to bid Agatha a good rest of her night.

"I'll give it some consideration. Enjoy your kaoliang (yes, I definitely copied and pasted it) and your company. Sleep well."

Although Rio would have been fine with leaving it at that, there was another message that came in a couple of minutes later.

"I will. Also, there will be another grocery delivery at 11am tomorrow. I ordered Phineas some treats this time. He's funny to watch when you're at work and he deserves a snack for the entertainment. Night, Rio."

It was funny, reading the word 'night' as a closure to a conversation when it was not even eight in the morning, but it was just one more thing that put a smile on Rio's face. It was a smile she found herself wearing for most of the morning as she showered and made herself a breakfast of eggs and chorizo that she'd found in the refrigerator. After grilling up a few tortillas, she gathered her bounty and turned to her three placement options.

Living room was already out. She didn't like the idea of eating in Agatha's living room, even if she consistently ate in her own.

So, that left two.

The table or the island.

Thinking it brave, Rio chose the table.

Three bites in, she picked her things up and relocated to one of the stools perched at the edge of the black marble island countertop so that she could resume her meal.

Rio left the table because she hated it. She hated how big it was, how empty it was. She hated that it was meant for so many and yet, Agatha confessed to occupying it alone. Rio had wanted to ask her a few times when the last time anyone else had sat at it was, but she was considerate enough to understand that it might touch a nerve to do so.

Agatha kept it for a reason. Rio might never understand the reason, but what she did understand was that there was one and that was all that mattered.

That was who Agatha was, she was realizing. She was someone with rationale, someone who could provide motivations for almost every single fucking thing she did.

Agatha was intentional. She made her decisions not based on the moment or a feeling, but because they were things that got considered, things that had some form of meaning, one way or another.

It made Rio think about the story Agatha had told her about the cameras and the two maids she had fired. She would have had every reason to be angry, to lash out for what they had done. But... Agatha was not spiteful for the wrong reasons, nor did she wish to unjustly punish someone for a minor crime of simply being needy. She could have berated them, claimed she paid them enough for them to steal from her, but Rio sensed that wasn't how that particular conversation had gone down.

No, Agatha chose to help. Because in her eyes, that was what she was doing. She helped by having an expansive and thorough career where she invested her intellect into literal space travel. She helped by eliminating threats because no one else could or would. She helped by showing compassion to those worthy.

And Rio understood finally that Agatha seemed to think her worthy.

She didn't know it, but that would make itself clear by the end of her day.

After her breakfast, Rio had done... not much at all. She considered going for a swim, but then talked herself out of it by saying she could do it another time, that she just didn't feel like it. The truth was that she simply didn't have the energy. It was this mild sense of lethargy that had taken her over, something she hadn't been able to fight off despite her best efforts.

What Rio considered the cause?

General work stress and her inability to get a good night's sleep.

The actual cause?

Her inability to get a good night's sleep, yes, but also her inability to truly rest even in those quieter moments. Her mind was churning constantly, a spin cycle of the same fifty thoughts over and over again. Not all of it was bad, and most of it wasn't, but it had been some time since Rio had truly put herself in a position to emotionally invest into another person. Choosing to do so with Agatha, in whatever capacity, felt like a risk she knew she shouldn't take.

But, as had rung true until those moments, Rio would continue to risk it every single time when it came to Agatha.

Because even if Agatha herself didn't see it, Rio saw in her every single reason it was worth it.

So she carried on about her day, getting a three word text around two in the afternoon.

"Goodngiht. I'm sleep."

So, apparently Agatha had polished off that bottle after all.

The thought of a very drunk Agatha spilling into some ritzy hotel in another country to land face-first in bed kept Rio amused, despite her outward appearance of not doing much at all. It was just television or movies, petting Phin, eating snacks. It wasn't like her to be so idle and yet, the stillness seemed to offer some form of gentle respite from the relentless overworking her mind had been doing.

Instead of letting herself anxiously twist over the endless possibilities, she chose to exist in what she had. It was peaceful, and it was quiet, even if it was lonely. By 6pm that night, however, it appeared as though her stillness had not gone unnoticed.

The moment the phone began to ring, Rio scooped it up and answered immediately as a warm smile found her lips.

"Now, ma'am, why are you up at seven in the morning on a Sunday?" Rio poked gently, trying not to let herself get lost in the idea that the very first thing Agatha had done when she woke up was call her.

When Agatha responded, it was after a yawn and her voice still sounded soaked with sleep. "V'been up since five. Had three cups of coffee. I might actually still be a little drunk." She maintained that tightly bound demeanor, even half-asleep but simultaneously caffeinated and hungover but simultaneously still drunk.

"And what's kept you from going back to sleep?" Rio asked through a light tone. It was meant to both care and tease, but Agatha's silence made a strange twisting happen somewhere in Rio's chest when it followed.

Rio almost asked if she had fallen asleep, but Agatha finally broke through, her soft voice landing right in Rio's ear as it passed through the earpiece of the phone.

"You. And how I know you'll say nothing's wrong, but... I know you won't leave tonight. I know you won't text Alice, or go to a bar. So..." Agatha paused and cleared her throat, though she was quiet a moment longer as she took a drink of her coffee. "I think you should invite her over."

Even though Rio was deathly aware that Agatha was being serious, it did not hinder the knee-jerk reaction she had to what Agatha had just said.

Rio laughed.

It was boisterous and amused, loud and clearly entertained.

But then, Rio realized, she was laughing alone.

Agatha really meant it. She truly wanted Rio to call her best friend, bring her over, and spend time with her in Agatha's home. Rio realized that the reason it had struck her to laugh was because the idea that Agatha was making yet another concession for her actually made her feel mildly guilty.

"Agatha, that's... No, you don't have to do that." Rio was trying to be reasonable, trying to get Agatha to see that she did not have to keep offering things that she wouldn't otherwise offer to anyone else.

But Rio didn't see it: Agatha would never have made those choices for anyone else, because anyone else could never be who Rio was.

"You're right. I don't. But I'm offering anyway because I have thought a lot about what you've had to keep from her and... She's your best friend. I know we are both of the understanding that you cannot tell her every single thing... But you shouldn't have to hide everything." Rio had once assumed that Agatha did not actually understand human connection and relationships in a way that would lend positively to her wanting those things, but it was just that; an assumption.

Clearly, Agatha did understand those things, but in a way that made her wary of attaining them for herself. She understood the complexities of trust and loyalty, the way they bonded people in even a platonic manner.

"I guess the point here is that I'm not trying to isolate you from your life. I don't want you to think that in keeping my secrets, you have to shut out what you already had. So... keep a few less and take Alice for a swim." Agatha paused, humming in thought for just a moment before she continued. "And I don't mind if you'd prefer to watch movies in the bedroom, but I do ask that she sleep in the spare room."

Rio was trying to keep up, to process the things Agatha was saying and the metaphorical volume that she was choosing to broadcast her message. Agatha was handing her freedom that she didn't necessarily need but could benefit from, but she was still being overt about her boundaries. Maybe she saw that Rio had zero attraction to Alice and vice-versa, but there was still a line of respect that she wanted left uncrossed.

Rio could honor that with ease.

"You... You know I'm okay, right?" Rio asked in return, a tight conviction in her tone.

"Yes, Rio, I know you are just fine and dandy. But... a little company won't kill you. Plus, I wanna watch her reaction for my own entertainment value. So, call it selfish if it makes you quit pouting like that. Or not. Show me more of that lip I can't wait to bite." Somehow, Agatha maintained this careful balance of being genuine, being ornery, and being annoyingly sexy in a way that Rio knew she could never cut herself off from.

Her eyes lifted to the camera in the corner and she did just that, pushing her lip out that much more in taunting.

"Really, though. Go get her. Enjoy the rest of your night with her, and tomorrow too. Fuck it, carpool Monday morning. Point being... Have fun, Rio. Stop hiding away and maybe take Phin with you to go get her. Let that boy feel the wind in his fur." The longer Agatha spoke, the more prevalent the laugher she was trying to bite back became. It was truly humored and light, a show that she knew how to poke fun and joke and yet still make it mean something.

"Okay, okay, you've convinced me."

"I didn't doubt that I would."

With a gentle but content sigh, Rio's eyes raised to the corner camera again. "I don't know if you're watching, but... Thank you. It's not a necessity, but the insistence is appreciated. I'll message you later, yeah?"

"Please do. But if she passes out in the foyer, I might message you first." That time, Agatha didn't even try to temper her laughter.

"Please do. Bye, Agatha. Talk to you later."

"Have a good evening, Rio."

The call ended and yet, Rio still sat there and stared at that camera with the widest smile on her face. Agatha didn't need to open the doors of her home to someone who was essentially a stranger, but Rio had given her enough pieces to understand that Alice would always be more friend than foe. More than that, Agatha had verbally recognized that Alice was someone important to Rio, someone that Rio had been feeding a great deal of misinformation to solely to protect the Agatha behind the Amelia, and maybe to protect Amelia, too.

Perhaps Rio had severely underestimated two things: 1) Just how much Agatha paid attention, and 2) Just how much Agatha actually cared.

Agatha was never going to show her attention in blatant or unnecessary hand holding or in snuggles on the couch, and that was okay. Rio had never really thought that she would. What Agatha was going to do was make informed decisions that provided a benefit to Rio, if not to both of them.

With that very fact in mind, Rio dressed herself and put Phin's harness on so they could descend to the parking garage. Once situated in the car, Rio pulled her phone out -- her actual phone -- and typed a message to Alice.

"Didn't go to Peoria. Coming to get you if you're home. I have to stop at my place first to grab something, but that only buys you an extra fifteen minutes. Oh, and bring a bathing suit."

Rio grinned and dropped her phone into the cupholder, setting off to her first destination: home.

She needed a bathing suit, too.

It had been intentional, the way she had not grabbed one the night she'd stopped for her things, but with company set to join her, she somehow imagined that both Agatha and Alice might not be too thrilled with her skinny dipping.

By the time she ran inside and returned to the car, laughing at the sight of Phineas perched so he could look out the driver's side window at her, Alice had texted her back.

"Um. Okay? We're staying in a hotel?"

Of course she was confused. Rio had been vague on purpose because while she had been given permission to share a little more of what she had been keeping close to the vest, there was still a sense of fun to be had when it came to shocking the shit out of her best friend.

"Something like that. So a change of clothes might also be a good idea."

Rio started the car again, but before she could put it in drive, another message came through from Alice.

"You're being really fucking weird. But I'll see you shortly."

With a chuckle, Rio fired back one more response.

"When am I not? Leaving mine now, see you soon!"

One more, with her phone dropping into its designated spot, Rio backed out of her space and took off toward Alice's, reaching her destination a good ten minutes later. When she pulled into the drive, Alice was already out front waiting, a small bag slung over her shoulder but a large grin on her face. She clearly knew Rio was up to something, she just didn't know what.

Rio pulled Phin into her lap long enough for Alice to climb in and immediately gave him to her to confine while Rio drove them to where it was they were headed.

"So are you going to tell me where we are going?" Alice questioned as she reached around the cat to fasten her seatbelt.

With a grin as she put the car in reverse, Rio looked over to her. "You won't believe me if I tell you, so you'll just have to wait until we get there."

Alice rolled her eyes, but chose resignation nonetheless.

"This whole new mysterious side of you is actually annoying as hell only because I'm used to you calling me and being like 'WE'RE GOING TO WRIGLEY NOT BECAUSE WE CARE ABOUT BASEBALL BUT BECAUSE I GOT FREE BEER TICKETS!' Not being all sneaky and sly," she commented as Rio began to speed up as she drove down the street.

Their chit-chat was light and rather funny as they ventured back toward the heart of the city. The moment that Rio turned a new direction, Alice seemed to be on alert, waiting to find out where their actual destination would be.

When she got close enough to Water Tower Place that she had no other option than to be in the lane that turned into the parking garage, Alice whipped on her, quick as a bolt.

"What the fuck are we doing here? Going swimming at a mall?" came Alice's interrogation, but she was grinning like a madwoman.

"No," Rio responded with ease. "We're going swimming on the 72nd floor."

"Rio. Shut the fuck up," Alice fired back, her eyes wide. "What the fuck does that even mean?!"

"It means that Amelia asked me to house sit while she's out of the country. And she gave me permission a little bit ago to invite you over. So... We're having a slumber party." It was a factual series of statements, but she could tell without even looking at Alice that Alice though she was full of shit.

"Rio, condos in this building cost millions of fucking dollars. What do you mean she lives here?!"

Alice was nearly screeching at her to the point that Phineas stirred in her lap and stretched out along her torso, one of his paws landing on her chin as though he were reminding her they were in an enclosed space and she did not need to be so loud.

Both Rio and Alice laughed at the same time as Rio quickly returned to Agatha's reserved parking space -- which Rio thought hilarious given that she wasn't even sure Agatha owned a car -- and shut the car off. When she pulled the keycard for the elevator out and held it up for Alice to see, she was wearing a devious little grin that she could not fight off.

"Up we go! You got Phin or do you want me to take him?"

With a scratch to the top of his head, Alice offered her answer. "He behaves for Auntie Alice. I can walk him in."

That being settled, the three of them unloaded and headed for the elevator. When Rio swiped the keycard and the elevator began to move -- with Phineas starting up his yowling and pacing -- Alice cut to Rio with wide eyes, having no choice but to believe her. With a shit-eating grin and a shrug to match, she simply enjoyed the ride and the obnoxious howling her cat was doing along the way.

The very moment the doors slid open, Rio unclipped Phineas' lead and he bolted off into the apartment, likely to find somewhere he could recover from the stress the elevator ride had induced within him.

Then, Alice looked around the edge of the door and nearly passed all the way the fuck out.

"What the..." she breathed, stepping out of the elevator and into the spacious and lavish condo. She was clearly verklempt, which was obvious by the fact that he mouth was hanging open as the direct result of her awe. "What the actual fuck is this, Rio?"

Rio was trailing behind her, beaming like a complete idiot as she simply watched Alice, studying every bit of her wonder. The main living space alone was obvious in its grandeur, but Rio knew just how much existed within that home that was most likely going to blow Alice away.

"You mean to seriously tell me that she lives here?" This time, Alice's head swiveled so that she could pin Rio with an incredulous and questioning gaze, needing some kind of clarification.

"She does," Rio answered with a nod. "And I believe I am allowed to inform you that she works for an aerospace company. Can't say much more, but... It might help explain..." Rio lifted a hand, waving it around to indicate the entirety of the condo, "...all of this."

"...You're telling me she's a fucking rocket scientist, too?! " Alice returned, completely disbelieving.

"Yup. And trust me, when she told me, I did not believe her." She was laughing, but she meant it. When Agatha had voiced it, it had truly seemed like a joke. Now, though, she knew better. Now, she knew that while Agatha had attained the career on the back of a scam, it was something she had sunk a great deal of her life into. It made Agatha happy.

"Okay, who the fuck actually is this woman?" Alice asked it, but she had already turned back around to venture forth and explore.

"Amelia Cohen. That's what you can call her. And Google actually has a fuck ton of results. So... Yeah," Rio offered in answer, shrugging again even though Alice wasn't looking at her.

As Alice paced over to the wall of windows, Rio could tell that she was actually speechless. Her eyes cast out to the water, just watching for the longest moment before she turned back to Rio, who was posted at the end of the couch, smile still stuck as if it had no plans of leaving.

"Have you..." Alice began, but then stopped herself to chew momentarily on her bottom lip. "You've been staying here this week? Not actually planning on going to Peoria?"

That stuck smile was not quite as permanent as she had hoped it might be, her lips turning down as she realized what Alice was asking. With a sliver of shame wrapping around her spine, Rio shook her head.

"I wasn't sure what I was allowed to say, especially after that day at work. And... I just... Don't really have the energy to go out and be a heathen for the time being. So... I'm sorry I lied, but I really do hope that you'll spend the night with me."

Alice's expression hadn't been injured or hurt, but it did convey that it felt odd to accept that Rio had been dishonest with her.

"I'll stay," Alice agreed with a singular nod. "But on one condition. Well... Two conditions."

Rio felt the nerves creep in at being offered ultimatums, but when Alice's lips split apart in a wide smile, they ebbed their way right back out.

"Go on," Rio encouraged, tipping her head.

"One: You owe me a tour. Two: You have to tell me what you're allowed to. That's it."

Actually... Those were two very fair asks that Rio could accommodate. The second would require a bit of a back and forth with Agatha to establish ground rules of what could be said and what was too much, but it was still easily manageable.
