"I think I can do both of those," Rio offered. She stepped away from the couch to move toward Alice, but Alice beat her to it and approached her with open arms, pulling her into a hug.

"I'm not upset. I get it. But..." Alice put her hands on Rio's shoulders and pulled back, looking at her at arm's length. "I know it had to be fucking killing you to not tell me about this."

Rio sagged slightly in Alice's hold, primarily out of relief.  "Oh, in the most ironic way. But... killing me to not tell you would provide a lot less danger than her actually killing me if I fucked up again." The laugh she tacked on at the end was indicative that she absolutely did not think Agatha would actually kill her, even if she fucked up.

In fact, hadn't Agatha already proved to her that even when she did fuck up, forgiveness was an option?

Taking a step back, Rio clapped her hands together before letting her gaze sweep the room. "Tour then!"

Wearing a bright and relieved grin, Rio showed Alice around the condo much in the way Agatha had shown her the week before. The art room, the spare room where Alice would be staying, and lastly the pool, which had drawn a massive reaction from her friend.

"Noooooo fucking way. And it's like... a legit fucking pool, too!" Alice remarked as she moved further into the room, marveling at all that it was.

"Fun fact: She told me she actually bought this place from Oprah. And again, at first I thought she was full of shit. But then she added in that she conned Oprah into leaving it furnished for an extra two mil... Then sold everything to get her money back and an additional six million. So... I think she meant it." By the time she finished, the humor over it found her again, causing her to laugh.

"You know, I'd say that when you shoot, you shoot for the stars, but your last three relationships have been... absolute duds." Alice paused, turning around to face Rio with an apologetic look on her face. "Sorry, not to imply that you're in a relationship with her or anything. But..."

"No! It's okay," Rio assured her, waving her over so they could exit the pool room and tend to filling their evening with food and films and friendship. "I don't know that I'd call it a relationship... But she considers me hers, and I like that. So. We're just... us, for now. I guess."

She shut the door behind them, leading Alice toward the kitchen once more so that she could grab one of the pizzas out of the freezer to throw in the oven for them.

"Well, I'm happy for you, as long as you're happy." It was sweet, and it was how friends should support each other, but it was how Alice always supported Rio. She could make bad choices, do stupid things, but at the end of the day, Alice still loved her and would always help her through whatever predicament she got herself into.

"I'm very happy, Alice. I promise."

While they waited for the pizza to bake, Rio took the time to show Alice the few other things about the home that were exceptional, like the massive fucking TV in the wall. Alice had simply stared at it for the longest time before asking if it was real, which sent Rio into another fit of amused giggles.

"How did you not die when you turned up here the first time?" Alice almost demanded in question, though she was clearly thrilled that this was the life Rio currently found herself living.

"I almost did. For more than one reason. Ahem." Rio grinned and plopped down on the couch, spending the remainder of the time it took the pizza to cook scrolling through shows and not actually deciding on one while they each argued their own choices.

Truthfully, it felt good to be there with Alice. Rio had known that Agatha might have considered the risk she was taking in facilitating it all, but she was thankful for the chance to atone for the way she'd been feeling like a poor friend. Alice wouldn't have even thought to acknowledge it, but Rio was self-aware enough to recognize her shortcomings.

So, they ate their pizza and they watched a foreign film Alice had chosen -- thinking it was going to surprise Rio, but when 'A Tale of Two Sisters' appeared at the bottom in English subtitles and Rio squealed her appreciation -- from the large dining room table.

It was one of Rio's favorite films, one that gave her goosebumps every single time no matter how many rewatches she sat through. The story, the shots, the acting. Every bit of it was like a comfort to Rio in the most macabre way. It was something she found familiarity in for a plethora of reasons. It was even better when they relocated to the living room, able to appreciate it close up.

When the credits began to roll a short while later, Alice turned to Rio expectantly, a warm smile on her face, though there was the tiniest shimmer of mischief in her eyes.

"So... I've been curious... And you can absolutely tell me to fuck off, but..." she began, her smile growing. "Ever since you came in with the hickeys -- so unlike you by the way -- you've... been different. Not bad different! But more like..."

Alice was fumbling, her dark eyes skipping from point to point on Rio's face in her worry that she might say something offensive. Considering all the talks they'd had over the years about anything and everything, Rio couldn't tell where the hesitance is coming from.

"You're getting so fucked. Not the other way around. It's literally bleeding out of you. So... I guess it just makes me wonder... Why her?"

Rio knew what Alice was asking, and while she had often asked herself the same question, she wasn't sure that she had ever actually found an answer. At least, she had not found a logical answer.

Why was she comfortable enough to let Agatha have access to her body in a way very few others ever had?

It wasn't about power dynamics or who was 'in charge.' It was simply that with Agatha, Rio just felt comfortable. There was relief over repulsion in the way Agatha touched her, wanted her, would completely wreck her and still handle her with some modicum of respect.

With a light shrug, Rio leaned forward and picked up her mostly empty beer, trying to down what few drops remained as if it might help her find the right words. She was grinning as she looked to her friend once more.

"Why not her? Nothing else about her makes sense... so why should that? It's cute that you noticed, though." Still smiling, Rio slumped over, letting her head rest on Alice's shoulder.

"Yeah, well, I tried not to assume when it looked like you'd been punched in the chest by a horde of babies. But the scratches kind of gave you away."

Rio almost said it. She almost opened her mouth to voice the thought that those were earned through her being the one doing the fucking, but she left it unsaid. Instead, she gave Alice's leg a light pat.

"I think I'm going to call it a night. Please, help yourself if you get peckish. The fridge will be restocked in the morning." With another tip of her head, one that caused hers to bump directly into Alice's, Rio pushed to her feet and stretched out. "Goodnight, Alice. Thank you for coming over and staying with me. I really appreciate it."

"Of course Rio," Alice returned, climbing to her feet as well. With an exchange of waves, they started to separate, but just before Alice tucked into the spare room, Rio heard her melodious singing coming from the other side of the condo.

"Thank you for being a friend!"

With a laugh as she began to shut the door to the bedroom, Rio rolled her eyes.

"Goodnight, Blanche!" she called.

"Goodnight, Rose!"

Note to Self: I Miss You Terribly

When Rio came-to Sunday morning, it was only because her phone was ringing, and had been for the last several minutes. She was hoping she could ignore it, that whoever it was would just leave a message and she could call them back later.

That might have been reasonable if it had been her phone that was ringing.

But it wasn't.

The burner had been ringing and dinging incessantly. By the time she was awake enough to register the sound of the ringtone, Agatha had already called four times and texted eight. Upon seeing the long list, Rio immediately dialed back, not even having checked the time. The moment the line clicked to life, Rio's sleepy mumblings were falling from her before she could think to word them better.

"Where's the fire?" she grumbled, covering her face with the hand that wasn't pressing the phone to her ear.

"No fire, but groceries are there. The front desk staff informed me the elevator has returned twice, still full." Agatha didn't sound angry, but she didn't sound happy, either. When Rio lowered the phone to check the time, she realized why.

For Agatha, it was almost one in the morning on a Monday and she had to work later that day. For Rio, it wasn't even noon and was still Sunday.

"Fuck, I'm so sorry. I forgot to set an alarm," Rio apologized, quickly scrambling out of bed to make it out to the elevator. Thankfully, the rest of the condo seemed empty for the time being, a respite in that Rio did not have to face Alice immediately upon rousing, or any further interrogation she might have had.

One fire at a time.

Currently, it was bringing everything in so that she could let Agatha off the phone to permit her to go to sleep.

"One too many last night, then?" Agatha prodded, but Rio knew if she truly wanted an answer to that, all she had to do was watch the security footage from the night before.

Maybe she would learn a thing or two Rio might have considered to be previously held close to her chest, but she would see that Rio's exhaustion came from nothing other than comfort and how much of it she felt residing in that condo, even in Agatha's absence.

"No, just couldn't fall asleep. Once I did, I apparently could not wake up." It was a simple enough answer, but it also gave her an out, one where she didn't have to admit that even though it was nice to have company in the form of Alice, a week without Agatha around was...

It was agony, if she allowed herself to be dramatic.

Going days, sometimes a week or so, without seeing Agatha and not knowing where she was or what she was doing was one thing. It had been an irritation, an annoyance, but it hadn't been enough to actually instill any form of deeply seated yearning. Now, knowing where Agatha was and knowing she wasn't going to randomly turn up and put her hand around Rio's throat and kiss her until it hurt, it was maddening, frustrating.

On one side of the page, Rio had been allowed far enough into Agatha's life to be able to miss her. On the other side of that same page, nothing could have ever prepared her for the totality of who Agatha -- or, in this case, Amelia -- actually was and what her life entailed. With the certainty of her location came the understanding that there were still days between them, days when they would have to resort to phone calls and text messages to make the distance manageable.

"Should I be giving wake up calls, then?" came a light cajoling over the line, though it was hard to take serious with the way it broke up at the end as Agatha yawned.

With the phone pinned to her ear using her shoulder, Rio collected the bags and relocated them to the island in the kitchen. The moment she was sure nothing was going to fall and break, she straightened up again and took hold of the phone, her gentle but dark gaze flickering to the camera in the dining room.

"You can call me whenever you wish. Isn't that the whole point of the burner phone being the best morning after gift?" Her tone was rich with her teasing, but something else happened the next second.

For just a moment, Rio hesitated. She could have tucked back into the bedroom to finish her conversation with Agatha before coaxing her to get some rest before work, but instead, she posed a quiet question.

"Are you watching?"

Immediately, the way Agatha's breath caught was audible; she'd been busted. It had truly been a question that stemmed primarily from curiosity, but drawing such a reaction caused a smirk to curl Rio's lips.

"I will take that as a yes." With the intent to usher Agatha off to sleep over the course of the following few minutes, Rio left the groceries unattended for the time being. Surely they'd be fine for the time it took to persuade Agatha to get in bed. She paced forward, down the length of that ridiculous dining room table, finding a suitable place to lean on the corner, leaving her perfectly angled toward the camera that was mounted in the corner.

"What do I need to do to convince you to try and get some shut-eye before you work in the morning?" Rio asked her, the question low and tapered, meant to go no further than the few feet of cubic space around her. Even if Alice did wake up, it wasn't exactly a conversation Rio wanted overheard, but perhaps not for the reasons Alice might have thought.

Agatha was quiet for the longest few moment, almost long enough that Rio began to think she was asleep. And then, her tired voice flittered softly over the line.

"Tell me something," came the soft request.

"Anything, my queen," Rio teased in return, her gaze still locked on that black shiny lens of the camera on the ceiling.

"What was the best piece of work you did while you were doing taxidermy?"

Although she tried really hard not to, Rio laughed. It was a light bark, but it wasn't loud. It was simply an indicator that of all the things Agatha could have asked her, the one she chose was also the most unexpected.

"Are you asking because you want to be bored to sleep?"

That time, Agatha was the one to breathe a warm laugh, one that caused Rio's heart to thud a little harder in her chest.

God, she was a fucking idiot.

Her heart was fluttering, or skipping beats, or doing whatever stupid thing it did when it felt some unruly form of affection. The more maddening part was that it was doing it in response to the sounds of joy from someone Rio knew was dangerous to covet.

"No," Agatha finally answered, though her voice had dropped a little more in a sign that the exhaustion was beginning to pull her under. "I want to hear what it sounds like when you talk about something that you're proud of."

Rio bit her tongue. She wanted to ask Agatha if she'd been listening, but that felt a little misplaced given the moment they were occupying in time; it wasn't the one where she needed to remind Agatha that she was proud of her . Before she could form an actual answer, there was a soft 'click' over the phone line just before another gasped yawn sounded from Agatha. If Rio had to guess, she had closed the laptop and was finally giving in to sleep.

"It was senior year, a fox. I had seen... some truly nightmarish stuff," Rio began, though she pushed off the table to retreat toward the bedroom. She was pretty certain Agatha was settling in, but just in case, taking the temptation to stay focused on the screen didn't seem to be the worst idea.

The moment Rio's gaze landed on the bed, an instant grin filled her face at the sight of Phineas curled up on Agatha's pillow. "Sorry, I'll finish in a second. It's... I know you can't see in here, but now feels like a good time to let you know that Phineas has been pretty attached to your side of the bed the last couple of days."

A soft but content hum sounded from the speaker as Rio climbed onto the bed and nestled into the mattress, flat on her back with the phone still held to her ear.

"I told you," Agatha jeered sleepily. She was trying so hard to be a menace, but it was clear that she was tired.

"Told me what?" Rio questioned back, her brow knitting slightly.

"That I'd win him over. Just didn't think I'd have to fly a million miles away to do it." She sounded confident, maybe even arrogant, but Rio would let her have it. It had been clear for a little while now that while this connection between them wasn't exactly an area of comfort, or even somewhere Agatha occupied space much before they'd met, she wanted it to be.

"I just think he's ready for you to be back," Rio offered simply, although it was anything but. If she had thought she could get away with it and pass it off as innocent, she realized her misstep the moment Agatha spoke again.

"Is he the only one?"

That one little question was quiet, and while Rio knew Agatha would blame it on being tired, it sounded the slightest bit... vulnerable, too.

"You know he's not, Agatha," Rio chastised. It held no edge, was not loud, but it was heartfelt and Rio meant it.

There was a lull over the line, an eerie silence that befell them, one that almost made Rio ask if she had said something wrong.  She was parsing out the right way to say it when Agatha startled her despite the fact that her voice was barely loud enough to be heard over the line.

"You're right. Because I'm ready to be back, too."

Rio waited for her to continue, to offering some quippy addendum that might harden the edges of such a sentiment, but nothing came. In fact, the grogginess in that statement alone should have told Rio what was coming next, but she offered a return nonetheless.

"I'm ready, too. I..." Rio paused, her lips sealing tightly in a line that turned them white around the edges. "I miss you, Agatha."

For every taunt or jab or inveigling that Rio had assumed Agatha would offer, she was almost unsettled at the lack of response. And then, she realized she had gotten what she'd been after since the moment Agatha had called and Rio realized how late it was for her and why , exactly, she was awake at such an unholy hour:

Agatha had finally fallen asleep.

Instead of immediately hanging up, Rio let the tables turn for once. For several long but peaceful moments, she simply tapped the speaker button and set the phone down next to her head on the pillow, a little closer to her than it was to Phin where he rested on Agatha's half of the bed.

For a good ten minutes, Rio simply let herself listen. It was a soft rhythm without a melody, just the steady in and out of Agatha's slumbered breathing. It was serene, it was calming, but it was also a reminder of why Rio was where she was, and what it was she was waiting for.

Maybe nothing about them made sense. Maybe it was foolish to think that there could ever be a version of their entanglement that wound up being long-term. Maybe all of that was true, but as Rio finally lifted up the burner to disconnect the call when the smell off Alice making coffee began to waft in from the kitchen, none of it actually mattered.

What did matter was that Agatha brought something to her life that was new, it was invigorating, stimulating even. In a world where Rio had fallen prey to the mundane of a day-to-day, Agatha had reminded her what it was to be curious, to chase answers and have little regard for the consequences. Agatha had managed to breathe life back into Rio... by killing people.

Perhaps a day might come when Rio actually cared how insane that was at its core, but it was not that Sunday, midday, as she tucked the burner phone in the nightstand drawer to meet her best friend in the kitchen for a cup of coffee.

They spent the rest of the day oscillating between lounging, snacking, and swimming, just cycling through until the time came for Alice to decide whether or not she was going to stay another night. Surprisingly, she had offered a thought for consideration.

"Should you ask her if it's okay? I know it's just one more night, but..."

The way Alice posed the question, it was a genuine respect for the fact that Agatha had already let her spend time in a space that was sacred to her. It was clear that the last thing she wanted to do was intrude and overstay her welcome; that feeling was rooted firmly in her friendship with Rio. They were both completely aware what they had been given in the form of the weekend together, but Alice did not want to push any boundaries on Rio's behalf.

Even more, it was an amends, an olive branch of sorts after what had happened at the morgue that day, the first and last time Agatha and Alice had been in the same room.

Checking the time, Rio was suddenly aware that she likely had a message or two waiting for her when she dug the burner back out. Agatha hadn't specifically told her what time she had to be up, but with it being... roughly nine in the morning? Rio had a feeling she was tossing back her morning coffee before whisking off to work.

"Be right back." With a lone finger begging a pardon, Rio pushed to her feet and quickly retrieved the phone, returning only a moment later as she swiped up on the screen. As predicted, there were two texts awaiting her.

The first one was from an hour before.

"There is not enough caffeine in the world to make this Monday bearable. Hope yours is better tomorrow."

Then, one from only a few minutes prior.

"I have been behaving myself and trying not to check in. So, if Alice hasn't left yet, just carpool to work tomorrow. No sense in making her go home tonight."

With a soft chuckle, Rio shook her head.

"What is it?" Alice inquired, though she didn't lean forward in an attempt to steal a glance at the phone. No, she had definitely learned her lesson there.

"She informed me that if I have not taken you home yet that we should just ride to work together tomorrow," Rio paraphrased, lifting her focus to land on her best friend, a warm smile curling her lips.

"You didn't even have to ask?" Alice questioned, brows hiking in earnest.

For a moment, Rio let herself understand why that might be so surprising.

It was because it was kind. It was sweet. It was intuitive and thoughtful. Given the fact that both Rio and Alice knew what Agatha did for a hobby, it was understandable why such softness could be considered suspect so easily, at least from Alice's perspective.

In addition, Rio understood that all Alice had to say was that it was very loving and attentive and she would have been put into a box that she could not climb back out of. It was a box where she would have to admit attachment to Agatha, to a literal murderer. It was more than just attachment, though, and that was what made it so fucking dangerous.

Rio wasn't ready to tell Alice -- hell, she wasn't ready to admit it to herself -- but she knew that she'd started feeling things for Agatha, things that would not be pliable enough to shove back inside if they got out.

For all the concessions it seemed that Agatha was willing to make, Rio simply could not bear the thought of running her off simply because she could not police her own emotions.

"She's very... observant," Rio attempted to explain, a soft chuckle leaving her.

"Or the security guy downstairs told her we haven't left since we got here," Alice shot back, dissolving into light laughter.

"That too," Rio agreed with a shrug, but was quick to redirect the conversation. "So... in any event... What movie should we watch now?"

With Alice decidedly staying one more night, the two of them settled in with glasses of wine and a bowl of berries to watch a Canadian film that was mostly in French, one that left Rio in silent tears by the credit scene.

"Alright," she voiced as she wiped at her cheeks and pushed off the couch. "I'm officially mad as fuck at you for that and am gonna go pout in bed until we have to be up for work in the morning." The words Rio chose said one thing, but the smile she offered said something else. It had been a beautiful film, but it emotionally struck Rio in every sore spot she had and while it left her feeling a bit raw, she did appreciate the suggestion.

Alice was quick to rise, offering a warm hug so that they could retreat to their opposing ends of the condo.

"This weekend's been really fun, Rio," she admitted as her hold loosened around her best friend.

"It really has. Thanks again for staying with me. It's been a good time," Rio offered, giving Alice one last squeeze before releasing her.

"Goodnight!" Alice chirped, departing with a light wave.

For just a moment, Rio watched after her before turning to do the same. Once within the confines of Agatha's bedroom, the door shut behind her. In a whip of motion, the burner was back out and she was typing a quick response to Agatha so that she might finally tuck in and rest before the Monday she would greet when she woke up.

"Thank you. I meant to respond earlier, but we ended up watching a movie. I'm going to sleep now, but I hope your Monday got better. And... Thank you. For this weekend. It's been... really, really nice. And not having to lie so much is cool too. Text if you need anything. Goodnight, A."

With the soft 'woosh' sound that indicated her message had been sent, Rio stowed the burner on the nightstand, right next to her own phone, and fell asleep before the sound of a response -- or the several others that followed throughout the course of the night -- graced her ears.

Upon stirring the next morning, there were six different text messages waiting for her.

The very first one made Rio choke on a dislodged wad of spit that landed in her windpipe the moment she inhaled a breath so sharp it was nearly cutting.

"Need a few things. Mostly my curiosity quelled.
Thing one: have you ever been fisted before? I mean, not that I want to try. But... just curious. Personally, haven't ever given it due consideration. Something to ponder over, I suppose."

What the fuck?!

Was Agatha okay?!

Who the fuck was thinking enough about fisting at... two in the afternoon (at least, according to the time stamp and Rio's quick mental math) to ask someone about it?!

There were still five other messages.

"Thing two: How many tattoos do you actually have?"

Twenty minutes later, another one had come through.

"Thing three: As an addition, so many tattoos, but have you ever had anything pierced? Hood? Nipples?"

Good fucking GOD . What the fuck had Agatha put in her coffee that morning?!

The next sat directly underneath, delivered five minutes after the previous one.

"Thing three point five: If the answer to the above question is no, would you consider it? Just hypothetically."

That one had a nuanced answer that Rio was not going to have time to dive into before she needed to get herself and Alice to work. She had considered it, but it wasn't something she'd actually sunk much thought into; it often felt like something she should have done in her 20's, not her mid-30s.

Another message, another soft bout of giggles that fell in response.

"Thing four: I'm actually kind of mad about that time we fucked against the window. I need to invest in a drone so I can see you full frontal with your tits smashed against the glass."

Apparently, someone was very, very horny while spending a Monday at work and she was having the worst time containing it. While Agatha might have seemed miserable because of it, Rio was already reading between the lines.

The admission Rio had made the night before was a mutual one, but with not having heard it and her inability to openly discuss feelings, Agatha was never going to outright say those words: 'I miss you.'

The last message, Rio had been expecting something completely wild and unhinged, but instead, what she saw melted her somewhere near her middle.

"Thing five, and the last one for the time being: Do you think we might be able to go back to the pier again? I've been thinking, and I'd really like a do-over."

That one struck Rio a little harder; that night had been damn near perfect, in Rio's eyes. It had been a mess of emotions, sure, and they had struggled to navigate what a social outing actually looked like for them, but over all, it had been a good night out by Rio's standards. For Agatha to ask for another opportunity in the same location, Rio knew that something about it bothered her.

Some part of her wanted to press, to try and uncover a bit more of Agatha's reasoning behind such a request. However, with less than an hour to get ready, get dressed, and head to work, Rio knew she had to be quick with her responses.

"Good morning, you devil. What a fucking list of messages to wake up to. I have to hurry and get ready for work, but I'll give answers now and we can go in depth when we have more time.
1. No. I have not. And I haven't really thought about it either. And it's 6:30am. Not ready to spin down that rabbit hole yet.
2. Left sleeve, under breast, back of neck, and a little heart on the inside of my right ankle.
3. I had my eyebrow pierced one time.
3.5. Have pondered it. Never really got the gumption, though.
4. ...You want to buy a drone so you can watch yourself fuck me against the window? And they say romance is dead.
5. I would really like that. Maybe a dinner date this time. (;
Have a good day, A. We'll catch up tonight."

It was too short, and she wished she could have said more, but it would have to do for the time being. Plus, it was probable that Agatha was unwinding for the day, perhaps while eating a meal with a colleague, or indulging in a glass of wine in her hotel room.

Well, that was what Rio had assumed.

As it turned out, Rio was learning pretty quickly that making any kind of assumption when it came to Agatha was a fool's errand.

By the time Rio had brushed her teeth, washed her face, put on deodorant, and dressed herself for the day, there was a message waiting for her.

"For the sake of brevity and not keeping you from work, I appreciate the responses. Dully noted. I hope you have a good day at work. Tell Alice I said thanks for keeping you company."

For just one fleeting moment, Rio was truly frustrated over the circumstances that left the two of them on opposite sides of the world. She hated that as she was waking up, Agatha was ending her day. By the time she was closing out hers, Agatha was preparing for the next one. It was annoying, it was upsetting, and oh the things Rio would have given just to hear Agatha voice the messages she'd been sending through text.

Okay, maybe not all of them.

...Who was she kidding?

Especially all of them.

"Have a good night, A. Talk soon. xx."

Before she could stop herself, Rio sent the message. And then she saw it, as well as the automatic closing that she hadn't felt the need to use in a message to anyone for at least the last decade.

Well, at least it wasn't a stupid heart.

Rolling her eyes at herself, Rio made her way out of the bedroom only to be greeted with the smell of coffee that emanated from two travel mugs on the counter. Bent over in front of Phin's food bowl, Alice was clearing a container into it.

"Well, good morning," Rio offered warmly as she paced toward her awaiting mug of coffee. "Don't have to make my own coffee or feed my own cat? Might just see if you can stay all week." There was an air of teasing to her tone, but honestly? Rio wouldn't have minded the company, especially with not having any official word of when, exactly, Agatha would get to make her return.

"Yes, well," Alice returned, standing to full height so she could discard the empty cat food container, "An extra night might have been a gift, but I really don't want to piss her off again. I can't have another dry spell for you on my conscience."

Unable to contain her laughter, Rio huffed it into her coffee as she attempted a sip, lowering it the next second to prevent disaster.

"Oh my God, you're so dramatic," Rio shot back, rolling her eyes.

"Yeah, well, in a truly dramatic fashion, if we don't get to work, we're gonna be hung out to dry," she returned, striding over to snatch up her own coffee.

"Okay, okay," Rio conceded, snatching up her keys from the small hanger on the side of the island.

With that, they were off and on a mission to chug through the work day. The morning had been easy enough and kept Rio fairly busy, but by lunch, she found her mind wandering back to the series of insane text messages she had received while she had been sleeping.

Apparently, she'd gotten a little too lost in the thoughts; the way she placed a bite of mac and cheese into her mouth and left the spoon there as she stared at some undetermined point on the wall behind Alice.

"Helloooo, earth to Rio. Come back, space captain," came Alice's gentle teasing. It might have been soft, but it was like a booster engine that sent Rio jettisoning back into reality.

"Huh?" Rio blinked, gaze landing on Alice who was wearing a piqued expression with her brows cast into arches. Immediately, a pink dusting and a sheepish smile found Rio's expression. "Sorry."

"Where did you go?" Alice questioned, tilting her head curiously.

That sheepish grin widened and Rio ducked her head to focus on the needless stirring she had started in her container of macaroni.

"Oh, come on. You're not going to start holding out on me now, are you?" Alice popped a tater tot into her mouth and chewed contemplatively, but her burning stare had not wavered in its silent interrogation.

Rio could have prefaced the conversation, could have tried to provide some context, but it felt unnecessary. Instead, she chose to ask a simple question.

"Have you ever thought about getting your nipples pierced?"

The abruptness clearly caught Alice off guard, at least judging by the way she sputtered and nearly choked on her drink.

"What the fuck?" she asked through a laugh, raising a lone eyebrow in question. " That's what you're thinking about on your lunch break?"

With an agreeable downturn of her lips, Rio just shrugged. "I mean, I was thinking about it before work, but I'm thinking about it again now." While she hadn't said much, the expression Alice was suddenly wearing indicated that she had said enough.

"She said something to you, didn't she?" Alice challenged, suddenly uninterested in the remainder of her meal.

Again, Rio shrugged, acting like she wasn't suggesting at her ripe old age of thirty six that she suddenly make a body modification, and for a woman no less.

That wasn't what it was, though, not really. What Rio saw in the question Agatha asked was an encouragement, an approval that she could and should do whatever it was she wanted with her body. It was a reminder that there was always time to try new things, to make new choices. While she had been pulled out of her boring and mundane routine the moment she had chosen to track Agatha down, Agatha was showing her that the change could extend further and touch other parts of her life, too.

"I've thought about it a time or two, but I thought it was probably too late. Plus, I heard the healing process is a bitch. I don't know if I could go that long without her touching my chest." It was a flat admission toward the end, but it was an honest one that was only flat because Rio realized what it was she had said.

It would be six to eight weeks for her nipples to heal. Inadvertently, she had just admitted that for the next two months, she did not envision anyone else touching her body other than Agatha.

The blush that filled her cheeks was instant, but it only accompanied the panic in her eyes as she made the realization. Instead of looking away this time, Rio sat up a little straighter and cleared her throat. Her lips parted but no sound emerged as she tried to find the right words, but Alice cut her off before she could form them.

"So just do one. I know it'll make the second one way worse, but... Might be worth some thought?" Alice leaned back in her chair, but the look she was wearing was a little on the smug side, made worse by the way she crossed her arms over her chest. She knew she had given Rio exactly what she needed: a workaround.

Again, Rio's lips parted, but this time it was to run her tongue along them, the debate warring in her mind. Before she could think her way out of it, she posed a simple question.

"Want to go to Cleopatra with me after work?"

The wild grin that filled Alice's face was both wicked and delighted, her amusement sparkling in her eyes. "Which one will you do first?"

Rio laughed, but she knew she did need to make that decision. However, she did not think she should make it alone.

"I have an idea, but I think I should get confirmation first." With a smirk, she leaned forward and slid open the top drawer of her desk, quickly producing the burner phone that she actually remembered to bring in that day. In less than thirty seconds, she'd pulled up her chat with Agatha and sent a quick question.

"Which boob is your favorite?"

It was one in the morning for Agatha, and as such, Rio did not expect an answer at least until she got back to the condo that evening. However, as she went to set the phone back in the drawer, it vibrated in her hand. Those lips were twisting up again as she opened the message and grinned so impossibly wide that it almost hurt.

"Mine or yours?"

"Mine, obviously. Like... Which one would you prefer to pay more attention to?" Rio was fighting for her life to not look like some kind of giddy school girl as she typed the question out and then sent it, hardly having time to look up at Alice before another text came through.

"Right."

Instead of providing any further elaboration on why she was asking such a question, Rio's response was succinct and to the point.

"Thanks. (:"

She almost expected the phone to ring, for Agatha to call and interrogate her on why she was suddenly the one posing off the wall inquiries. Instead, another text message came buzzing through.

"You're welcome. Anything else you'd like to know before I force myself to sleep?"

Rio considered this for a moment, the softer side of her winning out.

"Why can't you sleep?"

She knew it was probably too personal, and that Agatha would likely redirect and change the subject, but she still felt it worth asking. When she read Agatha's next message, she felt herself fill with both shock and warmth simultaneously.

"I want to be home already."

It wasn't an 'I miss you,' but it was even closer than Agatha's prior banter. Surely, Agatha had previously reveled in a life where she did not have to stay rooted, and yet, it was becoming apparent that she was not thriving in such a setting in the ways she might have before.

Alice had resumed her meal, knowing that she still had half a shift left, but she had been watching Rio like a hawk throughout the text exchange. What she was seeing was everything that Rio would not admit. She saw the soft gleam in her eyes as she stared down at the phone. She saw the genuine smile, and the excitement that was etched into her features.

What Alice was seeing was a Rio she had never truly known before, a Rio that was actually happy without making sacrifices to get there.

"Do you know when she gets to come back?" Alice asked unprompted, causing Rio's gaze to snap up to her, wondering if Alice could actually read her thoughts.

"No, but I was literally just going to ask." With another drop of her chin, Rio did just that.

"Do you know when you get to come back?"

The little bubble appeared immediately as Agatha typed her answer.

"Looking like Thursday, maybe. If everything goes well, at least. If not, it will be Monday. Hoping for sooner rather than later."

Rio could have chosen to be soft, to offer comfort, but she sensed that it was not what Agatha needed. What Agatha needed was a reminder of what was waiting for her.

"What's the matter? The sights not living up to the expectations?"

It was a gentle prodding, but Rio could have predicted what would come in return even before it did.

"The sights are fine, but the ones in my bedroom are much better."

The moment she read and processed the text before her, Rio's stomach churned and a dull pulsing began between her legs. Her skin was flush and hot, but she was trying to control her bodily response as to not completely give herself away, though she was doing a piss poor job of it.

"Alright! Time to go for me!" Alice announced, slapping her hands down on the desk to stand. When Rio looked up from the burner phone, she realized that Alice had already cleared her lunch trash and was ready to jet.

Snapping her focus upward, Rio offered a guilty smile, realizing that she had spent the last few minutes of their down time together ignoring Alice so that she could talk to Agatha.

"I will see you shortly. But, you'll really go with me?" Rio asked her, tilting her head. "She said the right one, by the way."

Grinning so wide her eyes wrinkled at the corners, Alice gave a nod of assurance. "Left it is! I'd call and make an appointment, just to be safe."

"Definitely. Have a good run!"

With that, Alice was off and Rio was typing one last text to Agatha.

"Go to sleep. When you wake up, you'll be a little closer to coming back. I've got to go back to work now. But really, get some rest."

The moment she sent it, the phone was stowed and the other was removed so that she could call the piercing shop to make her appointment for right after their shifts. With that mission accomplished, she was back to work, returning to the teenager that Alice had brought in before their meal. Suddenly, her lunch time conversation wasn't enough to bat away the slight ripples of sadness that filled her at seeing a life lost so young.

Finding a way through it, Rio did as she always would and handled the boy with great care as she completed his autopsy and stored him away. The rest of the afternoon was much of the same, but toward the end, she began to feel the nerves of anticipation when she considered what she would be doing when they left those offices.

By the time they were clocking out and climbing into that little Tiburon, Rio was practically buzzing. It didn't help much, but having Alice around definitely did. The piercer -- a woman named Dominique -- was ready and waiting for her when they arrived and was phenomenal when it came to being informative and attentive.

While Rio hadn't been scared , there was nothing that could have prepared her for that sensation, or the ones that followed immediately after.

Helpfully, Alice had chosen to drive them back to the condo, even in spite Rio insisting that she should be the one to take Alice home. That had been shut down quickly as Alice insisted that an Uber ride back to her house would not be the worst thing in the world.

Upon arriving back to a highly dissatisfied Phineas who was impatiently waiting for someone to feed him, Alice commandeered the evening duties and insisted Rio relax on the couch. After a moment, she appeared above the spot where Rio had chosen to lay, holding out an ice pack.

"You know as well as I do that it'll help with the swelling," Alice informed her.

Disappearing again, she tended to Phineas and made them a quick bite to eat, knowing Rio would need something on her stomach. Alice was also fully aware that once she stepped foot in that elevator, it was unlikely Rio would move again for the rest of the night.

With their meal consumed and Rio laid back on the couch, the ice pack cold and comforting on her left breast, Alice's duties for the evening were completed. She pushed to her feet and shuffled toward Rio, giving her shoulder a light pat.

"I wouldn't wear a bra for a few days," she offered softly with a gentle chuckle. "My Uber's almost here. But if you need anything, just text me and I'll come straight over."

There was a gentleness to Rio's expression as her gaze flickered upward to take in her friend, one that showed just how much it meant that Alice was always there and always so fucking supportive.

"You know sometimes I think you're too good to me," Rio teased softly. She wanted to continue, but was stopped when a yawn took her over.

"What you give, you will get in return," Alice reminded her lightly. "Have a good night, Rio. I'll see you in the morning."

"You too, Alice. Thanks again. Get home safe!" Rio called in return as Alice paced toward the elevator and disappeared inside, the doors shutting quietly behind her.

Alone.

For the first time in days, Rio was alone again.

To remedy the bout of emptiness that filled her at the thought, she dug out the burner to see that Agatha had been texting her over the last hour. Having been set to vibrate, Rio hadn't heard a sound for any of the notifications. Apparently, Agatha had checked the camera after Rio's shift, expecting her to be home.

"Is everything okay?"

Five minutes later:

"Are you alright?"

Then, again, ten minutes after that one, another one came through.

"Call me when you get this."

Before heeding that request, Rio read through the other messages.

"Alice brought you back? What happened? Are you hurt? I saw the ice pack. What's going on?"

There was a swirling of mixed emotions that began to pool in the pit at the bottom of Rio's stomach. She was softened by the show of concerned, but she also felt guilty for not having checked the phone while she had been out being a mischievous little asshole.

"I'm fine, A. Just wasn't paying attention and ran into something. Do you still want me to call, or are you already in the throes of work?"

Rio's lips pressed as she stared at the message, trying to parse if there was any other way to respond that might sound better, but she was coming up empty. She didn't want it to seem dry, but she also didn't want to give away the surprise of her hare-brained decision before Agatha could see it for herself.

"I'm headed to a meeting now, but should be done around noon if you're still awake. Also, watch where the fuck you're going maybe."

That message made Rio laugh. It was loud, it was bright, and it truly tickled her to see that despite the distance, Agatha was still Agatha. No matter how soft she might have gotten over how badly she was pining to come home, those edges would never fade.

"Will do. Enjoy your meeting. Give a ring when you're finished."

It had been Rio's goal to stay awake until eleven that evening, but the crash after such an adrenaline rush got to her first. Staving off the exhaustion hadn't worked for even a second, pulling her under before 10 pm. The next morning, there were a few texts from Agatha, though nowhere near as insane as the previous day.

It was nice to hold light chatter with her in the morning, but by the time Tuesday evening rolled around, Rio finally had an answer to the question of when Agatha would be returning. It came in a lengthy text message, an explanation for how things were going to play out.

"I will be back Thursday evening around 4 pm. Francisco will pick me up from O'Hare around then, and then I have some work to tend to. I know that you work until 5, so I will be gone by the time you return to the condo (if that is what you'd like to do. I'm not saying that you have to stay once I come back, but I would like for you to if it's what you would want). I should be back later on in the evening."

At this, Rio leaned forward on the couch, her elbows digging into her knees as she held the phone up with both hands, staring at it.

Agatha had been busy, apparently. She didn't need to state so plainly what 'work' she was going to be doing on a Thursday night because Rio knew her well enough to know that the itch had certainly been itching and Agatha was fiending for a fix.

With that in mind, Rio fired back a response.

"So I can meet you at the barn Thursday night?"

Agatha's answer was immediate.

"Yes, my little freak, you can meet me at the barn Thursday night."

My little freak.

It was so stupid, but the pet name made Rio grin like an entire idiot. Never before had she felt so accepted and seen by another person, much less someone she was actually attracted to, and it made her feel important. It made her feel like, to Agatha, she mattered.

"Perfect. Now, how long do you have before you have to be out the door? Planned on crawling into bed and working one out before I sleep, but if you've got time, I can stay out here."

The pleasurably painful grin she had been wearing only seemed to grow when Agatha answered her.

"I've got time."

Even before Rio had time to read the full message, her phone began to ring.

Give Me the Keys & I'll Drive You Insane

Chapter Notes

Hi, just wanted to let everyone know that due to the last conversation of this chapter and most assuredly the entire next chapter, I have added a tag to the list.
Please, if this is not you're thing, skip 31 and if it carries to 32, I will note it at the beginning of 32.
Thank you!

Wednesday was miserable.

It was slow, it was repetitive, and it was downright agonizing .

Thursday was even worse.

Focusing on work felt impossible; no matter how hard she tried, Rio found herself frequently glancing at the clock with the assumption that an hour had passed solely to be met with the reality that it had been little more than ten minutes. It was frustrating, it was draining, but over all, it just made that dull ache in her chest that she refused to name so much more prevalent.

When Alice arrived that afternoon with a plastic sack from the nearby deli clutched in her hand, she knew Rio was practically crawling out of her skin. It was on her face, but she instead chose to offer topics of conversation that might serve as a minor distraction from the way Rio kept glancing at her desk drawer.

The Cub's losing streak, the recent brawl at the Pier, nor the upcoming lineup of drag shows seemed to do the trick, providing no resistance against Rio's compulsive checking of the burner phone every few minutes.

Finally, Alice could take it no longer.

"She isn't going to text you while she's on the plane," she offered finally, her voice light but words painfully honest.

It was gentle in that Alice had never witnessed such compelled behavior from her best friend before and as such, she understood just a little more how much it all actually meant to Rio.

How much Agatha -- or, rather, Amelia -- meant to Rio.

"I know, I just..." Cloudy and dark eyes dropped to her desk, scanning briefly over the day's unfinished crossword puzzle, suddenly unable to look her best friend in the eye.

"You're worried because you like her," Alice supplemented gently, leaning forward over the desk, her elbows propping her atop her thighs. "And it's very apparent that she likes you, too. I know it's tricky and normally I'm a total 'keep the future in mind' kinda gal, but... with everything... Maybe this one time, it's okay to live in the moment."

Hearing such a statement from Alice, Rio simply blinked at her, digesting it.

Alice was the kind of person who was vigilant, trying to navigate her way toward a life she wanted to be living. For her to say something completely opposite to her normal worldview, Rio realized that she could see it, too.

Alice could tell -- without actually having spent time with both Agatha and Rio in the same room for more than a few minutes without it turning hostile -- that whatever this string of fate was tying them together, it was tight and binding.

What Alice saw was that Rio had changed in the last months, and for the better.

"Yeah? And still no padded cell?" It was teasing, but it was clear that she understood that her behavior was... a little... clingy?

"No promises there. You still make plenty other questionable choices. Who puts fruit on pizza?"

"Don't be mad because you don't have taste buds," Rio shot, tipping back in her chair the tiniest bit. "But, I digress. Thank you, Alice. I have... questioned my sanity a lot lately. So, even if I am losing my mind, at least I have your support."

Rising to her feet, Alice was grinning again. "We're friends, Rio. And I'll only ever interfere in your life if I think you're in danger. Which, oddly, is not something I've considered about this scenario." She paused, her brow furrowing in thought for the briefest moment. She looked pensive at first, but it quickly evaporated the moment a grin filled her face. "Shit, maybe I'm the one losing it."

"The descent into madness is at least a fun one?"

"If anyone would know, it's certainly you."

With a wave and a light encouragement that she could press on for four more hours, Alice had departed for her first afternoon run.

Where that left Rio was up to her elbows in work and spinning in circles in her own mind, far too anxious for time to progress just a little faster.

About an hour before the end of her shift, there was a buzzing that sounded from the next room.

She knew what it meant.

It meant that Agatha had come back.

Even in the middle of an autopsy on a middle aged white guy who'd been decked in a barfight and suffered severe brain trauma, Rio felt an immediate wave of warmth as it washed over her.

Everything was going back to normal.

Or, it would once they were sharing space again.

Rio did not rush, but she did work as fast as she could while still maintaining her professional integrity, finally finishing about twenty minutes after the text had come in. After washing up and scrubbing down her work area, the first thing she did was bolt toward her desk, scooping the phone up hurriedly.

There it was, what she had been waiting for:

"Back on US soil. Heading home to shower and change, but I am certain I will be gone before you get back. 9:30p. See you then, princess."

Oh God, seeing that in text almost had more of an effect on her than when Agatha poured it into her ear.

Then, she reread the message and the totality of its weight finally started to sink in.

Five hours.

After she had managed ten days?

She could manage five more hours.

Maybe.

If the anticipation didn't cause her to spontaneously combust first.

The exact second the time changed from 4:59 to 5:00, Rio clocked out, grabbed her bag, bid Alice a farewell and all but sprinted to the car. If it weren’t for the three times she dropped her keys, she might have made it back to the condo just a little sooner, but the end result would have still been the same; she still had to wait.

When the doors of the elevator pulled open, Rio had known already that Agatha would not be there. Some part of her had hoped that maybe they might share even a moment in passing, but realistically, she knew it wasn't going to happen. What was there, still hanging in the air, was the scent of Agatha's perfume. What was also there was her still-full suitcase as it sat behind the couch, completely discarded and untouched.

She was home.

Agatha was finally back.

Not in the physical sense, right at that moment, but in the sense that when Rio fell asleep that night, she wasn't going to be in that massive bed alone.

Also, it was going to help substantially that she'd had enough forethought on Wednesday to request that she have Friday off. She hadn't told Agatha, but somehow did not think she would find a distaste for the decision, at least this time.

Rio understood Agatha's motivations for wanting her to keep to her routine, but the idea of three days together where they could do whatever the fuck it was they wanted? Three days where they could fuck and swim and bask in the light of the sun as it streamed through those windows and never even leave the condo?

Turning that down would have been insane, and given the list of things that had gotten Rio to that point in her life? That was saying something.

Then, she thought about that almost-too-soft request that Agatha had made at the end of her barrage of probing questions.

Agatha wanted to go back to the pier. She wanted to have a 'do-over.'

Maybe they could do that over the weekend, too.

As Rio shuffled further into the apartment, she was surprised to find Phineas curled up on the couch asleep, but not because of where he was or that he was slumbering. What surprised her about his appearance was that he was wearing a collar. More than that, he wasn't fighting to get it off.

It was an intricate pattern, colorful in its weaving. It was clearly something Agatha had brought back with her, something she had picked up solely because she had seen it and it had made her think of him.

Something about it turned Rio's middle molten. Agatha didn't have to give gifts or bring anything back and yet, something in her had felt motivated to do so for Phineas.

It was more than that, though, wasn't it? It wasn't just about Phin; Agatha cared for Phin because she cared for Rio, and Phineas was the most important thing in Rio's life, a being she loved and cherished.

What it actually was? It was another way that Agatha was able to say she had missed being away without her having to say the words aloud.

After a shower and a change of clothes that consisted of form-fitting skinny jeans and a slightly-too-tight black t-shirt that revealed the smallest sliver of her stomach -- and clearly displayed the new addition to Rio's left breast -- she attempted to make herself something for dinner. In spite of her best efforts, she just ended up pushing the serving of noodles around her plate anxiously, stomach churning far too much for her to consider enjoying the meal.

By the time eight-thirty rolled around, Rio couldn't take it anymore. She had tried television, she had tried sitting in the pool room and staring out at the night sky. Frankly, she was going stir-crazy and she needed out.

So, with a kiss to the top of Phin's head, she grabbed her keys and found her way down to the parking garage, wasting no time in peeling out of it.

Going to the barn that early was pointless; she would just sit there, feeling the exact same way she had in that condo as she paced and sighed and checked the time over and over again.

Composing a better plan, she chose to drive.

Winding her way out of the city, Rio could feel as her heart began to slow and steady a little more in her chest. Her pulse wasn't pounding quite as hard in her neck and the thin layer of sweat that had formed on her brow actually stayed gone when she wiped it away one last time.

It wasn't panic, wasn't anxiety.

It was simply knowing she was less than an hour away from seeing Agatha again. For the time being, she was ignoring the emotional weight that came with that, even as it wreaked havoc on her body.

She drove, and then she drove a little more. The moment she finally met country roads, Rio felt a little more at ease. There was no destination for forty minutes, but there was something freeing in the way the night air whipped her hair around as she traversed the countryside with the windows down.

Upon checking the clock for the umpteenth time, Rio had fifteen minutes left. Thankfully, from where she was, it was all the time she would need to make it to where she wanted to be. With a grin that happened for no audience, Rio executed a U-turn in the middle of the road and began her journey to the barn.

As she had hypothesized, she turned up before Agatha; the way no light seeped out of the cracks of the front swinging doors only offered affirmation. Parking behind the structure, she shut the headlights off and did the only thing she could: she waited.

Punctual as ever, four minutes later at 9:30 on the dot, Rio saw the flicker of headlights as Agatha turned into the drive and bumped her way toward the barn. Instantly, Rio kicked her car door open and tried to get out, annoyed when she was halted in place by the seatbelt she had forgotten to remove in her haste.

Climbing out and making a beeline for the corner of the barn, there was a brief shout in the far reaches of her mind. It was a warning, one to not get too far ahead of herself. Running and leaping into Agatha's arms was not going to be the smartest play here and Rio was fully aware of that fact. She had somehow managed to draw Agatha in closer emotionally despite the physical space that had resided between them, and there was no part of Rio that wanted to chance wrecking that by being too physically aggressive.

The very second Agatha's SUV came into sight, the door swinging open, Rio felt acutely as her breath caught in her chest.

What was even more breathtaking was the devastatingly charming and excited grin that filled Agatha's face, even in only the moonlight, as she laid eyes on Rio's corporeal form for the first time in ten days.

Surging forward, small pieces of sense seemed to filter back and and while Rio did not run to Agatha, her pace was brisk and surprisingly, Agatha met her halfway.

For every bit of restraint that Rio had been trying to show, Agatha didn't seem to care. She, herself, pressed forward and raised her hands to immediately find the angles of Rio's jaw, using that hold to draw her in for a kiss they had both seemingly been aching for.

God, kissing Agatha had always felt so fucking good, but right then, it felt damn near transcendent.

Her lips were just as warm and full and soft as Rio remembered, but the way her fingertips flexed into Rio's skin made her heart hammer a little harder in her chest. It was a familiar kiss, but it was also... new, somehow. It was desperate, it was hot, it was even bordering on messy, but Rio didn't give a shit. All she cared about was the fact that she could actually feel how badly Agatha wanted it and needed it through the contact alone.

Agatha didn't have to say it, but as their lips parted, Rio did.

"I missed you," she whispered, but instead of choosing to reiterate or elaborate, she chose to initiate another kiss, one that was probably a smidgen too wild for where they stood in front of that barn. Agatha didn't seem to mind, though, and fed that wild and starved energy right back. Before letting it escalate any further, she took a breath of reprieve, but it was simultaneously one that seemed to offer clarity.

"Let's get inside," she suggested, though her mildly pained expression nearly shouted that she could have pinned Rio to the wooden walls of that barn and had her way with her without a second thought.

Nevertheless, Rio agreed with a nod.

"I'll get the doors," she offered sweetly, stealing one last chaste kiss before departing to do just that.

It took only a moment for her to open them, allow Agatha to drive in, and seal them once more with a soft click of the deadbolt. When she turned back, Agatha was already out of the car and closing the space between them. This time, there was no hold on her face but rather, Agatha's arm strongly and securely wrapped around her waist, drawing her in for another delectably fervent kiss that just about set her on fire from head to toe.

With little hesitance, Rio's lips parted the second they felt the pressure of Agatha's tongue, clearly begging for access to taste a mouth she had clearly since longed for. Rio let her. Agatha could have done any fucking thing in the world she wanted to right then and Rio would never have voiced a single complaint.

Agatha was back, she was there, and she was trying to consume Rio whole with a drugged man passed out in the passenger seat of her SUV.

God, this was the fucking life.

What an insane thought.

That didn't make it any less true, though.

Agatha shifted, pulling Rio closer in a way that caused her to hiss slightly into the kiss, pain radiating from the left side of her chest. Agatha didn't seem to notice, though, and continued to kiss and lick and suck and nibble every bit of Rio's mouth she could get to.

That felt like hunger.

It felt like desperation.

The attention was too much to contain as Rio nearly melted into Agatha's hold, a deep moan rattling both sets of teeth as it rumbled up her throat. She was falling deeper, crumbling further and then --

Suddenly left with cold lips and an empty mouth, Rio's surprised gasp was immediate and far louder than she thought it might be. Dark and startled eyes flew open to zero in on the woman before her who bore pink cheeks and seemed slightly winded.

"As much as I'd love to keep going," Agatha husked at her, gracing her lips with another quick swipe, "I have something to tend to and I fear I may be running out of time."

There was a smirk that found her, one that twisted Rio's stomach in delight and caused the dull thrumming between her legs to increase enough that she finally became aware.

However disappointed Rio was to finally have Agatha so fucking close and have to let her go, it paled in comparison to knowing what would happen and likely how the rest of the night might go.

"One more," Rio requested in a murmur just before sealing the space between them with another heavy and needy kiss. After only a moment, she found just enough resolve to separate the contact and release the tight grips she had formed on Agatha's biceps beyond her own cognition.

With a tip of her chin toward the vehicle in silent prodding, Agatha finally let her go, much to both of their chagrin, and began her process. This time, Rio didn't separate herself entirely. No, that was no longer a need to be too detached. Not anymore.

Instead of standing back against the far wall, her courage paved the path for her to be a bit closer, though still several feet from Agatha's steel table.

The precision that seemed to bleed out of Agatha as she dropped right into a routine she had not had in weeks was nearly tangible, her muscles tensing and flexing as she moved about the space. In the transfer from the vehicle to the table, it was almost as if she were hauling around a bag of potatoes instead of a full grown man that appeared to be slightly taller than she was.

Not wanting to break Agatha's focus but not being able to keep quiet at the same time, Rio posed a question.

"Did you work out a lot to kill time while you were gone?" It was genuinely curious, but there was a new energy to Agatha that Rio had not quite seen before when she had undergone her clinic in the past.

Agatha's head lifted from her task of transferring the man to the table, a confused expression twisting up her gorgeous features.

Rio shrugged, an almost-shy smile filling her features. "When you grabbed me, and even now... you just seem... stronger I guess."

Instantly, the wild grin that lit up Agatha's face caused that prevalent pulsing to begin again between Rio's legs.

"Yeah? And I assume you like that?" she returned, her voice low and thick with her mischief.

Again, another shrug, but this one took a little more effort to come across as nonchalant. "If you haven't learned yet, I kind of like your penchant for marking your territory."

"Noted," Agatha offered in acknowledgement. Not a moment later, she was right back to work, managing to hoist her newest victim onto the table so that she could position him exactly how she needed him.

It should have been alarming how positively calm Rio felt in those moments, but she didn't need Agatha to read off this guy's entire rap sheet to know that she had done her research and chosen carefully. It had been weeks at that point; she was not going to fuck up her own source of joy because she simply needed the fix without any thought.

Agatha was calculated; it was one of the things Rio had grown to adore about her. She didn't make entirely rash decisions without some form of reasoning, even in other facets of her life that expanded beyond her deadly hobby.

The moment the man was secured in the bindings, Rio found herself unable to ignore the impulse to step closer, closer than she had ever dared get in their previous encounters. Agatha's head snapped up abruptly as Rio's lower half appeared in her line of vision, an unspoken question written on her face.

"Just watching," Rio voiced calmly in explanation. Truthfully, she already knew all that she needed to know, but the idea of a closer look sent a thrill racing up her spine.

The smirk Agatha bore in the next second did much the same.

With no other elaboration required, Agatha grabbed the collar from where it hung, clutching it in one hand as she raised the prongs that then pressed pointedly into the man's chest with the other. Once accomplished, Agatha was almost poetic in the way she moved, sinking the collar down around his neck to click it into place. The mere sound caused a ripple of heat to course through Rio's body, ultimately landing yet again between her legs.

She had long since abandoned the idea that she was a bad person for being complicit in this, mostly because Rio could never get behind any reality where Agatha was considered a bad person for what she was doing.

Legal or not, what Agatha did was just and that was what mattered most in Rio's eyes.

With her focus locked in on the man on the table, Rio watched as Agatha's hand found enough purchase in the man's hair atop his head, forming a snug but secure grasp. A deadly grasp.

Rio's focus was locked-in, not wavering even the slightest bit from that immobile corpse-to-be. She knew what happened next, and like a dog waiting for a bone, she was practically salivating (behind both pairs of lips) for it to just happen.

Agatha had something else in mind.

"Rio," Agatha beckoned, her voice firm in its request. Rio's gaze did not lift, at least not until Agatha spoke again. "Rio, look at me. "

It was not exactly an uncommon ask, but it was typically reserved for when clothes were off and temperatures were raised. It wasn't even that far off from the very first time they'd stepped foot in that barn together and Rio had leapt into the madness that was Agatha Harkness.

At least, that was what Rio assumed.

Again, she was making assumptions when it came to Agatha.

Such a foolish game to try and play.

Agatha's real reasoning?

Rio had already thrown herself into too much of this, and while at that point, she had only actually witnessed the true act the second time, Agatha didn't want her to do it again. As she had said that night about the wallet from the man on the pier: She would offer Rio what plausible deniability she could.

Right then, Rio couldn't see it that way.

Right then, anything was possible and that was a terrifying inevitability.
