At the same time, something else about it had piqued Rio's interest enough to ask about after their orders had been placed and they sipped at the wine that had been poured.

"Why a suit?" she posed, tilting her head slightly to the side in consideration.

For a moment, Agatha simply stared at her, lips pressed firm against one another. Although she didn't look perturbed by the question, something about the sudden shift in the air around them made Rio feel as though she shouldn't have asked.

The storminess in Agatha's blue irises quieted and then resolved, replaced by a soft shimmer of reflection.

"Every date, 'work'-related or not," she began, but stalled a moment longer to find courage in a draw on her wine, "I have always worn a dress. Because... Because Amelia Cohen was dating someone."

Her answer presented as vague to anyone else who might have been listening, but Rio heard everything Agatha was saying.

She had scheduled dates for hunts. She had perhaps tried her hand at dating in the true sense. She had even gone on a date with Rio when she had been convinced her cover was intact.

All of those instances, Agatha had been projecting who she needed the world to see.

Right there, in a corner of The Palm as she sat across from Rio, she was finally just... Agatha.

"I feel like me , in this, here, with you."

The way it rolled off her tongue, it was so impossibly casual and light. It was like she was trying to float it to Rio, like it might be a good idea. No matter how light she wanted it to be, Rio knew just how fucking heavy that was.

For one singular instance out of her entire life, Agatha felt seen. She felt as though being herself, making choices that she wanted to make but never felt safe enough to do so, it was never going to negatively impact what was between the two of them.

"As much as I know this was your favorite of the day," Rio offered, flourishing a hand to indicate the dress. "I feel a lot like me, too." It wasn't consolatory, or patronizing, but was rather honest given their setting.

When Agatha spoke again, though, Rio found herself both surprised and delighted.

"I like it when we're us."

A truly pleased smile filled Rio's face, her leg extending enough to run the top of her foot along the outside of Agatha's calf.

"Me too, A."

For the quickest second, there was a flash of emotion across Agatha's face, though it was gone in an instant. It told Rio all she needed to know. It told her that Agatha heard what she was saying. For the sake of her cover, Rio obviously couldn't use her name, but in the same vein did not need to use her alias to show affection.

Because to Rio, she would never be Amelia.

To Rio, she was Agatha through and through, and even if the world couldn't know it, she did.

With the arrival of the appetizers came a deeper barrage of questions from Agatha's end, things she'd seemingly thought about in their time apart.

"Are you close with your parents?" had been the first, which came with the easy answer that they had both since passed.

"When did you realize you were a lesbian?" Something about that one had struck Rio somewhere low in her chest; it felt good to hear it out loud, to hear someone else say it with no shame or worry about who could be eavesdropping. The answer to that had been a little more complex in that she'd known young but spent too many years trying to maintain a 'normal' appearance. Being fifteen in a church attic and spending an hour making out with some other girl during the lock-in had been pretty valid confirmation, just not the religious kind.

"What would you be doing if you didn't live in the city?" It had been a thoughtful question, but Rio had an easy response.

"The exact same thing I do now, just in a smaller setting." It was honest; Rio still loved her job and always would, enough to the point that if she wasn't directly in the middle of all the hustle and bustle, it was still something she wanted to do with her life.

As they were finishing up and awaiting for Agatha's credit card to be returned, Rio found a question of her own that begged to be asked.

"Can I ask you something?" she posed before tossing back the rest of her wine. Maybe she was moderately buzzed and perhaps would not have posed such a question in a more sober state, but she'd already opened the door. When Agatha nodded her head in permission, Rio all but ran through it.

"Where will you go if you have to leave?"

It fell between them like a ten ton anvil, causing Rio's stomach to twist nervously at the stoic expression on Agatha's face as she seemed to contemplate the gravity of what had just fallen from Rio's lips.

The waiter returned a second later, handing over Agatha's credit card before bidding them a good evening. Alone again, Agatha found her answer.

"I don't know, but when I do... You will too."

That answer? It was just as heavy as the question that had brought it on and yet, the way Agatha was smiling said anything but. It was calming, a balm to the sudden flare of nerves that spiked up in Rio's chest.

With that, they made their exit from the restaurant, finding an awaiting Gio at the curb. Also, to be noted, was the pair of flats Agatha had stashed for Rio on their way to dinner. Sure, the heels were nice for show, but walking the pier in them would have likely left her sore and not in the way she preferred.

Climbing out of the SUV, Agatha offered her hand with a warm grin on her face despite Rio's switch to more sensible footwear. Rio took it with no hesitation, but when Agatha didn't let go as they set off toward the pier?

That was the moment it all made sense.

She was never going to be able to measure their pace on the same scale, simply because they had lived such impossibly different lives. Her own had led her to be compassionate, to problem-solve and remedy any wound. Agatha's had left her detached and separated from a world she truly wanted no part in.

The way Rio had learned to love, it was uninhibited and raw in the sense that when she found someone worth that emotional investment, it was hard to remember to pump the brakes every now and again.

The way Agatha felt affection? It was an entirely different experience, Rio was realizing. It was something Agatha truly had to think about instead of just letting herself feel it.

There as they strolled down the pier hand-in-hand, it was Agatha's well thought out showing that she wanted Rio to be closer, that she wanted to physically hold onto her. It was a display that Agatha did care about her and now, she didn't care if the world bore witness.

It was a sense of security for both of them, just for different reasons. It was how they stayed, walking up one side of the pier and down the other. Their chatter was light but sparse, at least until Rio caught something out of the corner of her eye for the third time since they had arrived.

Agatha kept stealing glances at the Centennial Wheel. By the time they were close enough to the ticket booth, she had stilled completely with her chin pointed toward the highest gondola, a place that surely had sour memories for her. They could have started walking again, could have just done another lap around the pier, but Agatha had other plans.

Didn't she always?

"We should get tickets," she stated, as though her mind was already made up. Her gaze shifted as her chin lowered, but she was looking at the ticket booth, not Rio.

"A-- Babe, we don't have to do that," Rio returned, giving Agatha's hand a tight squeeze. She understood the sentiment, but the last thing she wanted was for Agatha to push herself right into another panic attack for the sake of trying to prove a point.

Finally, Agatha turned her head, resolved blue gaze meeting Rio's slightly confused one evenly.

"I know we don't, but... I want to. The sun's almost gone and... Please?" It wasn't so much the ask itself that melted Rio, but rather that soft word that got tacked on at the end. It was a clear sign that while she didn't know how to funnel her wants and needs into words, it did not stop her from having them.

Agatha was a taker, and Rio had always given, but in that moment, Agatha wasn't taking.

No, she was asking Rio to lay this experience in her palm, to let her have another shot at something she felt she had mucked up the first time around.

Raising a hand to cup Agatha's cheek, Rio searched those beautiful blues for any hesitance, any sign that this was not something she wanted to be doing, but... surprisingly, she found absolutely none.

"Only if you're sure," Rio finally answered, the honesty ringing clear in her tone.

"I'm sure."

So, they did just as Agatha had asked.

They bought their tickets, waited in line, and climbed into the gondola. The entire time, Agatha never let go of Rio's hand. Not once.

"Are you alright?" Rio posed softly, pressed firmly against Agatha's side while still clutching her fingers tightly in her own grasp.

Agatha's focus stayed fixed on the thin orange line, the one that signified the end of another day, a day they had spent together, and for the longest moment, she stayed quiet. As the car ascended even high, Agatha appeared to lose a bit of the nerve she'd been clinging to while still on the ground. Her head snapped to the side and while it was obvious she was trying to hide the panic she was feeling, Rio could still see it.

"Rio," Agatha breathed, the sound a little strangled.

"Yes, my queen?" came a quiet return, one that was accompanied by the familiar gesture of Rio's palm cradling Agatha's cheek affectionately.

"Can you kiss me?"

In the blink of an eye, Rio all but melted.

It was such an honest question, a question that was practically dripping in its need for distraction.

With only a silent nod, Rio gave a gentle tug with the leverage she'd found near the back of Agatha's neck, closing the distance between them with a soft kiss. It wasn't needy or rushed, hurried or frantic. It was a kiss of patience, of understanding, of... well, love.

And Agatha seemed to notice.

The way their lips moved, latching and sucking softly, only the tips of tongues making their presence known, it was sensual. It was soft and -- dare Rio think it -- intimate, even . Agatha's muscles released the overwhelming tension, but it was clear that she craved more, as evidenced by the soft plea she made when they broke apart.

"Lean back."

As instructed, Rio leaned into the bench of the gondola, utterly gobsmacked when Agatha began to shift, turning and swinging a leg over Rio's thighs to straddle her. A second later, firm palms landed on the side of her neck, beckoning her attention. The effort wasn't exponential, but as she lifted her chin to take in the sight of the woman on her lap, Rio felt torn.

She wanted to tell Agatha the truth of how she felt for the third time that day and yet, the reality of who Agatha was happened to be right in her lap.

That reality being that of all people in the world to fall in love with, Rio had done so with the only person who might not know what to do with it and who might never say it back.

And so, instead of parting her lips and daring to spill that three worded secret, Rio chose to kiss her again.

Despite the fact that they were positioned rather intimately, nothing about the way Agatha kissed her felt sexual. It felt desperate and panicked, but it didn't feel like she wanted to immediately tear the dress from Rio's body and let it drop the hundred feet blow them. No, all it said was that she was busied, she was distracted, and the hold Rio had on her waist made her feel grounded when they were gently swinging around in the air.

When the wheel slowed and their car lowered down toward the bottom, Agatha begrudgingly broke apart the kiss and removed herself to sit back on the bench, apparently of the mind that they did not want to be banned from riding the wheel ever again. Still, the sight of her winded with pink-dusted cheeks was enough to bring an immediate smile to Rio's lips, one that stayed even as she took Agatha by the hand and unloaded them back onto solid ground.

"One more lap? I'd like to stop by the observation deck before we go." Agatha's request was earnest, but there was a sweetness to her tone that melted Rio somewhere near her middle, leaving her skin warm and flush with affection.

"Of course. Let me pop into the ladies' and I can meet you back there?" Rio offered, lips curling up assuredly.

With a nod, they departed toward the end of the pier, only separating with a kiss once they'd reached the washrooms so that Rio could tend to her business -- which was rather easy given that she'd heeded Agatha's earlier request. After washing and drying her hands, Rio followed through as she'd said she would and headed toward the observation deck.

What she found was a contemplative and wondering Agatha as she stared out at the purples and blues of the water and night sky, meeting in a reflection of beauty on beauty. Quiet footfalls carried her further, landing her directly behind the woman she cared for so deeply.

It took only a moment for her to make a decision.

Holding Agatha wasn't an option; it was not something Rio wanted to risk in a public setting and so, she chose a less physical alternative instead.

Reaching forward silently, both of her hands found light holds on the bar in front of Agatha, effectively caging her in but leaving enough room to not make her trapped. Once stationed, her front found Agatha's back, fitting together like puzzle pieces that so easily formed a bigger picture. Settled and confident that Agatha was not about to respond in any vein of panic, Rio's head turned, her nose nuzzling tenderly into that mess of a mane she had grown fond of.

"Thank you, for tonight. It's been amazing," she nearly whispered, placing a kiss to the side of Agatha's head, though lips found no purchase other than hair.

Agatha could have responded with a simple 'you're welcome' and Rio would have been pleased, but what she did instead?

There was an unmistakable gentleness to the way Agatha took hold of her right wrist and gave a light tug that quickly clued Rio into what it was she wanted. Before she could act on her own volition, though, Agatha lifted her wrist and brought it up to the other side of her body, effectively placing herself in Rio's hold.

She could have questioned it, could have asked Agatha if it was truly what she wanted, but a semi-frequent though struck her:

Agatha never did anything she did not want to do.

What she wanted, right then, was to be held by someone who cared for her, cared about her, and it was exactly what she got.

For just a little while longer, that was where they stayed, just watching the water and the way it shimmered in the moonlight. It was a peaceful series of moments, one where words weren't exactly necessary. Instead, all that needed to be known was that there stood Rio Vidal and in her arms was the most important person to her.

That was happiness.

That was comfort.

That was love.

"Are you ready to go home?" came Agatha's quiet question several minutes later.

It was the second time Agatha had delivered such a sentiment and yet, it still had not lost its ability to make Rio's heart trip up in her chest, squeezing and falling out of rythym for the quickest moment.

She almost said it, almost let it slip:

Whenever we're together, home is exactly where I am.

That of all things was inappropriate given their standing, both in the relationship they were trying to form and in the physical sense. In its place, Rio offered a much simpler answer.

"Yes. I'm ready to get you out of that suit."

The rest of the weekend had been spent tucked in the little corner of the world that was known as Agatha's condo. It had been a chance to catch up on lost time, a chance to remember skin on skin for as long as they had wanted it, and a chance to remember what it was like to simply be together.

Random times throughout the week, Agatha would occasionally grow quiet as she sat on her laptop next to Rio on the couch, doing research for her next outing. By Thursday, she was rearing and ready to go.

The only difference this time was that as she got dressed and ready, Rio sat at the end of the bed, watching her. She didn't ask questions or make needless observations, but rather just studied and assessed. It was the very first time she'd gotten to be privy to Agatha before she became Amelia and as such, Rio found the transformation rather riveting to watch.

When she stepped out, fully clad in a breathtaking black cocktail dress with a portion of her hair pinned back and the rest curled, she was a goddamn vision, though not nearly as much of one as she had been for their date.

The truth was, Rio understood her need to present, her need to showcase a version of herself that men would find attractive and want to spend time with. She was still breathtakingly beautiful, but Rio now knew that it paled in comparison to what it was like when Agatha showed off the side of her she only wanted Rio to see.

Shutting off the bathroom light, Agatha paced toward the end of the bed, planting herself firmly between Rio's knees and took hold on her chin, angling it upward with a playful question dancing in her eyes before she spoke it aloud.

"Are you going to meet me at the barn later?" The grin she bore was bordering on immoral, but Rio ignored the slight tremble it instilled within her -- there would be time for that later -- and gave a light nod in Agatha's hold.

"Of course." It was soft, but only because a lone thought had crept into her mind: the cops. It was a recurring thought, but one that she had been able to bat away with ease up to that point. Maybe right then, it was a gut feeling, or an instinct that she was not aware she possessed. Whatever it was, it compelled her to offer her next warning. "Just... be careful, okay?"

The laugh that left Agatha in return was almost admonishing, but Rio knew it was only because Agatha thought she was invincible.

She wasn't, and Rio really fucking meant it when she told her to be wary.

"For the sake of soothing your nerves, I will." Agatha leaned to offer a soft peck of goodbye before straightening up again. "I'll see you soon?"

"See you soon," Rio answered, leaning up to request one last kiss before Agatha headed out for the evening.

Wordlessly, Agatha met it instantly, a hand raising to cradle Rio's jaw affectionately. As they separated, she had one last grin to offer before making her way out into the rest of the condo. Just before the elevator doors closed, Rio heard her call one last thing into the home.

"Phineas, keep her company while I'm gone, would you?"

A soft chuckle left Rio's lips, far too soft for Agatha to hear, but it rose in volume the moment Phineas appeared through the bedroom doorway and leapt onto the bed, as though he had listened to the deliberate instruction.

She took a few minutes to shower him in attention, feeling only a little guilty about not giving it to him as much over the last few days. In all of... whatever this was, he had been the one being to truly carry her through it all and as such, deserved a little extra love.

As the quiet settled around them about ten minutes later, Rio heard something for the first time that night.

It was the buzzing of her phone in the nightstand drawer.

Not the burner phone

Rio's phone.

With a little too much gusto -- that startled Phin as he jumped off the bed and bolted out of the room -- Rio flung herself in the direction of the night tand, bouncing atop the mattress as she did so. As she fished the phone out of the drawer and peered at the screen, something in her went painfully cold.

There were six text messages, all from Alice.

Opening them, the chill only intensified.

"EMERGENCY."
"PICKED UP A SHIFT. OVEHEARD OFFICERS."
"UNITS MOBILIZING."
"THEY TALKED ABOUT THE SPINAL CORD KILLER."
"RIO FUCKING ANSWER ME."

Then, the last one, sent a moment before Rio grabbed her phone:

"WARN HER."

With her heart between her teeth, Rio understood.

Agatha was in trouble.

And only Rio could save her.

I Brought Fire to Burn It All Down

Trill. Trill. Trill.

For the fourth time in less than three minutes, all the goddamn phone did was ring and ring and ring and ring.

Clearly, Rio thought, if she was blowing Agatha's phone up all to hell, it was for a fucking reason. It was from the burner, so she obviously knew who it was that was calling her incessantly.

So why the hell was she not answering?! There was no way she had made it to the bar already; she hadn't been gone long enough for that. In fact, if Rio had run her calculations correctly, Agatha might have been pulling into the parking lot, but it was still no excuse to not answer the first four times.

Rio was not needy. She was not selfish.

Most of all, she knew better than to interrupt Agatha when she slipped into the headspace of the primal predator she could be when it came time to reap.

"Mother fuck!" The frustrated cry touched every wall -- glass or not -- as Rio punched the red button and ended the call.

Well, fifth time's a charm?

Losing hope and gaining heaps of panic in its place, Rio punched Agatha's contact one last time with a forceful finger. Bringing the phone up to her ear, she was not sure she could keep herself from vomiting if Agatha didn't answer.

Trill. Trill. Tr--

The line clicked on and the rush of relief hit Rio squarely in the chest like a speeding train.

However, before she could push out a warning, Agatha spoke first.

"What?!" It was snappy, it was bitey, but most of all? Agatha sounded fucking pissed.

"Where are you right this instant?!" Rio demanded to know, not offering any formal introduction, not with the way Agatha had answered the phone. There was only a direct path to getting her the fuck out of this mess and if she wanted to be angry about it, she was more than welcome.

She could be mad at Rio for days to come, or weeks even, so long as she stayed the fuck out of prison.

"Getting out of the fucking car! Why are you blowing me the fuck up?" Her tone was sharp and laced with venom, her irritation paramount at the fact that Rio was interrupting what they both knew was a sacred routine. It meant something to Agatha, and Rio was getting right in the middle of it.

"Get back in the car," Rio attempted, flustered over the fact that she was struggling to phrase things so plainly.

"No, I'm not getting back in the fucking car! I don't know what the fuck you think you're doing right now, but we're not doing this. " It had been some time since Agatha had spoken to her with so much ire in her tone, and truth be told, it was rattling Rio even further.

She'd never really had a panic attack in her thirty odd years of existence, but if she had to guess? She was dangerously close to one in those moments.

"I'm trying to fucking help you, Agatha! You cannot walk into that goddamn bar!" The backs of Rio's eyes were stinging with the threat of tears and as such, her voice had started to crack and break the longer she failed to just spit it out .

"Yeah? And why is that, Rio?" Agatha clipped in response, clearly only growing more irritated.

She had to say something with enough gravity to make Agatha turn the hell around and get back into her car, but she had no clue what .

"The cops! The fucking cops are there, they're waiting for you!" For as cracked as her words had been before, they were crumbling as the urgency and panic took her under. The tears that had been walled by lids suddenly slipped, rushing down Rio's cheek in nothing but sheer anxiety and concern.

The clicking of Agatha's heels over the line came to an abrupt halt without the sound of the bell ringing over the bar door.

"What the fuck did you just say?" Agatha snapped back lowly, her voice having dropped substantially.

"I said the goddamn cops are there! And if you walk in there, they absolutely will arrest you and detain you and question you for the rest of the goddamn night!" Rio managed, stronger this time. That strength was only sourced from sheer terror, the terror that when Agatha had planted herself between Rio's knees and kissed her like that, it had been the very last time.

She couldn't even dare to fathom a life where Agatha couldn't kiss her. Not only did she not want to, but more than that, it would kill her to envision it first only for it to become reality simply because Agatha did not trust her enough to pull her from harm's way.

"How do you know that?" Agatha snarled over the line, the clicking of her heels picking up again in the background, much softer that time.

"Alice. She picked up a shift tonight and heard a few officers talking. She texted me right away. Please, Agatha. You have to get out of there." By those last two sentences, something embarrassing happened.

More than just silent tears down her cheeks, Rio actually began to cry. She knew it was stupid, knew that she shouldn't be so damn emotional over it, but she simply could not help it. She had just gotten Agatha so fucking close -- hell, they'd had the most incredible night on Saturday with dinner and the pier and the countless hours of hot, sweaty,  and savage sex that had followed -- and staring down the barrel of a gun that said she might never get to do that again?

That was a lot more horrifying than looking down the barrel of the actual gun Agatha held in front of her face all those weeks ago.

"I cannot fucking believe--" Agatha huffed over the line, clearly lowering the phone in her frustration. A moment later, a woosh sound cut across the line as Agatha brough it back up to speak again. "You're sure?" it was tight, it was angry, but Rio understood that Agatha needed solid confirmation as motivation to actually listen to Rio's warning.

"I... I am. You... you know I wouldn't have done this... any of this, if I wasn't sure."

It was broken, but it was honest. Rio never would have interfered; deep down, she knew Agatha was certain of that, but her desire to keep on the path of her crusade was so damn strong that it was pushing her to not heed such a call.

"Fucking -- Goddamnit, Rio," Agatha grunted. The clacking of heels grew louder, but it was clear Agatha was still seething.

"Meet me at the barn. Just... Just get out of there and meet me at the barn."

Rio couldn't see it, but the next beat of silence only happened because Agatha was glancing back to the bar, fighting the urge to walk right in there and commit herself to her plan for the night.

Why couldn't she just believe Rio when she said she'd be committing to a lot more than that?

"Agatha!" Rio nearly shouted, her voice trembling over the name that she'd grown to love the taste of on her own lips. And yet, right then, it tasted like straight bile.

"What?!" Agatha snapped again, this time solely because she had not fully registered Rio's request to meet at the barn.

Agatha wasn't going to listen, not when Rio was a blubbering and crying mess. No, she had to buck the fuck up and handle this like the grown ass woman she was.

"Meet me at the fucking barn," Rio finally barked, the order strong and thick with her authority. It was an authority she did not have, not over Agatha, but she tried to fake it anyway. Although her chest was still quaking, she found a way to offer an end cap that Agatha could either listen to or simply ignore. "Goodbye."

Hanging up the phone was the most painful thing Rio could recall doing in recent years, but she was not going to sit there for ten minutes waiting for half of the CPD to descend on her and haul her to the precinct in cuffs. Agatha could listen to her, or she could not.

The only way Rio was going to find out what choice Agatha would make was to take that elevator seventy stories down, climb into her car, and drive out to the stupid barn.

That fucking barn.

It was the very first place Rio had gotten to see Agatha for all that she was. Even if she hadn't known her name then, she'd still seen through the veneer of the millionaire lifestyle Agatha had curated for herself.

Now, months later, Rio had fallen in love with her.

And she was going to have to sit on her hands and watch as Agatha blew her own life apart.

What Agatha didn't realize was that her life wasn't the only one she was going to destroy if she let this ticking time bomb go off.

Despite her shaky hands and the way she felt she couldn't catch her breath to save her life, Rio poured herself into the elevator, out of her mind enough that she paid no attention to Phineas during her wait as he rubbed at her calves, obviously sensing that she was upset.

As much as she loved him, there was not a shred of her attention that she could spare, not when she was so focused on making it to that barn.

Every bit of that attention was zeroed in on the idea that Agatha might not listen.

If she didn't, the last thing she would hear from Rio was that very curt and very snippy goodbye.

Rio had already thought it through; if Agatha got caught, if she went to jail, there was no fucking way in hell that Rio could ever go see her, visit her, partake in conjugal visits, not without outing herself in the process. She had been a silent accomplice, even if only because she knew what it was Agatha had been doing and had not responsibly flagged down the law to lock her up.

She never could have, not even if she tried.

Agatha had been a mystery, a riddle for Rio to try and figure out. However, for every single layer that she had managed to peel bad, Rio saw even more of who Agatha was and it was all she could seem to think about as she got behind the wheel and peeled off toward the edge of the city.

Agatha, who had seemed nothing short of a damn hurricane.

Agatha, who had stayed so damn guarded that Rio was almost certain she would have never revealed her true name.

Agatha, who saw Rio for who she was, past the 9 to 5, the white lab coat, and the devotion to her job.

Agatha, who was never overtly affectionate but had chosen to hold Rio's hand as they walked the pier, and had made the choice to climb into Rio's lap and kiss her until she saw stars simply because she thought Rio's beauty was far more important than the light of the setting sun as it dipped to reveal an inky night sky.

Agatha, who though she was unlovable.

Yet, Rio loved her anyway.

Telling her sure had gone out the window, though.

Now there was not a chance in fucking hell that Rio would utter those words. No, having just pissed Agatha off to the max? She would have been shooting herself in the face to make such a stupidly blatant confession.

Somehow, she'd thought herself in enough circles that when she looked up through the windshield, she realized there were no street lights and she had reached the outskirts of the city. She was closer to the barn than not and yet, she had zero recollection of how she'd gotten there.

That was dangerous; running on autopilot was not something she usually did, but it seemed as though Rio could find little else to focus on other than the blind hope that Agatha would do as she had been instructed and go to the damn barn.

Finally, illuminated in her headlights, the barn came into view and Rio wasted absolutely no time in driving around back and throwing her car into park. With a brisk pace, she wound around the front of the barn and quickly spun in the combination to the lock. She knew it was stupid; she'd done it before yes, but right then she was putting her fingerprints all over a mother fucking crime scene.

She didn't care.

This was going to go one of two ways:

1) Agatha was going to listen to her and meet her there and they would avoid the police entirely.
OR
2) Agatha wasn't going to listen, Rio would wait at the barn all damn night, and would leave when the sun came up, only for the police to surely find it at least a few days later.

Obviously, option one was the prime choice, but Rio was all too aware that Agatha? She was not someone who could be controlled or told what to do. She was not someone who would be given ultimatums and choose the option that best suited the other party.

No, Agatha did what was best for Agatha, everyone else be damned.

It took only a moment to push one of the doors open far enough for Rio to slip inside, flipping on the overhead light as she passed the switch.

She was there.

Agatha still was not.

All that was left to do in the interim was pace.

And pace.

And pace.

Rio was so deep in the trenches of her own thoughts that she did not hear the sounds of crushed gravel outside, nor the sound of Agatha's car door slamming shut so that she could open the doors to allow herself entry.

The only thing Rio heard was the sound of those very doors opening, and it scared the absolute shit out of her. Jumping out of her skin, Rio spun in a startled hop to see Agatha -- still wearing that delicious black dress -- with a face that could have given the paint job of a fire engine a run for its money.

She looked positively irate.

Agatha did not speak once the doors were all the way open, or on her way back to the car. Even still, she did not utter a single word as she shut the car off, climbed out and shut the heavy doors with fervor, causing them to clank as she slammed them. The moment she slid up the deadbolt so hard she nearly tore it clean off, Rio finally realized just how angry she was.

What she did not understand was why.

Agatha paced on heavy heels back toward the car, a hand flying up to press rough fingertips to her head as she fought to find exactly what it was she wanted to say. Rio tried to stop her before she said something they would both regret.

"Agatha --" she attempted, but Agatha's hand snapped away from her forehead and stilled, palm facing Rio in an attempt to make her stop talking.

"What the fuck do you think you're doing?! You have no righ--" It might have been sharp enough to cut, but Rio didn't care and cut her off anyway.

"No right?! No fucking right?!" Rio trilled, her voice climbing octaves with almost every word spoken. "Be serious right now, Agatha! You're only standing here because Alice texted me and I called you. You know DAMN well that you were ready to walk into that bar with who KNOWS how many people watching you like a fucking hawk!"

"I'm a big girl, Rio, I can handle myself," Agatha snapped, brow pinching tightly in a scowl that made Rio's stomach twist around itself.

"So what, exactly are you hoping to accomplish here?" Agatha fired, brow pinching even tighter in her anger.

"You're joking, right? What the fuck does that even mean?!" came Rio's venomous reply.

That was a blade, one that pierced cleanly through a section between her ribs and lodged firmly in her chest, her heart.

Not even Agatha.

She could choose Rio, and a life that they might be able to build together.

Or.

That was it?

It was that fucking simple for her?

How could it be so goddamn easy?

Her hands were back up again at her sides, her back completely to Rio as she began to pace toward the car to make her exit.

She couldn't leave.

Rio had fought so fucking hard, all that time, just to keep her around.

Could she?

Fuck.

No.

No.

No no no no no no no!

"I'm in love with you."

Rio wanted to keep going, to give her a laundry list of reasons she should stay, but would it have made any difference?

Wordlessly, she chose to instead step forward, purposely dragging her feet over the dirt covered cement floor so that Agatha knew exactly what it was she was doing. Even with that knowledge, she did not immediately reach for the handle and jerk the door open so she could storm off, likely driving right through those damn doors.

Surprised but somewhat relived, Rio kept moving.

She kept moving until her front was flush with Agatha's back, though she did not wait for the assistance as she wrapped both arms firmly around Agatha's middle, holding her close.

" Please, " Rio begged weakly, tucking her face into the hair that covered Agatha's neck. She drew in a slow breath, taking in the scent of her shampoo and perfume while of the mind that it might be the last one she'd ever get. "I love you, Agatha. I'm in love with you. And I... Please stay with me. "

For the longest minute, Rio felt as though she were clinging to a statue. She was holding on to something that might never change, set in stone. Agatha was her own person and if she did not want to stay, she wouldn't.

So when she lifted her arms to lay them directly atop Rio's, it was the first thing that caught Rio off guard, but it wasn't the last.

"Okay," Agatha finally breathed, her fingertips sinking into the skin of Rio's arms.

"Okay. I'll stay."

I Must Be Out of My Mind

Chapter Notes

Fair warning: This chapter and the 3 that follow it are all smut.
In addition, this chapter demanded to be written from Agatha's POV.
Thank you.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

"I'm in love with you."

Hearing those words, it was like being struck by lightning, not once, but twice in the exact same spot. It was a shock to the system in the way that every single limb suddenly felt numb and yet, Agatha still somehow found herself standing, even if her hand had fallen from the handle of the car door as if it were the grounding that had allowed her to feel that lightning so fully.

"I'm in love with you. I'm in love with you. I'm in love with you."

It ran at least three laps in her head before she barked her response, knowing full well that the only reason Rio was saying it was to make her stay.

"Don't! Don't fucking say that!"

Rio couldn't actually love her. No one could love her. Love wasn't an emotion associated with Agatha Harkness -- not ever. She was saying it to make this decision even harder than it already was.

The fact of the matter was that right then, trembling like a leaf as she stood less than a foot away from her quick exit, Agatha had no fucking clue what the right thing to do was. She wanted to keep going, simply because her crusade had since turned into a compulsion, but deep in the caverns of her chest, Agatha knew Rio was right. She knew that if she kept going and chose not to relocate, it was only a matter of time before the police finally found a grip and dragged her right to a cell that she would reside in for the rest of her mortal existence.

On the other hand, there stood Rio mere feet behind her, claiming an emotion that Agatha was not sure she was even capable of feeling.

And then she realized something very unsettling.

Maybe she didn't need to think herself capable to actually feel it, even if she didn't know what to call it.

What she knew, with certainty, was that she would have done almost anything to not have to walk away, but in her panic and terror, she almost had.

And then Rio had said it, the one thing that could stop her in her tracks.

"I am, Agatha. I love you. And I know that we exist in a reality where you may never be able to say it back, but that doesn't stop me from feeling it. I... I don't know if you feel it too, but... - Rio deserved better, and more. Sure, Agatha knew that she had come to treasure Rio's presence and she ached to have her around, but Agatha wasn't the picture perfect partner and she was certainly not wife material in the least.
- Maybe, without her around, Rio might know a peaceful life, a life where some impossibly lucky woman would get to wake up in the middle of the night to her sleep talking, or stir in the morning to realize that she was gone, but likely only to get breakfast. Maybe it would be a life where she could trust someone else to handle her the way she trusted Agatha to.

What Agatha didn't realize?

For as much as Rio was one of a kind in her eyes, she was much the same in Rio's.

Agatha did not move, she did not speak, and honestly, she was barely even breathing.

What should she do?

How could she stay, if it was only going to bring more chaos into Rio's life?

But how could she walk away from the only person in her entire life that had ever loved her?

Before she could run herself into the ground over it, Agatha heard a sound. It was quiet, the sound of rubber soles scuffing against the floor of the barn, but she knew what it meant.

It meant Rio was coming closer.

It meant Rio was coming to her.

Before she could think of some kind of reply, Agatha felt it all at once as Rio's body pressed to hers and her strong -- albeit not as strong as Agatha's own -- arms wrapped firmly around her middle; it was a move that mere days ago, Rio was too afraid to commit to on her own.

Rio had stopped being afraid.

So why couldn't Agatha?

" Please, " came her cracked and uneven whisper, jostling enough of Agatha's hair that it almost tickled as it brushed against her skin. She couldn't have laughed, though, not as they existed in that moment.

"I love you, Agatha. I'm in love with you. And I... Please stay with me. "

Right then, she was begging for the deepest thing that Agatha could give her; a future where they could be together.

She was stalk still as her thoughts whipped circles around the inside of her skull, pinging and dinging off of every single surface they could find.

How could she say no? How could she reach for Rio's arms and pull them off of her and get back into that car? How could she walk away from the only person in the world that had actually seen her, in every bit of honesty that she was?

The answer?

She couldn't.

Slowly, her arms raised and landed along the lengths of both of Rio's, clutching at her like she might be the one to pull away and declare it had all been nothing more than a joke. Deep down, Agatha knew Rio would never do such a thing to her -- especially given their current predicament and the hot water they were practically boiling in -- but fear was an irrational creature.

The only way Rio wasn't going to leave was if Agatha would just give her a reason to stay.

So, she did.

"Okay," she managed, but the sound of it as it hit her ears was foreign, like she didn't recognize her own voice. "Okay, I'll stay."

"Say it again. Please, say it one more time."

In a flash, Agatha's heart was trying to bolt away, slamming into her ribcage with fervor at how such a request made her feel.

She felt wanted.

She felt needed.

All by Rio.

Drawing in a slow and uneven breath, Agatha found her voice again.

"I will stay. Here," she whispered, grip tightening around Rio's arms, "with you."

Rio did not chuckle, did not sigh, did not make much of a sound at all that was not the quiet smacking of her lips as they resumed their work on Agatha's neck. In addition, Rio had started to squeeze her so tight that it was possible she might just snap her in half.

Agatha didn't care.

Rio could hold on as tight as she wanted for as long as she wanted, and Agatha would have let her.

She had almost walked away from Rio.

To Rio, it would have been akin to death to watch it happen.

If Agatha had to guess, she wanted to touch, to feel, to taste, to savor all that was in her arms, all that Agatha was and could ever be.

All Rio could hope for in a companion, a partner.

That was what she was, and Rio was finding ways -- very quickly -- to show her just that.

She was right; it didn't last long, but as Agatha lifted herself up, she did not immediately whisk herself away and instead simply stared down at Rio with a look on her face that was only strange in the sense that it was one she had never really worn before. Her eyes sparkled in their affection, but the way her pink cheeks pushed slightly with her smile showcased a softness that Rio felt so fucking lucky to bear witness to.

And she did her best to make it known.

"I love you too," she said this time, her chest finally beginning to slow as she beamed up at the woman above her.

That softness rippled slightly across Agatha's expression, but it did not entirely fade. Instead, Agatha simply looked... taken.

The moment passed them by and Agatha's head dropped, another kiss gracing Rio's lips before she spoke.

"You really should pee," she murmured, finally finding it within her to push away, much to Rio's chagrin. "But I'm going to start us a bath really quickly. If you wait, you won't even have to walk." Agatha's voice was stronger than her own felt, but it only helped Rio lull into comfort at what she was being presented with.

Aftercare.

Real, true aftercare, the kind that wasn't just sweaty half-cuddles and bumping hips to assert presence.

And Agatha had used another two letter word.

'Us.'

Was she really going to take a bath with Rio?

Rio was still running through it in her head as Agatha shifted and pulled out, drawing a pathetic whimper from Rio who had never before known an emptiness like that one. It was new, just as was almost everything else they had experienced that night. As much as she hated it, she kind of liked it a little bit, too.

When Agatha righted herself at the side of the bed, it had been Rio's intention to follow, but Agatha beat her to the punch.

"Nuhuh, c'mere," she voiced, leaning forward so that she was able to slide one arm beneath Rio's knees and the other behind her shoulder. Catching on, Rio was quick to raise her arms -- or, as quick as she could be given that they each felt like they weighed ninety pounds a piece -- to fasten around Agatha's neck, holding tightly as Agatha lifted her into a cradle of raw strength.

In only a few strides, Agatha crossed the room and slipped into the bathroom, setting Rio down with ease to tend to her business as she turned on the dual faucets to the iron claw-foot bathtub. A moment later, she turned and leaned to place a kiss to the top of Rio's head, though the way she hesitated made Rio wonder if it had been an automatic action as opposed to one Agatha had actually thought about.

"I'll be right back. You can climb in when it's high enough."

In spite of the fact that Agatha was clearly working through a plan in her head, Rio wasn't quite so ready for her to leave.

"But what are you--?" she began, but before she could finish, Agatha's fingertips found the underside of her chin as she planted another warm kiss to her lips.

"Gonna change the sheets so we have a dry bed to climb into," she informed softly, the tiniest smile causing the corners of her lips to twitch.

Rio nodded, but as she watched Agatha pace out of the bathroom and turn toward the closet, she honestly felt like she could cry.

It wasn't the kind of cry where she was upset or worried. It was the kind of cry where she realized that Agatha was still doing it. Agatha was still showing her what she couldn't say.

If she kept it up, Rio wasn't going to know what to do with herself.

It took a few minutes for the water level to reach a suitable height, but once it had, Rio slipped easily into the warmth and let it envelop her, soothe her aching muscles. She could hear the faintest sounds coming from the bedroom and then, the quietest conversation. Well, a one-sided one, anyway.

"No more noise, I promise. But you'd probably be better off hanging out in the living room for a while. I don't know if your mom will want to cuddle with you after a bath."

Rio had been melting away down to nothing all fucking night and yet that? That little snippet of Agatha's conversation with a cat who could not respond?

Rio had never felt more softened in her entire fucking life.

There was a little more shuffling and Rio could hear as Agatha left the bedroom and returned only a minute later, finally making her appearance in the bathroom known with a soft acknowledgement.

"Sorry," she offered, sidling up to the tub as she gave a soft pat to Rio's shoulder to encourage her to sit up. That in and of itself stuck Rio as something huge; Agatha was willingly placing herself between the cool porcelain of the tub and the warm heat of Rio's body simply because she wanted to .

It wasn't a conversation, wasn't a debate.

Agatha was just doing what she wanted.

"Took me a little longer than I thought. I forget how hard it is to put sheets on that fucker," she voiced, sliding down easily to fit perfectly behind Rio's form, thighs cradling her hips. Her voice was light and tinged with a hint of laughter, but it almost sounded foreign in its newness.

Agatha sounded happy. Not the kind of happy brought on by surprise ice cream or finding a hundred dollar bill on the street.

No, Agatha sounded the kind of happy that was brought on by being loved and knowing it.

"Have you ever thought about a smaller bed?" Rio posed with a gentle giggle as she settled against Agatha's chest, pleasantly surprised by the way Agatha's left arm landed gently on her stomach beneath the water.

"No," Agatha answered simply. lifting a hand to snatch up a bottle of body wash and the loofah that hung on the small hook above it. "Because really, I didn't have to change the sheets. We could have slept on my side and been dry as a bone. But... I don't know, I was trying my hand at being chivalrous, I guess."

That time, they both released the brightest sounds of laughter, ones that only seemed to echo in the acoustics of the tile around them.

Quieting down, a tender silence fell over them as Agatha prepared the loofah and set down the body wash, placing a soft kiss to Rio's shoulder as she did so. It did not break as she began her work, first wetting Rio's skin with a palmful of water before lightly working the soap into her skin.

Truthfully, it felt too fucking good to even consider speaking. It was almost transcendent, the way it warmed Rio from head to toe, even beyond the capabilities of the water. It was so gentle, so caring as Agatha washed at her skin, one arm first and then the other. As she then moved onto Rio's back, the sound of her voice caused Rio to jump the most minute amount simply because she had not been expecting it.

"No one's ever said it," she stated lowly, otherwise focused entirely on her task and the skin of Rio's back before her. "Not even my mother."

At first, Rio wasn't catching on. And then, when Agatha tacked on her addendum, Rio finally understood.

"Then I guess that means I've got quite a few years to make up for then, doesn't it?"

It wasn't a pittance or any shred of sympathy. No, what it was was something far greater: it was a promise.

"It wouldn't be your responsibility," Agatha returned, her voice notably even lower than it had been before.

"You're right," Rio responded. She leaned back, causing Agatha to pull her hands to the sides, so that her head could tip back to rest against Agatha's shoulder.

"It would be my pleasure. Not my responsibility." It was a guarantee, one followed by an assertion of that very fact. "I love you, Agatha Harkness."

Rio couldn't see it, but from the way the side of Agatha's face was pressed to her temple, she could feel the smile as it pulled at Agatha's lips.

Instead of finding something to say that she thought would compensate for her inability to use those words , Agatha simply turned her head and kissed at what of Rio's face she could reach, humming her contentedness all the while.

After a little more TLC to Rio's own body, the two of them worked to rid Agatha of the sex-induced film before climbing out to dry off. Shedding her towel to hang it on the bar, Rio had been all too ready to climb back into that big bed and curl up with the woman she loved, but Agatha's plans seemed to be more pertinent.

She surged forward and, much like she had before they entered, scooped Rio into her arms, cradling her as she delivered her back to their safe haven and its freshly changed sheets. What Rio immediately noticed the very second she settled was that in Agatha's place was a medium-sized bowl of cut strawberries. Laying next to it were two bottles of water and a couple of Liquid IV packets beside them.

For what felt like the millionth time that night, Rio felt like she could completely dissolve into tears, the ones that said she felt it, felt every bit of the love Agatha had for her.

"You got us a snack?" she questioned, clearly struck by the kindness of the gesture as she propped herself against the pillows.

"We've been at it for a while. Car break or not, we haven't had anything to eat or drink since this afternoon. I thought it could be good for us."

Agatha's answer was so simple, so genuine, and yet, Rio could hear the 'more' there.

You took care of me, so now let me take care of you.

And so, that was exactly what Rio did.

Or, at least that was what she did after she tried to grab herself a strawberry once Agatha had moved them closer only to be met with a lightly admonishing smack to the back of her hand.

"Let me," she voiced, reaching for one as she held it up, poised before Rio's lips.

Rio could have laughed, could have told Agatha that she could feed herself, but Rio saw it for all that it was.

Without protest, her lips parted and she took a bite, though it was far juicier than she had been expecting and a small stream of it trickled out of the corner of her mouth. Before she could even consider raising a thumb to wipe it away, Agatha was too quick in the way she jolted forward, a warm tongue cleaning up the mess first.

The quietest sound slipped out of Rio's half-full mouth, somewhere between a whine and a moan, though as her eyes fluttered open, she found Agatha watching her curiously.

"You alright?"

"Yes," Rio answered shortly, though she squirmed a little in place. "But if I cum again tonight, I might actually die and that definitely isn't helping."

With a satisfied smirk, Agatha brandished the second half of the strawberry, light positively sparkling in her eyes.

Oh, Agatha Harkness would be the death of her.

And Rio couldn't have been happier about it.

Chapter End Notes

The next chapter will sort of be a 39.5 and a little intermission from all of the smut.
But... It's Agatha POV so hopefully no one will be too mad!

There's a Hole in My Soul; Can You Fill It?

Finally, the quiet had come.

It fell only after strawberries and water and a quick trip – robed and slippered – down to the parking garage to grab Rio’s phone from where it had been idling (and vibrating with eighteen text messages and thirteen missed calls from Alice) since they’d arrived back at the condo.

Once the reassuring texts had been sent and a voicemail had been left at the County Coroner’s office declaring that Rio was ‘ill’ and would not be in that Friday, the air settled and stilled around them offering enough peace to lull Rio into sleep.

But not Agatha.

With Rio curled peacefully into her side, sound asleep, Agatha simply stared at the ceiling, trying to do all that she could to gather the pieces of her life as they laid at her feet and attempt to rearrange them into a new picture, a new vision.

Things had changed that night, so many fucking things, and if she were being honest with no one other than herself, Agatha had no idea what any of it meant.

She didn’t know what it meant when she wanted so badly to tell Rio what she wanted to hear, but could not find the words.

She did not know what it meant when she patted Rio's knee instead of offering a kiss to her head or cheek when she departed to fetch the phone and Rio seemed… disappointed?

No, that was in Agatha’s head.

Nothing she did – at least in the context of their operating relationship – had ever, and probably would ever, disappoint Rio.

But why was that?

What, exactly, did Rio see when she looked at her?

For just a moment, Agatha let herself rewind her night, searching for something specific. When she found it, those tireless eyes slipped shut and she let the film roll on the screen of her skull.

It was that moment, the one where she had climbed out of the car, practically frothing at the mouth, to see that absolutely terrified look on Rio’s face.

Long before Rio had made the declaration out loud, that look on her face had shouted her feelings right then and there. It had been the sheer horror of realizing that Agatha had every bit of power she could possibly possess to simply turn around and walk away and not knowing if she actually would.

It was the first time in Agatha’s life where she’d had to see the repercussions of her actions up close and personal. Murdering men was easy, but threatening to pull the rug out from Rio and completely upend her life as she had come to know it? That had been something that had hurt , even as Agatha maintained composure to make it seem as though it were so easy.

It wasn’t easy. It was far from easy.

Agatha had realized, staring into those glassy, wide, panic-stricken brown eyes, that it was one of the hardest things she had ever attempted to do in her life.

The fact of the matter was truly simple at its core:

Rio was probably the only thing in fifteen years that Agatha had actually given a shit about. In turn, Agatha was not stupid; she could see very clearly that for whatever reason, Rio also cared about her. She knew she might never understand it (after all, she was a literal serial killer who could barely stand the feeling of sweaty palms without getting unnerved), but perhaps she didn’t need to. Maybe all she needed to do was just… accept it.

Since blowing into Agatha’s life, Rio had changed so much, had shown Agatha so much more than she had ever understood in life. It had been almost instant and yet, Agatha had always tried so hard to resist.

She had tried that night at dinner when Rio’s constant pressing had spooked her and caused her to storm out.

She had even tried again that night after (stupidly) making the decision to go back to Rio’s apartment and Rio had demanded to know her name despite already knowing it.

What Agatha had quickly realized was that it was all pointless.

Sure, she was fully capable of shutting Rio out and pushing her away, but the more Rio fought against it, the less Agatha wanted to. By the time Agatha had become of the mind that she wanted to share space with Rio, even for a weekend, the idea of trying to close her out seemed laughable.

Now, weeks later, they laid in that big bed as Rio snored softly into her skin.

Oh, Rio.

Rio the relentless.

Rio the fearless.

Rio the stubborn.

Rio the lover.

Agatha's Rio.

That phone call while she had been in Taiwan had changed a lot, even if Agatha had always done her best not to let it show. It had established a claim for her, a stake in something bigger than she had let herself have before. It was all-encompassing in that way that Agatha had never called someone hers in the entire time she had been alive. She had things that were hers, a home that was hers, but Agatha had never had someone to call her own.

Now, she had Rio.

Now, she had more than she’d ever had in her life before and while it was a startling realization, it was also a comforting one.

The truth was that when Rio was around, Agatha felt like she actually mattered. The important job, all the money in the world, they were all just… things.

But Rio?

Rio was a feeling, a warmth that sometimes washed over Agatha in the quieter moments, in the moments where she was lost to a world of dreams and fantasies and sometimes murmured snippets out loud for Agatha to peek into her subconscious mind. She was an anomaly in the most astounding way, the only thing that Agatha had never actually been able to parse out or see with true clarity.

Not until right then, tangled in that bed with Phineas meowing softly from some distant part of the house.

Agatha could see it, truly see it.

She had always convinced herself that she wasn’t worth meaningful attention, or positive attention, and as such had always bristled at the idea of any kind of connection. Rio hadn’t given a single shit about that. No, Rio had kicked down every single reinforced door that Agatha had put between herself and the rest of the world with little hesitation and even less regard for the panic it might cause within Agatha.

Because how could she have known?

Agatha knew her place in the world, as Amelia. She knew the status that came with that name, the wealth, the achievements. But… Agatha had never truly known any place in the world, not after that night over fifteen years ago.

When Rio looked her in the eyes and said her name for the very first time, it had been like a slap to the face but only because it was a name Agatha had not heard in over half of her life. She knew who she was, but no one else ever had and she liked it that way. It was safe, it was comfortable, it was how she protected herself.

But Rio knew.

Rio had given enough of a fuck to do the research, to really fucking dig at uncovering who Agatha was.

It made Agatha feel like someone actually saw her. It made her feel, for the first moment but not the last, like Rio understood her for all that she was and still wanted her around. It didn’t seem to matter how angry she got, how much she lashed out. Rio could not bring herself to give a shit, apparently.

Or, maybe more than that, maybe she liked it. Maybe she had realized just how steeled to life and truly pleasurable experiences Agatha had made herself to be and so breaking her down and pulling away those defenses to a point where Agatha showed actual emotion? When she acted like something fucking mattered? Rio ate that shit up. It was all she seemed to want.

But, Agatha wondered, was it because she was getting to see the more human side to Agatha, or was it because she was making Agatha see it too?

As things stood, Agatha was certain of one thing:

She did not know what to call the things she felt for Rio, and having been someone who truly did not understand the complexities of love and all it entailed, Agatha was not sure that was what she would call it. There was another reason that Agatha was hesitating to put a name to it, though, one that was a little bit bigger.

If Agatha were to claim to love Rio, would it be honest?

Was it Rio that she could love, or was it merely the idea of her?

Agatha had grown far too attached to the idea that someone out there could actually understand her. She knew that what she did would always be deemed unsavory and criminal in the court of public opinion, but Rio didn’t see it that way. Rio saw the truth, Agatha knew that much. She saw Agatha’s motivations, that her desires ran deep to simply eradicate what blight she could in the form of men who perpetrated harm out of malice and anger.

Agatha did not kill because she was angry.

Agatha killed because she felt it was the right thing to do when no one else would take consequential action.

Rio knew that, and she chose to stay. She made the choice to –

“Hmmm, this is the life, huh Phin?”

The words were nothing more than a quiet mumble into Agatha’s skin as Rio seemed to cling a little tighter to Agatha’s form.

It was sweet, impossibly so, that those words were the one to tumble out of Rio’s mouth in the midst of her slumber, and it only added to the inner throwdown Agatha seemed to be having inside that head of hers.

Rio was happy, that much was painfully apparent. Agatha knew that there was still a lot to learn, so many things that Agatha had been trying to put off in the chances of an inevitable separation, but what she did know of Rio was that she had found something in the laylines between them that she had clung to, that she had not let go of for the world. Even when faced with the fact that Agatha was so willing to walk away, she did not release that iron-clad grip.

No, she chose to double down instead.

Rio had said those words likely already knowing the ramifications and still, she’d braved on. She’d said them because even if she would never admit it, Agatha knew deep down that Rio was aware it wasn’t a sentiment anyone in Agatha’s life had ever associated with her. Rio had told her that she loved her because she had felt that Agatha had needed to hear it.

Maybe she wasn’t wrong.

Agatha’s arm as it lay wrapped around Rio’s slumbering form tightened, holding her closer. It was a strange sensation that still made Agatha’s skin prickle beyond her control, but it wasn’t uncomfortable as it had initially been. Instead, Agatha found respite in the way it made her so very hyper-aware of every inch of Rio there was to be pressed against.

In a way, Rio almost felt like a blanket. Not one of wool, but perhaps one of silk as she remained so steady in every way possible. It wasn’t just in those moments, but in all others. Rio had been a balm for her in a world where Agatha would have stubbornly insisted she could take the heat and the burn that life had to offer her. Rio had soothed her in ways she did not know she needed to be soothed.

In the middle of that train of thought, Rio shifted beneath her hold and rolled to her opposite side, just out of Agatha’s reach. It wasn’t intentional, of course, and Rio had no active idea what it was she was doing, but the moment Agatha let the coldness and emptiness that now occupied that side take over, she decided she fucking hated it.

She hated not having the feeling of Rio’s skin flush and warm against her own. She hated the space, the distance that was suddenly between them. She hated that Rio was any further away than she needed to be right then.

So Agatha put an end to it almost immediately after it occurred.

Silently she, too, rolled to her side, a strong arm wrapping around the woman before her as her front pressed fully to Rio’s back and her nose landed in hair that smelled faintly of flowers.

Agatha knew she was not going to find sleep that night, but it did not bother her. Instead, it gave her all the time in the world to think about all of the ways she might be able to show an emotion she could not name. Even by the standard textbook definition of the word, Agatha did not feel that ‘love’ was all encompassing of every intricacy of what she felt for the woman in her arms.

No, what Agatha felt for Rio was more, even if she might not be able to tell her.

As the clock ticked past five in the morning, another string of words spilled out onto the pillow beneath Rio’s cheek, still entirely consumed by her subconscious.

“The rooted tree does not leave.”

That one made a little less sense than the one a short while before it, but it also pierced cleanly through Agatha like a steel arrow.

Pressing a kiss to Rio’s shoulder, Agatha whispered back a reply that she knew only Phineas – who had hopped up onto the bed and was curled up in the corner – could hear.

“I am only rooted in you.”
